reviews.review_text: INTRO This review covers a lot of the political repercussions of the poor launch reception but also discusses some key game features and their improvements. The nature of this review can cause quite a controversy so read at your own risk.  IMPORTANT NOTE FOR IMPROVEMENT The game is much more likely to achive a greater improvement if the development team is motivated to improve it. Negative reinforcement alone is not a good motivator at all and in fact can leave the person or people in question unmotivated to do anything. I feel that if we want to see good improvements on this game we should give more support to the good features of the game but in so we must not forget the bad ones either.  GRINDING Well the game has a lot of grinding as do other games and the grinding can be fun, but if you are just playing the game to complete it, then the grinding becomes the main objective and it can become very boring, if you take your time to explore and scan creatures and appreciate some of the good ones then you can expect to have a nice evened out experience.  SIZE OF THE GAME The game is big, very big. The game consists of more planets than you will ever be able to set foot on so there is that but at the same time this is just kind of an illusion as you are going around from planet to planet, eventually you will realise that there is not a huge amount of variation amoungst the plannets. But, there is enough to give you that illusion if you let it, of course you can nit pick and look really closely and break the illusion but you are only doing that to yourself, take it like a picture best viewed from a certain distance.  EXPLORATION It is no lie that No Man's Sky has a veriety of means to produce novel situations to the player, this is wonderful and really helps drive your onwards, the creatures that you discover can be very different from one another. However, you need to take this with a pinch of salt, it can't be easy trying to populate a game with all kinds of new creatures when the game is as big as No Man's Sky. There is a wonderful video that explains how the creatures in No Man's Sky are made up, I recommend taking a look at it if you are interested.  STORY The game has an objective but also has freedom, the 'main' objective (if you want to call it that) is to get to the center of the universe, yes you can do that but you can also take your time in doing so, that is how I have played it and I am enjoying myself doing so, you can really immerse yourself along the way and enjoy the game as an exploration.  SPACE TRAVEL Who does not love space travel, and no mans sky does it wonderfully, I can fly down to a planet and blast off from one with no loading screen and I can explore a vast collection of star systems and fly wherever I want, the game does this brillinatly. The only drawback from this is the inavbillity to fly close to structures and terrain with your space craft, this really breaks the illusion of flight and makes it feel like you are being bubble wrapped and your hand is being held, maybe I want to crash into the ground!!  GROUND COMBAT The combat in the game is some of the weakest combat I have experienced in gaming. However, the combat is there, it exists and I am happy that they put it in the game, the ground combat at least gives me some sense of danger whilst you are roaming around on the ground doing your thing. However the ground combat is really easy and does not pose much of a threat, this could really do with a tweak.  SHIP COMBAT Well, the ship combat in the game is a different story, I personally like the ship combat with a pinch of salt but yet again, the inabillity to fly close to objects and terrain ruin it so much, I want to fear the ground and other objects as I battle it out in my ship, I want to use them to my advantage as I take risks by flying close to the ground so that my enemy struggles to keep up. Besides this immersion breaker, the ship combat is awesome and does what it says on the tin. However, it is few and far between, you are not going to be finding a lot of combat unless you go out looking for it and even when you do it can take a while to find it.  CRAFTING & INVENTORY Of lord of lord, the crafting and inventory system needed a lot of work and work has been done. The inventory system was lacking to say the least and the crafting was simply combing two objects to make one, It felt very tacked on in the game. I am sorry Hello Games but this is one of the things that I couldn't stand in No Man's Sky and it needs an overhaul. I will however give it props that it does work and it does what it says on the tin so I can't complain too much, it is not somthing that will ruin your time playing No Man's Sky but sheesh, it could do with a little touch up.  VALUE A lot of people critise the game for its price and I completely get that, I do see how the game could be a bit too pricey, yes it is pretty costly but I am keeping my hopes up that with more and more updates the game will become worth the original money that I payed for it. The first update marks a great step towords a great game and I have faith that the updates will keep on rolling out  NOTE ON SUPPORT I know that the advertisement was really missleading and I know that the game was over hyped by a lot of people but if we keep throwing insults at the game just for the sake of it and just falling into confirmation bias, then all we will see is a crap game. Try not to be driven like a sheep with horse blinders on and make your own oppinion of the GAME and not the ADVERTISEMENT or POLOTICS that run with it. What we have here is a good game, its not the best game by any means but it is not a bad game at all. I have really enjoyed my time in No Man's Sky and will continue to play the game. Be unique and make your own oppinion of the game and don't follow the mass of people that are slandering the game for political reasons alone.  NOTE ON NEGATIVE REVIEWS The majority of negative reviews are unfortunatly the product of something called 'groupthink' (look it up) Where a large mass has come together and followed majority view and slandered the game without any real thought, in fact a lot of the reviews you will see have only reviewed this game, so you can see by this that they are just jumping on the band wagon and giving it a negative review. HOWEVER! before you go crazy on me, some of the negative reviews, in fact a LOT of the negative reviews highlight a lot of really helpful things that the development team can take action on, these are constructive reviews and well explained personal oppinion and I respect them.  NOTE ON POSOTIVE REVIEWS The positive reviews on No Man's Sky are lacking and I am making an inference based on the key points I have discussed that this is a product of 'The bystander effect' (look it up). Of course by saying this I am making the assumption that Hello Games is a victim in this and I know that will spark a rather large proportion of controvecy so please think of it as, this: Everyone is attacking the development team and no one wants to help by giving an alternate view, in fear of being attacked themselves. Yet again, I erge you to make your own oppinions.  TLDR The game itself is fantastic, I love it and will continue to play it, I have outlined a lot of the reasons as to why the game is seen as such a negative thing. The game has a few immersion breaking features but can be overlooked, as an exploration game its brilliant, as a survival/FPS, it lacks.  Overall I will recommend No Man's Sky not only to people that are new to it but also those that have purchased it before the update, give it another go and please make your own oppinion of the game, don't fall into 'groupthink'  P.S I value all others oppinions and I am open to constructive criticism of my review. Respect people and people respect you.

I bought this game because I like exploration game, without any hype or expectation like most people had. I was okay and cool with the initial release and was lucky that I've never had any crash like other user reported.  The gameplay itself was okay, the game managed to keep me busy with exploring and discovering new creatures, techs, multitools and ships.. for first several hours.  After a while, I suddenly already had discovered all the multitools and ships tech, and it was only matter of time to discover the materials to build them.. Discovering techs suddenly became boring. Multitools and ships came in different shape.. but with no different feature. Pistol-like or rifle-like, I couldn't feel any difference, what matters only the installed techs. Same goes for the ship, whether is big or small, it was really doesn't matter. The shape purely is for cosmetics, and I was not satisfied with this mechanics.  What keeps me up to play NMS, was purely because I like to explore, and the gameplay itself wasn't that bad. And now with the recent update, NMS was getting better. With survival mode, base build and what so ever yet to come, I guess I'll play this game regularly again for a while.

As someone who was onboard with this game from the onset, I never jumped on the hype train. Did Sean Murray choose poor phrasing/lie about a couple features in the game? Technically yes, given what was released. But as a developer who has worked with a number of publishers, what does and doesn't get cut when time becomes a factor is usually out of the developers hands. Maybe Murray blatantly lied, but why would you lie and then try to right your wrongs, when you already have the money??? Because everyting he stated was probably on the laundry list of features planned for the game. ♥♥♥♥ gets cut... thats a reality of game development.   No Man's Sky is exactly what I expected it to be. An infinite universe that you will never be able to even come close to exploring even a single percentage of it. Is there a lot of repetitiveness to the gameplay? Sure there is. Did anyone expect every single planet to be a completely unique experience? Do you actually think that if you went out into the galaxy you wouldn't find some repetitiveness/likenesses the more you searched? I for one quite enjoy the (mostly) relaxing nature of this gameplay. Cruise around literally anywhere and discover another variation of procedurally generated animal X. It's fun. Is it $60 fun? That's an opinion only you can make for yourself.  The addition of the new features in 1.1 is a step towards fulfilling the unattainable expectations generated by the public. I hope Hello Games continues to build upon this truly unique and beautiful game.  Unforetunately not many folks will actually read this, but the sheer volume of negative reviews on this game are completely unjust. This is a feedback vaccuum where 95% of people read something and then just spew the same garbage rather than actually formulating their own opinion.  Buy it. Play it for a couple hours and decide for yourself, and then refund if you feel it's even 1/4 as terrible as all these reviews would have you believe.

I picked this game up at the sale price of $35 and after the Foundation update. With that in mind, It's a pretty fun game. The environments have been fun to explore, creatures fun to find and stories developed worth sharing with friends. I am 7 hours in at the time of writing this and look forward for future hours spent in the game. There's something oddly charming about flying around this vast universe filled with planets to explore that take real world time to get to. I was at first a bit confused and upset with how long it took to get from plaent to planet, seeing as how a minute of doing nothing seems like a long time to warp from one planet to the next but I quickly found the down time to be relaxing. Something akin to taking a nice drive through space on autopilot, enjoying the act of looking at the slowly approaching planet, wondering what tentacle hentai monster awaits you next. Despite coming to terms with space travel though, I still think the game could do with a slight bump in pace. Sure you land on big planets but that doesn't do me much good when the good stuff is all really far away on foot. Pacing complaints aside I look forward to whatever future updates come our way. My favorite prospect would be being able to invite a buddy into my base and then launch off to go exploring together, kind of like virtual hiking with friends. Such a multiplayer element would be awesome. Also, the modding community for this game has already made some neat stuff, if we were to get some official mod tools we'd be in business for a long time coming!

After getting the game for nearly half the price I can only say I regret nothing... I love the concept and, above all, the feeling that I am travelling across a vast universe, this game is truly immersive.   I have to admit that I haven't been 'intoxicated' by the first version since I started playing NMS from the Foundation patch and I haven't experienced the bugs, crashes, or any problems that everyone rant about on release... So to me is just the game I was expecting.  This is not a game for everyone, though. It's mainly based on crafting, exploring, building a home base and upgrading your stuff. So if this reminds you of games like 'Minecraft', 'The Ur'Quan Masters' or some parts of Elite Dangerous and you like those games then yes, I recommend you this game, otherwise you're going to be disappointed.

The recent update has added the Survival mode, it has made the game difficult, finally it has challenge to it. Starting out in survival mode you will likely die a lot untill you get used to it.  Being able to set up a base on a planet you find favourable is useful.  I am yet to get a Frieghter of my own at the time of writing this review, but i am certainly looking forward to it.

A promising concept that's slowly being worked on. Maybe one day they'll finally get it on par with the expectations they set. It's not there yet, not by a long shot, but with the new update... it's not a total writeoff anymore. Here's hoping it keeps up.

No Man's Sky is visually spectacular and endlessly, if subtly, inventive. However, there's no pretending it's not a niche game. It is, at its heart, a repetitive time-sink, in which you must carefully manage resources in order to wander around and look at things that are slightly different from each other.  And yet . . . if that's your sort of thing, if you're the sort of gamer who plays Assassins Creed mainly to look at the 3D-rendered historical buildings and thinks all that action-stealth nonsense is a distraction, then No Man's Sky is an unparalled virtual tourism experience. It's an endless, procedurally generated nature walk with science fiction trappings and the occasional laser battle.  I bought it for full price on day one and I don't regret it, but it's definitely the kind of game you want to go into with eyes open. Buy it only if the thought of collecting minerals in order to earn the privilege of hopping from one vintage sci-fi book cover to another is one that really gets your heart pumping.

Well, Not following the 'Witch hunt' I think the version 1.1 is a foundation of many Updates that are coming, so It'll be great again I guess.. I see a lot of potential in this game so I hope they fix it.

- Smooth gameplay - Vistas to screenshot every minute - Seemless space to planet landing - Planet-sized planets - Very interesting procedurally generated planet terrains, underwater, floras and faunas (it's better with update 1.1 and I hope they will continue to improve it) - Over-the-top ambiance and generated music, immersive and mystic universe - Visual arts from genius artists - You feel the loneliness and it makes you feel insignificant - You can do some light trading, light fighting, light survival or explore like crazy - Very relaxing, almost an experience more than a game sometimes (perfect after-work game) - No hand-holding, you make your own story/roleplay from your imagination (big selling point for me) - Technologies system that you have to find and build while you explore - Procedurally generated ships and multi-tools making you hunt for your pefect one - Find alien's words from monoliths so you can understand what they are saying - Everything majestic is rare but when they happen, WOW. (paradise planets, big dinos, etc) - It's about the journey, not the destination, smell the flowers - You can install MODS - Passionate devs. This little team created a wonderful canvas where they can expend - I already got my money back if we take the popular '1$/hour' in consideration - NEW! Base building and you can own a big freigther

I was lucky as this game worked for me from the start. But very crappy. I noticed my computer had my better graphics card disabled, so I re-enabled it. The game runs much smoother now, with some lag and frame drops every now and then, but nothing I can't handle(as I already played 20 hours at under 20fps). The game itself runs much faster now for me now, graphics set fairly low, but still looks nice to my standards(originally a console gamer).  The gameplay is fun, I'm not going to complain. I play games to adapt to them, and have come to enjoy the crafting system. Limited space in inventories drives you to get better equipment or increase space so you can hold both materials and your upgrades.   Exploring a new planet is great, finding new animal species is interesting. Some might complain about certain buildings looking the same though. All planets I've visited so far have been very different, and I look forward to exploring more.  I can only hope for improvements in the future, but as it is now, it is a fun game. I am a sci-fi nerd, so that probably helps!

I personally love the game. I didn't come into the game expecting much, I wasn't on the hype train, no biases anything. I love just being able to sit back and enjoy flying, walking, seeing the space stations. I love trying to upgrade, and the fact that the universe is so fast. Honestly if you're in it for shooting, don't buy it. Yes there may be combat but that is not what the game is focused for. Many people feel lied to, but is there no room for updates? They'll listen to the community, look there was already a day 1 patch. Back to exploring.

Hello there,  I preordered this game in Feburary and was hyped for it since 2014. Many people started interpreting things into the game, that have never been mentioned from the devs so the danger of Overhype was real.  First of all I want to point out that this game is for people who enjoy exploration, discovery, gathering and crafting, e.g.  If you are one who can play Minecraft Survival vor 20 Hours straight, you will probably like this Game.  I personally really enjoy the game so far, it is like a arcade version of Elite Dangerous or the X-Series.  Most of the mechanics are present, but for example getting money is not that grindy.  Which is really my type of game.  The space travel is really nicely done, not a bit boring like in other games, your ship is really fast and the planetary gameplay is a classic exploration game.  But I rate the Gameplay 4/5, because of one really annoying thing: Sentinels I can understand, that Senitinels get angry, when I steal things or break Stuff or destroy the environment. However there is one extremely dumb thing, if you kill an aggressive creature, which is about to wreck you hard, the dang Sentinel Force gets there and finishes the job. -.- --> Self defence should not be punished in the game.   Moving on.  Many people complain about performance Issues, for example jittering or framedrops. I think it depends very much on your software setup, sometimes the game has short lags for me, but hey its release day,  Which game of the last years was bugfree of Launch? Especially from small studios.  One Thing that would be really nice is if you could adjust the level of detail, for the render distances. (when things start to spawn in, because when you're moving very fast close to the Planet everything just drops in right in front of you.  One last complaint: Some of the tooltips are really annoying (build grenade launcher xyz) would be nice if you could deactivate the tutorial after playing some whil and only leave story tooltips.  We will see how the game develops in the future.
i love the game besides the very rare lag whenever i get in my ship and then leave a planet  but other then that it runs very well

The game that polarized and divided the whole gaming world...  A fair warning... if you watch the trailer and want that exact game, DON'T buy No Man's Sky, the video is just a proof of concepts that maybe can be real in a couple of years and after many patches and updates, not now.  If you can forget everything you know about the videos, interviews and such, NMS can be an enjoyable game if a bit shallow, you have an entire universe to explore, granted much of it will feel the same... but i don't think that walking around Mars or the Moon will be very exciting either.  It's not a bad game, but it's not for everyone... try to get it for cheap.

This is the Starfleet-ensign-stranded-on-a-distant-planet sim I've always wanted! I held off getting this game after the initial release, but I'm so glad I picked it up now. The environments are beautiful and exploration is fun. Swimming in alien oceans never gets old. And you can feed alien wildlife! There are even baby versions of many creatures.   I started out in a Gek-enhabited quadrant. For my second save file, I'm in a Korvax-controlled area. I like the mini-encounters with the different species.

So far I have enjoyed the gentle exploration of a planet whilst repairing my ship. It's been slo, perhaps ploddy, but that is absolutely fine. Perhaps a better tutorial mode would make things more immediate for the more imatient players. I have just taken off and spotted a space station...which I crashed into. Again better instruction would help. This game is not the Messiah, but its not dreadful either.
It deserves a second chance.
Thank you Hello Games for not giving up even after all the negative feedback. It's easy to quit but you decided to stay and work on NMS. I really appreciate that.

I'm glad the developers have faith and have stuck with the game....

I love this game. Everyone is moaning how its not what they thought, and that's their opinion. Personally, I love that I don't have some griefing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ troll ruining my experience. The game, has a non-linear feel, gently pushes you to make decisions, learn some basic maths, and free-roam everywhere. If I wanted complex PVP I'd load up Eve Online or Star Citizen. Ultimately, this isn't a combat game, and nor will it ever be. Other games do that. Other games also have the griefing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ trolls. Infact most people that have rated this poorly are probably one of them and the games doesn't let them do that. Whilst I agree it's repeatative, so is Pokemon Go and that game lacks any sense of achievement or depth.   It is, then, up to you. Exploring many many worlds and encountering so much, collecting and crafting. Or not any of those and be a troll in another game. For me, I'm going to continue exploring the wonders No Man's Sky has to offer.

I definitely recommend this game if you love exploring and turning every stone to progress. Although it's not without problems/bugs, I personally feel the good outhweigh the bad. Overall score 8/10 (in my humble opinion).  Let's begin with the negative (as I have experienced them), since that is the topic of a lot of reviews.  - Sometimes crashes on startup from steam, however usually works after 2 or 3 attepts.  - Drastic fps loss after 2-3 hours of gameplay.  - Quite a bit of fiddling with the settings to get decent frames per second. Although I am on an old   750ti so I can't complain too much.  Here are some things that you should be aware of, however not necesseraly negative.   - You start with very little information and have to figure things out on your own.   (Personally I enjoy not knowing at first)  - A lot of inventory management because of limited space before you find ways to upgrade.  - No multiplayer. It would be a fun addition to the game but not necessary imo.  The good  - Exploration. The fact that you really have to search every nook and cranny to find tech and   upgrades gives you that feeling of accomplishment.  - Story. While it does not give you much to begin with, you find little bits and pieces you have to  put together in your head or even write down. It's the reason I'm still on the first planet after   17 hours. (I'm thorough to say the least)  - Graphics. Although not perfect, it looks a lot better than other procedurally generated games out  there.  - Making units (money). You can earn from trading, uploading discoveries and tons for 100% discovery  of a planet.   - Stable. I personally have never had a crash ingame, (only startup).  All in all I find this game very fun and addictive. Just when you're going to log off and go to bed, you say to yourself: 'what's over that hill'... Good bye sleep.   Even though I strongly recommend this game, don't take my word for it. Do your own research, check out youtube or twitch to find out if this is the game for you. At a steep $60 you should be sure. But for me it's worth every penny:).

I have lived and worked and played in a world where things take time to build, time to buy, time to create. I see reflections of that world in No Man's Sky--a procedurally-generated galaxy that is really an analogue for life a lot closer to home.  I became interested in this game when I saw a trailer last year. I did not follow it much beyond that, and as such, I did not jump aboard the hype train. Because of that, I was initially bewildered by some of the negative reviews. I've since read more about this, and I can understand the stuff that isn't just knee-jerk negativity without rationale.  Here is everything you need to know, good and bad:  1. The worlds are beautiful. I have spent about 45 hours so far discovering new places, and even the most forbidding worlds have an astounding beauty to them.  2. This is a very old-school game. It has the feel of King's Quest or The Black Cauldron, two games I enjoyed thoroughly when today's complainers weren't even a gleam in their father's eyes. There is no instant gratification here. There is no instant-win here. There is travel and exploration, gathering and building. Which means...  3. There is no instant gratification here. You aren't going to be able to outrun the game. You aren't going to be able to shortcut this to any meaningful extent (and doing so would be missing the point entirely). You aren't going to be able to bypass the laborious process of amassing enough wealth to let you buy a ship that allows you to amass more wealth. Like life here on Earth, you will put in the time and the work, and you will build something for yourself. And then you will build it bigger and better, bigger and better, bigger and better, ever onward.   4. This is not (really) about combat. Yes, there are space battles. No, they aren't spectacular. Do not expect the rush of battle, the thrill of victory. I went after some space pirates a few times, won some, lost some...and haven't really sought out battles since then. It is more of an afterthought than a primary element thus far.  5. The flight controls are not intuitive. Coming from flight and space simulators meant I thought I knew how I would handle ships in this game. That turned out not to be the case. The controls don't quite line up, and the ships come with a 'flight assist' that actually makes things more difficult. You cannot fly close to the ground, so get rid of any ideas of stunt flying on a gorgeous planet, or doing loops through giant arches, etc. Landing is done by pressing a key to engage an autolander, but you cannot look down (or left or right) to ensure you are properly lined up with your desired landing spot, so you'll miss it 9 times out of 10. I have found this component to be frustrating.  6. The UI has an annoying habit of making you perform a 2-second-long click on everything. This is only a mild annoyance until you are in combat and need to recharge a weapon. At that point, fiddling through menus that take two seconds to activate can become a bit more problematic.  7. This is not a $60 game. The developers have done AMAZING work with their small team in putting this package together. And it is indeed a pretty package. But we have essentially paid for the process, not the result. The procedural generation is fantastic, and works quite well. I'd gladly have paid $40, or even $50 for this title. I believe a lot of today's angry reviews stem from this being at the same price point as something like Skyrim, and I think that upset is justifiable.  8. Buy this game if you like games like SimCity, Cities:Skylines, King's Quest, ARK, Space Quest, Myst, Riven, Farming Simulator, Chess. Games where things take time.   9. Do not buy this game if you like Halo, MMOs, Call of Duty, Titanfall, Overwatch, Checkers. This is not a fast-twitch game, and it will not excite you.  10. If, and only if, you meet the above criteria, I recommend this game to you.   This game is NOT for everyone, and my review is based solely upon your ability to know what you like before making a purchase. As for me, I have had a lot of fun exploring new places. I've watched incredible animals appear from caves and fight with one another, and then with me. I've seen beings that look like pineapples bounce away from me as I, in turn, ran away from something that looked like a dinosaur horse. I've seen underwater outposts, tears from frightened aliens, Grand Canyon-esque cliffs worth photographing as much as traversing.  Know what you like, and know what you're going to get before you buy. If you like the exploration more than the battle, the building more than the result, then this is for you. And I would recommend it to you.

There are so many negative reviews of this game, I figured to come on here & throw in some feedback.  My specs: WIn 10, i7 4790K, 980 Ti, 24G DDR3.  The only problem I've had was the game not running smoothly at 2560x1440 -- while *simultaneously* streaming. Switched to Borderless Fullscreen, 1080p & turned VSync off. Runs smooth after that.  As far as the gameplay goes, it's exactly what I expected of the game. Keep in mind I've been ignoring the vast majority of information outside of E3 trailers, etc, because I prefer to get my info while playing and not allowing the hype to get to me. With that in mind, here are my feels:  Pros:  - This game is GORGEOUS. I love the fact that its not the standard browns & greens, and its genuinely a beautiful game. - The variety of things to find is magical. The creature combinations are NUTS. I found a planet that had FLYING EELS FOR BIRDS. - The survival aspect of the game is light enough that its not nonstop fixing/healing on all planets. Some require more work and more gear to balance, but its background for the MOST part. - The crafting is pretty cool. - If you don't have enough Exosuit slots, look for Outposts!  Cons:  - The Procedural Generation *can* show itself after a few planets, but the devs are showing themselves to be working on new content. - Some of the space flight is unyieldly. When this happens, you can slow yourself down to make it a bit easier to control.   Last Word:  The game is exactly what I expected it to be after going in with minimal hype. If you enjoy exploration & survival games, don't hesitate to give this one a chance. :)

I want to balance the negative reviews. I have a fairly powerful system (GTX 980 x 2), and as of today's NVidia driver update this game runs at 4K full settings around 50FPS.  It's gorgeous to look at, and absolutely compelling to play IF you have the imagination and self-direction to make your own story and set your own direction.  Inspiring scale, beautiful planets, and a sense of progress - all from a small indie team.  In my mind this is groundbreaking.

If you are an explorer, this game may appeal to you.   You repair, craft, explore, discover places which you can rename and upload them, there are worlds of all kinds and sizes, some with mostly water, barren, dead moon, lush and tropical, different sky colours, it is a very pretty and calm game. You can attack pirates, discover alien technology and outposts, buy, sell and trade raw resouces or found items, follow the storyline or go your own way and for that it is an enjoyable game.  Minor spoilers to follow:  However ship creation is non-existant so far, puchase, find and repair one on a planet...yes, upgrade shields and weapons and engines etc, but you cannot design your own or add inventory slots so far.  After 65 hours I have yet to find an Atlas Pass V.2 or V.3,   Don't sell your Atlas stones as you need ten of them and if you die from pirates and have them in your ships inventory they are gone, if this happens go to options and reload the previous save, I did not know this at the time.   If you sell an Atlas stone you get 60,000 units or so however if you want to buy one it is about 2,300,000 units or more.... very irritating as you cannot start a new game if you lose your Atlas stones. You only get one game, there is no 'start a new game' option.  The generated planets are interesting and varied but the longer you play the more similarities you find on every planet in every system. Especially the platinum plants, zinc plants, I've found crystallized gold which is odd and some creatures that looked like a random generator just rolled the dice a few times with feet, legs, body, head, ears, etc and looked out of place, but a lot of the creatues are indeed interesting and cataloging them is funish but pointless except to upload them and receive a completion bonus of credits.  The story is great, I found myself spending hours hunting down language stones, ruins and monoliths to learn the 4 different languages but again after 65 hours I have learned over 600 words and can pass most verbal tests but sometimes you wonder exactly what is being said as only about 50% of the conversation is translated for me now and don't get me started on the Atlas language as you don't learn much by the time you begin to interact with the Atlas stations and have no idea what it's really saying to you. You will find monuments that teach you a word like, 'murder' and then a little while later you find one that teaches 'murders' or 'murderous'...that feels cheap and it has happened more than a few times, there are many text errors, one I keep seeing is when you access a plaque and it says,'the knowledge of the Gek hannel into my mind' or something... but 'hannel'? Really? Ugh....  Eventually you will find that the only thing left to do after buying a better ship, upgrading your exosuit(I have 37 slots and counting), upgrading your multi-tool and upgrading your ship and following Atlas' path is to head towards the centre of the galaxy (I am in the Euclid galaxy)and it is a loooong way, I expect to take another 20 or so hours of only crafting warp fuel, warping as far as I can and through a black hole which helps a little but breaks something on your ship every time and then repairing with elements that do not show up is very time consuming.  Don't get me wrong though, this game is unique and if you know what you are getting this game is excellent and hopefully thay release a giant patch and some dlc to give more to do and more achievements.  Will update in future

Overall a feat of excelence given the scope of the game and the team size. \TL:DR  I've really been enjoying NMS since I booted it up. it started out super slow but once I got the hang of what to look for it's been a riot. In my play time I've learned a few things that are only a minor irritation for me but might be more so for you. First off there is a loading screen, it's very well masked but it's there. Going planet to planet trying to scan all the different things is kind of fun but super irritating when you have one animal left and can't find it. As for people complaining about the multiplayer rug pull, I'm pretty sure that's going to get patched right quick. Most likely it was a desynch problem between the two players who met up. I feel that this game is getting a bit of a bad rep at the moment, yes it has its bugs and crashing issues right now, which is indeed frustrating to say the least, so for the time being maybe just avoid playing it too much until the very small team of devs fix some of the bugs. I haven't logged much time yet, only due to the annoying lagginess of the game, but from the 2 hours or so that I have, I have enjoyed myself in the game. Some people seem to miss the concept that this is a survival game. Which is not really true. It’s as much survival as Minecraft is, where all you have to do is make sure your health and shields are able to handle some time out of your spacecraft. Planet similarity is to be expected with this type of procedural generation, so if you were expecting every planet to be unique in every aspect, that’s just the wrong idea. The real point of this game I believe is using the economy, resources, and other beings you find along the way to aid you in reaching the center of the universe. This is about farming resources that are in demand to buy upgrades for your ship, figuring out what types of planets yield what resources, and deciding what kind of player you want to be, whether you are a pirate or explorer. Despite your views on this game, I believe that Hello Studios set out to deliver an exploration game that put into perspective the scale of the universe, and I believe they delivered on what they promised. So give this game a go, and if you don’t like it there are steam returns for a reason. Happy Exploring!

Man this game got a lot of hate straight out of the box. I feel like most of the negative reviews are not warrented. So people are complaining about things like I can't upgrade my suit inventory space (you can you just have to explore the game), there is no challenging combat (just keep going through the galaxy), the game is boring (play more then an hour and a half).  Pros:  -Pretty game world: they said it would remind me of old sci-fi novel covers; mission accomplished. -Pretty neat inventory/upgrade system. You have to balance between; upgrading your suit/tool/ship with mods or saving that slot to get more loot. It is a system I've never seen before, and I like it. Other might not. -Really well done exploration game. This game won't appeal to people expecting a shoot'em up game. This just isn't what this game is.  Cons: -Silly click and hold to click UI elements. I get it to craft or use an objects, but it should really be turned off for most elements. It is something I got use to but is still clunky -Flying on the planet doesn't feel right. I want the ability to fly through arches or under floating rocks, even under water. Right now it just isn't enjoyable. I want to be able to crash.  Overall a really good game. $60 good? Maybe, if you want an exploration game.

So I'll go against the grain here. There seems to be a lot of negativity towards this game, but I've put down a little over 10 hours myself so far and I'm absolutely blown away by what such a small indie dev team has accomplished.   I'll start off by saying I never let my hype before launch get the better of me. I knew not to expect some fantastical dream land where everything I ever wanted in a space exploration/survival game will exist. Especially not by some small dev team.   Now, I understand people are getting their panties in a twist because the game isn't running too well, or maybe not even starting at all. Still doesn't justify planting a negative review right off the bat because 'that'll show em'. I on the other hand haven't had any huge issues. I've got all the settings maxed out, FOV set to 100 on both, and FPS set on max. I run a GTX970...So nothing too highend these days, but the game runs fine for the most part with some hiccups every once in a while. The one exclusion to this, is on planets with LOTS of water. The game chugs along for me when vast amounts of water is in sight.   In any case, these issues and more will most likely be corrected in the coming weeks with Nvidia's Game-ready driver updates, and the updates being pumped out by Hello Games.   I'll leave this off with a quick list of Pro's and Con's off the top of my head.  Pros: -Stunning colors/visuals. -Great variety of ships & multi-tools. -Plant and animal life seems very diverse. Haven't run into things too similar to each other yet. -The lore/backstory between the races in the game, along with atlas itself is pretty interesting.  Cons:  -Flight controls (Mainly on planets!)...This has to be the biggest for me. It's pretty clunky. I wish ships could hover in spot and go up and down instead of being forced to move forward all the time. This makes it hard to land where you want. You can't even really point the ship downward to even see where you're going to land. This definitely needs to be addressed. -Galatic map. While cool initially due to seeing the scale of the universe/galaxy in this game...It's very barebones and pretty painful to navigate. I'd definitely like to see some improvement in this area...Maybe even a way to search for a specific system?   The state of the game in terms of optimization and such could be under the Con's section, but I believe that'll be dealt with in the near future and as such doesn't deserve to be put there.   I'll edit this if I feel like there's something worth adding or changing as I progress through the game.

Here's my honest review of No Man's Sky. Stick around and I'll give you some things that I hope will help. :)  Personally, I am a man who can get bored of a game really fast. There are few games I find myself coming back to to play (Skyrim is one example of a game I come back to). If you're like me, you'll generally spend a few hours in a game and quit it for quite a long time. Not that you hate the game, you just got bored of it. In the moments I find myself bored though, No Man's Sky is one game I always come back to. Granted I don't play it as much as my friend does but I find it to be a good game when you're bored of your other ones.  This game is pretty visually intense so just be aware of that buying it. I personally still feel I am lagging a bit at medium visuals on everything and anti-aliasing off. Most other games on the other hand I don't have that problem with. So be aware that depending on your system and graphics card, it may not be as beautiful as the trailers, though I still find a sense of beauty in this game.  If you're also like me, you like having an objective. I mean I usually free roam in games but having the option of something to put my efforts into is something I hold dear. This game will give you pretty much nothing. I've had two 'objectives' so far which was repair my ship and get credits to get a hyperdrive (which I will add I have not done). Otherwise the only objectives you'll have are self made ones. So if you do play like me, again be wary of that fact. This to me doesn't make the game unplayable but it does give me a harder time trying to stay in the game.  Overall though the game isn't that bad. I was expecting most of the things that I listed on here and I might have sunk $60 on this (which for me is a lot of money) but I don't regret it. I'm enjoying my time there and I plan on continuing with the game into the future. My only hope is that they will add some sort of multiplayer so that I can play with my friends. If you're borderline on this game I recommend grabbing it. It's good when you're bored and it's fun to experience what it has to offer. Worse comes to worse just get a refund through Steam. But I have certainly been enjoying it thus far.

I bought No Man's Sky with mixed feeling. After all, there's been a lot of reviews that says that this game is buggy with lots of crashes and bad FPS readings. Last night I had a gaming session of seven hours and only once I needed to restart the game. It was after five hours of play time when suddenly my FPS dropped from 70 to 7! No other glitches or performance issues. Game itself is highly addictive... 'Damn I should go to bed. Maybe if I just quickly peek over that hill...'  There are a few things though I found somewhat annoying or that might have been made better. Game is very quick to start, that's good. But throwing the player on to alien world without suggesting any kind of graphical setup is a bit harsh thing to do. You can't tune your setting until you allready are in the game. And what makes this really annoying is that after you change your settings, you need to restart the game. And guess what? That also changes the planet you are on! Ok, optionally you can play a while with default settings so you get your game state saved and start fiddle with your setting after that. Another thing is that I guess most of the FPS issues are caused by those default settings. If I recall there was a FPS lock set to 30FPS by default. So by default there's VSync and this external FPS lock restricting your FPS.  User interface is nice. It's not as good and intuitive as I expected but one can come along with it. It does do everything that needs to be done and after a while I got used to it. What felt strange at first was that if something took time to get ready you just can't click an action button and wait, you need to keep that action button pressed to get things done. But that's just a matter of getting used to that.  Since No Man's Sky is an indie-game and no other game can offer same feeling of loneliness and vast space I would say it's a 10/10. If it would have been released by any of the big companies I'd say it is 7/10... I'm sure that future updates will make NMS even better experience. NMS is not really a cheap game but I guess it's worth of it's price tag. If you like fast paced action shooters then stay away. If exploring and casual shooting is your thing... Then this game is a MUST!  Ps. Did I say feeling of loneliness? During my 7 hour session last night I saw three flying starships in the game? Dunno if they were NPC or PC but that was a bit of a downer ;)

Okay, despite its many, many, many flaws, I love this game. Like I love Space Engineers. I've already played it some stupid number of hours (going on, what, 18 hours straight? I planned my weekend around it already and my GF has cloistered me into the office where my gamer funk won't bother the more civilized of the home.)  If you're on the fence about buying it, wait until Hello gets it in front of a real QA team and cleans up the rough edges. This is not a release-quality build of NMS. This is a 'Steam Early Access'-quality build. I realize they probably couldn't do Early Access due to whatever weird contract they had to sign to suckle the Sony cash, but really this needed to be in front of a much larger audience before a 'real' release.  It has a lot of compatibility and interface issues (see the /r/NoMansSkyTheGame subreddit for the comprehensive ♥♥♥♥♥fest). If nobody at Hello is foolishly married to the interface, they'll probably hear the hundreds of thousands of voices yelling at them to stop with the 'click-and-hold', slow-as-balls fade-in menus, intrusive achievement screens (that can get you killed), silly puzzles you can't do over even though in many cases it's completely unrealistic (for example being unable to access your inventory when offering something you have in your ship would be the correct thing to do), and unskippable, immersion-breaking cut-scenes peppered every-freaking where.   They say it's a chill game, but when I think chill games I think easy-to-use UI, for example Banished -- The UI responds to you quickly and gets the hell out of the way. NMS does not have an easy UI. All that said, you will be awed by beautiful renders of amazing worlds, even if you have to play on the lowest possible graphics settings (like me with my GTX660M). You will learn by trial and error what works and what does not work. You will find yourself immersed for hours on end in a mindblowingly large sandbox in which you have a choices between one of three different narrative guides or pure open sandbox play. If you liked freelancer, elite, et al, and prefer a game that is more procedural sci-fi novel with some narrative depth rather than the Elite: Dangerous flight simulator, this game was made for you.

Few people have played the PC version long enough to write a meaningful review, but that hasn't stopped hundreds of angry nerds with technical issues (of which I've had NONE) from writing 'reviews' based on the twenty minutes they spent trying to make the game work before they gave up. I'll try to provide a more honest look at the game.  No Man's Sky is about exploration and survival. The bulk of the gameplay consists of wandering around with a camera and gathering resources. A lot of reviews stress the resource angle, but it's actually quite easygoing if you want it to be. Just gather two or three different minerals as you go to keep your equipment charged and you're fine.  Along the way you'll learn bits and pieces of alien languages, which helps you interpret what merchants on orbital outposts are trying to say. These guys will buy your junk, sell you new stuff, or even offer up their ship for you to purchase. It can get a bit grindy if you want to buy an expensive ship with money from resource gathering, but you could do the same thing through exploration if mining bothers you.  On planets you can discover flora, fauna, and various locations. Some locations have a scanner that may lead you to other locations, and you have some choice in this. Scan for local transmissions or check out an abandoned manufacturing facility. Up to you. Sometimes you'll be confronted with a choice relating to the aliens who left artifacts lying around. If you choose right you'll increase your standing and get a bit of lore.  Visuals and sounds are abstract and strange, colorful and awkward. Don't expect the highest fi, because that's not what they were going for. It's more about feeling like you're in a place far from home and far outside your experience. In this NMS has succeeded, but it'll be lost on many. The game doesn't hit you over the head with its purpose, so if you're used to that it'll seem more than a bit aimless. That's half the fun.  NMS bears more resemblance to Flower than to CoD or GTA. The challenge is subtle and the reward is newness rather than imaginary points. It's not for everyone. I often toss a game out after less than an hour of play not because it's bad, but because it failed to grab me. NMS grabbed me from the start. Averaging my ratings returns a 5/10, but that's not accurate because things like combat are only a tiny part of this world.   It's worth your time, if only for the novelty, but PLEASE wait for a patch or two so you can actually play it. I'll agree with the critics that this should be priced lower. If the premise of NMS interests you, you should look into Rodina for a cheaper alternative. It's unfinished, but it scratches the same itch.  Anyway, right now I'll say the game's a healthy 7/10. I don't usually do reviews. So this is more of a recommendations list for what needs to be patched, to make this worth the pricetag.  No Man's Sky has a procedurally generated universe, full of wonder and strange animails and largely samey looking locations. There is little striking variation, especially in the things you actually interact with.  Despite encountering three different sentient alien species so far in my relatively short exploration of the game, all the tech looks the same. All the bases look essentially the same. The ships even look surprisingly similar.   So on to the dot points: - Fix the achievements. You are doing them wrong. Achievement should be something aspired to, not something that gets in the way and slows down the game. At least offer the option to minimise the alert, so it just pops up as a text box in the bottom corner. Having the entire screen narrow and your HUD obscured is a pain. Also, please make them a little harder to get. An achievement for everthing I do in the first hour? A little much. I can manage without the constant applause.  - Make the ships different. Getting a new ship should include some change to the basic stats of the ship, whether power supply or armor or shields or speed. Currently it is only the number of inventory slots available. Everything else is completely ignored. You essentially get a new ship so that you have a bigger bag to stuff things into.  - Fix the inventory system. Things needs to be stackable. Having a single pearl take up as much room as 500 units of iron is beyond stupid. And having two pearls not be able to be stacked, means two pearly take up as much room as 1000 units of iron. Which is just... dumb. Have a limit on the stacks, sure. And maybe add a tech so that you can store them more efficiently. But it makes collecting things from your exploration actively discouraged.  - Fix the tech system taking up space in your inventory. Perhaps split them out into two separate inventory areas, so ships can be differentiated based on the amount of cargo space, and how many upgrades you want to put on them. More different options means more fun.  - Allow the analysis visor to the turned on, and left on, without having to hold down the F key. Just press it for on, then press it for off. Is that really even something that needs to be pointed out? Or am I missing something in the controls that I should somehow magically know?  - Include some tutorial-style tips for the controls. Seriously. Even just a quick overview.  - Have an upload all option for explorers. Going through and manually uploading each rock you found is a pain. If I want to do that, and name them, I can. But an upload all option would save so much time.  - Add visual effects for the mining laser upgrades. Having it look exactly the same (or pretty much the same) no matter how many fancy techs you plug into your magic tool is boring. Even a colour change would be good.  - Make techs movable in the inventory. Also make them able to be turned on and off so we can try them out, in combinations.  - Fix the flight controls. The flying feels rubbery and weird. And have some kind of punishment for flying into stuff. Even taking some shield off would be useful. Invulnerable space ships? Boring.  - A down pointed camera for picking landing spots. My god but trying to land where you want is a pain. Especially on trading posts.  - Autopilot for trading posts. Select and let the machines do the work.  - Speed up speech interactions. It takes so, so long to talk to aliens. And its all text. Let me speed up the text. I read fast, and waiting for the next word to show up makes me feel like I am being actively prevented from playing the game.  - Info boxes that pop up when selecting a ship, before you speak to the alien. Not the tech, just the size and basic stats. Having to talk to the alien, select the menu option to make an offer on the ship, and only then find out its a piece of junk that I don't want is annoying. Also let me go back to the trade menu after that, rather than exiting out.  - Merge the buy and sell trade menus. Why are they separate? What is the point of that?  - Have a record somewhere easily accessible of the number of words found. Maybe each time you find a new one, note how many you now know of that language in a pop up. Again in a bottom corner somewhere. Or a top corner. Not filling the whole screen.  - Stop getting in the way of me having fun with overly long messages, overly large menu screens, and repetitive cutscenes. Or at least let me skip them. How many times do I need to zoom out of the planet so I can see that I now have a map marker? - Give me a map. At least a minimap. Any kind of map. I have a spaceship, but no idea where I'm going.  That's all for now. I suspect a lot of patching is in order. Or modding. Lots of modding.   Other than that, its a fun time. So I'm going to go with a yes to buy this game. If you wait six months and the price comes down and they fix a bunch of stuff.

Review from just after release  Firstly, I'll have to say that I am not seeing any fps-drops or lag. I'm on an Asus RoG with a Geforce 980M 4gb, 16gb DDR3 RAM, i7 4.00ghz quadcore. Maxed everything out in options menu, even SSAAx4 and ultra-shadows, and I have no problems whatsoever. Only a little load-lag when I start up the game. No lag AT ALL while playing. Runs completely smooth at all times. You people must have torrents, Windows updates, 50 browser-tabs or something running in the background. I hardly see any landscape-popping either. I had been afraid of that, after watching so many videos.   Conclusion  I'm loving the game so far. Already met a couple of aliens, got a new gun, tried to break into a research facility, got pummelled by drones, escaped, and farmed an entire asteroid field for fuel.  TBH, though, some of the ground textures aren't convincing, and I don't like the way mushrooms sway in the wind. That just looks wrong!  9/10   Additional review, almost 3 months after release  Even after the aftermath, I still recommend the game. It's evident that HG are working on a rather big update right now, and just about all crashes have been eliminated. Granted, the gameplay is a bit bland, but that's sort of the point of the game: focus on exploring the planets, and don't rush to max out everything, and you'll be content for many, many, many hours. Just pick up a few bibs and bobs along the way, to sell to traders or at the terminals, and pick up a new ship and weapon when you can. The best thing you can do for yourself, is to max your suit inventory, though. That'll be a tremendous help, in avoiding the inventory clutter. Don't hold on to things you don't need.  With mods, the game can be transformed into a variety of new forms. Crazier planets and more varied everything (Better Worlds mod), removal of the many small irritations you might have, higher definition textures, more cash from doing discoveries, more AI freighters and fighters in space, amazing asteroid fields etc.  When you get a hold of the save editor, your NMS-life can change forever. Personally, I'm not much for cheating, but simply changing all the unstackable items in my inventory to stack in 10000s, to avoid spending my life managing a clunky inventory, is one of the best things I've done for myself in this game.  The game engine is an incredible piece of art, and I am sure HG are going to take advantage of it, and will rake back many of their lost customers, after a few good updates. If they even take the time, to make it more natively modable, there's a large community waiting hungrily to lob content at it.  I do see quite a bit of landscape popping now, but I think some of the mods adding crazy amounts of trees and foliage, are to blame for that. The author of the Better Worlds mod, TemplarGFX, has an increase in draw distance in the works. I'm hoping he gets it going!   Conclusion  It retains its score of 9/10, but only because the game doesn't seem to mind being bent over by modders. If you don't care for modding, the score would be around 6/10, simply because the vanilla world generation is too restricted, and the gameplay is next to non-existent, clunky and even irritating at times. But as a universe exploration simulator, it's actually doing a pretty good job out of the box.

Alright, Now that I've had time to really play this game, I want to add my two cents. Especially with all the negative reveiws.   Let me just say this, for 90% of the gamers out there this game is not for you. This game is for a certain audience, and I happen to be one of them. I did NOT like Elite: Dangerous, it just wasn't for me.  However, this is a great game. It's for those who want to explore space, but at a less hectic pace. Objectives exsist, but you don't have to do them. You go at your own pace. It's a great game for after work when you just want to keep things mellow. You can explore and look at the beautiful scenery in the game, or go start a fight with the sentinels. Maybe you want to explore new planets and spend your time tying to 100% completely log a particularly interesting planet. That's the beauty of this game, you honestly can do WHATEVER you want.   Now some complaints from others I want to address:  1. I see that people are saying that 'every planet is the same', and I promise you that's not true. Certain planets do look similar but if you are willing to explore the star systems, you will find wonderful planets that look out of a dream. They are truly amazing.  2.Some people say this game is grindy. While this CAN be true in the game, it's all about how you play. Past building your first star ship and any MAJOR upgrade that is needed to complete a task, the game is only as grindy as you make it. Any augument for your multitool, exosuit, or starship is completely optional; it is not required for you to complete the game or even leisurely explore a star system. You really only need a few materials to sustain yourself and your equipment's charge as well, all of which can be easily found on nearly every planet. Once you build your main items, the materials you gather and the things you build are for the most part up to you.   3. The 'its not worth $60 dollars' argument. Now, how can someone justify the price of a game for everyone. FOR ME, the game is worth every penny I spent. All $59.99 of it has gone to good use. For you, the game may not be worth that price. That is something you need to judge for yourself, I cannot tell you what this game is worth to you. Sure, you could say that this game has less features than other $60 games and I would agree with you 100%. However, what about games like Battlefield and COD. Those games cost $60 as well, but have less features than games like Skyrim or MGS 5. The 'Not worth $60 ' argument is 100% wrong, due to the nature of this game. Let me put it this way; if you are willing to utilitze and appreciate this game for what it offers, then that price does not matter.    If you're interested in the game, I suggest you watch someone on youtube play it. I would recommend only watching the first 2 hours of the game though, as to not spoil everything for you as you progress in game.

No Man's Sky is very good if you like just straight exploring. I've played 12 hours and am still blown away. People are saying that there is a lack of things to do, but this game is very different from most. Instead of hitting you over the head with stuff you need to do, it gives you a general direction then says go play. No Man's Sky is a game where you make your own fun inside of it. Instead of saying 'Oh there's a quest marker there! I guess I should go check it out.' I instead say, 'Wow, there's a cool rock formation or a new alien word I can learn over there!'. There's a lot to explore and the variety is very good.  There are a lot of performance issues so I'd wait a bit for those to get sorted out. You need a pretty beefy computer to get a stable frame rate. If you have a good computer that is above the min specs, and can handle some choppy frames here and there, it's great.  Even though I really enjoy the game, and Hello Games has said they will continue to add new things, No Man's Sky is not for everyone. If you need quest markers constantly telling you where to go, who to talk to, or need faster gameplay, it's not for you. However if you like to stop and marvel at what is around you and take it slow, this is the game for you.

<h1>What it is good at</h1> Good for casual gaming. Beautiful planets, Amazing creatures, Good time sink when you just want to relax.  <h1>What it needs</h1>  <b>Better flight controls</b>: It's too easy right now. It needs more complexity in its flight. You can manuver straigt, and roll, that's it. The fights in space seem to be all about, who has the better shields. Dog fighting is almost not possible.   <b>More planet variety:</b> While there are many many planets, each planet is essentially 1-2 textures. All planets have just one characteristic. Its either a forest like planet, or its a dead planet etc. The planets are huge, but after you have see 10 feet of it, you have pretty much seen all of it!   <h1>What it is really bad at</h1>  <b>Balancing it's act</b>. Okay, so you have huge planets, huge universe, but the spacestations only have 1 room...really?  <b> Better Economy system:</b> Something I find very irritating, is that the gameplay is pretty much, mine stuff, make more money, then fly to other places. I think it needs more. It gets tedious very very quickly,  <b>CONTROLS</b>: the game does not support flight controls, as in flight sticks. and it should.  <h1>bottom line</h1> If you like casual space sims, get it.  If it is discounted, get it.  If you want to spend hours aimlessly looking at interesting creatures, get it.  If you are expecting anything other than a 'travel here and look at stuff game' don't get it.

It strikes me, reading through most reviews, that a lot of people were expecting a rather ridiculous range of things from this little indie game; so in lieu of a traditional review, i think instead I'll simply tell you what No Man's Sky is, and what it isn't.  What it is ...  - Art - Inventory management sim - Survival genre hybrid - Technologically impressive - Exploration heavy - Oddly relaxing  What it isn't ...  - Multiplayer - A new religion - Better than sex - Elite: Dangerous - Star Citizen - Endless grinding (just for a bit, in the beginning)  The more I play, the more I enjoy, and I couldn't recommend this game enough, but I knew what it'd be going in. A lot of people climbed onto the hype train and they aren't getting off anytime soon, and their reviews are all here if you're wondering how they feel. But for what it's worth ...  - If you loved the exploration of the first Mass Effect - If your best memory of Kerbal Space Program is stepping foot on another planet - If Minecraft is or ever was something you enjoyed playing - If your inner child hasn't been smothered to death by the crushing indifference of everyday life - If your inner child is dead, but you've got a few hrs to burn anyway ...  ... You will probably love No Man's Sky.

Well that was a bad launch wasn’t it but is the game good? I think it is in fact a marvel, a pocket universe running on my humble machine, I get a small thrill being the first, whatever I am, on an unknown virtual planet. Fun? That’s where it gets tricky, it’s most fun if you find science fun, there is some violence, don’t worry but it probably will be unsatisfactory if you thought no to the former.  There are goals, although not rigidly enforced but if you need structure, there is some. I’m a long way off from the “End-Game” but I do know where I might find it, centre of the galaxy, probably.  Now, the heart of the matter $€60. Is it worth that? I think it’s 100% inflated but I knew that when I pressed the buy button. Is it worth it if geeky science led exploration is your thing? Again no, there needs to be deeper tools to gain more information and insight from your surroundings. Hopefully they’ll add to the science sandbox but 10-1 they’ll add to the combat side of things and nobody gets the game they want.   I’m going to vote yes because there’s no middle ground to this voting system but if your pockets are deep and your curiosity insatiable then buy, if not wait for half the price.  **Edit - Couple of hours later : **  Changed to the experimental patch and wow, that's made a difference. Graphics are 100% smooth as silk, I got the occasional rare glitch before, they also seem better even though I was running at max before.  The most important thing though, I was suffering a bug with my scanner, it rarely worked but I didn't realise, now I can tag everything, rocks, trees, plants, so one of my major gripes is no more.  The more I play (and bugs squashed, features added), the happier I am with the purchase. Universe is massive, beautiful and strange. I genuinely enjoy this game and if you're comfortable with the price point, you may too.

In any case, If you like exploration games this is a must.

No Man’s Sky… i wrote this because i don't want to see this masterpiece ruined by a bunch of people who just want another stupid AAA clone.  This game is about exploration, and discovery, both concrete and abstract. It’s for people like me who enjoy discovering a cave that wasn’t put there by developers, feeling the beginnings of panic as you realize you’re getting lost in that cave, feeling relieved at finding the exit, but realizing it wasn’t the place you originally entered. Then finding a mountain range that wasn’t placed intentionally to prevent you overtaking its heights, then after reaching its peak, seeing a vast, beautiful, and untouched landscape stretch to the horizon, knowing that you can explore every bit of it...or none of it, and spotting a river or lake that isn’t taunting you to never cross its borders, but rather to explore its challenging depths and mysteries. It’s for those who appreciate the slightest variations in color and style of grass that make an environment unique. And having that character enhanced by a unique atmosphere, weather, and wildlife. It’s for people with enough curiosity to find the difference in animals that look very similar but your analysis visor classifies them as different species. This, for me, is No Man’s Sky. And as if that wasn’t enough, there are gentle --and at times, not so gentle-- game mechanics to enhance the journey. Death avoidance (not survival) pushes you to explore and find resources in a respectful manner, not to abuse the land and fill a bottomless inventory. This game is for people who feel a twinge of remorse for destroying the beautiful column of Heridium, or who, after collecting Platinum from the manmade silos by blowing them up, wonder, is it really my right to take this, or am i in the wrong? Then hearing the hum of sentries approaching, watching them scan the wreckage of your deed, realizing that you’ll have to answer for your actions, and deciding weather to run from the consequences, or to fight back and answer violence with violence. I’ve begun to make the moral decisions for the player at this point, but No Man’s Sky is your story as you explore the universe that is the closest man has ever come (speaking in terms of real-life-history-making) to replicating the beautiful, varied--and for those who don’t take the time to “smell the roses”-- mundane, reality that we live in.  10/10 for making the best game i have ever played!

'Sean lied', 'refund button works' and other negative reviews filled this game. However, there are not so many reviews about the ACTUAL game. Everybody talks about what is it supposed to be but nobody thinks about what is it at the moment or can become.    So this review is for those people who don't care about all that 'omg he lied/bad ending/game sucks/I expected more'.     First of all, I need to say - at the moment this game doesn't worth that much money. Yet it doesn't mean that No Man's Sky is a bad game. It's more like an Early Access game.   This game is not for everybody. Literally. You can compare it to walking in the park. Some people enjoy looking around, exploring, searching for new stuff without any point or actual end. Some people don't. Same is with this game. It's all about exploring, walking, listening and such stuff. It's an awesome game for taking epic and awesome screenshots. It's a nice game to chill after a hard day. It's a perfect game for dreamers. And it's a terrible game for those who are waiting for action all the way, storyline and the gameplay like in CoD.   You have a freedom to explore all the planets, all species. Some people say that random makes animals to look ugly, unreal, stupid. However, we can't know for sure if those creations can't be real. Moreover, random doesn't always make them that unlucky. Sometimes you can find something really nice looking.   Another problem that everybody complains about is that there are no those super epic space battles. Again, this game wasn't made for action. The main point of it is a calm exploration. Not the destruction of everything, killing the evil guy and living happily with a lady. In this game you have your own adventure and only you decide what do you want to do.   So fast cons and pros:  + Nice graphics (not for everybody but really unusual) + Really a lot of stuff to explore. (if you are not looking for fast running point-to-point) + Epic space + You can be first to discover one of the best planets + There are probably going to be some updates to this game  + Lots of freedom for modding. + Awesome ambient.  - Mostly all animals have a same colour - Animal's sounds may become annoying - Some colours are too toxic.  - Can be a bit too grindy (however, mostly all games have grind. At least you don't see here standart 'I need eggs. Go kill hens and bring me eggs') - No real point. You are free. You need to find what to do.    A pretty but overhyped game. Too high price for the current stage but maybe we'll get something more in the end.

No Man's Sky is a strange game to say the least. I'll get into that later but let me get one point across; this game isn't for everyone. This game if for a group of people who find enjoyment in exploring a universe and finding a perfect scene straight from 'A Sci-Fi novel cover'.    Ok with that out of the way No Man's Sky is flawed in a lot of ways, it's inventory system is the perfect mix of pure pain and horror, a lot of assets pop up constantly, and it's very very slow at the beginning; at 9 hours in I'm still struggling to progress. You also have to bare the bugs and slowdown, some people have claimed to crash on startup and some have claimed to be perfectly fine. I find myself having some slowdown but I've never crashing. Also it's very Alt-Tab unfriendly but you can bring it back up in a second in task manager.   It may start slow but it speeds up a lot. The game is completely RNG so you might take a bit longer or shorter depending on how lucky you are with your spawn point but you will progress. With an Atlas Pass v1, you can start picking up upgrades for your inventory and all around better loot. With a better multi-tool you can start hitting harder and mining quicker making grinding a bit easier. As you learn alien languages (Yes you have to learn every word by finding the words at monoliths) you can pass speech checks with more certainty because you know what they are asking you to give or do.   If you plan to buy this game please be aware it is all RNG, you may be the luckiest person and only find banger planets or you might for squatt. And make sure you give it a bit because there is a story, there is progression, and there is a great game under all the day one problems, give the game a few more weeks and Hello Games has a chance of making the game they set out for it to be.  TL;DR It's good if you want to explore but it's a slow start and kinda buggy ATM.

Note that I am marking this as Recommended, but I am recommending it for a very select group of people.  The very first thing I will say is that No Man's Sky is definitely not meant for everyone, there is a very niche group of people that will enjoy it, and if you are not in that group, you will likely hate it, or find it immensely boring. That said, if you are part of the group the game is intended for, you will find a lot to love. Not to say the game isn't without problems.  First off, if you don't find the idea of a game focused purely on exploration exciting, this game is most definitely not for you. Wandering onto a planet for the first time and touching down on a hill top, getting out of your ship to see the sun rising over vast plants of grass flowing in the winds with strange, and sometimes beautiful creatures wandering across the hills can be very exhilarating. And if you're like me, when you find one of these planets, you'll spent many hours on it just trying to analyse and name every thing on that planet, tracking down all of the knowledge stones, and finding as many new blueprints as you are able.  On the flip side, you need to visit the rarer systems (The color of the stars matter FYI) to ever find planets that are arguably worth exploring. Early in the game, you will find a lot of planets that just seem like barren wastelands with underwhelming, or non-existent creatures. It really takes many hours of exploration off the beaten path before you are truly rewarded with the beautiful sights you were likely expecting from the E3 trailers. And while I, personally, have not found creatures quite on the scale of beauty of those found in the E3 trailers, others have. They are out there, you just have to be dedicated to finding them. After all, this is a game about exploration, the whole purpose of your existence in this literal universe is to explore, and seek out these amazing sights.  As for gripes, I do have a few, my largest one being that you are not free to fly around while in a planets atmosphere as you please, you are locked at a certain altitude above ground level, and the game strictly enforces it. This is immensely irritating, especially when trying to land near a certain landmark or building, and trust me... on certain planets with extreme weather or hazards, you will want to land as close as possible to those if you haven't installed any hazard protection in your suit. This is coupled by the annoyance of there being no method of free looking while in your ship on PC without plugging in a controller. I'm no programmer, but I'd imagine it can't be that complicated to bind a toggle to a button to allow the mouse free look while flying. After all, this is a game about exploration... let me look around while I'm in my ship.  Inventory management is 50:50 for me, in the beginning, it is the most irritating thing in the universe. But once you start finding drop pods with exosuit upgrades, or a ship with a fairly large inventory, it becomes a lot more manageable.  Overall, I do recommend the game, but as I said in the beginning of my review, I only recommend it for a very select group of people. If you are expecting an action packed adventure, this game is not for you. If you are expecting an epic story, this game is not for you. This game was designed from the ground up for people who enjoy the thrill of exploration, and finding new and exciting landscapes, creatures, or flora. For those that enjoy being a virtual photographer.  If you are a part of that group, you will greatly enjoy this game, despite the flaws.  A note on performance, as has been brought up in many reviews. I have had little to no problems on max settings with performance overall, despite a little bit of hitching in the first half hour or so when I booted up the game the very first time, my specs are listed below: GTX 1070 32 GB RAM i7-6700K 500 GB SSD
