This game is honestly a ton of fun but is not without its issues and I'm going to try my absolute best to be objective.  Overall: The game is incredibly fun as it stands (if you can run it) and has a ton of potential if they continue to update it but I'm not sure I would have kept my preorder if I would have known that I would have so many performance issues and would have ot try and troubleshoot crashes for my friends too. It's entirely unacceptable to launch a game that doesn't run for a huge amount of people when you had so long to playtest it. Can be somewhat lonely if you don't talk to others (I was playing at the same time as friends on teamspeak so I had company).  Pros:  - Very unique and calming experience that looks pretty good. - Extensive options menu - Exploring is fairly rewarding and somehow doesnt really seem to get repetitive even if some of the planets feel similar.  Cons: - The UI literally feels copy and pasted from PS4 (long pressing with mouse click?) and could seriously use some work. - The optimization at launch was attrocious and still needs some serious work(thankfully there are a lot of workarounds available on reddit to help with performance) - Changing fullscreen modes requires a full game restart which makes no sense whatsoever - No multiplayer (I didn't care for it but I don't like the dishonesty/lack of communication surrounding this) - Serious lack of communication by HG overall despite having a bigger PR team than dev team. - A lot of things are just very unintuitive and easy to miss if you don't know to look for them. - The game has some serious quality issues with the audio and uses white noise for atmosphere WAYYYY too much.  Now that I've hit 100 hours I'd like to add a few things: - Almost every mechanic and system within the game goes entirely unexplained and you need to look reddit for stats and general game knowledge. - The inability to move upgrades and parts around within the ship makes no sense at all and adds unnecessary difficulty to the game that literally shouldn't exist.  - As someone used to Elite Dangerous' flight mechanics, I really really don't like the space combat in this game. It just doesn't feel good to me.

Well, not the MAIN reason of the under-cover savant-status I will try to argue for.  In this game, the goal is just something to aim for. The true game is maintenance of your systems and figuring out how to reach the center as fast as possible. I recently read a review were someone said: Wide as an ocean, deep as a puddle. Well. Kind of. However, the shallow game is the smoke-screen. In reality it is so wide, and so shallow that it eclipses the very concept of our lives and circles back around to become the most deep game that has ever, and can ever be produced by humans on a transistor based computer system. To understand the game you must consider 'what is a game'. For the past decade and a half we have moved away from the roots of gaming, from epic classics like populus and qubit. Todays games have hand-holding, constant rewards, and a pat on the back even if you do poorly. Todays game has exposition of how important your actions in the game are. They have action and insane experiences that take the post-real narrative found in movies and turn them up to 11.  Take a game like CS:GO. In reality it is not about skills, it is not about getting ranks. It is about playing, finnishing, and, win or loose, start queing again.  No manssky does away with all that and return to the foundation of what a game is. Sure, the game has a samey-feel to it. Sure, the animations are very stilted and immersion-breaking. Sure, the AI is JUST passing the nightmare found in Alien: Colonian Marines. And yea, sure, whoever coded space-combat and its companion systems; should be shot, quartered, and forced to grow potatoes in Greenland. But, as you play, you realize that were there is need for after-thought and a deft hand in design, nomanssky has you covered.  Different upgrades to your warp-drive allowes you to go from mostly dreary and booring systems, to dreary and booring planets with more grass. At the highest tier you get to go to blue systems, and by then, you will be longing for a grass-less and foilage-less planet. If only as a change of pace. Different colored back-drops indicate what type of resources you are most likely to find in the system space, and perhaps even on the planets. Different systems are not explained to you, you learn them by spending hours in game and slowly seeing patterns.  Industry standards are turned on their head all through the game. As an example:  Money does not matter, since you simply will have no chance to pass the ever rising cost of new ships. Once you finally grind to max itemization, money is used for buying items so you can get back on the road rather than spend hours looking for that one shit♥♥♥♥ing♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ resource you are missing to repair your hyper-drive..  Because that is what the game is about. It is about staying on the road.  The end goal does not matter, it is the journey that gives life meaning.   Noamnsky is ♥♥♥♥ing philosophy!  So, awards time. Do I reccomend it to the gamers of today? Hell No. I'd be hardpressed to reccommend this game to ANYONE. Still: Do I think you should all buy it and play it, ♥♥♥♥ yes.  /Noam Chomsky.  <EDIT> It needs to be said that the marketing of this game was EXTREAMLY misleading. And that is something we need to combat. Through legal means, low sales, and refunds. Sadly, I cannot get a refund because I stand by the words I have written above. The scary thing is that if NMS ends up doing really well economically, then we will see in move towards NMS type marketing. And if we have that, then gaming will die eventually.

I don't normally post a lot of reviews, but wanted to take a moment and give my $.02 on No Man's Sky.  I understand there's been a lot of hype on this game and quite honestly, a lot of it was unwarranted. It was always built as a gargantuan space sand box. It was never billed as being an action-heavy shoot-em up. So, I puzzle at the high number of negative reviews, all of them seeming to hinge on the game being 'boring.' Well, boring to you might be paradise to others.  I'm an old gamer and was looking forward to this one because it was laid back. What I read about it over the past six months or so, told me that this was going to be in a very similar vein of the old Starflight game that came out back in the mid 80's. I played the heck out of that and enjoyed it immensely. When NMS opened, I was greatly pleased to see that I was right. This is an open-universe sandbox where I can explore and do pretty much exactly what I want to do. I could not have been happier. That said, here's my 5X5 Pros and Cons:  5 PROS  1. You are completely on your own. Figure it out.   2. Incredibly vast. I'm only on my 2nd planet in my starting system. I don't want to leave.  3. Robust crafting system. Seriously, I don't even know how many blueprints I have now.  4. Planets have everything, from flora and fawna to aliens to crashed ships to all kinds of secrets. Hence, why I don't want to leave the planet surface.  5. It's wide open for you to play how you want to play. Do you want to linger on planets and explore? Do you want to get out into space and look for someone to scrap with? Do you want to get to the center of the universe as fast as you can? Do you want to study the aliens and learn their language so you know what they're saying--currently this is what I am working on and it's quite entertaining? Whatever you want to do, it's all up to you.  5 CONS  1. I'd like to see more textures introduced in the future. At the moment, there are a lot of similarities to aliens and ships.  2. On that subject, I'd love to see some love given to player-allowed cosmetic upgrades. Letting players customize their ships with colors and decals would be a wonderful addition.   3. I like the trade network, but there needs to be more variety. There also needs to be some randomness in the buying and selling. If you do a little studying on how it works, you'll see it's pretty easy to make money. Find out what the network is buying and then visit all the ships that dock and buy low, so you can sell high. I spent about an hour in the space station working the network and was able to upgrade my ship significantly.  4. I'd like to see a little more wildness to the planets, at least in terms of hostile aliens. While the fire pit I'm on right now forces me to stay near my ship or I'll cook to death, it would be nice to have some random T-Rex like creature come and try to have me for dinner.   5. It would be nice to see them rework the slot system with ships. As it stands, every slot can have equipment upgrades or cargo. They could improve the ship building piece of this game by seperating it out to have X number of equipment slots and X number of cargo slots. It would also add for different variations to similar skins, more so that exists now.  Overall, this is a definite 7 or 8/10 game and worth the money. Some improvements going forward will push that higher and I have no doubt it will continue to be refined. I, for one, could not be happier with my purchase.  Oh, as as far as people ragging on the PC port? I have an older PC...granted, it's an Alienware and I keep it in good shape, but it's not a brutally fast gaming rig like a lot of people have these days. With my PC, I have had absolutely ZERO problems playing the game. No Frame Rate Issues and NO crashes.

I don't usually write reviews for games, but I know a lot of people have been on the fence with buying this game because of how expensive it is. I've played games like minecraft, space engineers, kerbal space program, spore etc. All of them never really did it for me. I wanted to spend less time on creating the thing I'm flying, and more time exploring and building other things/ surviving. I remember when I played spore I was begging for someone to create a mod that allowed me to get out of my spaceship on different planets and walk around the cities and explore the planets themselves. Yea it had a hollogram thing but it just wasnt the same.   I digress, this game really hits that spot for me that none of the other games did. I really enjoy being able to explore different planets, pilot my ship in and out of space whenever I want, interacting with different alien races.   I think it's easy to be tempted into flying into a planet quickly checking out what resources it has, maybe mining a few, and then leave the planet to check out the next one. Then people complain that the game gets boring after a while, when they aren't seeing the point. You can fly at high speed in your space craft for 20 minutes straight and still not be to the other side of the planet. There is so much exploring that can be done just on 1 planet. The past 2 days I've spent all my time on 1 planet, excavating important resources for maintaining my ship, interacting with the alien species, finding monoliths, learning the language of the species to build relationships with the race. This has led to me finding an ancient pool of resources/technologies from a tribe, finding a downed spaceship that had hyperdrive installed on it, and gaining artifacts worth tons of cash. This is all just on 1 planet. I feel like I'm playing out a sci fi movie on 1 planet and I still don't feel like I'm done.  I think if you are a disciplined explorer/survivor enthusiast, you will thoroughly enjoy this game.

It's a really good exploration game, and it gives you a good feeling about how lonely space is, but still keeps you interested with npc's. With very low chances to find other people, it is mainy a single player game. In my opinion, its definately worth the buy and I very much enjoy the game.

So far this has exceeded my expectations. I've only visited 3 planets, but each has been completely different, the third being a lush paradise planet with awesome land and undersea locations...lucky I guess (I'm still looking for an ingame camera...if there isn't one there should be!). With changing day/night lighting, scenes morph constantly, so it would have been nice to stand and capture the atmosphere...truly beautiful! (edit: I suppose I can use the steam camera instead...didn't think of that!)  Standing in the entrance to a coral encrusted sea cave, looking out on a blue sky with some kind of alien pumping station standing in a glistening sea...that's all I was hoping for (easily pleased! :D). Diving down through the atmosphere of an alien world from space is a wonderful experience. I've played many spaceship sims over the years and nothing has been as much fun as this - smooth and unbroken from deep space right down to a detailed and lush landscape. Hop out the ship, run down to the shore and dive down to the depths of a crystal clear ocean. I commend Hello games for this achievement alone. It's a shame ship controls don't allow me a little more freedom to skim over the surface at a lower altitude, but I guess that's the payoff for having such a detailed landscape. We are made to fly at a height that limits detailed inspection and thus not bog FPS to a crawl.  I generally prefer to play/explore/construct alone and I hate to admit that I loved Minecraft from the start (still do) for the same reasons I wanted this game...relative infinity and no-one else to spoil things.  Gameplaywise and graphically this is everything I expected it to be and more. I wasn't interested in multiplayer, I didn't expect to be able to build an intergalactic empire and didn't get caught up in the hype...I just wanted to relax and explore a procedurally generated universe.   Not one crash so far. Worked silky smooth at 90fps with all settings set to max from start with a few ingame graphic option changes. My PC is pretty average now at i7, Geforce 970, 32Gigs internal memory.  I'm sorry there are so many who wanted/expected there to be more to NMS and I can completely understand the frustration and disappointment for those experiencing technical problems...hopefully the majority of these 'will' get sorted. However, IMHO too many people who would not normally like this type of game got caught up in the media hype. This started as an Indie game that had such an incredible launch trailer that everybody jumped on the bandwagon and as a small company Hello lost control of the weight of expectations.   I agree with the majority here that this should never have been billed as a triple 'A' game and £39 is overpriced if it's not 'your' sort of game, but this probably wasn't Hello's fault. However, with updates and add-ons, I think it could achieve this status. I'm excited for the next update, that this is early days still, and the game has enormous potential, but there's still so many good surprises, even at this stage. Personally £39 was money well spent as I love it so far. Hopefully updates will extend that satisfaction for a sufficent number of hours that I won't eventually feel I paid too much. I liked it a lot. Too many people didn't understand what it was until after they bought it hence all the ♥♥♥♥♥ing and moaning and complaining.  Don't believe in all the thumbs down. If you understand that you're getting into a game that is single player, mostly about exploration through a massive amount of worlds that are similar in ways but different in others. It's procedural generation people. You think they could fit unique content 18 quintillion times? Your fault for hyping it up too much.  However if you like exploration, cataloguing stuff, solving small logic puzzles and exploring a never ending sandbox, then enjoy. Think of it as Diablo, people run the same rifts and greater rifts over and over and over with little to no variation. Now apply that logic to space travel and you have No Man's Sky.   Pros:  It's awesome Loading times are gone unless you account for the time it takes to enter and exit a planet's atmosphere or warping to another system. Graphics aren't bad. Lots of little things to check out and sink your teeth into. Good soundtrack Good ship variation  Cons:  Feels a bit empty but then again with so much to play with it's going to feel empty....it's space. Could use a bit more variety in terms of things to do. Could benefit from a mission or two or maybe factions besides 'Reach the center of the galaxy' Could use more variation on elements to gather and more craftables.   That's a pretty basic review but it's a thumbs up for me. When you wanna relax and just aimlessly wander around a giant sandbox getting upgrades and checking out all the quirks the game has to offer.....then it's a definite must have. If you're expecting a structured journey with someone holding your hand the whole way or to have every single planet be entirely unique then you're going to be disappointed. You can't have unique and 18 quintillion in the same game. It's just not gonna happen. Now if you consider unique as 'Hey that animal has wings now and on the last planet they were purple with only 4 legs', then you will eat this game up.  P.S. My favorite thing to do so far is find the language stones as it automatically translates once found during dialogue with an alien. Knowing what they're saying and which thing to give them goes A LONG WAY towards getting blueprints and multitools worth having (3 hours in and I have a 14 slot multitool that only cost me 100 carbon)  So yeah, that's my review. I hope you enjoy. If you don't, feel free to write your own review and all that jazz, just don't critique the fact that I like it for what it is and didn't make it out to be something it's not.

No Man's Sky should be in a genre of its own: Discovery.  Those classifying the game into a survival game, space game, first-person shooter, simply aren't doing the game any justice. It's not trying to be any of those things.  No Man's Sky is a game where the sole objective is discovery for discovery's sake. New species, new planets, new aliens, new languages, new trees, plants, fish, oceans, terrains, atmospheres, it's all about finding new things.  Trade, survival, civilizations, combat, all give your discovery context and meaning, but lead back to the roots of discovery for the sake of discovery, and what a lot there is to discover.  In my hours with No Man's Sky, I have been more immersed that any other game I've ever played, and I have an extensive library. Further, No Man's Sky technical marvels are beyond what I can possibly imagine.  If you have ANY sense of discovery, wonder, and adventure, then this game is for you. If you find that boring, or a silly premise for a game, then, by all means, don't play.  As far as technical issues go, I have faced none and the game plays around 40-60 fps in 1080p with an i7 3770k and a factory 980. Tips and tricks, try turning down the settings to Medium, still looks great and is very smooth, and also make sure your frame limited is set to Max in game.  TL;DR  If you have any wanderlust or adventure within yourself, I can recommend this game wholeheartedly. If you, on the other hand, need an objective, or a concrete point as to why you are doing things, then this game might not be for you.

Kalosia, the planet that I had named after the Greek word for 'beautiful' and 'good', was my first planet in No Man's Sky. Unlike most of my friends who were excited to take their pre order ships into space right away, from the beginning I was absolutely enthralled by my planet and couldn't imagine leaving it so soon. I clumsily fumbled my way through my ship's repairations and, once finished, decided that it could wait. I was worried at what I'd miss on the ground while gliding through the skies, and so my journey began.  On foot, I turned myself in the opposite direction of my ship and started out. It was overwhelming at first. There were so many things to scan and creatures to chase and admire. While my goal was to 100% my planet, I also very much understood that I may not be able to. The only direction I knew to go was away from my ship, but occasionally markers would pop up on my screen of the direction of an undiscovered sight and I would head there before moving on with my journey. Quickly the feeling of being overwhelmed was replaced by excitement with each new discovery I unveiled. I walked, I explored, all while sustaining my life support and thermal protection from the plants and minerals I came across on my way. I turned to look at where my ship was and noticed I was 48 minutes walking distance from it, but had been traveling for over two hours, never going longer than 20-30 minutes without a new discovery.   When I was ready to move on, I realized with dismay how absolutely far I'd gone away from my ship and did not have the energy to travel all the way back. My goal then became to find a site with a beacon to summon my ship to me and then I could take my exploration to the stars. Not 20 minutes later, I came across a site with just that and as I got my arrangements in order for space flight, I realized I had ended up with a 100% on my planet. I claimed my large credit reward, but to me the real reward was being able to complete it without traveling to every corner of my planet, desperately looking for that final unidentified creature to fill my log. It all just happened as I walked in one direction, never going long without discovering something that to me made the entire trip worth while.  I don't know what it is about No Man's Sky. You're reading the review of a person who sticks usually to theme park MMO's or competitive multiplayer experiences, games with clear goals and directions in mind. I've tried unsuccessfully to get into other games where the point is to make your own way but they've never appealed to me in the slightest. This couldn't be more different with No Man's Sky. I feel like the wonder of being a kid and discovering video games for the first time can and is being relived with this game.   I'm very thankful to have had this experience at 7.4 hours in and am very much looking forward to many, many more.

Beautiful worlds, beautiful (sometimes wierd) fauna and flora, seamless interface from land to atmo to the Black (which isn't usually black ;p)  Extremely immersive gameplay for those that like to take their time and figure things out for themselves a bit (so will probably appeal more to adults.)  A basic mathematical knowledge is required for some of the numerical 'puzzles' & a good grasp of language for the witty cultural references , element naming & descriptions.  Everything I was expecting and more.  EDIT: After 46 hours playing:  If your rig can run it, you're an adult, and you think you'll like it, get it.  Think about the number of copies sold, look at the negative review numbers on Steam (and the other place) and you'll see that less than 5% of folks who have the game don't like it and a lot of folks posting about it don't have it, or couldn't understand/ run it and refunded.  Don't be dissuaded by the sheeple trying to trash the game; it is very deep, has a lot of strategies for playing, requires zero grinding & may refresh your mathematical skills solving some of the puzzles.  Don't spoil it for yourself by watching any 'how to play' videos; just jump in, learn and enjoy the experience.  I'd say it does need a mature outlook to get the full enjoyment out of it, since there may be a lot of reading conversations and background lore (and nodding to Sci-Fi themes) in the quest paths.  If you liked reading Doc Smith, Johns, Burroughs, Aldiss, Heinlein, Clarke, Watson, Baxter & Banks et cetera then you'll probably love it.

Aside from the problems at launch (which I got lucky with and have only had FPS issues) I am enjoying the game quite a bit. It's very relaxing to be able to just sit down and explore space or planets, and find underground cave networks that go on and on and on.   Likes: Freedom - You can do what ever you want when you want (as long as resources allow), and if you want to spend 10 hours on 1 planet finding ruins, transmission towers, and more you can. Want to farm resources on a planet then go sell them for the best prices possible so you can get that big ship? Go do it. Want to just hit space and name as many planets as possible? Go for it. No load times - There's no loading, you can go from a planet to space with no loading and it's very seemless. It transitions very well, and easily. I find myself doing it a lot and bouncing between planets in a system and not once have I had an issue with it. Only real load times in my opinion, are warps, but those are fairly quick and you don't really see them as load times. Massive Scale - This game is huge, the planets and moons are huge, and space is huge. Literally endless areas to explore and visit and alien lifeforms to discover and resources to farm. Hours of fun are to be had here.  Dislikes - It honestly feels like somethings missing, maybe its lack of multiplayer in a world where we've grown so used to 99% of games having some form of being able to play with your friends, or maybe it's just the fact that planets feel empty aside from ruins, transmission towers, observatories, etc and few and far inbetween alien life forms. Perhaps it's the fact we have so much potential that we can't help but let our mind wander a bit with features we'd like added. Either way it just feels like something is missing.   Don't get me wrong, I will be playing this game quite a bit. It will help me through down times at work, give me something to do in my free time, and even if I'm gaming with friends it'll be fun to play and compare what we're finding as we're playing. Just sucks we wont be able to join up together.   8/10

I don't know where all these negative reviews are coming from. I understand the game has a few bugs, though I've only found one game breaking bug where one multi-tool upgrade module on one planet in one building at one waypoint caused the game to crash. Other than that, the game lives up to what it was marketed to be.  If you do your research before buying this game (or any game), as you should, you'd see the metaphorical small print under where it says '18 quintillion unique planets' and that small print says 'procedurally generated'. Essentially, that means every planet is different on the surface but the same at its core. It would be nearly impossible for any game creator to design a game engine that would create a procedurally generated world as vast as this one AND have every aspect of that world be truly different in such a way that every new discovery would 'wow' you.  I have 33.4 hours on record for a reason. This game is chock full of wonders that, for me, never get old. Yes, you have to grind a bit to survive at first. Want to fix that? Upgrade your multi-tool. Get more slots, install more modules to destroy terrain faster, mine faster, reduce cooldown. That way you can make a 20 minute pit stop and have fuel for hours. You can also make money accumulation less 'grindy' by doing that, leaving loads of free time to EXPLORE.   In Summary: If you like to nit-pick irrelevant issues, this game is not for you. If you have the attention span of a humming bird, this game is not for you. If you expect more than what Hello Games says is in the game (e.g. more storyline depth, more alien races, more things in general), this game is not for you. If you feel entitled to everything and don't believe you should have to WORK to get materials, upgrade your equipment, etc. to a point where you don't have to grind anymore, this game is not for you.  However, if you like the videos and screen shots you see about No Man's Sky and you don't fit into one of the categories above, you will love this game. You will love the beautiful views on serene planets. You will love the sheer vastness of the game. You will love the fact that there are things to do every 20 feet on every one of the 18 quintillion planets available for you to explore at will (and in space), even if these things seem mildly repetitive because they are still fun. You will love the fact that you are truly free to do whatever you want, to BE whoever you want. You can spend your entire time being a botanist, zoologist, or geologist and document everything on every planet. You can be a scientist and focus on finding new technology and upgrading what you have. You can be a miner or farmer and trade vast quantities of materials. You can be a hunter or bounty hunter and hunt animals, kill sentinels, and destroy enemy starships. You can be a trader and hunt down rare materials, items, etc. and get rich. You can even be a pirate, friend of no one, and hunt friendly star ships for their loot. Or, you could follow Atlas's directive and travel to the center of the universe.   TL:DR: Take the game at face value. Do your research. Watch some videos. If you like what you see, you're about to fall in love. If not, walk away now.

It's a rather zen exploration game with crafting and survival elements. I wouldn't expect this to blow you away. Lower expectations from 'first ticket on the hype train' to 'realistic realm of imagined possibility' and I bet you'll find something to love here.   Hardcore fans of Elite: Dangerous and it's simulation-level attention to details are probably not welcome here, however, as the game doesn't play like elite at all. Many processes are automated and the combat is fun if a bit arcade-like.  PC Gamer's Andy Kelly said it best in the following paragraphs: 'I love science fiction, because it fires my imagination in a way no other genre does. In Arthur C. Clarke’s novel 2001: A Space Odyssey, in a chapter titled The World of the Gods, the Discovery passes Jupiter and sends a probe into the massive, chaotic storms raging in its atmosphere.  The way Clarke vividly describes an “endless sea of mottled gold” and how it’s so alien that it’s “meaningless to eyes accustomed to the shapes and colours of Earth” has always stuck with me, because it makes you realise just how terrifyingly, infinitely unknowable space is.  And, for me, No Man’s Sky captures some of this sci-fi magic. It makes me feel like I’m voyaging into the unknown, a speck of dust floating in a vast cosmos. But to appreciate the game on this level you need to take some responsibility yourself. You need an imagination.'  TL;DR you need a good rig, imagination, and a desire for things to slow down for a while.   Review Addendum: it appears that people with different hardware combinations are suffering from a variety of issues from crashing to hitching to massive FPS drops and total unplayability. At native resolution on my Geforce GTX 860, the game struggled to reach 'cinematic' framerates, so allow me to emphasize that this is a highly tentative recommendation based solely on the level of relaxation the game allows, which was surprising for a game featuring survival elements.  I cannot recommend the game in its current state if your system has any struggles or difficulty running modern titles from 2014 on. The chances are high that your system would stutter and the experience would be unplayable. [These problems have, as of this edit, 8/18, mostly been fixed with hotfix patchesand driver updates, however some people continue to have issues.]

Played since launch, no crashes and no complaints. The game is everything that was promised and more, IE. a gargantuan playspace filled with procedurally generated content. Sure some of it looks repetative, but then that's how the real world works too. Most of the differences are fairly subtle, and I'm fine with that. The game is about the experience of your journey, not about fulfilling objectives and reaching a finish line. If you're the kind of person who's sunk a respectable amount of time into games like Elite Dangerous, odds are you'll enjoy No Man's Sky. If you're the kind of person who needs someone to hold their hand to complete even the most basic of tasks, look elsewhere for your entertainment.  There's enough to do and see that no one will be able to see all of it in one lifetime.  Too many people have overhyped the game to themselves, and now that it isn't the second coming of Christ, but a reasonably well-made indie game on a larger budget, they're burning the house down.   Be aware however, that the combat is terrible. Once you get used to how it works you'll be able to hold your own, but it's a plodding and loose shooter both in space and on land. The flight controls are clunky if you're coming from a game like Star Citizen or Elite Dangerous. It's not a sim, so don't expect to fly like one.   The first hours are also difficult given the lack of tutorial or real explanation on how the different game systems work. You'll need to figure a lot of it out for yourself, which isn't necessarily a bad thing.   This game takes some getting used to, but once you do it's a fantastic experience. All in all, I highly recommend No Man's Sky to anyone with an interest in survival games (there is a survival element to this) or exploration/adventure games.

I have to treat No Man's Sky like one big endgame. I've already defeated the enemy, saved the galaxy, and now it's time for me to see what I've saved.  No Man's Sky fits the definition of an open world better than any game I've seen yet. Many of the planets that I have visited have felt unique. The size of each planet probably is larger than most maps made for other open world games such as Fallout 4 and GTA5. Combine that with thousands or millions of systems, and you have a world that is never going to be completely explored by you. You will leave a small mark on it by discoveries, viewable by all players should you upload them, and continue on your journey.  Your journey is open ended, and you can go wherever you feel like. No Man's Sky does give waypoints, but they are free for you to ignore and go back to later. The game will even provide new waypoints should you go a little bit too far from one, and it would be too hard to go back. Wherever your journey takes you, it will be a grind. You will find yourself repeating an action to fufill a blueprint technology, learning words to speak to aliens and gain from them better, fighting enemies that want to hinder your path, or simply mining to repair a broken part, or make something new. It is impossible to just do something; you must work and maintain to reach your goals.  No Man's Sky is the biggest endgame I've played, so big it didn't need to include the originial story, because the original story stopped mattering when it ended. This game is a must play for those that love the grind.
Say what you will about the hype insanity, but I happen to love this game.

It's a rather zen exploration game with crafting and survival elements. I wouldn't expect this to blow you away. Hardcore fans of Elite: Dangerous and it's simulation-level attention to details are probably not welcome here, however, as the game doesn't play like elite at all. Many processes are automated and the combat is fun if a bit arcade-like.  PC Gamer's Andy Kelly said it best in the following paragraphs: 'I love science fiction, because it fires my imagination in a way no other genre does. In Arthur C. Clarke’s novel 2001: A Space Odyssey, in a chapter titled The World of the Gods, the Discovery passes Jupiter and sends a probe into the massive, chaotic storms raging in its atmosphere.  The way Clarke vividly describes an “endless sea of mottled gold” and how it’s so alien that it’s “meaningless to eyes accustomed to the shapes and colours of Earth” has always stuck with me, because it makes you realise just how terrifyingly, infinitely unknowable space is.  And, for me, No Man’s Sky captures some of this sci-fi magic. It makes me feel like I’m voyaging into the unknown, a speck of dust floating in a vast cosmos. But to appreciate the game on this level you need to take some responsibility yourself. You need an imagination.'  TL;DR you need a good rig, imagination, and a desire for things to slow down for a while.   Review Addendum: it appears that people with different hardware combinations are suffering from a variety of issues from crashing to hitching to massive FPS drops and total unplayability. At native resolution on my Geforce GTX 860, the game struggled to reach 'cinematic' framerates, so allow me to emphasize that this is a highly tentative recommendation based solely on the level of relaxation the game allows, which was surprising for a game featuring survival elements.  I cannot recommend the game in its current state if your system has any struggles or difficulty running modern titles from 2014 on. The chances are high that your system would stutter and the experience would be unplayable. [These problems have, as of this edit, 8/18, mostly been fixed with hotfix patchesand driver updates, however some people continue to have issues.]

I never really bought into the hype, which I don't think can genuinely be attributed to the creators, and preferred to keep in mind the small size of Hello Games team, and their relatively humble statements about what this game was going to be: 'A game about exploration and survival in an infinte procedurally generated uiniverse'. Is it not that?  I had minimal issues on release with my 4 year old PC; maybe keeping drivers up to date actualy helps.  Yeah, and while playing I've had moments of boredom while visiting another bleak 'shades of brown' planet, but I've also visited planets where I've just stood still and stared in amazement at the incredibly vivid and varied landscapes. I have never posted a review before but I feel that I must defend No Man's Sky. This is one of the most unique games that I have ever experienced and it deserves merit for it's ridiculously large sense of scale. I have never seen an exploration/survival game that makes you feel like you are jumping galaxies and traversing new terrain.  The beating heart of this game is mining and collecting resources...so if you don't like that mechanic than this game isn't for you. Sure, there is a vague, over-arching purpose of finding the center of the universe, but this game is about exploration and looting. The exploration in this game is at-your-own-pace--it is relaxing and it's what sets it apart from other games. To me that is the most rewarding part. If you were looking for a linear story to guide you to every point of the game, well...you won't find that here.   Many people are complaining that this game is monotonous and boring because they aren't seeing enough variance in the biodiversity and the topography. Well. I have some advice for you. Don't sit on one planet and go to every waypoint. Hyperdrive to other solar systems where you can mine rare minerals and discover new species of wildlife. I discovered a snow-covered planet with many mult-tiered docking stations that offered many rare items I was seeking. I've also seen deserts, plains, and planets with nuclear storms as well as woodlands.   The alien and animal life is procedural just as the terrain is. The interaction between the sentient aliens is similar to Mass Effect where you are given a dialogue tree and a certain response will illicit greater rewards. The animal interaction is real-time. I've seen gliding animals that you can befriend or kill for Carbon, cattle-like creatures with horns that attacked me so I bolcasted them and was rewarded with resources. I have yet to see giant wildlife but perhaps I will find something in another star sytem.  Before the game came out for PC I was reading reviews by Kotaku and Polygon stating that the game 'wasn't what they thought'--that they wished it was more about exploration and less about survival. Well, what would the game be without the survival element? If there is no danger can the game be fun at all? I'm sure if they had taken away that aspect of the game people would complain that they wished it were more difficult.  After pumping more than 20hrs in looting and collecting resources as well as upgrading my ship and my tools I can say that this game will become more about exploration as you progress further. Folks have been whining that the inventory management is a pain. Well, guess what? You get to upgrade the inventory space of your ship as well as your Multi-tool and your Exo suit. As you progress forward there are moments where you must decide what is the most valuable item or resource and what you can do without. That is part of the challenge of the game and this style of inventory management is nothing new in crafting games or any open-world RPG for that matter. The more upgraded space you have mid-game the more resources you will be able to hold which will yield longer periods of exploration. Oh dear, people just love to complain.  I am surprised by all of the negativity surrounding this game. Hello Games did not try to please the casual gamer but perhaps the truly die-hard survival fans. They have created an addicting mining/resource management game with a focus on survival and exploration. This is what they said the game was before its release date and that is exactly what they have delivered.

I had no technical issues (Running a R9 and a A10 proc) but that being said no games fun if you can't run it. On regards to game play i came in with no expectations besides it's space. That being said I love the whole game. It gives you 3 options (2 in reality), go to the centre, follow atlas, or blindly travel for travels sake (not a great option). The games huge but like others said you can't build (which would be pointless because you're always moving) and you can't destroy non resource based terrain ( ie the ground of the planet) unless you use a grenade which is inefficient. The space combat isn't super in depth but it's still fun in regards to a side thing to do well exploring.  People looking for a in depth space combat/ Mass effect style conversation/ minecraft or starbound like terrain destruction and building will be let down if they play this. On the other hand someone looking to just explore and find new weird planets, plants and animals (so many weird animals) well making your tools and ship better for the sake of going to even more extremely hazardous planets will have a great time.   TLDR- If you can't play it everything sucks wait for patch. Game has loose objectives so if you need guidance then not the game for you. It's about exploring mainly go in thinking that. Nothing ever lives up to it's hype, judge on what it is not what you thought it would be.

No Man's Sky is getting a lot of bad reviews for what it is not... it is not a first person shooter, or a 4x game. It is to a degree a survival/crafting game of moderate complexity.  What No Man's Sky mostly is, is an open world sandbox exploration game par excellence.  When you play World of Warcraft and go to a new place, or finish a quest, you know that thousands, maybe millions of people have done the same before you.  In no Man's Sky, so far as far as is known, only two players have ever been to the same planet. Looking over the horizon and seeing something no-one ever saw before... there is something essentially human about that which has almost been lost. It gives you a sweet pang of loneliness, isolation, pride, joy.  If a huge, diverse, independently living, unwinnable and pointless game like Dwarf Fortress or Minecraft appeals to you, or if you just want to make up your own story in your head as you go, this game is for you. If not, maybe not.  Definitely one for the Explorer types.

UPDATE: so, a little update after passing my 100-hour mark. The game has obviously lost a bit of addictiveness after the 40-50-hour mark, but it''s still going strong in my gaming-day. It has definitely changed from the run to the upgrade that was before, now it's more like a veeery relaxing, very calm experience where I get to jump from system to system, finish the things I have to finish (achievements, languages, a couple of rare crafting blueprints), check out the world around me, mine some eridium, etc. Performace has been a bit up and down with the updates, it started okay, it went down quickly in the subsequent weeks and just last week got back up with the last update (the devs are doing a hell of a job working non-stop to fix all the performance issues). I still experience stuttering when moving quickly, I'm starting to think my processor (AMD A8 5600) might not be up to the task because I see it 100%-ing all the time when I get framerate drops.  The story, or better, the lore it's getting clearer now, especially reading Reddit daily. It feels like a huge jigsaw puzzle where the whole internet needs to put everything together in order to find the right key in which to read the great amount of informations and stories left around in this universe. Definitely something to keep you even more addicted. For example, the abandoned buildings stories didn't make much sense to me at the beginning and they felt like some sort of collateral, secondary stories, while now that I'm getting the big picture they DEFINITELY feel like the pivotal point of the whole history of our character.  One last thing I feel very different about my previous review is that I was critiquing the soundtrack to be underused. I have to say that, after 100 hours, I can still hear music that I haven't heard before! Sometimes a song starts and I'm like 'wait -- this one is new'. All the subtleties of the sounds are amazing, the footsteps when you run, the breath when you run out of stamina that has a deeper, helmet-like ambience, the bleeps and boops that sometimes you hear while you cruise into space, the animal voices, everything in the sound compartment is INCREDIBLE. Not only from the amazing band which is 65daysofstatic but also from all the ambience that surrounds you. Amazing job!  Now, to the question. Do I recommend this game?  There's been quite some hate on this game, a lot of very contrasting opinions and so the only thing I can say is that this game is EXCELLENT in the first 15 hours, then it gets a bit more subtle. The game switches quickly from what you can do to what you can see, and I feel like the latter part hasn't been appreciated by most.  If you decide to buy this game, do so expecting a very subtle, relaxing experience that will bring you into a parallel universe. It won't always be exciting, it won't always be funny, but it will definitely be worth living.   If you get this game right, it can potentially walk with you through a large part of your life, kind of what Minecraft or World of Warcraft do.  I obviously recommend you to get it if you're into this mood, but if you're expecting big blows, explosions, fights runs and action, then stay away from it because it has basically none.  ------  After three years of patient (and unpatient) wait, I've finally had my chance to play my first 5-hours session in No Man's Sky, a game that I've dreamed about since I was a kid in the '80s. This game is absolutely what I was waiting for: a space traveller sim, a minecraft in weird exoplanets, a chill game and a survival-inspired experience.  I won't stay long on why you should or should not buy this game, you'll read plenty of better reviews on the media in the next few days, so I'll just address something that I haven't seen addressed around so far: don't buy this game if you don't like the survival games.   In fact, NMS is inspired by the likes of not only the survival section of Minecraft, but also to the slow-paced feeling of that masterpiece called The Long Dark, which the developers openly admitted to have partly gained inspiration from (even though NMS is not as hardcore and difficult as TLD is). Inventory management is absolutely a huge part of the game, and as I can understand people hating to do that, I feel - being part of the survival-lovers audience, that the inventory management is absolutely spot-on and give that challenge that most of us are looking into modern gaming.   So be advised: NMS is flying with ships, is mining resources, is upping your tools, and NMS is also managing your inventory and put a brake to your hoarding syndrome.   Another tip: there's a great little game called Out There, from a couple of years ago, that was some sort of pacifist FTL spinoff. Well, Hello Games must have played Out There a long time because EVERYTHING in No Man's Sky is a 3D reenacting of the 2D interface of Out There, from the inventory slots shared between tech and elements, monoliths, the language-learning sub-game, mining, etc. Which is great, because Out There is a small gem. I've been dying for this game since it was first announced years ago, and the hype never ended. Now that I have it and have played a fair amount, I'll say I really like it. It's a very fun game, but it's very relaxed and certainly a game meant for relaxing, exploring, and anything but trying to be the best. Your constant progression is for you and not to compete at all. With that, many people won't like this game, but if you can sit back and enjoy the beautiful scenery and exploration, you'll enjoy it.  Pros: -Constant Progression -Open ended decision making (through exploration and NPC communication) -Beautiful scenery and overall aesthetic -Broad and great color scheme  -Easy to pick up -Quality sound effects -Decent ground combat -Terrific space combat -Fun and 'Star Wars' like space travel mechanics -You get to name everything you discover  Cons:  -Repetitive -Virtually all planets have life so it's not as special to come across -Spaceship feels clunky on planet -Constant mining simulator -Most plant, animal, NPC, and ship designs are repetitive -No good way to traverse land on foot -Every solar system has a handful of  NPCs and a handful of NPCs only. There are no larger civilizations to find -Every 'quest' is essentially the same, there is no diversity -Not much NPC communications outside of trading or one lined confrontations.    I think I got most of it, but there surely some things I left out. Overall I'd give the game a 6.5/10. I'll give it a lot more with some good updates

Before buying it is key to read the description:  'No Man's Sky is a game about exploration and survival in an infinite procedurally generated universe.'  It is exactly this and its realization is stunning.  For the record, the game runs supersmooth. There was no problem whatsoever, it runs flawlessly.  As I said, people should read description before buying. It is NOT a game for everyone, as the developers in fact had already clearly said. This is not fast paced action, it is not a shooter, mmorpg or competitive PvP. It is single player, sci-fi space exploration/survival set in a procedurally generated open practically endless open world/universe.  It has very old-school touch to it, both in terms of gameplay (very arcade-like), as well as in terms of artistic style, sound. etc. It has kind of retrofuturist feel to it. The game manages to capture the classical 20th century sci-fi aesthetics.  NMS is definately already an important part of video gaming history, it is superoriginal in both gameplay and visuals. But before buying you definately need to read the description. The game is exactly what has been promised. As with all games, there is room for additions and improvements in the upcoming updates, but as it is now it already fulfils its goals perfectly.  11/10

This review is positive, but only for those who are interested in the niche this game currently resides in. If you're wanting a survival game purely, go elsewhere. A space sim, go elsewhere. A light space sim, some survival that gets lighter as you progressive, and heavy on self-driven exploration, then you should read on.   The only comment on development I'll make, besides that I kept myself in near radio silence on it's hype machine, is that this game would have been better served as not a PS4 retail game AND have released as an Early Access title.   Overall, I've greatly enjoyed No Man's Sky. There are definitely some ups and down to the experience, but this feels firmly in the realm of survival type games I have played before with the added benefit of gorgeous vistas. I solely play this game to check the boxes of the things offered as a part, but really enjoy the framing and making screenshots. Yea, it's not really the game persay, but it's what I enjoy; the vast display of various vistas, animals, and plants you can find. I've only explored a few systems in my initial 20 hours, but I can say it's been enjoyable. Peaking over hills, under rocks, and hunting down good shots is definitely something I love.   So basically, as an experience, it's great. As a light game, it's good. What is was hyped to be? Not even close. Largely incomplete at the time of this writing. That said, I would still buy it. Make sure to check out the loads of awesome mods for it, as for better or for worse, I see a lot more great things coming for this game from that crowd.

Before I say anything else, I wanna say that this game is purely exploration/survival with a hint of other elements like combat, trading etc. So if you don't like exploration, don't buy it. And most importantly, don't buy it because of the hype. Its hyped because of its technical complexity and because no other game has ever attempted Procedural Generation at this scale. Basically this game became so popular before its release because its UNIQUE. So if you are looking for an experience similar to other games, don't go for this and do us a favor, please don't say ♥♥♥♥ about the game based on your self assumed expectations of the game. Anyway, this game is a technical marvel and just being in there, playing for hours alone, trying to explore and survive makes you realise how vast the game universe is and in turn how vast our real universe is. It has a sense of awe about it.  The gameplay could have been less repetitive and the PC version should have been better optimized/tested for the lag issues. I'm sure Hello Games will fix it soon or I hope so.  Conclusion: I would request everyone who likes trying out new, unique games and who like exploration to definitely try NMS and for the others I won't recommend it.

I bought this game twice - once for PS4, once for PC. The negative reviews here have some truth to them, there are bugs. The PC version here on Steam is definitely a port, and it's got downsides and glitches. I didn't experience the '10fps' or crashes that others did, but I know that porting these things can be a real science unto itself, and I believe that others have those problems, and that you might too. But having lived through gaming in the 2000's, I can tell you that it's not a horrific port. It's not a great port, but trust me, this is just 'mediocre', it's not 'terrible'.  But i think that detractors miss the fact that this is a fantastic game. I enjoy singleplayer games, I like exploration and combat and crafting. I'm a huge space fan. And I'm alright with the game not being 100% astronomically accurate when it comes to things like not being able to fly into the sun or the planets not orbiting. These are gameplay decisions that I think make sense. What would you -do- with a gas giant or a sun anyway? Can't land on them. If i wanted Spaceship Simulator, I'd play Kerbal. The focus of this game is complete, seamless freedom of movement. And it accomplishes that beautifully - i expected that there'd be some fake loading sequence as you enter or leave a planet; some kind of 'reentry' mode where you're not actually moving while it loads. But it truly is a seamless transition. (jumping between solar systems is, regrettably, a loading screen, though).  There are multiple ways to progress in the game, too. You can craft upgrades for suit, ship, and gun. Fuel for your ship is a goal, parts for crafting, exploring the lore, learning new words in alien languages, it's got a variety of things to do. Some people complained about being bored - I don't know how. I found myself constantly feeling like I had _too much_ to do, too many things to collect, discover, name, learn, buy, sell, and craft.  And while you may notice patterns after a while (I found nearly-identical creatures on two planets, once), that's a limitation of our expectations. True alien life may not even look like life to us at all - so complaining that the depiction of alien life in NMS is reptative ignores that life on earth is reptative. NMS sets out to make animals and plants that we can usually identify as an animal or plant - not to create 18 quintillion evolutionary histories.  I think the people complaining about the game were ones who didn't know what to expect. Who wanted some kind of space MMO, or a ripoff of Elite: Dangerous where you can fight on planets too. That's not what this game is, there are other games like that, and you can play them. This doesn't have to follow that formula.  As of writing, I have about 25 hours on PS4 (in addition to steam hours). I don't regret it, I love this game. Maybe it'll get old soon, maybe I'll figure out how it works and not be surprised or interested in exploring anymore. But that's every game ever. I have a steam library full of games that I once enjoyed, but wouldn't play today because I've already been there and done that. This game doesn't have to last you for the rest of your life, you just have to enjoy it for $60 worth of your time to make it worth it. And for me, it's definitely made up that pricetag.

I've heard mixed reviews about this game, and so I was hesitant to try, so I set a 1-hour timer for myself (plenty of time for a refund), and figured I'd give it a shot.   I totally understand why people don't like this game, it is a bit of a niche. If you like games that are a little lower paced, perhaps don't have the most excitinig modeling, and are open-ended, this is your game. If you're expecting this to be 'like Elite Dangerous, but not,' you're going to be sorely disappointed.  What I like about the game: It's very relaxed, and I don't feel like I'm under pressure to do EVERYTHING there is to do... it can't be done. I have a goal (atlas) and I work towards that goal at my own pace. I feel I've played enough of this game at this point to be able to 'tell' what's coming, but I still enjoy it. It's very open-ended exploration. I get a chance to go where I like, and there's always the question of 'what does this do?' but I'm free to explore as much as I like, or just gloss over and go on my way.  What I don't like about the game: I've had very intermittent instability issues (3x1TB 10,000RPM RAID, I7-2600, 32gb RAM, GTX970), where the game crashes to the desktop. It appears to be if I have too much running in the background and the system is big, it'll have problems loading everything.  Who would I recommend this game to: If you enjoy free roaming games (Fallout series, minecraft, dayZ) type games, I highly recommend it.

It's actually a good game when paced right, but being cheaper would have softened the blow for a lot of people. Hopefully the negative reviews don't discourage future content from hello games, as in its current state this game is a good framework to be improved on.

While NMS might not immediately appear to have as much content as other $60 games, it makes up for that in amazing exploration. The thrill of going to a new planet and seeing what's on it is the main point of this game, and everything else is just extra. I've been playing for almost 30 hours already and it's felt like only a few. I don't mind the grindey nature of upgrading your stuff, and it feels like if Destiny + Minecraft were combined. With that being said, the game isn't perfect. The crafting UI could use some automation, and there could be more to talking with NPCs than a riddle or math question with an instant reward. I'm okay with the game not having much story or quests, but at some point after grinding my way up to the top, the exploration might seem repetitive. If HG adds content with updates I see myself continuing to explore. The hype train was huge, and for me it is scratching that space exploration itch I've wanted for awhile. I don't fault Hello Games for selling out to Sony at all. The game wouldn't even be close to this sucessful if they had released it as an alpha on greenlight so they clearly made the right decision. It's debatable whether or not the price of the game justifies its amount of content, but I'm not regretting my purchase at all so far.

Do you play Kerbal Space Program not for the engineering or navigation, but because it just lets you fly wherever you want, but you wish there was more to do when you got there? THIS GAME IS FOR YOU. I wanted freedom, in space, and I wanted it to be beautiful, and I am very happy with No Man's Sky.   You do not play this game to complete a story, or acheive some great goal. You play this game to just get lost in beautiful, gorgeous space; to fly fast and not give a damn where you're going because wherever you end up will be new and exciting (and if it's not you can just leave, ♥♥♥♥ it).  If you need a game to hold your hand and tell you what to do, or where to go, or tell you when you've done a good job, or even a game that set goals for you and helps keep you interested, don't buy this.   It's not the ultimate game. It's not for everyone. It's probably not for most. It's for the few who love classic scifi enough to live there and not have anyone tell us when its time to go home.

This game achieves what it sets out to accomplish. You may not find all the things you are searching for, but if your eyes and ears are open enough to see and to hear, you will discover overwhelming beauty in every moment.

There really should be a button below that says 'Not sure' under the 'Do you recommend' question, because that's how I feel about this game. It's an amazing concept, it has so much to explore and do, but on the other hand it is endless grind to get resources to do it. After a while the resources become patterns of movement on a planet to achieve a goal. But that is exactly what the producers said the game would be, exploration based game so a lot of opinions out there that the game is not what it was set out to be is wrong. I have 11 hours so far, and in this time I have, without rushing, managed to explore 4 planets and 1 moon quite thoroughly, warped once to another cluster of planets and bought a new ship for roughly 2m units. That's only 11 hours. If you are the kind of person that enjoyed Ark, Mincraft and other resource grinders you will love this. If you are a COD kid with an adrenaline addiction you will give it a bad review. You don't go around fightinging everythign that walks, it's not even remotely on the same par with violence as Ark is. Things usually don't want to kill you, and even if they do, you have enough time to get away. I understand that I have not spawn on a planet that is very violent, something I will most likely experience, but so far it has been nothing but pleasurable.  To address people's comment on performance issues. I have played this game since about 6 hours after it came out. PC Specs (i7-6700k, GTX 970 SLI, DDR4 3200mhz ram 32GB) and I run the game maxed out on every setting. So far the only time I had frame drop to around 60 was on a planet with extreme amounts of grass, water and snowy patches. Other than that the game has run smoothly nearby the 100 fps mark.  So overall, I'm leaning towards recommending the game.

UPDATE: so, a little update after passing my 100-hour mark. The game has obviously lost a bit of addictiveness after the 40-50-hour mark, but it''s still going strong in my gaming-day. It has definitely changed from the run to the upgrade that was before, now it's more like a veeery relaxing, very calm experience where I get to jump from system to system, finish the things I have to finish (achievements, languages, a couple of rare crafting blueprints), check out the world around me, mine some eridium, etc. Performace has been a bit up and down with the updates, it started okay, it went down quickly in the subsequent weeks and just last week got back up with the last update (the devs are doing a hell of a job working non-stop to fix all the performance issues). I still experience stuttering when moving quickly, I'm starting to think my processor (AMD A8 5600) might not be up to the task because I see it 100%-ing all the time when I get framerate drops.  The story, or better, the lore it's getting clearer now, especially reading Reddit daily. It feels like a huge jigsaw puzzle where the whole internet needs to put everything together in order to find the right key in which to read the great amount of informations and stories left around in this universe. Definitely something to keep you even more addicted. For example, the abandoned buildings stories didn't make much sense to me at the beginning and they felt like some sort of collateral, secondary stories, while now that I'm getting the big picture they DEFINITELY feel like the pivotal point of the whole history of our character.  One last thing I feel very different about my previous review is that I was critiquing the soundtrack to be underused. I have to say that, after 100 hours, I can still hear music that I haven't heard before! Sometimes a song starts and I'm like 'wait -- this one is new'. All the subtleties of the sounds are amazing, the footsteps when you run, the breath when you run out of stamina that has a deeper, helmet-like ambience, the bleeps and boops that sometimes you hear while you cruise into space, the animal voices, everything in the sound compartment is INCREDIBLE. Not only from the amazing band which is 65daysofstatic but also from all the ambience that surrounds you. Amazing job!  Now, to the question. Do I recommend this game?  There's been quite some hate on this game, a lot of very contrasting opinions and so the only thing I can say is that this game is EXCELLENT in the first 15 hours, then it gets a bit more subtle. The game switches quickly from what you can do to what you can see, and I feel like the latter part hasn't been appreciated by most.  If you decide to buy this game, do so expecting a very subtle, relaxing experience that will bring you into a parallel universe. It won't always be exciting, it won't always be funny, but it will definitely be worth living.   If you get this game right, it can potentially walk with you through a large part of your life, kind of what Minecraft or World of Warcraft do.  I obviously recommend you to get it if you're into this mood, but if you're expecting big blows, explosions, fights runs and action, then stay away from it because it has basically none.  ------  After three years of patient (and unpatient) wait, I've finally had my chance to play my first 5-hours session in No Man's Sky, a game that I've dreamed about since I was a kid in the '80s. This game is absolutely what I was waiting for: a space traveller sim, a minecraft in weird exoplanets, a chill game and a survival-inspired experience.  I won't stay long on why you should or should not buy this game, you'll read plenty of better reviews on the media in the next few days, so I'll just address something that I haven't seen addressed around so far: don't buy this game if you don't like the survival games.   In fact, NMS is inspired by the likes of not only the survival section of Minecraft, but also to the slow-paced feeling of that masterpiece called The Long Dark, which the developers openly admitted to have partly gained inspiration from (even though NMS is not as hardcore and difficult as TLD is). Inventory management is absolutely a huge part of the game, and as I can understand people hating to do that, I feel - being part of the survival-lovers audience, that the inventory management is absolutely spot-on and give that challenge that most of us are looking into modern gaming.   So be advised: NMS is flying with ships, is mining resources, is upping your tools, and NMS is also managing your inventory and put a brake to your hoarding syndrome.   Another tip: there's a great little game called Out There, from a couple of years ago, that was some sort of pacifist FTL spinoff. Well, Hello Games must have played Out There a long time because EVERYTHING in No Man's Sky is a 3D reenacting of the 2D interface of Out There, from the inventory slots shared between tech and elements, monoliths, the language-learning sub-game, mining, etc. Which is great, because Out There is a small gem.      PRO

As someone who has been looking forward to this game for a year, I was rather sad to read all the negative comments. 'Do I still wanna buy it? Is it really worth the money?' This game is more of an experience than a traditional game. Disregard game reviewers because I personally believe it's not something you can play for 20 hours or even 40 - 50 hours and claim that you know enough to judge it in its entirety.  Play this game for yourself, though this is not for everyone I think if you give a chance it grows on you. If you enjoy exploration, chances are you're going to love this game.   I can't really give it a review either as the game has given me so many varied emotions. But I feel that's the point. You enter a galaxy that is uncaring, unhelpful and downright dangerous. Some planets will have storms that will wear down your hazard protection faster than warp speed, others will have pristine landscapes littered with beautiful and strange creatures. Unlike many, I haven't had a single problem with the game. Undoubtedly, many others are having problems, and I hope those issues get resolved. But, personally, I'm quite enjoying this game.  I will say this, I understand completely why this game is so divisive. You either are going to enjoy it, or you're going to hate it. I doubt there's much middle ground.   The graphics are gorgeous. The universe is alive and varied. And it can be very fun. But the actual mechanics of the game are highly repetitive and there's aspects that seemingly try to work against you (piloting the ship, for example). Really, the only big hook here is the vast universe, as the gameplay isn't terribly inspired or deep.  Ultimately, your enjoyment of the game will hinge on whether or not you can lose yourself in the nearly endless universe. If spending hours scouring an obscure planet to find one more bizarre lifeform, one more hidden station, one more blueprint tucked away in some terminal can suck you in, then you can easily forgive the basic and repetitive gameplay. If not, or if you're looking for something more action-packed, this ain't a game for you.  This is a lonely, contemplative exploration game with a weak crafting system and a lot of tasks repeated ad nauseum. But when it works, it's spectacular in its immersion.

So far it's been a rollercoaster experience. The first 2 hours were absolute amazement. Then I began seeing a bit of the repetition, including small inventory spaces. However, I pushed on and suddenly realized that upgrading was fairly easy to do. I increased my inventory, purchased a new ship with more space and better hyperspace drives and moved onto the next galaxy. I saw some life on planets along with exploring and finding some crazy rare items to sell at trade centers. I was so into it I forgot about the fact that I was seeing fairly similar planets, even though the amount of systems are supposed to be virtually endless. Sure, there are some with different toxicity levels, arctic levels or ones that will give you heat stroke. The absolute vastness alone is what drives you, not knowing what's next or the curiosity of what's still out there to explore. At times you feel like you've seen it all. Other times you feel like you are mining resources on this random planet for no other purpose than to answer that question of, 'Well maybe there is something so unique or crazy out there that all my time will be worth it.' I still can't answer that question.  13 hours in and I really am enjoying the experience. That's what this is though, I wouldn't label it a game in any sort of means. It's an experience. I think behind the visuals and algorithms to blend the experience together took a lot of work and by no means was it an easy process. I never really desired this game for more than what it is right now, considering there is so much to still discover and so much potential for this artform to become an actual game someday.  Is it for everyone? No, absolutely not. Only people who enjoy the idea of exploration. Is it worth $60? No. If there was more substance built into the other elements then maybe.  My only complaint. In playing this now and for however long I plan on doing so. The idea behind No Mans Sky is exploration. They have created something so massive that they lost the ability to design anything with substance. Why bother creating a true to size planet if each planet follows a fairly similar patern or elements or general rules. There should have been a higher degree of randomization in each system and planet. The idea of discovery begins to fade for almost everyone once you hit a threshold of limitation in what is supposed to be a virtually endless world.  The only way I can compare this game is that they created something too big for such a small purpose. Exploration should be that sense of the uknown. I feel as if in my journey, there are still some of those uknowns. However, in the grand scale of this project... I feel as if i'm looking at uniformity where chaos should reign.  I do recommend buying this for the experience. Wait till it's on sale or further developement is in place. If you want a game, look elsewhere for now.

Honestly, at $60 this title is overpriced and I recommend waiting for at least a 50% off sale.  No Man's Sky is fun but shallow. Discovery is the main objective and there's a hell of a lot to find, which is great if that's what you want in this game. If you're expecting much more than that, you'll be disappointed. The aliens you meet add to the universe but they are too spread out for it to feel like a functioning universe. Completely empty planets would be an interesting mix but I haven't run into any yet. There don't seem to be populated areas, just one alien at an outpost or space station, and if you're lucky you'll run into a few aliens who dock at the station while you're there.  The audio is absolutely a highlight of NMS. Mellow exploration music quickly transitions to up-tempo rock music during combat. If you paid attention to just the music, you could find yourself flying around for hours just to hear the soundtrack.  The framerate issues are well-documented and the reason is a bad console port. The spaceship movement feels very wrong if you want to do precision flying. The ship seems to just do what it wants instead of what you want. The mouse feels floaty, especially during combat. The discovery screen takes 10 or 12 seconds to go away, in which you can do very little. It wouldn't be an issue if it didn't happen every time you did something the game deems remarkable, but it happens way too often and pulls you out of the immersion. They needed more time to fix not only the bad port but the questionable choices (such as the bad field of view, which feels claustrophobic even when set to maximum).  Hopefully they can fix the big issues soon and make this game better. I think they also need to drop the price but if you can get it on a good sale, give it a go.  TL;DR: fun, shallow, pick up if you want to fly in space and explore planets. Great music. Wait for a good discount and for them to fix the glaring issues.

I've had absolutely no problems with the game. It runs great on my machine! (AMD FX-9590 w/ GTX 960) The game is absolutely beautiful, and a huge accomplishment for such a small team of developers. It is definatley not for everyone, though. If you are expecting a shoot em up, high action MMORPG, or a scientifically accurate space simulator, this is not the game.   If you do want a sci-fi, fantasy, exporation game, with some space combat rolled in that you can take at your own pace while seeing and naming things no one has ever seen before, then this game is for you! I have seen some absoultely stunning sunsets, landscapes, and definately enjoy flying seamlessly from surface to space and back.   It also isn't so complicated you can't play it without learning a bible of controls like many space games. It is a bit lonesome and desolate, but with the mining, crafting, and upgrading you begin to see how the game is largely designed to take you on a journey and the more you put into the exporation and discovery, the faster you will be able to get to the center, which seems to be the overarching goal. Intial Thoughts: Since I have been following the development of this game for a considerable time I purchased it based on the what I had read and seen pre-release. Pre-release reviews are very hard to guage considering the title has been in development for five years and many things with regard to game play and styling changed throughout development, however as I like the game style and the genre (I play elite and I enjoy Sci-fi) I was going to buy it anyway regardless.  Play Style: Just like in Elite Dangerous there is grind, it's unavoidable if you want to craft, buy a better ship or purchase items through the market. The crafting system is straighforward and eases you into more complex recipes as you progress through the game. You have to hunt for elements and manage inventory slots in order to create the more complicated stuff like warp fuel (this can also be puchased from traders). You gain credits from selling discovered items, places or materials on the market or by selling to traders either on the planets or on space stations. The markets are very simple and cannot be compared to the likes of elite or eve, however they are functional.   The flight model is basic with simplified controls but fits in with the styling of the game. Don't expect a DCS is space this was not what the game was designed to be like. Combat on the surface and in space is pretty basic. I could find no way of locking a particular target (unless I missed this control somewhere) however I could stand my ground easily against a few targets at once. Weapons like everything else in the game can be upgraded and added to through the crafting system.  Closing thoughts: There seems to be a large number of negative reviews about this game, many are as a result of the game either crashing, poor frame rates or just not starting at all. Some reviews have been made with 30 mins of gameplay, how a proper view of a game can be made in so little time I just cant understand?? Many of the issues seem to be linked to AMD chips. As I run on an Intel i7 clocked to 4.7Mhz, 32gb of ram and use a GTX 980Ti I have experienced no problems with regard to frame rates or crashes. There was some stuttering to begin with but this dissapeared after the day one patch.  Overall I like this game, If you like crafting, Trading, exploring and the Sci-Fi genre then you will enjoy this game go buy it!

Those are only parts of a greater whole. No Man's sky is full of mystery. Ancient artifacts and abandoned stations litter the worlds. You fly from star system to star system, planet to planet. Each solar system has its own story told through interacting with these aforementioned elements. Each solar system slowly clues you into its history. Alien races that lived and died, fought and colonized, living through peace and war. No Man's Sky is a unique sifi survival game in a mysterious universe with millions of twinkling little suns before you to explore.
