To be completely honest, I would not recommend this game to most gamers. Not for the reason that it may be badly optomized for many people, nor for the fact that people believe that this game is just repetitive exploration. I would not recommend this for most gamers out there because No Man's Sky is not a game that was meant to appeal to everyone's tastes. It is a simple game that came from the collective creativity of those at Hello Games.   Hello Games had a vision with No Man's Sky, and they wanted to do everything in their power to keep the final product as close to that vision as they could. Sure, they may have been a bit secretive about No Man's Sky, but that does not mean that they did not create a great game. They created something that may even revolutionize how the gaming industry sees their products.   With so many delays and such a great amount ambiguity surrounding the game before its launch, It's no wonder gamer's were disappointed. We began to artificially hype this game to more than it was ever supposed to be. We disappointed ourselves with our own delusions. Hello Games did not develop a bad game, we as a community imagined a game that was not developed. We will continue to disappoint ourselves as long as we keep hyping up games as we did this one. Personally, I enjoy this game, but it has its fair share of flaws. It may not be worth $60, but it is a game I do not regret trying.   Game developers should learn from Hello Games. While appeasing everyone is the safest route for a game developer to take, maybe it's time to try something a little risky despite the fact that it may end in failure. How else will our generations shape the world. Will we continue to throw our money at the Call of Dutys and Battlefields of the future, or will we be the generations that defines the gaming industry for generations to come.  I will not recommend this game for everyone because not everyone will enjoy it. As a game, it is pretty mediocre, but it has the potential to open people's minds to a new era of gaming.

NOTE: This review is based off MY expierence of the game. Therfore, I will not include the crashing and severe lag other players seem to have. The game has never crashed on me and runs great maxed out (AMD FX-6300, GTX 960).  I started out really confused but excited as I entered this strange new world as my character wakes up along side their crashed ship. You spawn on a random planet out in the middle of a random system (in my experience, I did start over because I had to restart the program to change the graphic settings). I then met some spiky, red, pulsating, levitating dog toy called 'The Atlas' that told me a bunch of stuff I didn't understand in the confusion of the new game. I took some time to learn the controls they don't really teach you (it's mostly very basic, and they give tool tips for the less obvious). I then walked for 10 minutes to reach a deposite of rare resources I needed to repair my ship. While I was annoyed at first, I was glad they gave me the chance to explore the plannet on foot and discover outpost and fight enemies. Once I collected the cache of materials, I called in my ship to a nearby trading post with a bypass chip so I didn't need another 10 minutes to walk back. I was a little concerned seeing the reviews early on, but I stuck with the game long enough and explored as much as I could and learning about the game and all the mechanics they probably should have taught you (bypasses have one use and can be used to open special containers and call in your ship to your location, flying requires no fuel but take-off will, save stations). I did have complaints at this point. The way you saved seemed completely unnessecary and annoying, a lot of my quest and objectives were unclear, and I had to look up how to progress frequently because the game never taught me even the basics of upgrades, naming and uploading discoveries, ships, alien languages, or sentinels. Also, the game is not multiplayer like it was said to be, which was disapointing, but I surprisingly didn't mind becasue I felt this game would probably be best enjoyed solo, at least for me. Though being to fight space pirates, explore planets, and discover wouls be amazing to do with friends. And the graphics were a little eh, even maxed out. Objects also had to be surprisingly close to render sometimes, but I can understand seeing how the game generates such a huge, seamless space all at once. I also had difficulty flying, as often the ship would not turn or dive properly, and many times I found myself trying to land at a specific location, but ended up infintely rolling across the planet head-first. Or I sometimes would not be able to enter a space station because I would just bounce off some sort of invisible barrier. I also ran out of fuel mid-space travel a few times, and the game did not tell my I could mine astroids for it, so I drifted slowly back to the nearest planet over the course of 10-15 minutes just so I could gather a few plants. Another note that won't apply to most, but I thought I should add: The steam controller does NOT work well with No Man's Sky. At the highest sensitivity it feels like a slow drag, which forced me to just give up on it for how bad it was for flying and combat (half the game). Although, I would like to hear an opinion from someone who know show to mess around with the controller settings and has came up with moddifications for it.  I also have read many reviews stating how each plannet feels a copy and paste of another with a slightly different layout. While this is certanly not an insane idea by any means, I do not fully argee with it. Yes, most of the planets share the look of just a few templates of forest, tundra, desert, etc. No, not every planet really does have any huge reasons to visit them all. You wouldn't miss out on much if you passed up a few planets that didn't seem interesting. I'll admit, I did eventually start skipping more and more planets as I played, becasue I only needed certain things from certain places. But, every planet has different wildlife, locations (monoliths, observitories, etc), alien words to learn, and even special treasure. On one planet I discovered, I was about to leave because not only did it seem a little bland is it's veriety of resources I could get anywhere but also it's horrible -98 degree flash-floods, I found arguably the best thing so far. There was a completely massive cave system through most of the planet, and the halls were completely filled with rare artifacts I sold for a total around 2 million Units before I realized I needed to leave because there were so many I would be carrying them back for days worth of trips if I wanted to get all of them.   VERDICT: No Man's Sky gave me the same feeling I got the first time I ever played Skyrim. Like I was truly in a real world I could explore forever. And my love for space really did make it a great experience, and that thankfully I was able to enjoy this game without crashes or lag. While I unfortunetly I could never recommend this game to any die-hard action game fans, this is THE perfect game to just relax and enjoy the beautiful soundtrack and visuals as you upgrade your ship and explore the vast No Man's Sky.

I feel a little disingenuous reviewing this game so soon after it's release. However, I thought it was worth adding a different opinion to the tide of negativity.  Unlike a lot of you folks, I did not follow the hype of NMS. I don't tend to believe things unless I see them for myself, and I was just not seeing a lot of what was being claimed. And I think that may be why I'm enjoying the game.  Originally, I did have some frame rate issues. So I looked in the options and realised that for some odd reason, the game is set at 30 fps out of the box. Probably something to do with it's console origins. Once I'd changed this to 60, and maxed everything out, the game runs beautifully. I also really like the way it looks.  As for the early game experience, the lack of hand holding is actually quite refreshing. Like the rest of you, I had no idea what was going on at first, so I just noodled around, trying things out. Within my first hour, I had worked out how the game worked, and what it wanted me to do, and was leaving my first planet. I would say that was a design win.  The tagline - this is not for everyone - is very true with this game. If you like to be led in games; to be told where to go, what to do; you will not enjoy this. You will find it frustrating at best. If you like digging around in sandboxes to see what you can find, then you will love NMS.  I personally have had no issues running the game; but I imagine that has something to do with the fact that I have many games already installed, and hence all the redists that a game like this might require. Not shipping the game with the redists it requires is a pretty egregious error if you ask me; and one that shows Hello Games' newness to PC gaming. I hope they fix that in future patches.  I should note that the game didn't cost me anything. I got Steam cards for my birthday, and kept them aside for the release. If I'd have paid £40 GBP for NMS - especially on the strength of the supposed multiplayer stuff, I would probably not be as happy as I am.

This game has had a pretty poor launch on PC, but now that I've worked out the kinks it's actually pretty cool. Initially it was incredibly choppy and the FOV being so low by default made it feel very claustrophobic. But after tinkering with the graphics settings (I disabled vsync, changed the FPS cap and resolution, and turned the FOV up) it runs considerably better and I can now run it fairly smoothly on maximum settings. A lot of people are reporting crashes to the desktop but I guess I'm lucky enough to have not experienced that. Also there are still sudden FPS drops that usually last a second or two every once in a while which is a little annoying, but nothng that discourages me from playing.   As for the game itself, it's a dream come true if you're an explorer or an adventurer at heart. I haven't gotten very far yet but it seems so far to mainly consist of discovering plant/animal species and landmarks on whatever planets you fly to, and then optionally naming them and uploading them to NMS's servers for in-game currency. You can then use this currency to do things such as buy new starships or upgrade your existing gear. You can also mine stuff both on planets and in space, which is quite simplistic though satisfying, and then use the stuff you mine to upgrade or repair your equipment or sell it for more credits. My main gripes with this include the lackluster combat (it is by no means bad, but it's not really remarkable either) and the tiny amount of inventory space you have. This results in often juggling around stuff you've mined to be able to carry it all without having to dispose of anything. It can be a little tedious.  The best part by far is the exploration. Each planet is quite markedly different from the last in general, and the atmosphere is almost always really breathtaking. Recently I landed on a mostly barren, hostile world with deep red skies. Looking off into the distance staring at the rocky plains and hills while the howling wind sfx played over the lonely piano music is really quite an experience. Not only that but knowing that if I want, I can walk over to that horizon and discover whatever may be there. It's more than likely going to be more barren plains, but just knowing you have the chance to explore whatever you can see if you want to is really amazing.   Flying in your starship from planet to planet is absolutely breathtaking and seamless too. If there are loading screens, they're hidden under one of the many space flight animations very discreetly. Hello Games really nailed the sound effects too. The whooshing when you accelerate, the sudden rumbling when you hit a planet's atmosphere, the earthy thud when your starship touches down. Really one of the main strengths of this game is the audiovisual experience it creates.  So, despite this game's shaky launch and currently slightly shallow game mechanics, I would definitely recommend it if you, like me, enjoy exploration for the sake of exploration itself. No Man's Sky really makes you feel that sense of awe and deep curiosity about what you could possibly discover next.

Graphics are a big part, yes (and my GPU stress pushes it to a stable 66C, which is the temperature it usually reaches when playing any high-standard-graphics game), though due to the high-quality continuous procedural generation (definitely a CPU-intensive task), it's worth a decent amount of speculation. (OPINIONS INCOMING)  Pros: - The graphics, on ultra or high, are actually freaking amazing. I love them, even if they're not up to everyone else's standards. I've seen 4K as well, and it's incredible at the massive resolution those monitors and systems provide. - The gameplay, while not diverse enough for some people, is wholly engaging and actually often fairly challenging. Admittedly, I'm not too good at space games, but I find them extremely fun, and the challenge adds to my enjoyment. - The concept - a space game based almost purely on exploration - is probably the best I have ever seen. I sat eagerly at my computer for 2 hours waiting for the release simply because I couldn't wait to waste my days away exploring seemingly endless, procedurally-generated... Everything. It blows my mind. - It's easy to lose yourself in the game. The immersion, for me at least, is intense. I love that in a game - when I enjoy it so much that it's easy to picture myself in the place of the protagonist(?), I know that I'm going to have a good time. - The system itself, once you understand it enough, becomes very intuitive. You need to look up button prompts now and then, but everything soon becomes almost second nature. - It's just damn fun to play. I hate to sound cliché, but 'the possibilities are endless'. There's a certain goal to the game that I won't spoil (well, more than one), but you can just disappear off into the distance like I did. It really is that easy to break the system - there is no cemented rule for what to do. The game even starts by giving you an option to run away and do whatever. It's great.  Cons - No coherent direction at the beginning of the game. You're left to work out what everything does. The beginning is fairly simplistic, yes, but my first run ended with me getting lost in a huge, hollowed-out cave in a mountain. I just had to restart. I had spent almost 2 hours on that file as well. It was frustrating, but I got over it. - Inventory, sizes, and item stacking. In your starter ship (I pre-ordered, so I got the special ship (18 INV slots, but I'm not sure how it compares to not pre-ordering), 18 is enough for a while. You can send items to your ship inventory from your suit, but can't retrieve them or craft with them unless you're really close by. It fills up so quickly unless you only take stuff that you need. I have tons of gold and iridium lying around in INV slots 'just in case', and it's becoming a problem. The good news is that you can sell it all off. Markets are easy to trade with, and it's not often that the expected rate is much of a big deal. On item stacking... You can stack twice as much of the materials in one space when in your ship, so you need to search your suit INV for anything you can put in your ship without losing space in it. It's tedious. - The timed cursor click is weird. You need to hold down on menu options for a single click to register. It's understandable in-game, but just goes against all common sense for it to be in the menus too. It's called a 'click' for a reason. It's mildly annoying to click multiple times, momentarily forgetting the mechanic. - Crashes, bugs and optimisation. Not really much to be said here. Just be patient and wait for the patches. If an infinite exploration game is what you want, then it'll be worth the wait if it doesn't work for you now.  That's all I can think about now. I'll add more if I think of any when I wake up. And go back onto it. I have relinquished my days and nights to No Man's Sky. There is no turning back.  I recommend the game. It's just an opinion. I enjoy it.

Just wanted to put in my two cents -- No Man's Sky worked perfectly out of the box for me. It might not for everyone, but take all the bad reviews with a grain of salt, okay?  Now onto the main review!  It's just what I was expecting. A lonely space exploration game. Gameplay elements hint at a greater galactic history that we, as players, have yet to discover. There are several named races of spacefaring aliens and I'm not sure if those are procedural or not. I can't wait to learn their languages and be able to communicate better with them! Discovering the lore is going to be really fun!  I've traipsed through several toxic and/or irradiated planets, scanning plants, animals, and minerals as I go. Each is fun to name and catalog. I've made friends with some of the fauna on my way - a bouncing mushroom jellyfish who pooped copper because we were friends, a saber-toothed chicken cow who howled at me and followed me like a dog, and a diseased-looking desert fox which scampered away until I fed it some minerals.  This game is not going to hold your hand. It will give you hints as to how you progress in the small beginning quests, but at times I felt it was difficult (learning to fly the space ship, figuring out how to craft items, etc.)  Now, as for the things that could see improvement (keep in mind that the devs are already working on patches -- this game is still HELLA fun even as it is now!). I noticed a few glitches with the lighting and textures in the Discovery menu. Talking to aliens sometimes makes my textures flicker. Nothing too crazy.  Probably the worst thing so far is that I can't alt-tab in and out of the game properly yet. Once I alt-tab out, I have to go into Steam and click the 'Play' button again to get it to switch back to the game properly (no progress lost or anything by doing this, don't worry).  That being said, it is now 4 AM and I've played this game for at least 7 or 8 hours straight. So I think it's a good game, and I'd recommend it. If it doesn't work for you yet, guess what? You can refund the game and try it later when it's more stable. Or maybe it isn't for you? That's okay too!  SIDE NOTE: I'm really glad the devs pushed the release date to a Friday... my work schedule would have been ruined if this came out on a Tuesday...  (I plan on keeping this updated as I continue to learn more.)  OKAY, BACK TO PLAYING!

UPDATE: Few people have as many hours on this game as i do. I would have more but currently cannot get the game to launch no matter what i do. Now i have to downgrade my review.   Lets ignore the hype. I didn't follow it at all. A few days before the game came out i started looking into to it and watched people's play troughs in the days following the release. Lets be honest here. This game isn't for everyone. If you don't like a grinding resource gathering centrist type of game play then don't get this game. But don't listen to all those reviews that are upset at the game cause it didn't live up to the hype. Honestly, nothing lives up to the pre release hype so you gotta over look it and judge it for what it is, not what the expectations were.   Personally i love the game. I have over 20 hours in and i see where a lot of the complaints of the game play are coming from. Things do get repetitive. The seeming unlimited universe is rather more limited then the hype lead us to believe. But i still love exploring things. I am certainly getting my $60 out of the game. However there are some short comings.   The UI is a bit clunky with the constant press/click and hold to get anything done. I think some parts of the UI could do without this. Diversity of ship handling needs to become a thing. Space combat is a joke at this point and i would love to see it improved. Likewise the handling of ship slots needs improvement. I wish limitations where set as to what the various slots can be used for. Most of all i want to see some side missions introduced. Let me pick up missions to escort shipments, raid shipments, hunt down pirates, and transport people to different locations. Lets have some more interactions with the species of each and get some more faction style interplay between the species. If i gain status with one i should lose status with another. Make us choose a side.   There is so much more this game can become. I look forward to seeing what future updates bring. All i have to say is that most of them should be made free. Cause right now this is a $30 to $40 game at best. I do recommend the game but you may want to wait for a sale before picking it up.

I wouldn't normally review a game after having it less than a day and playing only a handful of hours, but I wanted to chime in here-  I had high expectations for probably about 2.5 years now, and upon my initial dive into the game I feel like they were met. I'm having a blast playing No Man's Sky. It's one of those games I can zone out and get lost in as I wander around and gather stuff, like Salt or Skyrim. Or, if you've played Rodina, then it is perhaps somewhat comparable to that, except without the narrative and on a much grander scale. Anyway, so far I've explored 3 planets in my own little corner of the galaxy, and it was actually hard for me to even want to get into my spaceship to leave the first one after walking around for about 3 hours.  I guess I just really like the idea of standing on an alien mountaintop or lake shore knowing that not even the developer has gazed over this vista (much less, meticulously hand-placed every rock and piece of foliage).. That instead the place emerged naturally from rules, and not from a human touch. And that you're not moving from one region to another through a series of load screens- instead it is one big continuous sandbox. To me all of that makes the discovery and exploration even more fulfilling.  Not sure where people got the impression that it was a MMO or something. It is single player game, folks. It says it right here in the Steam page. I heard the dev state that it was single player forever ago, although granted maybe they said other stuff since that confused the issue.  So if you're confused about what this game is, let me try to clear some things up for you-    -IT IS SINGLE PLAYER.  -It is massive a procedurally generated galaxy of countless planets, stars, life forms, etc  -When you find an undiscovered star system or planet or planetary location you can claim discovery credit and even rename it, and this gets uploaded so other players can see that you in fact discovered it. So I could be mistaken, but this is the only thing that I understand to be even remotely multiplayer about the game- that in the unlikely even that you happen to make it to one of my planets, you will be able to see that I was there FIRST SUCKA.  -You gather resources so you can fix, fuel and upgrade your spaceship, then you fly your spaceship around  -Resources are also required to protect you from the environment and sustain your life support systems  -You discover technology blueprints to upgrade your ship, suit, mining tool/weapon, and then from your resources you craft these upgrades  -Outposts are scattered around the planets, some with trade terminals where you can buy and sell stuff. Some have alien NPCs, but they speak in a language unknown to you. You can discover language clues that let you unlock the language 1 word at a time   -You can pick fights with robotic drones or creatures on the planet surface. I understand there is space combat as well, but I haven't gone looking for any of that kind if trouble yet  -You can also feed some of the local wildlife, and they will become happy and poop out rare resources for you  -ICYMI- IT IS SINGLE PLAYER  -It is NOT a simulator of the Milky Way galaxy, or even an astrophysics simulator as far as I'm aware  -It is not a hardcore flight simulator either. Landing is automatic. To compare, the stuff I'd seemingly spend the most amount of time and effort doing in Elite Dangerous (aligning my ship with a landing pad) is what I spend the least on in No Man's Sky, and I like that about this game.  -And if you need a strong story or narrative, then be aware that you probably won't find it here in No Man's Sky   If I am forced to offer a critique of the game at this point, I would be that the character models for the NPC aliens look rudimentary compared to the other creatures and environment overall- that is to say the NPCs are not 2016 AAA quality. But since that wasn't really at all what I was looking for in this game, it really isn't a complaint that I have.  Not something I anticipate, but perhaps there is a chance that after playing 70-100 hours the sense of discovery will have worn off and I'll find the game a bit boring and repetitive. Who knows, and I can surely update my review later if that is the case. But even so, I'm pretty sure I'd still recommend this game even after I got tired of it, because I think it is something really cool to experience.  Basically, if you are like me and you saw the first video and said 'Yep, that looks like a neat game,' then I believe your expectations are reasonably set and that you will enjoy No Man's Sky. If you're looking for something else, then you should probably move along.  Also- I read some complaints about performance issues, but I haven't had any kind of problems like that myself. In about 8 hours of gameplay the game crash 1 time, but other than that it is running 100% smooth. I am playing on a 1.5 year old Alienware Alpha, so it's not like I have a high end custom build either. Maybe folks need to update those Nvidia drivers or something...

No Man's Sky is a really sad story of miscommunication and misinterpretation. Sean Murray was vague but was never outright lying. This world is so giant that if there were conventional multiplayer it would be rendered useless. I invite you to play for a month straight and see if you even run into anything that's already been discovered. That's just things that other players have seen, the chances of seeing an actual human even if it were implemented are (pardon the pun) astronomical. To insist that some server should be sending and receiving packets constantly for the jackpot millionaire powerball snowflake chance in hell you cross paths with another human is insane. This is the logical conclusion for multiplayer in a game where there is next to no chance in running into other people.  Moving on, the game itself is extremely enjoyable in my opinion. If you are expecting a campaign story to hold your hand this is not it. If you want space minecraft this is not it. If you want an unlimited space game with the same complexity as something like Elite this is not the game for you. If you want to explore alien worlds and be in constant awe at the procedurally curated environments before you this is the game for you. If you want to meet new spacefarers and become victim to galactic misunderstandings this is the game for you. If you want to paint the stars red with pirate blood or become a pirate yourself, this is the game for you. There is something for everyone once you get situated. Anybody complaining about how there's nothing to do haven't been playing long enough to see the wide range of encounters available. Also saying that each planet is just a recolor is ♥♥♥♥ing dishonest and you're either an idiot or lying on purpose if you think that. Some are burning, some are freezing. Some have cave networks, some have giant outcroppings of rocks and minerals. Some are devoid of life and others are full of angry creatures that will rarely bear resemblence to anything else you've seen yet.  I completely understand if you hate this game for it's rocky launch. It's a five man studio, you try releasing a single game ever in your life and find out how easy it is. Studios with hundreds of people who have whole departments specifically for QA still release broken games on release. To hold Hello Games to the same standards as AAA studios is intellectually dishonest and intentionally misleading.  tl;dr This is a game about watching an empty absurd world and carving meaning into it through your actions. It will not hold your hand or direct you any more than suggesing one of three paths. One of which is to remain a free explorer forever.  Possibly GoTY? I need to see if it's worth playing through to completion, and how well content scales through to the end.  Keep in mind this is all my opinion, no need to get pissy about it. If you hate the game I'm totally fine with you hating it as long as you're fine with me having the time of my life. I still can't believe five people were able to make this game.

*new review after 80+ hours*  Pros: - Best planet generation in a game EVER - Literally endless planets with beautiful scenery that you can spend many hours in each one - Flying low across the landscapes scanning and looking for POIs - Stunning space scenes with planets/stars/staships/asteroids etc. quite 'realistic' - Fun to find all species on a planet (and get a good reward) - Interesting to gradually learn the lore and languages through ruins, monoliths, etc. - Ship combat in space is quite fun - Very few issues encountered in 80+ hours - Performance on my average-good system is fine at 1080  Cons: - 'Plot' runs thin fairly quickly. In fact I messed up one of the few goals in the game - Not enough artefacts. Tired of seeing the same half dozen things - Flying over terrain is limited by auto-hover. Would like more control e.g. hovering - Difficult to land where you want due to above - Can't look around starship windows with keyboard/mouse - Ship combat over planets virtually impossible due to above issues - Ship combat in space could do with more fleshing out, e.g. scanning ships, more weapons - Too many installations/buildings/POS's on planets. They are too easy to find; unrewarding - You pretty soon run out of 'tech' blueprints to find, making most alien interactions pointless - Wandering around on planets, while great, could be helped with a ground vehicle of some kind - Some inevitable repetition, main culprit being space stations. Everything else quite ok. - Fade-in (rather than pop-in) of landscape might bother some - Price; I had no issues paying full price, but realistically it could've been $10-15 cheaper  For me the first pro outweighs all the cons, so I can recommend the game. For me, as soon as I hit 10-15 hours I'd had my money's worth, so the extra 65+ since then is the icing on the cake, and I'm still going :)  Get it if: - You can appreciate walking simulators - You can appreciate the tour-de-force of the planet generation - You can put up with a bit of a grind (mining, find species) - You can pay full price - You want to support a small team that could do bigger and better things in the future  Don't get it if: - You must have multiplayer (you can see other players' named planets, that's about it) - You got into the hype and your expectations exceed all reality   *old review follows*  Loving the game, put 16 hours into it in first 2 days which is a lot for me. At first the performance was horrible but after updating NVidia drivers it runs great although my GTX970 can be pushed back as low as 30 FPS on more demanding terrains. A lot of fun, lots to discover for those of us who haven't ruined their experience with spoilers, videos etc.  No spoilers below IMO.  To be balanced, here's the issues I've had.  - bad performance UNTIL upgrading to latest driver AND turning off shader cache in NVidia panel - I'm still a *bit* surprised at my 970 not having better performance especially at 1080 but it's not bad - one CTD (actually 2. After reloading from the first it CTD'd again at the same spot but then has been fine)  Don't expect a flight sim type game when you're flying around. It's definitely on 'easy' mode where you can't really crash; auto-landings; auto-docking at space stations, etc. The space ship is really just a way of getting you around, it's not the focus itself at all. Cockpit is very basic and nonfunctional really. Which is all fine with me. I *definitely* would like to be able to look around to the sides though! [edit: you can't look around with mouse/keyboard but can with some controllers ]. And down wouldn't hurt either. The views would be spectacular, but as it is you kind of have to bank over to the side to see down below you. Would like a VR-type cockpit like flight sims have had for decades now [edit: as I said, only with controllers]. Locking onto a target (destination) would also be nice. I haven't had any space battles yet.  [update: I've had quite a few space battles by now. Don't expect Elite Dangerous, but they are exciting enough. Really only 2 types of weapon, and recharging shields means going into your inventory! I haven't tried attacking large ships as yet.]  The menus are pretty annoying as you can't just click an option, you have to hold the mouse button down for a second, VR-menu-style. Not sure why. It took me a few minutes to work this out and gets a bit tedious but hardly an issue.  I'll update as I visit more worlds (about 5 so far) but I'll be happy to slowly eke out the goodies this game has in store for some time to come.  [update: 77 hours in and still enjoying it. Haven't even tried to advance to the core yet but might start doing that. Have identified species on 2 worlds. Have also earned quite a bit of cash mining and selling rare resources. Upgrading you ship is the most difficult (expensive) part. Unless I'm missing something, you don't get any 'trade' value on your existing ship. You just pay the asking price, move across anything in your inventory, and job done. So if you have an 18 slot ship you might pay $1.5m for a 21 slot ship. But then if you buy a 22 slot ship you might pay $2m! I could be wrong on this though as I haven't bought more than 1 ship (and then I re-loaded anyway).You can also disassemble your ship's tech to recover some of the resources before you do the deal. Dogfights above planet surfaces are basically impossible due to the auto-height feature. You can't really point where you want to go/aim.]

Ok, so unlike the rest of the world i have not been living the past 2 years of my life waiting for No Mans Sky. Also, unlike the rest of the world i actually enjoy this game. I like the exploration, and massive scale, and just the fact that they were able to teach a computer to generate all of this, along with zero loading screens in an only 2GB game. I love how little by little I am learning more about the three main sentient species you encounter whether it be their history, ideals, or language. However, like many others here have already stated, the game has a lot of repetitive qualities. Constant mining and upgrading is what you spend most of your time doing, but even in this case it is lacking. There is little variation in the ships, which i find truly saddening, and even the environments so far have been repetitive in many cases. I think the game has a lot of potential though. Frequent patching over the next couple years (NO DLC PLEASE) and maybe some limited mod support could make this game very exciting. Adding some more variation in the capability of the ship design, more sentitent beings, and more variation in the planets (gas giants, planets that don't have random bases when its all barren) could really make the game alot more interesting. I don't know the limitation of the game because I'm not very far, but maybe more galaxies you can go to? These galaxies will have different sentient species to interact with, because i mean 3 in the whole galaxy? And what species are we? What happened to our species?   By the way, my rig has little to no issues running this game in high settings 1080p, with a i7 5820k and a gtx 970, but i can see how many would have trouble running the game as mine dips below 50 on some occasions.   So I only recomend this game if you can see yourself exploring, and if you have a pretty good rig or are ok with playing on lower settings.   I do feel however that many people would not be interested in this game. There isn't really a storyline, there isn't mulitplayer, there is some action in space, but on the surfaces of the planets there are just weak animals and robots.  More customization of your ship and blaster would add a lot to the game  This game cannot be rated out of ten because it is really a game that certain people will enjoy and others will hate. I suggest waiting for a sale if you are lenient, and if you are lenient I doubt you will enjoy the game.

For the most part, I was excited for the last couple years or so after listening critically to exactly what Sean over at Hello Games said in his many interviews, and more importantly... what he   didn't   say. After reading excited 'game to end all games' super game hyperbole and and watching hundreds of people shout out premature acclaim for this game, and seeing the resulting aggrandized hype ballon like an overstuffed teddy bear I began to worry.  Now, finally after playing for about 5 hours on my PC, I can confidently say that I'm very happy with NMS! The game is exactly what Sean and the other talent over at Hello Games always said it would be. Mainly an exploration game with light survival within a beautiful procedural universe.  What some might call rudimentary game objectives I see as ingeniously crafted procedural story content. These objectives are fun and do provide a sense of accomplishment and help you feel like you are the story, or at least that there's a continuum that you are in and can learn about if you care to. And that's the key...    If you care to.    This game does not lead you by the nose in any way, and because NMS doesn't offer you tutorials and hold your hand tightly like a mother holds their child's in a crowd, it takes a bit of time to figure out exactly how to interact meaninfully with the universe. Once again, I take this as a credit to Hello Games for not treating their audience like a bunch of dribbling nincompoops. Instead, I feel that Hello Games is expecting you to draw from your many hours of time spent on all sorts of other games to get into stride in NMS. Very refreshing!   With many pleasing game objectives that keep coming as you explore, although a little sparse to start, I'm beginning to feel like I'm my own master in NMS, like I can make the choices on where to go, what to do. And because I can ignore everything if I want just to see what's on the other side of the next rise, or on the next planet up there hovering in the sky, I also feel like I'm the master of my own rewards. I love it!  Because in No Man's Sky you not only can choose your own pace, but are required to, I have found myself relaxedly exploring an area, just seeing what is out there, and also found myself in the heat of combat with the crazy, ultra-conservationalist sentinels who keep calling in reinforcements.  I strongly believe that No Man's Sky is a Gamer's Game. Not some sort of ultra accessible 'story driven' (read 'on the rails') shoooter like the masses seem to crave. This is what I believe to be the biggest reason that people have for their unfairly derogotory stance and disappointment with NMS.  So, if you're available to take a deep breath and quit expecting a 'massively cinematic convoluted story with hundreds of hours of hand crafted objectives' as conjectured by excited fans on top of the 'Sandbox Survival Exploration game within the framework of a finely tweaked and excellently balanced procedural universe full of billions of star systems to investigate at your own pace' as Hello Games has always defined NMS to be...  No Man's Sky may be the title for you!

Forgetting all the hype, rumors, conjecture, and flat out bullcrap that was was flying around about this game, it must be said that the game delivers EXACTLY what was promised. The Universe is mind-bogglingly huge, and drab. The sense of scale and space makes one feel completely insignificant.   But this isn't a detraction--it's what was promised, and it's what makes finding something truly bizarre or cool that much more rewarding. In fact, if I have any specific complaint about the game itself, it's that the universe is perhaps a bit TOO populated; I was expecting more barren rocks, but life abounds everywhere I've been yet.   The game is what you make of it--no more, no less. It's lonely as hell in space, which makes getting mauled by a deer with antlers growing out of it's ♥♥♥ all the more interesting.   That all said, I have to be honest when I say that the game wasn't ready for release. I have been lucky enough not to have the stability/crashing/launch issues many, MANY others have reported, but I do have several specific gripes: - The User interface is abysmal. Like, REALLY bad. Crafting is clumsy, everything is counter-intuitive.  - The galactic map is practically unusable. there is no sense of scale, and distances between objects have no reference so might as well be arbitrary. Planning routes is best done by closing your eyes and throwing a suction dart at your screen for all the UI will help you - The Atlas is useless. Mouse-over a 'discovery' to see a static animation of your discovery that's in the worst possible angle. You can't examine, rotate or otherwise inspect it. You might as well start collecting Windows 95 desktop icons and show them off to your friends.   Really though, the game is a spectacle, and well worth a look. I really hope the Devs decide to rework the UI.   Bottom line: It's an unpolished gem. rough/gritty/dirty patches, but the sparkle is there.

I've never written a Steam review before. It seems every game I've taken the time to play has already had countless reviews reflecting every possible opinion and verdict on them, and hence there is little point adding my voice to the mix.   But I feel compelled to do so with NMS, as whilst all current reviews seem to be overwhelmed with the obvious and understandable outcries of 'It's broken', 'It gets boring/repetitive', 'It's not what was promised' etc, my experience with the game has been something else entirely. My review boils down to a simple, single part of my play time so far.  My defining moment with this game came when I first flew into space and went into the galactic map, which does just that: it shows a map of the galaxy around you. The centre shows the star of the system you are currently at, and in every possible direction there are neighbouring stars.   By default, the map wants to show you the route to the 'centre of the galaxy', the loose goal of the game. But after a few minutes I realised I was able to switch to a 'free exploration' mode, which allows you to search the map as you please. You can strafe, you can rotate, and...you can ZOOM. So I zoomed out.  Then I kept on zooming out.  Over the next few seconds, the true scale of this in-game universe hit me. It was such a powerful moment. Hundreds and hundreds of stars filling the screen as my own star and I faded into lonely insignificance. All of them undiscovered. All of them playable. I literally stared wide-eyed for a few seconds and then quietly uttered: 'Woah.'  It's a gaming moment that I know I will not be forgetting anytime soon.

No Man's Sky is a game I would compare to that of a train set. There are those that don't much care for train sets and find them boring, those who think train sets are neat and will mess with them for a little bit before moving on to something else, and others who think train sets are the one and only medium for entertainment in their lives.   Which ever you are, I would reccomend playing no man's sky a little just to get an idea of the vast scale of which the universe and the planets hold. It will try to keep you entertained by othering 'side objectives' and random ambushes, but you can't deny the feeling you get when you first fly into space and activate your hyperdrive. Oh, and let's not forget that creepy tingling feeling I got when I flew into the mouth of a black hole.   Issues: The game starts at medium settings locked at 30 FPS. The game isn't exactly graphiclly intensive (Maybe a bit more CPU intensive seeing as how it has to calulate the size of everything), but locking us at 30 FPS from the start felt like an insult. Even lower end systems can probably get over 40 FPS on this.   Grinding. Now, you may read other reviews that say the game is only about grinding, but it isn't. The objective is to explore and see the different types of creatures, fauna and wildlife. While exploaring you're supposed to stumble upon new items and technology. However, to get around you need to find supplies for Hyperdrive fuel, and that takes time. Considering a full charge on your hyperdrive drains after 4-5 warps, you'll be scavaging supplies for a while.  Overall: 7.5/10

Early Review, subject to change.  1. If you are having trouble getting the game to load, MAKE SURE YOUR VIDEO DRIVERS ARE TOTALLY UP TO DATE. This is especially true if you have an AMD graphics set. Go to AMD's website and get the latest drivers from there; I recommend the Crimson management software if you have Radeon chipsets. Reason this is important: my drivers were up to date, according to Catalyst, but the game would not load. When I did this (went to AMD directly and got the Crimson graphics management software) the game loaded without a problem.   2. Exploration. That's what it's all about. There is no 'end game' so far as I can tell.   3. Getting off planet. When you start out you can't necessarily get off planet right away, because you will need to gather resources. Caves are good, but you can easily find resources you need without going into them. On the other hand, fully exploring the planet you start on can be fun too.  4. Tech. There are a lot of tech enhancements which take up slots. You find them by exploring various sites.   5. There's no multiplayer yet in the traditional sense.

The game isn't a battle, except for the battle to survive. The game is an exploration. There are 18 quintillion unique planets to discover. Sure maybe you'll see 2 or 3 creatures that look similar and sometimes the landscape looks the same as it was on the last planet, but each planet as a whole is surely unique. However, if you're someone who doesn't mind being alone and has a curiousity in seing all kinds of strange creatures and worlds that are completely up to you to explore then this is your game. First of all let me tell you I was not hyped by this game like a lot of users. In fact, I watched a stream (PS4 version) yesterday, I liked it and I decided to get it on PC today.  You may wonder: is this game really good? Is it for me?  The answer: it depends on your likes.  I personally love it because I enjoy exploring the world, taking your time, with no hurries, creating your own way. Don’t expect an epic story here. Well, the truth is the story can be as epic as you want. It’s up to you.  It’s basically a survivor game but it offers an unique experience (not seen before in any other survivor game). NMS does not have an explicit goal but encourage you to attempt to reach the center of the galaxy. Of course you can totally forget about that ‘goal’ and visit as many planets as you want. Inside of them you have to find elements to power and repair your spacesuit, tools and ship. You then craft bigger and better weapons, tools and engines to reach more remote locations. Also, actions like analyzing the animals and plants of each planet reward you with credits (you can use them with vendors to get more resources).  In theory, NMS can be a multiplayer game but in the practice the game is so huge that there is a low chance that 2 players are in the same planet. It’s possible but the experience is single player right now. According to the devs, more multiplayer features can be added in the future though.  Finally, technically the game is simply correct. It is worth mentioning that the game does not have any loading screen and the size of the terrain to explore is almost infinite. NMS runs well on my rig, definitely much better than on a PS4 (it also looks better). It’s truth that my rig is quite powerful (you can check it out on my profile) and maybe the game has to be more optimized in order to run better on lower systems. They also need to fix some annoying bugs like random crashes (permanent black screen) after exiting the game or alt-tabbing.  I also think that the price is pretty high and this can be one of the main reasons that some users don’t get it.

After spending the entire day playing this game, I can most certainly recommend it. I avoided looking up things about the game before playing to get the full feeling of discovering new things, and was extremely surprised to see the negativity around the game when taking a break. I've had one crash all day, and the game's been a solid 120 fps.   Comments about the game being unrealistic are true, but who cares? It's science fiction, and I don't expect them to adhere to every astronomical law and theory known to man. For a small indie team to pull off a game like this, even with the multiple delays, is astounding. Every planet I've visited so far has felt different, and unique. There's been ocean worlds, barren scorched worlds, and intimidating toxic-rain filled worlds. Each with different wildlife, somewhat different flora, and unique day/night cycles and atmospheric effects to match. The vastness of the game is constantly reminding me that I'm almost certainly the first person to ever see a particular planet or system, and it's so satisfying.  I consider this game a technological marvel, and enjoy the immersive feeling of being on an alien planet that every planet and moon I've been on has given. If your computer doesn't run it, refund it... but don't feel the need to leave a negative review and further insult a very small development team that is doing their very best to allow everyone to experience true interstellar exploration.

Just go and do things for their own sake. Like the rest of life.

All right, this game community is surrounded by hate, people feeling cheated, and, of course, the usual 'game does not have a feature I like, so I dislike the game' argument, but I'll try to make a positive review with valid criticism, hoping it to be useful to whoever has any intentions to play it. Here we go:    Overview    NMS's main features are: - Planet and space exploring; - Alien language learning; - Procedural generation (pretty much everything in the game is procedurally generated, with a few exceptions);  NMS is about trading, In order to improve your character with abilities and extra backpack slots, and your ship with technologies and extra cargo slots, you must gather resources in the planets you visit. You then sell everything, make your improvements and go back to resource gathering again. But it doesn't mean all you can do is trading.  NMS is also about exploration. Each planet can come with several different stats, which determine how your gameplay is going to be. The main ones are: - Hazards: e.g. radiation, low/high temperatures, toxic atmosphere...all of these will gradually deteriorate exosuit armor; - Wild life: most living creatures you find will be docile, but others will attack you on sight if you get too close. Some planets are completely absent of wild life; - Sentinel behavior: sentinels are little floating robots that roam the game's universe, and can become aggressive and attack you with if you try to obtain too many resources from a specific place in the surface of a planet, they are the main enemies during on-foot exploration.  Besides these stats, planet generation includes many structures, like: - Ancient alien buildings and data banks, where you can obtain knowledge of certain alien languages; - Outposts and spaceports, where you can obtain technology upgrades, replenish your health and shield, trade, upgrade your multitool, and interact with alien sentient races; - Drop pods, where you can buy extra slots for your backpack; - Downed ships, which can be scavenged for resources or be repaired and used; - Landmark towers, where you can save your game; - Beacons, which create waypoints to points of interest in the planet when activated; - Ore veins, which vary according to the planet and are usually exposed in surface, and can be mined for money or upgrades; - Abandoned outposts, which can be used to discover new locations, obtain alien language knowledge or find new upgrades.  Star systems, galaxies, etc, are also procedurally generated, including asteroid fields, huge fleets with star cruisers, space stations, etc.  Finally, there is an array of ways you can interact with life forms: - documenting wildlife you see; - finding knowledge of wildlife species in databanks; - learning words of alien languages (which gradually translates conversations between you and sentient aliens); - increasing or decreasing your standing towards sentient alien races through different actions.    Gameplay    In order to keep your character healthy, you must constantly obtain materials to repair your exosuit and recharge your life support system. Your starship also demands constant maintenance, specially if you plan to use it to quickly explore planets. The idea of grinding for resources might feel very annoying and repetitive, but as you make enough money to upgrade your stats, it will, eventually, pay off.  There is a single tool in the game, the multitool, that features four functions: laser miner, bolt caster, scanner and grenade launcher. The laser miner is the function you are going to use most. It is capable of destroying rocks, plants, ore veins and crystals and obtain their base materials, and it can also be used as a weapon if needed. The bolt caster is a blaster weapon, used primarily for defense. The grenade launcher is a digging tool that can easily create tunnels, and eventually used to mine or attack. Finally, the scanner helps you find useful items, highlighting anything it finds within its radius. Multitools have their own inventory, with a fixed number of slots, and the purpose of it is to install upgrades that improve its functions. Better multitools, with more upgrades/slots can be bought, but there is no way to equip multiple multitools at the same time, meaning once you replace your current one, the previous one is lost forever.  The backpack is the personal inventory of the player. It starts with a limited number of slots, which can be improved with extra slots as you explore. Items are sorted in, basically, two types: stackable and non-stackable. In the backpack, stackable items will stack up to 250 units per slot, which is not bad. The bad part is that exosuit upgrades also need free slots to be installed, and you can't see what upgrade you can or cannot build unless there is at least one free slot available. This design decision is really dubious, since there could be another set of slots dedicated just for upgrades. It gets even worse because three of these slots are always taken by the jetpack, life support system and exosuit armor, which are the basic functions of exosuit. They shouldn't take space in the same place you are going to use to store collected items, it doesn't make sense.  Now, for the starships. They work pretty much like the multitool, having their own inventory and upgrades, and being permanently replaced whenever you buy or activate a new ship. Ship inventory suffers from the same lack of logic of the backpack inventory: upgrades take the same space used by stored items (which, unlike player backpack, can stack up to 500 units per slot) and the basic functions of the ship (blaster cannon, take-off thruster, etc) also take spaces of its inventory. Ship control is very basic, pretty much like any arcade flight simulator, but when flying too close to the surface of a planet, the game automatically adjusts the angle and height of the ship according to the relief of where you currently are, meaning you don't have absolute control over your ship's movement. This causes your vision of the surface to be limited, and can make your life harder if you eventually enter into a dogfight with other ships. It can get worse: once you activate landing sequence, the game calculates the best place for your ship to land and the ship then begins to descend until it reaches the calculated position in the ground, and, sometimes, this can produce unexpected results, such as the ship ending up landing inside a cave, or in front of a big obstacle. This caused my ship to get destroyed twice when I tried to take-off, which in turn had me waste resources to fix damaged parts. This was definitely a terrible design choice. No problems when navigating through space, though.    UI    Exploration usually feels rewarding and immersive, but there are a few downsides: while all systems and planets you visit become listed in the menu, there is no easy way to find them again, should you ever plan to go back and finish discovering all landmarks in a planet, for instance. Also, you can not bring up the universe map when inside the atmosphere of a planet, only being able to when in space. Another dubious design choice.  Some actions you perform, such as unlocking a computer, helping a sentient alien or activating a beacon, create waypoints while you explore the planet. These waypoints can not be controlled in any way by the player. Also they, sometimes, disappear and reappear for no reason. The lack of some kind of local map also helps make it confusing. The only waypoint guaranteed to stay where it is if the starship one. In this context, UI needs to be reworked.  Beyond that, everything works fine.    Performance    Game runs smoothly on high end hardware, and in 16 hours, I got only two CTDs, which is usually not a bad number. Game code could still be improved to prevent such occasional crashes.  That said, I give it a 9/10.

First of all: This game is not for everyone! Some people love it, others hate it. I'm here to give my honest opinion on the good, the bad, and the annoying.  Second of all, my general feeling towards the game: I loved it! It's great to just roam around, see new places, new creatures, admire the sights, etc... Even if after a few dozen hours playing it starts to feel similar to places you've been before, it's a great experience. And, if you're patitient enough, you will eventually find something unique to that one planet, unlike anything you've seen before. Overall, it is almost exactly what I expected, but there is a lot of room for improvement. And I mean, A LOT! On with the review then!  The good: - Graphics are nice, but don't expect ultra-realistic stuff here. It has a unique art style, and on that context, I think it's great, leading to some breath taking scenes at times. For example, I was on a mostly barren planet once, duriong the day. It was ok, and seeing the sun set was a really beautiful experience. But when the night came... I literally lost my breath when I saw it. Lots of small dragonfly-like things, not sure if 'insects' or some other type of life form, or even some chemical thing. But it was beautiful. Lots of red dots filling the air a few feet above me. Sometimes they would form a big sphere around me, sometimes they just looked like stars, until I moved and realized they were a lot closer. Simply amazing. - The sounds. The sound effects are simply amazing! But what really shines is the ambient sounds. A lot of small details make you actually feel like you are exploring an alien planet. Distant aniamal cries, small animals squeaking about, insects (?) doing their stuff, the wind, the water, the cave sounds... Everything sounds so beliavable! Even if you're on a completely lifeless planet and hear something, you get that chill up your spine and the first thing you think is 'I must hide!', that's also awesome! Not sure if it's a bug, but if it is, I hope they keep it!  - The music: Not much to say here, just... AMAZING! 65DOS did a great job here, and the procedural coding perfected the context aware music! It's like you know how the song will be when you start combat, for example, but it's never quite the same! It's like when you recognize a song and think 'Oh, that song! I love that one!', but it's not quit that one, and still awesome to hear. - All this lead me to... The atmosphere. Oh, the atmosphere!!! They nailed it on this department!!!! All of the above work beautifuly together to create one of the most immersing atmosphere I ever experienced on a game! - The crazy stuff. Sometimes you'll see mundane things, recognizable animals, and landscapes similar to Earth's. But sometimes... You'll see a crazy horse-like thing with a worm head. A big primate with small butterfly wings. A floating island (not that uncommon). A really unique land formation, sometimes with a regular, almost crafted shape. And so many more things! Some may even be considered errors, but when you encounter stuff like that, it makes for a unique and joyful experience.  The bad: - The ship flying part. Overall, the ship controls feel very clunky. It's like it's either move or don't move. You move your mouse a bit, and nothing happens. You move a little more, and suddenly you went too far. Sensitivity settings don't really help here. But the really bad part here is flying on a planet. It's really, really, really bad. You can't go too close to the surface, because the 'autopilot' will move you back up, and keep you on some kind of rails. This really kills the flying experience. Also, it makes it nearly impossible to know where you'll land, which in turn may lead to some dangerous situations when taking off. Oh, and also makes dogfighting on a planet nearly impossible, because NPCs are not limited by this. I don't know if it's also because of this, but rolling is almost impossible on planets. If you roll and the pitch up to turn, as you would with a fighter plane, you just get lost because of the autopilot insisting that you make a different movement. It's weird, and takes a lot away of an otherwise joyful flying experience. - The sentinels. They are everywhere. Every. Single. Place. I think this really kills part of the 'into the unknown' experience. You won't find a single empty place where you can gather resources alone and in peace. (Except for some really deep caves). You can go to the most barren and with the lowest security possible planet, and when you land and start mining that big Emeril vein, there it is, a stupid sentinel scanning and getting mad at you. That is just awful, because I can't go anywhere to simply relax. Eventually I'll need supplies, and as soon as I start mining, I have to let the serenity go away, and start worring about not being seen by those f-ing flying robots. Yes, there are ways to escape them, but it kills the experience. I wish there was a way to just turn them off entirely, or at least make the low security planets really low security, without those things flying around everywhere. - Lack of maps. It's common to venture very far on a planet, and then want to return to a trading station you found a while ago. But it's simply impossible to backtrack, once you leave a place, it disappears from your HUD, unless you're very close to it again. And, sometimes you just found a gorgeous place, want to return there again later, maybe to show it to someone, or whatever. You can't, because once you leave it, you'll probably never find it again. So, a planet map would be really really great. But, of course, not only a planet map. A better galactic map would also be good, with a way to really know where you came from, a way to easily find on it a system you left behind a while ago. Or even find systems a friend discovered. Something like 'Search for X system. There it is, it'll take... 385 jumps to get there. Ok, at least I know it's there.'. This would also enable personal journeys to be created. Like 'I went through a black hole, ended up here. My objective is to get back to the X System.'. It'd be so much better... Oh, and a system map, where you can easily see all the planets there, of course.  The annoying: - Every planet is already explored. Well, not by players, but every planet has a lot of places with aliens on them. Every system has a space station. Everywhere one of those 3 races have a big presence. It's weird. It's one thing to only find ruins and abandoned places somewhere. It's another to go inside a building and meet an intelligent creature there, just waiting for me. This and the sentinels everywhere makes it impossible to feel truly alone and helpless. - The slots. Everything is about them slots, and there's NEVER enough of them. You only advance by getting more slots, and it's just annoying. More starting slots, please! Oh, and more stacking! - The survival. Well, it makes sense that there must be a challenge to get things going, but everything just decreases too fast, and instead of just exploring and searching for cool stuff, you always find yourself having to search for resources and manually reload everything (and with sentinels everywhere). Make it so everything decreases slower (or at least an option?) and automatically recharges if you have the right 'ammo'. A very simple fix. - The combat is shallow. It's not bad, but it's not satisfying either. I feel compelled to write a review for this. I feel there is a large contingency of fanboys, forcing themselves to see a perfect game where it does not exist, alongside a large contingency of trolling flamers, hellbent on seeing this game fail for some odd reason (hi half of reddit). I find myself in the middle, with tempered expectations and expecting just about what we got: a flawed but interesting space exploration game.  A simple tweak vastly improved my performance. In the graphics options, set to MAX FPS cap. The default for some reason is the lowest possible setting, and reality caps your experience about 10 fps lower than whatever it's set at. A stupid error, but easily fixable. I installed later in the day, and have had zero crashing problems. I'm running 24GB of RAM, and a new 1080, with an i7-2600 @ 3.6. The game looks good on ultra settings, however the draw distance is a bit disappointing - I have a feeling this is a reality driven by the procedural nature of the code. Never the less, it would be nice to see textures further out. Looking out the cockpit of your ship while flying low over hillsides can yield some pretty impressive landscapes.  As an aside, dropping in and out of atmospheric flight ocassionally shows some graphical bugs as textures render at different draw distances from the player.  The UI is clunky, and takes getting used to. It reminds me of my limited time playing Destiny, long ago.  I've found so far, that the < 10 planets I've visited all have life, are fairly similar in construct, and differ only by color at this point. I am curious to see if this changes as I approach the center (I've been avoiding reddit and gameplay footage to discover for myself). I worry that the gameplay will get slightly repetitive as I continue my trek towards the center; I can already feel a pattern of resource gathering and travel.  The language aspect of the game keeps interactions fresh, and spending some time looking for the monoliths to learn the various languages is an interesting sidequest that can drive a lot of exploration on each planet. I also wouldn't call these 'planet-sized planets', as the devs mentioned so many times. Some planets are large, but I wouldn't put them at Earth sized planets by any means. Maybe Lunar sized, or Pluto sized.  A big complaint of mine is the inventory capacities of your ship and suit. I understand the design choices behind it, but it does get frustrating running out of space when a huge stack of an element occupies the same amount of physical space as an orb or trinket. Having some customizable inventory management would be a nice addition.  Will this game keep me occupied after twenty, thirty hours? I'm unsure. However, very few games do any more. I feel this game has a fairly casual feel to it, and is accessible for an hour to two hour session at any time.   I'm not sure if I've been fortunate, or if a majority of players having success are staying silent (although, I think this might be unlikely), but I've had a fairly positive experience. This is a good casual exploration game with interesting scenery and a slightly intriguing lore. If you're looking for a shooter, stay away. If you're looking for Elite's better, shiny-er cousin, stay away. If you're looking for MULTIPLAYER, stay the hell away. This really is a single player experience. The combat and trading elements are quite secondary to the survival and exploration elements of the game. As designed, the player is driven into a nomadic lifestyle. I've heard rumors of basebuilding being a possible patch onto this game, but I honestly can't see how it fits into the experience. Maybe I'll understand the motivation as I get closer to the center of the galaxy (but, I'm not really expecting much change).  As a bit of a disclaimer towards the price, this casual space exploration genre is something I've been waiting for since I was a kid, so I'm a bit predisposed to enjoying the game, it fits me well. I'm not terribly upset at spending $60 on this game, as most AAA titles that run for this price have utterly disappointed me anyways. However, I'm at a point in my life where $60 for 30ish hours of entertainment over a month or two is an acceptable return. I'm hoping that I can get that longevity out of this experience. We'll see what the next couple of sessions bring.  TL;DR: 7/10, plenty of room for improvement, but not close to the dumpsterfire reddit and metacritic users reviews would have you believe (if you can get it installed and playing).

After countless delays and riding a huge hype wave, No Man's Sky was finally released this August and it is fair to say that, throughout time, not many games managed to divide opinion as much as this one.  In No Man's Sky, you explore a procedurally created universe full with 18 quintillion unique planets. Starting on a randomly allocated planet with your ship wrecked to bits, your first goal is gathering materials in order to repair it. After that, the universe is yours to freely do what you like among what seems like an infinite number of solar systems which you can 'warp' between.  In the short aftermath of the game's release, players have criticised it and developer Hello Games for countless things including lying about features the game was supposed to offer and didn't. For the avid fan who had huge expectations from this title, No Man's Sky can become repetitive and boring after a few hours. But looking on the bright side of things, it still offers a unique experience that for some manages to hide its flaws.   The vastness of the world available to discover is astonishing. This fact alone contributes on both sides of the coin. You can very easily find a similar repeating pattern upon travelling from planet to planet and from one star system to another, mining and trading your way towards some random objective you set out to complete. But on the other hand, the vastness in itself can lead to some amazing discoveries, beautiful sights and adventurous gameplay moments.  Some people may find not having an end-goal that is set in stone demoralizing. Sure, there is the centre of the Universe there to discover, but you may find the game more fun when setting out to do your own stuff. For those of you who truly just want to explore new worlds and to live childhood dreams of travelling through the universe, this game may captivate you fully.   Three different sized planets, one moon and a spaceship - the game offers numerous breathtaking moments like this. Exploring is the key word here. Sure, there are space fights, mining and searching for resources, learning alien languages, some sort of dialogue interaction with said aliens, fending off that pesky weird looking animal/monster that keeps attacking you, fighting sentinel drones, escaping storms and blizzards and hoarding money to buy that beautiful spaceship you desperately want to have.   But when the line is drawn, this game is all about exploring new worlds and living the experience of travelling through space with relative freedom and finding out what's out there. Although it can feel boring at times after a while, it can get better if one keeps playing because of certain features that one can only unlock after some good hours of playtime. That and the chance of meeting something new and rare add to the excitement.  The apparent lack of multiplayer options can cause a headache, especially since the developers stated that it will be available. This being said, if you want to buy the game for some cool playtime with your friends, this is not the title for you. No Man's Sky is best enjoyed alone - just you and the stars and planets above. The small chance of you stumbling upon a planet or system that was already discovered by another player can add to the 'so I am not alone after all' feeling, but don't count on that.  65daysofstatic's soundtrack for the game is worth buying alone. One of the biggest positive aspects of the game must be the sounds that accompany you on your journey. The sound effects are very well done, starting with the robotic voice that constantly bugs your ear with information, going through the various spaceship sounds you hear while flying and ending with the overall atmosphere that animals, wind, rain, various technologies and all other elements create during the time spent on a planet.   The music is also magnificent. 65daysofstatic managed to create an imersive score that is generated as you play the game, and the actual soundtrack album is absolutely perfect - one of the best albums of the year if you ask me.  The game's graphics don't seem to be out of this world for 2016 standards, but somehow, No Man's Sky manages to procedurally generate some amazing sights that you can only try and screenshot every time you witness them. It is a title for casual gamers and romantics that love to take slow walks in nature, not for the hardcore achievement-hungry competitive players. Because of this, the 60€ price tag may scare off some people, and it can be understandable.  All in all, No Man's Sky is a glorious game that has the downside of having to deal with the fact that it can get a lot better in time, if certain features make it into the game. Hopefully, they will. Hello Games has stated that it will constantly improve the game with their small team, and although many people will say otherwise, their accomplishment in releasing a game this big and interesting is reason enough to buy it.  No Man's Sky could just be the start of a whole new game subgenre and it can only get better.  Rating: 7/10, 3.5*

So, these are just my thoughts after four hours of play.  First of all, I've been following this game since it's E3 announcement in 2014. I have been itching to play this game ever since, watching interview after interview and becoming a fan of a game I haven't even played. Needless to say, when I was at work on Friday, August 12th, I was crushed when I got word of the game not even loading for some people. There were reports of severe hitching that made the game unplayable, people with $2,000 rigs complaining that performance was so bad they couldn't navigate the world properly, etc. With my humble $750 rig, I was immediately afraid that I wouldn't be able to run it.  So, when I got home, I was surprised when I turned on my PC and found that it... ran. FPS was pretty bad, but I resolved it by first lowering all of the graphics settings, restarting, and then bumping them all back up to high. Performance immediately improved. I experience hitching, but it's not bad enough to prevent me from playing.   My absolute biggest issue are the controls. Frankly, they're a joke considering this game was $60. The flight controls are completely counter intuitive; the ship has a mind of its own and tries to veer off in random directions. Leaving and entering the atmosphere is difficult. Again, for $60, I expect these things to be polished on release. I'm very disappointed with the inabillity to Alt Tab. The options to adjust graphic settings are very bare bones. The menues are not at all optimized for PC, which creates a frustrating experience at times. The inventory system is terrible, I'm constantly juggling between materials and found cargo. Basically, what I'm trying to say is that the PC release isn't finished. There's still a lot of work to be done and I HOPE that the devs address these things immediately. If they claim to love the game as much as they do, they should make these things a priority.  Now, onto the GOOD things. I'm very happy with the survival aspects. The game challenges you, you need to be aware of the condition your technology is in at all times. You'll occasionally find creatures that want to murder you on sight. It's pretty much exactly what I was hoping for. Some people aren't pleased with the grind for resources, but personally, I enjoy it. It's relaxing rather than frustrating.   The explorations aspects are what I enjoy most. I love discovering the creatures and even the plant life I come across. You're rewarded via currency when you upload your discoveries, so you can literally make a career in this game as just a plain old explorer. Each variety of life I've encountered is unique, some you can even befriend into following you.   Generally, I'm enjoying this game, which is why I'm saying I recommend this. However, the issues absolutely need to be addressed for me to feel as if it's worth the $60 investment. If you're experiencing issues that make the game unplayable, please, do not just sit around ♥♥♥♥♥ing on forums. Actually submit your issues to Hello Games so they can review and set to work on resolving them.

This game is what it set out to be. Giving that it was created by a small group of developers using only their own money. It's a beautiful game that never claimed it was going to be the polished perfection of AAA games.   People rate this game based on what they thought it was going to be not what it is and was supposed to be.   For me it is exactly what I always wanted, pure exploration in a universe that nobody knows anything about. It has elements of many games but is its own thing. It's new and that puts some people off. They want to be led by the hand and feel overpowered immediately.   If you have no sense of imagination and need constant action this game is not for you. It's for those of us that love to wander and discover, to uncover a story of our own with a little helpful hint now and again along the way.   It's a universe to play in and it's excellent.  Yes there are bugs but what AAA doesn't have them? They are being dealt with faster than any game I've seen before. And I'm happy to wait.
