What this game is at its core:  Resource Gathering Inventory Management Space Exploration  Other things you can do in the game:  Fight off space pirates (2 ships or 2 dozen ships) Document the different species on each planet (Small pool of skeletons to generate so a lot will begin to look the same after 2-3 systems. Hopefully HG will add more skeletons to their generation list) Interact with Aliens races and learn their languages (Limited for now.) Pick fights with sentinals (Planetary police force a-la GTA) Free roam! (Following the main path will give you relatively similar planets on your way to the center of the Galaxy. I recommend forging your own path to the center as you can run across more extreme star systems.)  If the three core ideas present in this game don't interest you, then move on. While it has other things to do in game, it's the three core mechanics that really drive the game. This is not a game you try to beat in X amount of hours by getting to the center of the galaxy. You can play it that way, but don't expect something grand and different. It will be more of the same. It's repetition at its finest. Gather X resource for X upgrade. Run out of inventory, sell, gather more resource, sell, upgrade inventory, sell. Again, if that's not for you, then move on, this is not your game.  There was a lot of gameplay ideas that did not make it to the launch, which encompasses half the negative reviews. The game is indeed a mile wide and an inch thick. But HG has expressed their plans to add to the depth in the coming weeks, so there is still hope. The other half of negative reviews deal with performance issues. People with top end machines couldn't run the game and people with potatos could play it just fine. Most of these performance issues have been fixed or have work arounds. You'll probably have to spend around 10 minutes to configure your settings for the game, however.  I have 20 hrs so far, and still find myself enjoying the game. I don't mind the game for what it is and what it offers now and didn't follow the two year hype around this game. I'll certainly get my $60 out of it and hope for future improvements. Again, if you don't like repetitive gameplay, this is not for you. But if you are interested in the game but on the fence from all the negative reviews, I'd say wait awhile and see what updates HG will push out. If they start to add more non dlc content, it would be worth the buy. If not, it's your call.   6/10 At Launch with no content update

TLDR: If you like exploration and (mostly) solo survival games on an epic scale, I recommend it. If you want action packed fighting, linear story lines, or lots of friends to play with, this is obviously not the game for you. While I worked fine on day one, all the issues other are experiencing obviously indicate it may be worth waiting for a little bit to buy. Don't worry, there will still be plenty of virgin planets to call your own when you log in.  Longer version:  Lot of hate and vitriol, damn few game reviews.  Put in some time today and overall, I like the game. I like the concept of exploring new planets, finding a hundred different kind of plants, animals and minerals, and uploading them all to some galatic guidebook. I went for a swim in a radiactive sea to find some submerged ruins. Took 4 minutes to get there and back and the only question was if I'd run out of oxegyn or rad shielding first. I've been attacked by a droid, a plant, a prehisoric sabertooth looking guy, that damned ocean and sometimes the air around me.   The complete lack of tutorial threw me at first (I couldn't figure out how to use the Atlas so that may have helped) but most of the game is pretty intuitive. The crafting setup is not instinctive so I findmyself dropping out of the window I want pretty regularly, but hitting Tab to reopen it is hardly the end of the world. It's a little frustraing to deal with really limited inventory while trying to gather the things you need to build and fuel your first hyperdrive. The ability to swap from inventory to ship (when close enough) is helpful but overall the lack of stacking, lack of bags and sheer number of items (mineral, fuel, trade goods, upgrades, etc.) and limited ability to sell or convert items has made this part of the game a little annoying.  Biggest current performance downside for me is an apparent memory issue. After about a couple hours in game things slow down. Not frame rate stutter, just everything you do. You run like you're in molasses, you shoot slower, open inventory slow and need 3 times as long for the alien interaction text to come up. I'm certain it's on the list of things to address after all the crashing issues are resolved. For now I'll consider it a built in indicator that I need to go take a break.  All in all, it's a recommend for me. Hopefully I'll be able to meet up with friends some day but if not I'm still enjoying the game.

In all honesty, this might just be one of the single best exploration games I know and I can warmly suggest this to anyone who enjoys sci-fi exploration, genuine discovery and/or a mining/trading for large stacks of green. I fail to see how it is as overhyped as people claim and I believe the majority of perfomance complaints where made by people who failed to realize that this isn't a small game or a typical low-requirement indie, but rather a game comparable to many AAA titles in both scope and graphics.  The game isn't perfect however, as even with a quite expensive and high performance MSI gaming laptop, it was certainly playable, but definitely not optimized. I experienced a stuttering, but acceptable game for about an hour or two per session and then it started to get slower quite rapidly, even becoming unplayable after only 3 hours game time. This contrasts quite heavily to a friend of mine, for whom the game ran smoothly on max settings, clocking in at 60+ fps average (I advise you check with a friend owning a similar pc build in advance of purchasing it, whether or not it will run on your pc).  Unfortunately the biggest turnoff was the clutter of hype and misinformation from the pre-release community, making me think I bought a multiplayer game that would allow me to explore with friends... Unfortunately, that wasn't the case. This game is, and will for quite a while remain, a singleplayer ONLY game. This is not necesarily a bad thing in my opinion, but I would not have payed the 60 euros for it had I known in advance. This cannot really be blamed on the devoloper however, but rather on too many people likening it to other titles such as Dangerous Elite and confusion arising from this comparison.  tl;dr: -Good game -Infinite 'replayability' -Currently poorly optimized for many systems -Singeplayer only (for a time at least)

I know this game isn't working properly for alot of people. It's not optimized for me either, I get around 30 - 80 FPS with framedrops that are common. I run the game on an i7 4770 with the amd radeon r9 290x.  Performance out of the way I'll tell you my thoughts on the game. I have played the game for a total of 22 hours and just finished my ~11 hour session. I think I'm addicted haha. But when you sit there eleven hours straight you start realising the potential problems for the game, for example - the grind is real. I mean really, really, really real. It's insane. From my playtime I have achived one ship worth ~1.2 million and have an additional 3.7 million on me. For a really good ship you need 17 million.   But the thing is, it's okay because this is sort of the purpose of the game - exploring, mining, trading. You get more resources, blueprints and additional units by exploring, it's all in the exploring. Sometimes you get lost in the 'story' and you don't really know what to do, because the narrative isn't the focus. It's frustrating at times but is really rewarding at it's best.   As you make your way through the galaxy you get to explore planet sized planets (as Shaun Murray says all the time) and they are really unique and interesting most of the time. But as much as I love seeing new planets and animals it starts to get repetetive. You see the same skeleton structure of animals over and over again and you start seeing through the games algorythmes. I tried to change things up mid- play by becoming a pirate, to change things up a bit, but I got shot down right away. This game really plays with risk reward, but doesn't really encourage the player to do anything but mining, because it's the safest and most rewarding way of play.   Summary: You maybe shouldn't be listening to me, because I might be going insane and I should probably eat something, but the game is fun. Really fun in fact. But it gets repetitive, it really does and i guess it comes down to what sort of person you are. Set your own goals, push the limits and No Man's Sky might just be the best game you'll ever play. But then again, it's repetitive and needs FREE, not paid because then I will litteraly visist Shauns house at night and stab him, content updates. If not I'll stop playing when I get to the center of the universe, and i suspect you will to.

No Man's Sky is not a game for everyone. You have to be the type who enjoys sandbox adventures, where you create your own story, your own adventure, and don't need to be lead by the hand. While there is a story in No Man's Sky, it is not one that is easy to follow and you have to hunt for the answers. I am 12 hours in and I still have so many questions with only a few answers I have come to solve.  Such as the alien race I am with are against the sentientals, due to some old reason. There is this Atlas calling to me to follow its directions, and a strange alien spore that seems to consume life, but yet to all this, I have yet to solve some of the answers as to why, but I know, bit by bit, it will be explained and this is also why the game is not for everyone. You have to enjoy the hunt, the search, and wonder what is around every corner.  It is a game about adventure, your OWN adventure, not the path everyone else walks, but how you, yourself, walk that path. To sit back and compare stories with friends, who, like you, are also trying to survive in a mysterious galaxy.  For those who do not like this type of gameplay, they will find the game boring fast. For those who like a direction given to them, they will find themselves lost, confused, and frustrated. This though, is alright, because again, this game is NOT for everyone and I would not recommend it to everyone, but only to those who love the things I have stated.  It is also not about the latest graphics or realistic combat, as you have games like Star Citizen or Elite Dangerous for those, both which I have played, both which I respect, but no. This game is not like those. It is more relaxed, more colorful, and more fitting of its art style that mimics the older days of sci-fi. If you want real, you will not find it here either.  Now, do I believe the game is worth 60? That is hard to say. I have no regrets spending the money for this game or supporting a small Indie company, but that price tag is one you have to decide if YOU think it is worth it, for me, it was, but for others, they may desire to wait for the sell, or for things like Base Building to come into exsistance, and that is fine as well.  In the end, I do enjoy this game greatly. I find it has breath taking moments, mysteries to be pondrered over, and a video game experience I have no felt since the early days of Minecraft and even harkening back to older games where things felt like a true adventure. I give this game an 8/10 and I know I'll be playing it for years to come.  As for you reading, go check some Youtube streams, twitch streams, maybe Let's Plays, and make your own choice if you believe this game is for you.

I'm sure you've read all the 'haters' reviews. 5 minutes of game time and they're bashing the game because it won't work properly, run properly or even at all. Thing is, Hello Games has even stated publicly that over 1/3 of all the tickets inputted into their ticket system have well BELOW the marked specs for the game. BELOW the specs. Head scratcher? Nah? Common ♥♥♥♥ing sense. Listen, if you're pc or laptop does NOT meet the specs, don't complain when it doesn't run properly. Period. That's common ♥♥♥♥ing sense.    What else is wrong? Well, travel is fantastic. Exhilarating even at times. There's a few things that annoy me personally. One, the distance from entering a planet's stratosphere to meeting the ground takes a whopping 30 seconds, if that. I KNOW this game isn't based on realism, but c'mon. From outerspace to ground in less than 30 seconds is not 'believable'. Equipment degradation happens way to quick. Personally, your life support shouldn't need 'fixed' every minute. Makes no sense. These ♥♥♥♥ing drones. Seriously. If you happen to be extracting minerals and one of these ♥♥♥♥ers happens to come too close it'll set off the whole bunch of em against you. While easy at first, the fact you can visit planets that you will get swarmed in 30 seconds by a dozen or so. Just, not fair. Also, what is their purpose? Why are they even scanning everything that you seem to want to extract?   There's no real cement to the story. No real reason you seem to want to travel, to extract, to help. We get some written dialogue, no spoken. Even aliens don't really beep or moan or anything. You get written 'dialogue' pertaining to the alien thoughts and spoken word. While I do like the fact you can 'learn' the language it takes a LOT of time to know enough words to understand even 1 alien. Needs some work to make a little better.     All in all, there are probably too many things to nitpick about. The game does a LOT right. It really does. Travel, the many, many accessible upgrades you'll get for your mining tool and ship. It all adds up to a lot of fun. We need more and a lot different randomizations for each planet and camps. Too many look identical in their make-up. Aliens all look the same. 'Puzzles', ie, random objects you need to solve in order to accomplish some kind of goal are entirely all too easy. They're also all the exact same in the end. You have, maybe half a dozen or so random puzzles you'll have to solve over and over and over again. Needs more randomization and some harder puzzles implemented.    The game looks gorgeous. There's some really annoying pop-in that happens and no amount of graphical distance spacing seems to help. I believe it's the tech and NOT a GPU intensive job. The tech is just making assumptions based on your distance from the objects and THIS needs fixed as well. Badly. It happens ALL THE TIME. You'll notice it. It doesn't neccessarily take away from the immersion but it can be annoying when you're playing with everything on 'high' and nothing helps. While the game looks amazing at times, stupid things that people like to see are not available. You're just a floating arm. Looking down reveals you have no legs. Getting in and out of the cockpit could have a really cool cut scene that can happen showing your entire body. It does not. In fact, you don't even get to pick if you're a man or a woman. You're just a human, I'm assuming.    Sound design is wonderful but can be weird at times. You might notice some sound 'lag' when shooting asteroids or whatnot. It rarely happens, but again, should be fixed.    The game NEEDS some kind of mapping allowable while you're adventuring on a planet. That would be handy dandy. Star maps are okay but can get tedious accessing and trying to figure out where you're going because it doesn't auto align itself.    All in all, it's a good game that can be great. If the devs really follow through and fix what's missing and/or broken this will evolve into an epic space/adventure sim that will just OWN the genre.

Ok, this review is for people who really enjoy sci-fi and  allowing your imagination to run wild. No Man's Sky is for people  who enjoyed 2001, The Martian Chronicles, Cosmos by Carl Sagan,  and anything that just opens the mind up to whatever might come.  First of all, it's a procedural game. What does that mean? Well,  not even the creators know exactly what you might find since  everything is created with mathematical procedures that they  developed. It's an amazing experience, diving you into a world of  colors, creatures and the unknown. That is the key to the game,  not the center of the universe. The unknown. Every time you play,  you don't know what might happen or not, see or experience, hear  or explore. It's not linear. Space is open, endless, boundless,  empty at points and most of all, who knows. No Man's Sky gives  you the opportunity to let go, dive in, who cares about score or  what you have, there's no competition besides what your mind and  eye might find. It's an explorer's game, for fun and excitement  of roaming around a world that could be whatever it might be at  that given time.   If you want to be pampered and want it easy, things to kill,  stuff to buy, right away, this isn't a game for you. But, I would  let my kids play this game in a second, truly mellow and immense  environment where perhaps they might learn something about being  passive. I play games and enjoy all kinds but No Man's Sky is  trying to introduce you to an game that wants you to come inside,  explore, open it up and see. You can play at your own pace,  explore the entire planet you're on, see, feed, make friends with  the creatures and relax. The music is great, the ambient sounds  really throw into where you're at the time and some action,  shooting things, ships, gathering items, for those with the itchy  trigger finger. Yes, you can run around shooting everything but  not the point. And what is the point, well, perhaps there isn't  one. I think it's about immersion, taking you mind for a while on  a small journey into your ship, investigating worlds like they  once were perhaps for travelers back in the day on this planet,  very unknown.   I highly recommend you try this game and just sit back, have a  drink, rest, turn the lights off, put on a podcast or some music  and enjoy. Leave the shooting for another day.

This game is not going to spoon feed satisfaction to a weak imagination.  However, if you are a sci-fi fan who has always wanted to fly all sorts of spaceships, explore gorgeous alien vistas, and find exotic exotic lifeforms then this game hits the bulls-eye. Just existing in the NMS universe, stories will just happen. Go for a walk and adventure will find you. Set your own goals and be surprised what twists and turns naturally unfold before you. I personally enjoy the laid-back play-style.   If you are in the mood for a more challenging experience then make harder goals for yourself. For example, try walking around the equator of a small moon that has a hazardous atmosphere and is prone to punishing storms. The mods for this game are amazing. Pick the right collection of mods and you will have a brutal survival game. This game is has the potential to be anything you want it to be.  This game is not for everyone, but it is a MASTERPIECE for me.

It's a game about exploration, awe, and science fiction. IMHO.  There are better space ship management sims, far better. Better dogfighting and shooting games, far better. More graphically impressive space games, more realistic space games, games with greater depth in just about every area that No Man's Sky could concievably contain.  Other than exploration. While it may not have 'lived up to the hype' for a lot of people, it's worth remembering that people way over hyped this game. It was a cool idea and exciting, it was never going to be the second universe everyone seems to want. My biggest disappointment wasn't actually with the game, but I wasn't expecting the impractical or obscenely detailed. It was the design choices.  So, here's my list of why this game is totally awful;  1. Removal of control from the player. Find a save spot? Welcome to several seconds of disembodied head floating and staring off into a cliff for no reason while you'd rather be sandpapering off your face. 2. Achievement widescreen. Why? Why do I care if I walked a bunch of arbitrary units? No what I care about is the giant monster growling up my backside but I can't shoot and my hud is gone and there is a giant medal flashing in my face for no reason. I get the feeling whoever had this idea has walls and walls of trophys for dumb sports and showing up and walking arbitrary numbers of units and they just had to share their joy of shiny objects with everyone.  ....Here's a tip; stay away from that person they're dangerously stupid.  3. Inventory management. Hundreds of units of iron? Or one small access card. Seems legit. Sept for the part where I want to gouge out my eyes with my thumbs because when have you ever left a huge square area of empty space around your bank card when you store it in the trunk of your car. Is a wallet too much to ask for? What about a cargo upgrade for my ship so I don't have to cram all my minerals next to the engine and systems. Who does that? Do you tape your luggage to the bottom of your car? Under the hood? WTF.  4. Some of the POIs will rip your head off your body, hurtle it into the air, and then suck you back down. Presumably to remind you that pop-in exists. And by remind I mean grab the back of your head and bash it into pop-in until your teeth bleed.  K.  But I like it a lot. In the moments in between all that, it's actually not all bad. If you prioritize resource farming to high value, and plan out your routes and upgrades, take it one thing at a time, most of the issues with inventory go away. Surprisingly I enjoy the farming, it's more difficult to manage space for resources than it is to find them, and some rare materials pay well enough that you can cram your inventory with that for quick money.  Edit;  People tearing into the game should probably check their own expectations first. I watched this game get hyped to the point of insanity. Go watch peoples youtube videos and listen to the theories put out there by people before the game was released. The kinds of stuff people expected from this game weren't always reasonable, and sometimes they were down right insane. Stuff that makes you wonder if they didn't confuse 'Procedural Generation' with magic.  Here, take this analogy. Tesla released a car with an auto-pilot feature. It explicitly states in the handbook to keep your hands on the wheel and be at attention at all times even when auto-pilot is active. Someone has already died from not following that simple direction.  It wasn't a missing feature, it wasn't a false promise, it wasn't the worse thing that ever happened. It was someone who had expectations that far exceeded their reality. Just like many critics have with this game.  Oh and I wouldn't be surprised if a fair number of people bought it thinking it was going to be like call of duty but with space ships and were sorely disappointed when the game didn't immediately start cramming explosions and scripted cutscenes at them.

I've played more than 35hrs upon writing this. I recommend this game, though I do have a few issues. I was a little disappointed when I discovered some of the limitations, but I made the most of the game, nonetheless.  The game is mostly procedurally generated. This means that you'll find most planets have a different terrain, weather, certain minerals, type of Flora (Plant life), number of Creatures, Alien NPCs, etc.  Pros: -The story revealed through the relics and the abandoned structures is actually quite interesting. -You may find some of the scariest or majestic creatures out there. -The landscape can make for some breathtaking images (wallpapers Cover pictures / etc.) -You cannot crash your ship into anything but asteroids. -Shows lots of promise.  Cons: -Due to the randomness of it, you may actually see a bit of repetition. -No real risk, unless you're really trying to die. And even then, it's pretty difficult. -You may find some of the stupidest creatures out there. -You cannot crash your ship into anything but asteroids. -No real specialization, yet. -A lot of the content that was show to or otherwise revealed to us before launch was not in game. -Finding that last species, just to name it Waldo or Carmin Sandiego. -lots of grinding just to earn enough for a new ship or exosuit upgrade.  Overall: If you enjoy (randomness, pseudo-exploring space, collecting, or just looking for an experience), this game's for you. But if you're looking for action, a simpler EVE, or the giant snakes from the previews. This game is not for you... Yet. :P  P.S. If you accidnely (or not) switch out of the window, Alt+tab until you hear the sound for the game. Then Shift+Tab to open the steam browser. Alt+Tab again to get back to the game. Enjoy!

I downloaded 4 hours after release. Running on an i7 with 32gb of RAM and an nVidia 780 with all settings on max. There was some stuttering during the startup, but it has run great ever since. As always, make sure your OS and drivers are updated and restart after installation. Ignore the reviews from people complaining after playing for 5 minutes. If your game crashes after the intro, use Google and debug the issue (No Man's Sky Twitter even has some suggestions). If you can't handle that, go buy a PS4.  As for the game, I don't pay attention to hype. I don't read reviews from people paid to write reviews. I let the game come out, then I watch people on Twitch play. If it looks like something I'd enjoy, I buy it. It's that simple. I can't believe how many people are complaining about what the game should or could have been. Unless a game is the third or fourth game in a series, it's silly to think you know what the game will be based on previews and demos.  That said, the game is a ton of fun for those of us that love exploration, management, and western RPGs. In the Elder Scrolls games, if you're the type to say 'F the main quest' and go wandering into the wilderness, then you'll enjoy this. If you're the type that favored combat and questing, then this won't be your cup of tea. The 'quest' in NMS is extremely vague and only serves to push you onward.  As for repetition, the worlds and creatures are programmatically created, so they won't all be winners. If you don't like a world though, you're just a little plutonium away from the next.  If you liked exploring Skyrim, farming in Harvest moon, and flying around in a spaceship ala Freespace, then this may be the game for you.

Some planets have more hostile sentinals and wildlife leaving the mystery of what you will find on the next planet, and filling your gameplay experience with fun easy combat. The ship fighting was a little difficult to get a hold of, but once you get it you can protect yourself from pirates or even help other NPC's being attacked. Any problem that people are having with this has also been made very clear they are going to fix, and plan on updating regularly. And besides, space in this game is a whole lot more exciting than the space we have around here, how would you feel if you had to travel to your third solar system just to find signs of living creatures?

Unlike most people, I enjoyed No Man's Sky. Now, this review will probably get a lot of hate, especially since I'm going to address many claims people made about the game.  1. Multiplayer Yes, multiplayer was promised for the game, but it wasn't completed at the time of release. And with this big of a universe in a game, it would be nearly impossible to find other people anyway.  2. Performance issues This one is easy, and it happens with almost every new game like this.  There are millions of different combinations for PC hardware, and developers can't test them all, so sometimes they have to assume how the game will perform on hardware that they don't own.  3. Advertising and hype Well, I don't even know where to begin here. The hype for this game was unbeleiveable. And that's mostly to do with the fact that the videos that were shown of the game were pre-rendered, and not actually in game footage. You guys do realize that almost every developer uses pre-rendered materials for trailers and promotions right?  4. False claims When people say that false claims were made about the game, I agree. But, you do have to realize, these developers were probably just as excited, if not more, as us for this game.  It's their baby, so of course they're going to brag about planned features, and things that they want this game to become!  Overall, this is not a terrible game if you like grinding and tedious repetetive tasks. Even though the game is not all it's cracked up to be, it's still not terrible, especially with the new base building update that gives you more to do than just explore. If you were expecting the game to look like the trailers above, don't get your hopes up. The game does a good job of making every planet look the same, and sometimes that's not a bad thing. It means you'll always be near resources that you need to make your ship go. The only lack-luster things that need improvements on planets is weather. Trading is one area of the game that could be improved. I would love to see the ability to create an intergalactic business where you sell the materials you mine from planets. I would also love to see automatic mining and crafting, and maybe farming. This would maybe be an end-game thing, but it would be something to sell on you intergalactic business. I can't wait to see what this game will bring in the future, but for now, it lives in infamy.

No Man's Sky is just about nearly everything I expected from it going in. I remember watching the original trailer for the game when it was revealed about two years ago and having my doubts, and while a large number of features that were promised don't seem to have made it into the product we received at launch, I'm still very happy that we received as much as we did.  It's one thing to go into something like Subnautica and swim around for a bit in something hand-crafted by the developers. But to go into No Man's Sky, and have just the moon of a planet be larger than anything most other games could ever hope to achieve is incredible to me, and with hardly any loading in between.   Minecraft might be massive, but when I'm travelling around the limitless world at a fraction of the speed I'm capable of travelling in No Man's Sky, the game still runs into caching issues, throwing me at large masses of blocks that haven't even loaded into the game yet. This is even disregarding the game's incredibly long initial loading screen. And despite being in development for as long as it has, vanilla Minecraft is still lacking much substance. It relies on the community to create its content for it.  While I'm hoping that No Man's Sky will one day have the community support other games in the genre have, at the moment, the vanilla content is quite significant. I'm not simply trying to survive like in Subnautica, or crafting my way to the Ender Dragon. I'm trying to reach the center of the universe.  It almost feels like what I'd hoped Starbound would eventually become. Each type of planet feels unique. And as you progress further into the game, you need to be prepared before stepping out onto the surface of some of the harsher but more rewarding planets.   Ignore the reviews from those who've played less than 10 hours. Games get more difficult as you progress through them, everybody knows that. No Man's Sky isn't Dark Souls where your first few moments will leave you dead. The game eases you into the deep end so by the time you get there you're actually ready, and if you can't deal with not having everything thrown at you at once, maybe this isn't the game for you.  Early on I stepped onto a planet that claimed its sentinels were on high security. As soon as I stepped out of my ship, I found some various items that were worth more individually than a stack of anything I'd ever picked up before. Not long after picking them up, I was being chased by sentinels of all shapes and sizes. On another planet the regular temperature was -200°C, with storms that brought that down to -300°C. Like I said, you need to show up prepared to fight off whatever it is that some of these more extreme planets will throw at you.  Reading other reviews, I'm not entirely sure what other people wanted from this game that it didn't deliver on. You wanted multiplayer? As disappointed as I am that it doesn't have multiplayer, that's simply not the game it was advertised as. Sean Murray may have made some things out to seem like they would be better than they are. But at no point did he stress that this game would be focused on multiplayer aspects. You can name discovered planets, systems, plants, animals, etc... And other players will see that you named these things.  And the reviews regarding performance? Ark doesn't run at 30fps on some of the beefiest computers you can make. Subnautica has performance dips all over the place and has the added benefit of little to no visibility that comes with being a game taking place underwater. Grand Theft Auto V, one of the most popular games on Steam, didn't even run until a week after launch on most computers because of an issue with people having the '@' symbol in their Windows sign-in username. This small team behind No Man's Sky not only pulled off a game that performs better than the two previously mentioned, but it also has an appealing aesthetic and is running on an engine that they created from the ground up.   Pros

Let me start by saying I did not follow the hype leading up to the launch of No Man's Sky, and heard about the game a day or two after launch. That might color the fact that I have enjoyed the game for what it is, rather than what it is not.  That said, if you like exploration games with a hint of minecraft/OCD collection of resource games, its a great title. There are nearly endless places to explore, name and experience. Yes, the planets and fauna get a bit tiresome being made up of similar components/body parts, but I still get a kick out of seeing animals even the greeks would have had trouble imagining.  I nearly walked away from the game an hour in or so when my ship decided to land on, and by land I mean violently collide with, a copper node which was (as they all currently seem to do) floating a hundred feet off the ground. I nearly killed myself trying to jet pack up, inevitably taking tons of damage when I failed to get up high enough. That said, perserverance pays divdends in the game. Clearly, I got back up there eventually. It was rewarding in the end.  The resource collection element of the game can be a touch tedious as well, but you are always driven by the endless need to upgrade your ship/multi tool to get that one extra (or two ... ♥♥♥♥ or three) spot(s) to perfectly synergize your modifications. And of course all that comes at the cost of having to farm up a ton more resources to rebuild for the Nth time. For an OCSD riddled person like myself, thats part of the fun though. Probably not for everyone.  TL:DR No Man's Sky delivers on many of it's core conceptual promises, but will not please everyone. Its also quirky in terms of some game play, which makes it fun if given the chance.

No Man's Sky had a lot more hype and expectation than I had imagined - and why not? For such a small development team to create a universe with such incredible scale, discovery and exploration speaks volumes of Hello Games. It is the fundamentals on the ground that are seriously lacking. Coupled with frustrating bugs and issues, the sense of wonder this game offers quickly fades.  Hello Games is partly responsible for the hype, as is Sony, but we too are held accountable. For every new trailer we brought with it our own expectations, interpretations and demands. It wasm't until the few months leading up to launch that we finally had an idea of what this game actually is.   It's a survival game. A chance to explore 18 quintillion planets, scrambling for resources and battling against oppressive sentinel forces, fighting off pirates and bounty hunters in space and discovering and naming a plethora of procedurally generated creatues, phallic-looking flora and some funny looking fauna. In my first few hours with the game, it was all this and more.  Starting on my first planet, I begin searching for resources and materials to repair my ship. Everything is new, everything is exciting. Lush colors and landscape is awash with new experiences, chances to learn how No Man's Sky works. Within an hour, I have learned that Sentinels are mean, how to mine resources, learned new words to an Alien language, which resources are beneficial, my backpack is absolutely small, all while exploring this gorgeous new world.  After repairing the ship, I set out to the stars into the galaxy, and it is undoubtedly a 'wow' moment. The first time you break through the clouds, reach the stars, planets are all around you waiting to be visited, explored, plundered, your mind boggles with all the possibilities that lay ahead.  Once again, No Man's Sky is a survival game, with many different things that are out to end you. Depending on the planet, the climate can be extremely harsh, sentinels can be more aggressive and the indigenous creatures are just as equally fierce. At first, you'll stick it out, thinking of ways to defy the odds, and get the vital materials you need until you realise that, with the number of planets this game has to offer, it's much easier to jet off in search of a more hospitable environment.  It's difficult to consider No Man's Sky a survival game when there is very little reason to 'stick it out'. When a planet just isn't welcoming, there will be dozens more within the solar system that will welcome you with open arms.  On the subject of planets, while they certainly look gorgeous at a distance, up close, the textures can appear blurry. Land patterns repeat, rock formations look bland, and any patch of water will be completely still. The consequence of procedural generation is, ironically a lack of uniqueness and detail. Additionally, you won't have to explore many planets before you get the sense of deja vu.  When on a planet, you'll spend a lot of time mining, which is fine, but the creativity is lacking. It won't be long before you know what materials you need, and where to find them. The fact that you simply have to grab them and shove them into your spaceship's engine or combine them to craft an element to add to the hyperdrive. It lacks a certain connectivity and drive that Minecraft has in chunks.  The only reason you keep collecting is because of the main objective; the journey to the center of the galaxy - the Atlas quest - but the path to completion is a strain on my patience as the monotony kicks in.  To move to new planetary systems, you need to upgrade the aforementioned hyperdrive, doing so by combining certain elements to craft components to create energy cells. In the beginning, I was strolling, wandering around every planet, picking up the materials as I found them. But as teh objective became more and more pressing, the sense of discovery no longer seemed to intrigue me.  How long you choose to chase Atlas will simply be how much patience you have with the gameplay, or how long before the immersion breaks and the realisation that you've done the same four basic tasks for the past ten hours hits.   Unlike a numerous amount of others who suffered from bugs or crashing, I was fortunate to have suffered the occasional framerate hiccup here and there - before referring to reddit for the fixes we as a community who purchased the game had to discover for ourselves. Before any of the patches, including the latest patch this month in August, this game suffered from the aforementioned crashes, bugs, and framerate loss. Since the patches however, I haven't experience any problems with the game, and have not suffered a loss of immersion because of any bugs.  That isn't to say however that this game is perfect. It is far from. No Man's Sky is a good game. Sean Murray and Hello Games' vision of creating a vast universe on a scale unseen in video games hs no doubt been achieved, and it will certainly provide anyone who plays it with sopmething unique.  However, the fundamental gameplay isn't deep, or rewarding enough for me to stick around and explore many of the planets the game has to offer. With a basic combat and inventory management, it quickly wears thin, and you'll feel like you're dragging yourself from system to system in search of Atlas.  Does it luve up to the hype? For anyone who has been following this game for years now, probably not. But, if you can appreciate this game for what it is - a technical marvel that will no doubt vastly improve over the coming months, then there is certainly plenty of fun and a sense of wonder to be had. It's just a case of how long before the fun stops.  I can't in all good consciousness recommend this game, especially at its current price. I can however, recommend you to follow this game as it is further developed, whether good or bad, and to ask yourself if you want to play it - regardless of reviews, good or bad.

PRO TIP: there is a game in here, it's just hard to find amidst all the sightseeing. If you're looking for the game, here's the deal: go to planets with 'frenzied' sentinels, empty your inventory, and collect Gravitinio balls. Don't try to fight the enemies you'll aggro, you'll end up killing them and spoiling the fun; instead, use long jumps to run from them, keeping the pace up as you collect more Gravitinio balls and lose yourself in the planet you're visiting. It's actually a decently fun bit; you just have to seek it out on your own, and therein lies No Man's Sky's greatest weakness.  Apart from finding the (relatively rare) activities within the game that are either challenging or exciting, there is little to do in No Man's Sky that fits the traditional definitions of a game. Rather, No Man's Sky is a tech demo, and it demos some very impressive tech. I knew it was a tech demo when I bought it, so I was not dismayed to discover that the veneer of gameplay was paper thin throughout most of the experience.  If you go into the purchase knowing that you're buying an exhibition, not a game, then I doubt you'll be disappointed. However, if you go in hoping for a good story, polished gameplay, elegant controls, interesting characters, or anything else other than a 'space bumbling simulator,' then you will likely end up among the many others in these reviews who were tricked by a rampant hype machine into purchasing a 'game' that is fascinating to think about, but often very dull to play.

Here's a perspective from someone 50+ (just recently purchased a gaming rig with GTX1080) and is my very first Steam review.  I don't like games where your life expectancy is all of 5-10 seconds. I LOVE open world exploring games with a dose of survival thrown in. I logged 300+ hours playing Skyrim and is my favorite game of all time (so far). I prefer single-player games.  That being said, I waited patiently for NMS (even pre-ordered it). Installed it the 1st day and started exploring! My home planet was a radiation nightmare, but it taught me vital survival skills. I can say with all honesty that I NEVER Googled any tips/tricks etc. Everything I learned was by hard knocks, and had no problem figuring things out as I went without tutorials. I eventually made it off-planet after repairing a couple crashed ships (for more slots) and moved out into the Cosmos.  I am in love with NMS! I come home from a stressful day, and it is very relaxing booting up and taking off. Last night I landed on a veritable Garden of Eden planet. I'm planning on surveying this planet 100% for the 1st time. Sentries are forgiving and flora/fauna are abundant. Nothing is trying to eat me as I stroll the surface.  Sure there are physics and glitches that can be tweaked, but my experience has been solid out of the box. Give Hello Games a break and be patient. You try staring at code all day.  I also love the fact that I have no idea who I am. Am I Male or Female? Am I Alien or Human? I can read English or can I? All I am sure of is I am ambulatory and can die :(  If you are looking to rack up the largest body count possible, then this game is probably not for you. If you like exploration and the fantasy of planet discovery by all means give it a try!  Keep up the nice work HG!

So I thought I needed to write this review. I really like this game despite the shortcomings and shortfall of features that where suggested by Hello Games. It needs further work to fill out the game but the procedurally generated system is awesome in what it achieves.  I get that the Planet Flora and Fauna generation are repetitive, but of course that can be fixed by Hello Games adding more assets and I hope they will be, the modding community on the PC I suspect will also add to the pot...  I get the inventory management is a pain, Hello Games could fix that easily with Exosuit, Multi Tool and Ship 'Capacity Modules' (at a price in game of course) that could be added to increase the default stack sizes (no pain no gain). I also believe all items should be stackable. these of course in line with the current upgrades could be scaled. - I currently use a NMSE Mod to fix this part.  I get there are only three races, but hang on they have a whole language each and again this could be enhanced by Hello Games via new DLC Content.  I get that tracking back from whence one came is an ordeal unless you adopt some form of numerical naming system for systems discovered. Not sure this should be changed but the ability to set cross galaxy waypoints might be a solution…?  I get loading resources in battle both on the ground and in space is a “real pain”, this could be fixed by Hello Games by introducing 'Automated Resource Loading Modules', again at a price and again scalable in keeping with the game. These modules when clicked could perhaps have 5 slots in which to specify resource load preference and of course would only work if you had the required resources in your inventory. It would be great if in game warnings told you when your resources where depleted with respect to these modules.  I get flying low is a bit hit and miss, Hello Games could easily fix this with both the ability to look down and hover (perhaps Look Down/Hover could be another Technology Module ...... this has been easily fixed at present by the modding community but what of the PS4 players no such luck …  I get the achievement screens pop up and get you killed potentially, these should be disabled if you are in combat, Hello Games should fix this …  However, when all said and done I am really enjoying this game and the challenge of collecting, analysing, fighting and exploring and hope Hello Games enhance it as they have promised to do so.

Then warp off into space and do it again in another system, following different paths through the universe based on storyline content, path to the center or fly into blackholes. So it's comical that people are giving a single player exploration game negative reviews because they wish it had real time multiplayer. Final edit until further notice:  After more consideration and ten hours of play, I still recommend but with some strong reservations. The other reviews stating 'a mile wide but an inch deep' seem to nail what this game has achieved. The amount of travel and random encounters on planets is staggering, but the immersion is limited greatly by the lack of understanding who you are, why it is you're jumping from galaxy to galaxy, and who the various sentient races are that you rarely encounter. One would think that in the vastness of space, especially in areas where there are strong Gek, etc. presences that small towns would be on the planets with some various quest lines (e.g. need 500 plutonium for my ship, etc.) However, one rarely runs into another sentient creature, and if one does, the dialgoue is limited to very, very few choices of selling and buying items or charging shields. No Man's Sky is a story about the search for god in a Dr. Seussian galaxy. The plot is revealed in engimatic fragments from a variety of sources, all profiling the dominant three races of the galaxy: the Gek, the Korvax, and the Vy'Keen. Through the often poetic accounts of their histories, you gleam tiny bits of knowledge of creation and its creator. The further you explore, the more you discover.   Overall, this is an incredible single-player experience. Some worlds are stark and inhospitable, others are paradigms of alien beauty. The story is one of wonder and truth, tackling some pretty big questions in lovely prose. It's a marvelous experience that is enhanced by crafting, pirate combat, language research, and more.  My main complaint is that I can't go back to worlds I've enjoyed most. There's no current way to navigate back to previously discovered destinations (unless you have incredible memory and superb navigational skills in a contextless void of stars).  If you want a multiplayer experience, you're out of luck. If you want a singleplayer spirit journey through the stars and across alien heavens and hells, this is your game.

It's finally here, after all the unasked for hype, and surprise, there is a barrage of players who decided not to 'spoil' themselves by actually reading about the game and are complaining about its gameplay not living up to their wild expectations, or who can't get the game to launch or have issues with a day 1 release of a game that was frenetically worked on until the last minute.   -Want some honesty?-  The game is good. If you are fortunate enough to be able to run the game without anything outright egregious in the way of bugs, it's pretty solid thusfar. I haven't yet actually left the planet I started on just because it's as interesting as I expected and I'm having an awful lot of fun just roaming around finding monuments that teach me an alien language word by word. I knew what I was getting into, because I read all the previews and watched footage showing me that the main game loop was specifically gathering the resources you need to survive and persist, and exploring environments discovering new animals and cultures and the remnants of older cultures, across different planets. This is exactly the kind of game I've always wanted, and insofar as what Hello Games actually promised the game would be like, they've actually delivered. They're apparently working on new features to add to the game as time goes on to increase its scope even more, but you'll get the most from this game if that basic idea of exploration and curiosities is what sates you. If you're like me, and you start a character in an MMO just to run across the worldmap trying to avoid high level enemies and see the environment for fun, this game is probably right for you.  The launch was bad. Because of their cram to really polish the ingame features they had and the feeling of how to introduce you to this world, they didn't give QA the oversight a game of this size desperately needs on the PC platform in particular. I have confidence they're working on fixing it- they pushed out patch 1.3 within the set of days between platform launches, and another patch was pushed out almost immediately on release to try and contain the damage. Yes, crash on launch bugs suck, and so do many of the other bugs they hadn't caught yet. That said, while the price point may have made this look especially bad to us, they're a small team who dealt with a lot of constraints all along the way from the announcement of the game to its delivery, and it's to be expected that there's QA teething issues on a platform as diverse as PC. It will get better over time- the future of their studio is at stake on this one so I really doubt they plan on pulling a WB.   -Will I have technical issues?-  If you have an AMD processor, you may want to check if it supports the SSE4.1 instruction set, because if it doesn't, the game will likely crash on launch at the time of this writing. This isn't that uncommon a bug, I can think of at least one other game that had this issue on launch without using many brain cells (MGSV: Ground Zeroes). It probably won't take too long to fix it but there's no harm in waiting to be safe.  If you have a graphics card that isn't reasonably new, you're treading on unsafe ground. This game is ambitious and tries to use a lot of close-to-cutting-edge features to get off the ground. OpenGL 4.5 support has been cited on twitter as a necessary requirement- what does this mean in practical terms? I can run the game on an AMD HD 7950- high end a few years ago but long before the Fury cards and the new RX series released. You absolutely need something recent and you probably can't skate by with even a mid range card as old as the one I cited. Even with my setup (intel i7 3770k, 16GB ram, HIS AMD HD 7950) I had to turn AA off and shadows to low with frame rate uncapped before the game started humming at a reasonable speed. Welcome to the next hardware generation folks.   Otherwise- update your drivers, be ready to search the steam forums for bugfixes, but give it a shot. If the game itself as I described it still interests you and you think you're going to get your hours of gameplay out of it for the price, it's certainly worth the plunge. Ignore the outrage addicts all over the store page right now- some are understandably upset and a little impatient but others are practically buzzards demanding a carcass of a game.

I rarely write reviews, but I thought I should write one here as the game is getting a lot of hate and is nearing the crash and burn stage now. And I need to say that there is some redeeming value to the game. For me, enough to give it an up vote.  Does the game deserve all the negativity? Or is it worth buying and playing? Well, it depends.  The game was overly hyped to the extreme. To the point that there was just no way it was going to live up to expectations. If you bought into all that hype, then likely the answer is no. If you go in not expecting too much after reading reviews, comment threads, and watching video and you still think you would like to experience it, then the answer might be yes.  What there is to do in the game is explore. That is pretty much it. If you're excited about the idea of flying around to different systems and landing on different planets and hoping that you will come across a unique and really cool landscape or discover a really cool creature, then you will have many hours of fun. If that doesn't excite you, you will probably not like it. There are other things to do, but they are very basic and very repetitive. Basically, besides exploring and discovering (the things that for me make the game worth it), here's what you can do:  Upgrade your space suit, upgrade your weapon/mining multitool or buy new improved versions, and upgrade your ship or buy or find new improved versions. Basically, there are no differences in ships except for the way they look and the number of available upgrade slots they have. Same with weapons.   Buy and sell stuff. This is very, very basic.   Learn the language of the 3 or 4 alien intelligences in the game.   You will occasionally get attacked by space pirates. This is always the same and the combat is very lame.  There is supposedly some kind of story going on there which you will only discover, I guess, by learning more of the alien languages. This has failed to excite me anymore than shooting rocks does.  Basically, to be honest, except for the exploring, the game will get very boring quickly, probably in less than 20 hours. I have 71 hours in and I am still finding very cool new things. This takes a lot of patience. It's a slow and chill type of game.   That's about it for now, that's what the game is, love it or hate it, or somewhere in between.

No Man's Sky was indeed an overhyped, super ambitious undertaking that could definitely go either way. Fans put a LOT of faith into the developers at Hello Games, considering the prepurchase price was, and still remains, $60(United States).  I went into this game like every other fanboy/girl, expecting above and beyond amazingness from a game that is, for all intents and purposes, cutting edge. It's pretty much what Minecraft wants to be, without the shelter building.  That being said, after 17ish hours of non-stop gameplay, what is my personal verdict?  Honestly, it WAS(codeword, WAS) going to be negative. I walked into the game expecting to build a shelter and fly into cliff sides and fly into suns and generally being a complete ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥ in the beginning of the game before I got serious, but to my stunned surprise, I was able to do none of these things! I also just generally felt the game was very linear and sort of uninspiring in terms of what your ultimate goal is! I mean, you start the game, and then you're on your own! The lack of tutorial is a very bitter/sweet concept, since it can leave one feeling very immersed, true, but also very hopeless. This game definitely caters more to the young adult - adult audience, whereas the younger preteen audience might get really annoyed really quickly due to the lack of how-to in the game.  However, after playing it a bit more, getting a hold of those pesky how-to ropes a bit more firmly, and experimenting a bit with where to go and how to do things, I've come to discover that this game is a definite diamond in the rough. It is an entirely new game, released just 2 days before this review was written, and it's already at only 58% positive out of 33.5k user reviews. That is INSANELY premature, and I wish people would lay off the thumbs down button until the developpers have had a chance to catch up with the demands being launched at them post-release. With all that considered, No Man's Sky does exactly what it advertises; you get to explore the biggest game world ever created, with over 18.6 quintillion(18.600.000.000.000.000.000) planets, and you get to name the things you discover. As of right now, the game is still incredibly early in its development, and as far as I've heard, the next major update is going to be somewhere around 22 gigabyte in size. As in, a TON of new stuff is gonna get added periodically.  That being said, the graphics are fantastic, a bit campy, but to be expected, considering how huge the game is and with no blatant in-your-face loading screens to speak of, and the game runs smooth as butter. I have yet to crash, even once, which to me is the telltale sign of a well put together, structurally sound game.  So please, ignore all of these premature naysayers who seem to complain about everything from lack of multiplayer, to lack of shelter building, to lack of content and lack of general fun and games. Take the game as it is, and realize that all of this and more will for sure be added in due time. Patience is a virtue! :)

***Potential Spoilers***  I was recently asked, 'How was Survival mode?' The following was my response:  Wonderfully humbling. At the end of two hours play, I found myself in a hollowed out chunk of Iridium, watching as the last 5% of my life support ticked away - praying that my toxic protection recharged fast enough to book it back to my broken ship (which, by the way, I started a 14 minute hike away from), hoping that a bug/crab wouldn't notice me and continue to eat my face. I managed to get to the hunk-of-junk with one piece of health, no supplies (if you die you lose all materials AND some piece of equipment breaks), no toxic protection, and no life support (you can sit in your cockpit and you don't need life support, but it doesn't recharge either). I finally decided I couldn't leave, repair my ship, or repair an equipment - so I popped the hatch and let the acid rain corrode my suit, falling to the ground and towards the waiting crab-a**holes.  It was the most fun I've had in NMS since the first few hours after unboxing it. One mistake can cost you dearly and every choice matters. I found myself leaving or ignoring Gold/Iridium/Emeril for desperate searches of Thamium9 (grab every piece you can!). Lastly, with the latest patch my PC went from being able to run the game on middling graphic settings and cranking out the heat, to all settings maxed out (excluding AA) and having my laptop purr. Great update, beautiful game, good work HG. At $60 I was happy with NMS - which met my $1/hour gameplay ratio and being one of the few games I could play with all members of the family. At the current price point(s) its hard not to recommend this game.   P.s. With three modes it gives our family multiple 'profiles' for people to play: my eldest - Normal, me - Survival, and my middle child - Creative. Thank you again to the Hello Games team!

I have not experienced what everyone else is. Frame rate is staying steady around 60fps, hasn't crashed. Only problem that I've been experiencing is the fact I cannot ALT+Tab back into the game.  My specs if you are wondering: 980ti, 32 gb ddr3, 4790k @ 4.8. Game is stored on an nVME SSD as well.  Settings are all maxed out, 2560x1440p vSync at 60fps.  Onto the game itself:  Yes, is somewhat repetitive, but still an amazing game. I've explored 10 or so different systems and around 20 planets, yet, always running into something new. Planets are amazing in terms of procedurally generated terrain. The caves I've entered so far aren't really in depth. Only go a few feet to the end. Overall: 8.5/10 Reason: Somewhat repetitive, bad launch day for most players.

Yes, true, NMS did not meet the expectations, everybody has before release. It is receiving quite a bit of bashing right now.  So why do i upvote for this game?  In my opinion the basic game mechanics are brilliant. The transitions from planet ground to orbit, from orbital space to other orbital space, from orbital space to different systems are remarkably well done. I see NMS as THE main engine which any SciFi game should have as a base engine.  I have spent 40+ hours right now on it and it actually was much fun to explore the mechanics, to develop a better ship and suit, to explore the given surroundings ... and just move on, when it starts to get boring. For me, s.th. interesting happens all the time.  Besides that NMS has its shortcomings, no doubt about it. There is almost no catchy mission system in there. Much relies on the little storage space your're given in the ship and suit. What I don't understand here is, that they did not implement some basics that, for instance, the original Elite (I mean the version for the C64 from some decades ago...) already has, like a tradechart, where you con compare prices of goods on other planets, or lootable wreckage after won dogfights and most of all, a tight, yet easy to embed storyline. Elite had all that, it was not that much of an effort to do that and made the major difference in terms of 'fun, playing a game'. The NMS engine virtually shouts 'hey here, put that in', as it was made for such enhancements. Even more not understandable why that is not in the first release.  Anyway, what should happen now in my opinion: They should bring the graphics to a current level. Any further NMS game would not be accepted, especially after the hype, w.o. any decent graphics. This would not bring any advantages, it would just make the engine fit for the next shot. Then the game should have at least a mission line as the original Elite has it. This should be piece of cake, since they humbly tried to embed such a thing (but failed). The latter also means, that those people, that did the current 'missions' should not be allowed to have a hand on such a mission redisign. Even if meant well, or done by people whose job is not usually to produce missions (I expect both to be true for the current release), it is obvious, that nothing good comes out of it. After that, bring NMS2. This should be the game, we all wanted.  Nevertheless and after such a critique, I keep with my upvote. Besides all the missing an lacking mechanics it is a good SciFi engine and 'playing' the game is soothing and nice to look at. It just has no real goal. But after 40+ hours it seems, that it still is enjoyable. If your're a fan of the genre you can buy the game without regret.

I'll be totally honest with you, weary traveler of the review section...  This game is wonderful. Really unique and wonderful. However THIS IS ONLY IF YOU ENJOY IT FOR THE REASONS I DO.   These reasons are: infinite exploration, fairly simple mechanics, great for roleplaying as a pirate, or a merchant, whatever you like. Beautiful and lonely/desolate atmosphere that really creates a sense of loneliness.   A few basic cons: The combat is basic, nothing special, but I admit it's pretty fun to face off against a ♥♥♥♥ ton of sentinels when you're trying to grab rare items. Flying across planets can be a bit gimicky, your ship has a set level it has to be above the ground, it can go higher, but it cant go too low. Which can complicate landing precision. Meeting the various aliens in the universe is a pretty mundane task, either giving you resources or blueprints (or sometimes a slap). Learning the languages of the three species is a task that feels even more pointless and convoluted than the riddler challenges from the arkham series.  But I have to say, the thing that both causes me endless wonder, as well as endless depression/and/or/nostalgia/regret is leaving a system. Knowing I will probably NEVER return to those planets is honestly a pretty strange feeling that I both hate and enjoy.   Important note: I did NOT go into this game WANTING multiplayer, I did NOT go into this game wanting to be able to build houses. I did NOT climb aboard the hype train of this game. And because of that, I was satisfied. Was it worth the $60? eh, maybe not. But I have found possibly the best time-filling game of my entire career as a gamer. And for that, I'm grateful.

What can I say. If you overhyped and bought the game and you don't like it now, it is your fault. If you want a refund after spending more than two hours in game, you are a theif. And if you think it is sean murrays fault for 'lying', you are kind of wrong.  There is two sides to developing the game: The Devs and The Buissness (Lets call them the suits)  The suits say 'You need to get the game out for <Insert date here>' The devs say 'We can do that if no problems spring up'  And of course, as is the way with code and something complicated, problems will spring up The Devs will say 'We can't get this out, you need to give us more time to refine everything and flatten out the bugs with the big things like multiplayer' And the Suits will say 'No, you said you could get it out for now so you have to relese it now. Just put the things you have finished on the disk'  And so content gets cut from the day 1 relese. Everyone gets mad and people start throwing acusations without solid evidence. This is how it works, you just have to accept it and move on.  Now on to the big question: Do I recommend the game?  Yes.  If you want multiplayer it might be a bit of a wait but the wait should be worth it in the end. Just wait for new updates is all i am saying and don't be so hard on a man who wanted to share a dream with the world that got badly receved because of time constraints.

130 hours so far, just completed the Path of Atlas and felt like I rushed it, still haven't gotten to the center of the galaxy. This game is beautiful. I have platform jetpacked to the highest floating mountain of copper and seen planetrise over an irradiated desert while the storm raged. I have dove under alien seas and followed coral bedecked caves that continued deeper than my materials could replenish my air supplies. I have been ambushed by stout hawk beaked owl bears while mining plutonium in a red toxic jungle. I piloted my fighter barely limping into the atmosphere of a paradise planet after barely surviving a dogfight against more than a dozen pirates attacking a Korvax freighter convoy. I found a shining ball in the ice field of a frozen moon and had to fight off ruthless automatons who took issue with my plunder. I have found respite from heat storms in a cave I found by blasting through the surface with grenades, only to be swarmed by skittering monstrosities. I have learned the ancient secrets of the rise and fall of civilizations from cyclopean monoliths. I have found the logs of long dead travellers that described their demise at the hands eldritch horrors and gleaned new technology from them. I've salvaged new ships from distress signals alive long after the death of their senders. And I have not yet finished my explorations.

No Man's Sky is a difficult game to discuss. Thanks to the insane amount of hype and huge expectations for the game, it's almost impossible to start talking about this game in any way but by saying what it is NOT.  It is NOT a simulator. It is NOT an MMO. It is NOT a game with structure or direction. It does NOT have a 'story' to experience or an ending, though it does have a smattering lore that you can stumble upon.  No Man's Sky is often dismissively called a 'screenshot generator.' That's pretty true - and not necessarily a bad thing. What else is the game?  It's an exploration game that uses procedural generation. The best way to think of NMS's procgen is as 'riffs on a theme.' There's a cool looking hippo thing. On another planet, it might have horns. On another, it might be flying. On another, it might want to eat you. But all its creatures are variations of a base.  Same goes for the planets: there are dead planets and lush planets and toxic mushroom planets. Some have moons. Some are flat, some are not.  If you're thinking, 'Wow, that sounds boring...' then congratulations! This game is not for you.  But for those of you who think it might be cool to wander around on a toxic mushroom planet with weird flying hippo things for a little bit, No Man's Sky is an incredibly chill game. It helps me calm down after work. I've gotten in the habit of firing it up for an hour at the end of the day just to clear my mind and shake off work stress. It works wonders for that.

I understand that this game is not for everyone (mostly about exploration and discovering new things) and the game as I see it is closest in play style is Cubeworld (another very additive exploration game which you just simply explore to your hearts content). Obviously right now No Mans Sky has much more depth (in my opinion) than Cubeworld (obviously completely different settings/enviroments) however they have both nail the exploration aspect spot on and if you just want to get away from multiplayer games for a while this is an ideal vacation. I am really interested to see what they do next (and yes I know multiplayer and large freighters are maybe coming but I am more interested in the things that they dont announce :-)). I hope this helps explain this game to other potential explorers out there.

If you buy No Man's Sky, you're either going to love it, or you're going to hate it. Doesn't seem like there's much middle ground with this game.   For what it is, I still enjoy coming back to No Man's Sky. This was my first day back after having not played for several weeks. Dropping back into it, I was surprised to find that I'm still driven to explore these worlds. I thought maybe after collecting all the achievements I'd be done with it, but I still enjoy fixing up my ship, and bouncing around the galaxy. For me, there are still things to do, and places to see.  If you like to wander and explore at your own pace, you might enjoy this game too. For me, the most exhilerating aspect of No Man's Sky would have to be the freedom of direction, and knowing that any place you go will never be quite like the places you've been.  At first, I was disapointed, like most people were when the game didn't hold up to the hype or match the quality of the screenshots and gameplay footage used in the marketing materials for the game. At the same time though, I have to admit that the environments in No Man's Sky are still just as stunning, if not as polished. Sometimes the details are subtle, and can be slow to surface. For instance, some of these worlds are more desolate than others. Given a chance though, even the most desolate of them have managed to surprise me in one way or another. In the end, if it turns out a planet just doesn't interest you, the next one is only a minute or two away.  Despite whatever shortcomings the game may have, I think No Man's Sky is a worthwhile experience. For the time I've sunk into it, I feel like I got my 60 bucks worth out of it.

First off, this isn't my final review I'll be doing on No man's sky. I've only got 20 glorious hours under my belt so far, even though I'm wearing shorts, and I'd like to come back to review it again at 100 hours, later in the future (Honestly, probably a week or two)  KNOWN ISSUES **IMPORTANT**: There are many issues as the game has been out only 6 days (from writing this first review), as to be expected for games like NMS. Please go check out the steam community and read up on work arounds to figure out if you even want to consider this game. I personally was lucky to be able to run it right off the bat, and hopefully these issues are fixed soon!   No mans sky is the incredibly hyped game created by HelloGames, a small team who generated a universe only costing the space of a whopping 2.5 gigabytes (with no updates or DLC included in this number). There isn't a forced goal in this game, only a guide towards the 'Center of the galaxy' in which a promising reward awaits to those who can travel there. You will be crafting, and mining resources very often to help aid your journey if you decide to either free roam and discover, or follow a very thin line between star systems similar to a GTA style GPS system to the center giving you the best calculated path. You will also be surviving in harsh conditions on both barren and flourishing planets while being careful of the wildlife including plants, and the dangerous sentinel race watching you almost constantly.   HYPE: Hype didn't kill the game, it just seriously hindered it. I've known of the game for a little over a year, maybe 2, and my appreciation for what Sean Murray and his team were doing grew as I read more and more about the game, watching Sean change words every so often or change his mind about features, this game has been a sort of placeholder in this year for me, as I looked forward to it's releasing so much. The thing about hype though is that, like old memories, some people put their own images in their heads and warp details about the game to their liking rather than accept it for what it is early on, and build on the image they've created, sometimes even sharing it and putting it into others minds. For No man's sky, possibly the most hyped game ever created in quite a long time, this was really dangerous.   GAMEPLAY: Collecting resources= A+ Trading= B- (Not a fan of switching things out of your ship into your inventory to sell) Crafting= B+ Exploration= A Quality/Graphics= A+ (This game if you can start it up, runs fairly smooth on high settings, and can run on most PCs I'd say made in the last 3 years) Movement= C+ (Moving can actually become quite bothersome and slow, but there are techs in the game to assist in this)  You'll be flying and spot things you want to visit on your way to visit something and end up visiting those things before visiting that other thing you originally had planned to visit. This is 99% of planet travel, you experience a lot of 'Ooo, shiny!' moments playing this game. The writing for events when arriving at certain places you can interact with, is genious and beautiful, reminding me of the writing for notes in the Amnesia series. There is also a large puzzle element in NMS that I'm sure players who like being given choices can appreciate.   PROMISES: I'll go and say right now that ever since being listed on steam, even before pre purchase, this game was considered a singleplayer when viewing the games details, even if Sean was saying players could see eachother. Maybe people took Seans word over steams which in all honesty makes sense, but I was fine with either outcome. Many people had valid resources stating that Sean changed what he said, and many did not, using websites that almost seemed like gossip rather than factual material. With multiplayer, I can agree it'd be nice to see others and show off your ship, and a few friends and I are hoping that at some point, the game does allow this. You should all know that from the looks of it, Sean seems to be a little bit of a softy for players ideas, and I'm sure with popular demand, things will be added in just like Construction and Freighter building will be in the near future (Confirmed by Sean Murray).    MY OPINION: The games incredible, exciting at times, and relaxing.  I can't say I've heard of people paying $60 dollars or more towards a game simply to experience these 3 things. Thats the issue with hype once again is that people expected it to be more, but it's really what you make of it, not what they give you. 'It's an experience to be had' has become a favorite quote of mine for the game, and I can agree that even while collecting and crafting can get frustrating, I haven't gone more than 8 hours without playing this game a good 2 inbetween without a break. I fully recommend the game for what it is and I congragulate HelloGames and creating a masterpiece in my eyes.   If you don't think you'll enjoy it, then check out the other similar options, no need to bash the developers seeing as floods, death threats, delays and lawsuits all in 3 years have already made them feel terrible I can assume. Find somewhere to post and send in ideas for the game, wait and see if they're added, drink some Tea or Coffee, and enjoy some other games while you wait.  I hope my review was of some help, sorry for the length, Enjoy.  ~Blue Jay
