So i have played this game for about 100h+ now (i was offline for a long time, steam playtime is glitchy), and i think i am ready to write a review about it. So here i go  First of all, i enjoy playing this game in the current state, and i am one of the few that actually like it. Now the gameplay, people always confuse this as an mmo or a multiplayer game. It isn't. And it wasn't meant to be. If you followed hellogames, you would know that the chance of meeting another player is really rare. Like REALLY. And that scandal with two players meeting and not seeing each other can be simply explained. In a podcast, Sean Murray said that each player is put in a 4 person lobby, and those 4 players he is able to see, the others are not. Much like in elite dangerous, you are not able to see others, because you are on a different server or lobby, same goes here. If one of them might have logged of and back in i think in a few tries they would have able to see each other. So this theory is busted. Now the factions. I agree, it is a missing feature. But it is not a reason the quit the game, because it wasn't meant to be a faction vs faction war game. It was meant to be an exploration game. I do NOT doubt that factions WILL come in a few updates, but it is sad that they aren't already in the game. Epic space battles are a thing, it is called a distress signal, but you can only help out the freighters. And even if you kill almost all the pirates, a few missed shots that hit the freighters would turn that battle into a free-for-all deathmatch. I think it is just a bug really. Now, people always say this game is dull exploration wise. I can deny that, visited hundreds of planets and i never see anything anything very simmilar to each other. The more you explore, get close too the center, the more cool stuff you will see. And it is not the 'same sh!%' over and over, it's new all the time, trust me i know. Now ships never stop to amaze me. They are all different in their looks, that is the missing feature of most of the space games, ship variations that is. Ship classes maybie know as a missing feature, but if you look from an another perspective, it isn't. I have found out that most of the trade ships are slow, but their weapons are powerfull. Also they have more health then other ships. The fighters are fast and deadly, but have low health. Science ships are good for exploration, they are small and they are fast, good shields. And all of that are just natural things ships provide you without any upgrades on them. I dislike the fact that all types of ships can carry the same amount of resources, and have 48 slots, but maybie it will change in a few updates. Now when buying a ship, fighters do not get 48 slots, but the big traders do. So maybie ships are for buying, not found crashed. Capital vs capital ship combat might come when the ability to own a freighter is released. Hellogames are trying their hardest to work on these FREE updates, to include more content and have the missing features back in the game. Music of this game is the best i have ever seen, and i have to give a thanks for 65DOS for making such a great soundtrack. Portals aren't working, but HG said that they removed some features that caused crashing, maybie in the future we will see them. Also there are alot of people saying there aren't big dinosaurs and food chains. I can deny that, i have seen animals go up to water, drink the water, and then go explore with their herd. I have seen an animal almost the exact size of that dinosaur of the e3 2014 trailer, not to mention there is a mod to make animals even bigger. Now fish might be very small, other big fish are always preditors as far as i am concerned about this, but i haven't explored all of the planets, i can't say there aren't big herbivore fish. The caves are also a problem, because they are said to have rare resources in them, but are on every planet with only a few resources. I think the caves will be more usefull later, to find iron for the new base building feature coming up, so that fixes it. I can really say this game isn't a grind or a game with an ending. It's about exploration, you can't expect a game of this size to end. The universe is wast and unexplored, so go for it. I am putting my trust in hellogames and the community to resolve the missing features and lack of content, but for now i will give this game a 8/10. We will just have to wait and see how it will turn out with content added. Till then folks

I WANT A REFUND TOO!!!  Just joking :D though.  I just want to write a review to level out all the negative reviews this game has had all this time.  I believe that people who got dissapointed were gamers that didn't know what to expect from the game. Its a Game for starters! It's bound to have limitations. However most people actually wanted everything: They wanted to get the first proceduraly generated, acurately simulated, space exploration, flight simulator, Rpg MMO, first person shooter...  I mean... c'mon now!  For me the game was a my personal gamer's dream: An immense world to explore in and It feels like that: Immense.  Of course there are some inconsistencies: for example the developers claim that the world is so huge that it's improbable to meet another person, but the most planets that you come across have aliens and structures on them! In reality though, in an 18-Quantilion-planets-universe, it's really hard to find a planet that is suitable for life, let alone one that contains inteligent life, or even aliens. Take our solar system for instance. Only one out of the tens of significantly big celestial bodies that revolve around the sun actually carries life. Even at that analogy, life (or aliens) should be availabe only on one out of 50 planets available in no mans sky! And that is by taking for granted that at least one planet of each solar system contains life.  If you wanted to be that accurate though, you'd create a boring game. But it's a game. So game elements need to take priority here so that it's not boring.  Many people claim that Rodina is better but... Rodina has only 4 planets! The only thing proceduraly generated there is each planet's anaglyph. There is no vegetation or special surface stuff like water or rocks or similar. Rodina is nowhere close to NMS.  Having put that out of the way with all the Liars anti campain which I personally found annoying, I have to say that it's a great game! It's huge, and gives room for a lot of exploring which I personally love.  Improvements could be released of course. For example ship interriors could be added. That way you could get up and walk around in your ship (yes... that is the only part that Rodina is better than NMS)  I believe that part of the fact that I am happy with the game is due to the fact that I didn't follow all that pre-release hype. I learned about the game about a week after it had been released and watched a couple of in game review videos before buying... Maybe that's a good practice for people to follow when buying games. Wait till they are released and then watch a video or two before deciding...  Hope you enjoy the game. I did and still do.

Considering the size of the team which created this game it's pretty amazing they managed to create something of this magnitude. I think something a lot of people fail to appreciate is that the developers of No Man's Sky are pioneers in the field of procedurally generated environments. I'm sure many games in the future will learn from the model variation techniques used by NMS and now that a small development team has shown it's possible to generate an entire universe with procedural techniques we know it's not an impossible task.  Is the gameplay kind of shallow and repetitive? Sure, I wont deny that, and I was hoping it might have been a bit more detailed, but if you just want a fun exploration experience then I would recommend this game. Do I think it's worth the price? Until we get more updates to iron out all the bugs and add some more features to the game, I don't think the current price can be justified. But it's their game and I can't really blame them for cashing in on all the hype. I'm willing to pay the given price just because of the technical innovation it contains.  I think the main reason many people are annoyed with this game is because they were expecting something that wasn't such a single player experience. They were told they could at least see other players if they were in the same place but it turns out that isn't true. It's not shocking that isn't true since creating a MMO is never really what they set out to do and they never tried to portray the game that way. There's also a bunch of networking problems that come into play when you start turning it into a multi-player experience.  As it stands I'm not really sure that allowing players to see each other would really add anything to the game at the end of the day. I think the best development path for this game is to just accept it as a single player game and add features which help that single player experience. I heard something about the developers wanting to add base building, and my question to that is: wouldn't that completely go against the exploration nature of this game? Why would we want to settle down in one spot when we have the whole universe to explore?  One advantage of this game being a single player experience is that modders have a lot more freedom in what they can change about the game. Finally, I think people are exaggerating just how pointless this game seems. Players shouldn't expect hand holding in a huge open universe. Rust is an extremely popular game (and a another example of why procedural worlds are awesome), yet the progress of everyone is wiped away every few weeks and they all have to start over again. It's the most pointless thing I've ever seen yet I find myself continuing to play Rust.  Pros:  * Every planet is quite unique, I haven't come across similar looking creatures too many times and I still have the sense that I've only seen a small fraction of what the game has to offer after playing for 50 hours. * The color schemes are very beautiful and give the game a very fantasy sci-fi feel. If you prefer a realistic space experience then this feature may not appeal to you. * The algorithm which decides positions of grass and plants and things like that seems to be pretty well designed. Some planets, such as tropical planets, can look quite breath taking, and knowing you're the first person to see it makes it even better. * The terrain generation seems to be very well done apart from the odd floating land mass, although I think that is intentional in most cases because it's shown in the trailer and copper is commonly just floating in the air. * In particular, I find the cave systems to be very interesting and well positioned. Cave systems can be very large and complex, with multiple exits and entrances. I'm fairly sure they don't use any cave models, it's all procedurally generated. * Another nice feature about caves is that they protect you from harsh conditions. You can even blast holes in the terrain to create your own cave and the engine will still detect that you're under cover even though the cave is dynamically created. * The alien language system is fairly ingenious I think, I'm guessing they use a dictionary file to generate alien variants of every English word. Some people seem to think it takes too long to collect enough words, but I think it's a good challenge. * The music is very well done, it fits the game nicely and enhances the atmosphere a lot. I also read some of the music is procedurally generated, which is pretty cool. * The writing is pretty decent. That may seem like a strange thing to say since there's no real story line to speak of but there's actually quite a bit of reading in the game and it meshes well with the vibe of the game. * Overall I think NMS has done what it set out to do but it clearly has a lot of untapped potential. It's impossible to please everyone and some people simply don't enjoy exploration games. I'm sure it will get boring eventually but for now I'm still enjoying all the sights on my journey to the center of the galaxy.  Cons:  * Variety of structures is very limited, once you've seen a few buildings you've basically seen them all. Definitely needs some improvement here I think. * Too many structures on most planets imo. It shouldn't take 2 seconds before coming across another structure after just finding one. It takes the magic away from finding a structure when there's so damn many. * When it comes to structures, I think the type and amount of structures should depend on how civilized the planet is. For example some planets could have large cities with sky scrapers and large trading centers. * Sentinels do seem a bit too pervasive, I'm not sure if I've seen a single planet without them so far. Like structures, I don't think they should be so common, and should be non-existent on many planets, especially barren ones. * The physics doesn't seem as realistic as it should be. For example larger planets don't appear to have a stronger gravitational force which acts on the player or ship. * Many people seem to think that all starships behave exactly the same way despite size or shape, from what I can tell there does seem to be slight maneuvering advantages with better ships, I could be wrong though. * The fact that all alien NPC's just seem to stand there is kind of annoying. I mean there is AI for other ships but the inside of a space station could feel much more immersive if NPC's were walking around and doing stuff. It would also be kind of cool to see some aliens mining resources on planets rather than just flying around. * I've heard people say too many planets are barren and boring, but I think the opposite is true. Most planets have some form of life, which is completely opposite to real life and highly unbelievable. If planets with creatures were harder to find then it would make finding them much more thrilling. * When buying a new ship, you shouldn't have to pay the full price and then abandon your old ship, it makes no sense. You should be able to sell your old ship or exchange it for another ship. * Solar system mechanics are rather simplistic, I don't think planets can have rings around them and there isn't things like asteroid belts, asteroids are just everywhere in space.

Launched the game only expecting what the trailers and interviews gave in-vision for the release.  I found No Man's Sky to be quite relaxing but also entertaining with suprises as I discovered new planet types, species, plants and elements.  Learning about the Atlas and Korvax Primes definitely caught my scifi attention. Deciding on whether I wanted to continue learning how to speak GEK or Vy'keen was tough. GEK seem to have stupid but funny things to say, but the Vy'keen were talking to me about displaying honor to aliens and giving me tips in space combat.  As I continued to upgrade my exosuit and multi-tool, learning that the multi-tool could be a semi-auto, full auto or shotgun was quite cool. Maxing out my exosuit with all the weather conditions was awesome, being able to jetpack around on planets for so long, not having to worry, just exploring.  Reaching what appeared to be my destiny, the center of my galaxy. I was expecting something way out of the ordinary, a twist or something. But I was simply 're-born' upon another galaxy. I do recall reading Korvax passages about portals providing a second chance, maybe they meant the result of reaching the center of the galaxy?  Not being able to choose a side between GEK or Vy'keen and fly along side them protecting freighters was a bit of a let down. Only having the opportunity to take on up to 12 pirates at a time, which became to easy once I maxed out my Phase Beam. I would like to thank a Vy'keen Captain for that starship combat information.  No desert worms were sighted during my travels. Reaching every solar system type, I believe I have now seen it all. Mastering many planets and moons along the way, even a few black holes! Finishing off my max-slot starship as a fighter.  I was hoping that one day I meet Hirk, only to find out Hirk was killed before all this even began. Thanks.

TL;DR: Ignore the hype. Wait for it to go on sale.  This game bears many similarities in both theme and mechanics to a little mobile/PC game called 'Out There'. If you enjoyed that, you will probably enjoy No Man's Sky, as it's basically an immersive 3d-version of it.  The primary gameplay loop involves entering a system, exploring planets for blueprints, materials, derelicts, and attempting to communicate with aliens. It's a very chill game where you just sort of wander about looking at the procedurally generated sights, and slowly upgrading your equipment. There's a general questline for you to follow given to you by unknown entities, which is intruiging, but the payoff is somewhat disappointing.  Unfortunately, there is not really a lot of content variety here. You will probably see all there is to see in a dozen or so hours, and there's not much reason to keep playing after that. I would probably recommend waiting for it to go on sale for that reason alone.  If you followed the hype on this game until release, then you will be disappointed regardless on what the game actually ended up being... Hello Games did a VERY poor job of managing consumer expectations on this one. It got to the point where media outlets were calling it an MMO-minecraft-alike-in-space-with-EVE-elements, which is an impossible dream that couldn't be further from the truth. This is a solely single-player experience by an indy developer, and shouldn't be judged as anything but that.

Obviously most people don't like the game, or are just parroting other people's remarks in the reviews to join in the hate. Whatever. Here are the things that I enjoy and don't enjoy about No Man's Sky.    Pros:    Lots of planets. After exploring over 30 different planets, so far all of them have been unique in their own way. In a game with so many planets, it's entirely possible you could start out somewhere where the worlds around you all look the same. Maybe I just got lucky.    Relaxing. After a long day at work, it's nice to come home and jump in a spaceship and warp into a new system, or land on a new world. I like seeing a cave and wandering into it to find that it's a deep network of tunnels running through a large area of the planet. I like island-hopping on an ocean world, or running from the sentinels as I steal precious albumen pearls. I like exiting a world and seeing freighters and frigates warp in from another system, regardless of it happens pretty much all the time. It adds to the experience.    Great soundtrack. The music really adds to the atmosphere of this game.    Great sense of scale. Some mountains, and some rock formations, really make you feel puny on some worlds. There are also tiny moons that take a couple minutes to fly around, and planets that would take you a while day to fly around if you're flying at surface level.    Flying in your spaceship is pretty cool. Occasionally you'll get into dogfights in space. I've ran from a fight down to the surface of a world for a few hours, and then gone back into space and the pirates were still waiting for me, that was pretty neat.    Art direction. I like the attention to detail in the different alien races, the buildings, the different ruins, the little touches on certain plants or animals. Ship designs are also pretty cool.    Puzzles. I like the math puzzles that appear for some of the buildings you go into. Some of them you start to recognize after doing them a few times, but it's a nice touch and I hope they add more elaborate ones in the future.    No multiplayer. I don't need some brat following me world to world and trying to shoot me down and won't leave me alone.    Runs smoothly. I heard there were a lot of issues getting the game to work properly for lots of people. I have a GTX 950, 16 GB RAM, and 500 PSU. Haven't had one single issue with this game. Again, maybe I'm just lucky. Or maybe people thought they could play this on their Famicom.    Cons (suggestions really)    Can't board freighters and frigates.    I want to see the frigates and freighters get destroyed slowly by space pirates if I do nothing. I'd like to see the big ships fight back against the pirates. Which brings me to my main issue.    I'd like to see more life instilled into the game. I like exploring a world and getting that desolate feeling that I'm the only one there exploring it. But I don't like going to a space port where ships are arriving constantly, but no one gets out. The chairs in the lobby are empty. No one else walks in and makes small talk with the Gek at the front desk of a outpost. There are no aliens sleeping at one of the camps you'll find. The ships coming and going is a nice touch, as are the bigger ships warping in, or small ships flying overhead while you're exploring, but it doesn't go that extra mile that you'd find in a polished product, I believe.    More alien variety. This goes for the races you can talk to, and the ones you scan. Every once in a while you'll spot something unique, but usually they tend to follow a similar bone structure. This game could be any 3D modeler or texture artist's dream! But it doesn't push it enough.    No fights with the locals. Let me stir something up with the Gek that tries to pull a fast one on me with selling some cheap piece of junk. I don't care if the sentinels come in and torch me, but I would like more challenge. It's fun when you arrive on a high security world and get attacked for messing with anything or simply breathing in the vicinity of a sentinel. I'd like to see better AI and more versions of the sentinels. I'd like to see the alien races get up out of their chairs and pull out a gun and get into a fight with you, and maybe they have shields of their own.    More treasures and things you can sell, and maybe create some sort of hub where players can upload really rare artifacts they found while exploring that other players can look at when they access the trade network. You emphasize showing off discovered worlds and species, but how about the other things we find like trinkets, or camps or ruins even?    More technologies. Again, sky is the limit! A gun that sprays lasers in all directions, or shoots electricity, or turns into an underwater scooter that lets you swim faster, I don't know.    Learning the language should help you communicate with locals that are sitting around the trade port and maybe they point you in the direction of something interesting on the world you're on.   In the end, it doesn't feel finished. I wouldn't recommend it for $60 right now. I don't disagree with the 5/10 score, though I might rate it a 6 just because I find myself enjoying what's there so far. I do recommend it if you enjoy space games and flying around in your own ship and just landing on a new world to see what's there. Not every world will be a winner, but landing on the ones that are make the journey worth it.

This game is really not for anyone, at least not with the current list of features. For me i's a really good way to let go of the stress of my work. No Man's Sky opens up really slowly. But it opens up if you slow down to it's pace. Like a really good, slow conversation with one close friend and a few beers. Like reading a book from Tolkien or Asimov. Yes, it could be more varied...but i'm a biologist and even in the real life variety i see the repetition. Yes it could be more streamlined...but Earth 2150 was blocky in every meaning and i love it. Just like NMS. (Maybe i am this positive towards the game because i have seen almost zero major bugs, and only had 2 or 3 crashes. No major FPS-drops either altough i play it on a Dell notebook.) While i have problems with the way HG (not) communicated with the would-be playerbase, i really don't think they lied more than any advertising does. It doesn't make it right...actions can make it right. Bugfixing, adding features for free, and listening to the diminished playerbase. And they seem to doing this. So, if you want a faster, more varied game, then wait. If you really like old Sci-fi cover art AND don't mind the snail-pace then give it a (long) try.

I've heard all the ♥♥♥♥♥ing and moaning about how this game isn't what it was supposed to be. After all of that one might wonder why I bothered with it at all but if I learned anything from my late Son it is this. Make up your own mind. Don't listen to critics or wannabes so here I am with my own opinion. Some may not like it. Even more may think I don't know what I'm talking about. Still others may consider me an idiot but I don't really give a rat's ♥♥♥. I am simply putting my two cents in the mix. With that said here is No Man's Sky the way I see it.  It must be hard to describe a game like this without coming off either as a lyer or stupid. The simple fact is nobody has ever done anything even remotely similar so no wonder the creators and spokesmen had such a hard time and have been the blame for everyone's gripes. 'No Man's Sky' is a multyplayer! No it's not! It has this issue! It has that problem It's nothing like those jerks said it would be! It's boring! I thought the graphics would be better. These are just a few of the complaints people have come up with troling the game before they've even played more than a few hours. I think like any open sandbox game there are going to be a few bugs the best way to get rid of is to let people play and stand back and watch. Maybe Hello Games could have spent a little more time fixing a few bugs but people were already ♥♥♥♥♥ing about it being delayed so who's to blame for it being released with a bug or two, certainly not Hello Games.   As far as bugs go most of those I've heard or read about have turned out to be simple fixes that had more to do with the capabilities of the pc or play station running it. My own pc isn't all that new and yet I've not had a single problem I wasn't capable of fixing myself with a little help from a friend and a bit of tweaking. The only bug I heard about that wasn't easily fixed was when a player complained a creature had a horn for a head and no way to feed it's self and no way to breathe. If your gonna be that picky go play Mario or some other of the like that won't over tax your high standards.   Other complaints were that the game didn't have everything the creators said it would . How does anyone know what the game has in store for them if they haven't even played more than a few hours and I wanna know how the guy who claimed to have beaten the game in what has got to be an impossiblly short amount of time managed to do that because I've been playing quite a few hours since friday August 12th at eleven am and I see no way it could have been done without cheating and if one is gonna do that before even bothering to give the game a chance he doesn't deserve to be heard in the first place. Oh,!, and by the way how much did he pay to get an early copy? I am reminded of the phrase 'More money than brains'.  'They talked the game up so much that it was no wonder people were disapointed' I'd like to ask those who said this do you have a life? I, myself have more important things to do than to waste my time in front of a pc reading, watching, listening to everything the web inundates us with concerning who knows how many new games out there. Do I think it may have been a bit over hyped, yeah, maybe but I didn't sit here on my pc sucking it all in. I have places to go and things to do.  'The game is boring.' Ok, it's not 'STALKER' It's not 'Metro', it isn't 'Doom' Wolfenstein' or 'Call Of Duty'. It wasn't meant to be and if you seriously thought it was then you need to go back and spend another useless forty or so hours watching listening and reading all the crap that is still out there. Only this time pay attention. No Man's Sky is an action, adventure, survival, exploration game and nowhere have I seen the words first person shooter. I admit I wasn't sure myself why the word action was used in describing this game but I have to say it has had it's moments and it does seem to have more of these moments as one explores deeper into the game.  Now I got to admit I've come down pretty hard on the armchair critics of this game but it is only because I feel it deserves more than a quick play and then being dumped on. There are people out there who like myself don't have a lot of money to spend. To them I would say check the game out maybe even play a little on a friends game if you can before you buy. If you're looking for something with a lot of action and shooting and all that. Don't spend your money but if again you are like me and love to see what's over the next batch of pixels then give it a try and don't let the armchair critics keep you from making up your own mind.   I highly recomend this game to dreamers, Sci fi lovers and adventurers everywhere.  To Hello Games I want to say this. Thank you. Thank you for giving me worlds to explore, a universe to find my way in, a story that never ends. I have only one request and it is this. I would, like the planets I explore be able to give my ship a name. I don't think that's too much to ask.

When the game first made its debut, I thouroughly enjoyed it for the first 20 hours. No Man's Sky was something fresh, unique and different that piqued at the science I have interest in. The auto generation is quite remarkable and it is really neat to traverse across the different and serene varieties. Some of the scenery is simply astounding and you can become immersed by it. Stock piling different elements and materials that are needed, and solving the game in general was rewarding in the beginning. Gameplay became a little redundant (as it can with many games) and there was little to really do soon after, aside from upgrading your ship and multitool. After I completed those, I shelved the game for awhile. I knew they had mentioned updates, so I was going to just wait and see what was added. The overall premise at the core was a tremendous idea and achievement, it just needed more layering and depth.  After the update, I think they made a pretty big improvement and a step in the proverbial right direction. In my bias, the foundations that this game is built on play to my favorite interests. There is so much they could do with a game like this and no sky is the limit. I think that is what a lot of games lack these days, bold vision and creativity - something different. As long as the company improves with continuous additions to the gameplay with more customizational elements and variety, the better the game will become. Nothing good was ever accomplished without someone taking a chance.  It can still live up to its hype, and then some.  toodlez

I think this game is a decent framework for a game that I hope to see evolve over the coming months. Is it everything I hoped for? No. But it is a fun sandbox to play around in and definitely a pretty good achievement for an Indie Developer. I preordered and I didn't get what I hoped for, but it's silly to attempt to return a game just because it's not what you hoped for. If you buy a car and drive it off the lot, it's yours, period. No returns... A car is worth a lot more than a game. People need to take some responsibility for their choices. It's a game that had incredibly lofty goals. It's a sim game. Anybody who's ever played sim games would know that the developer ALWAYS has ambitious goals regarding the design of the game, but as it's developed they have to trash certain ideas to make up for time and money. Look up the entire history of Maxis. We bought it. Just play it or not. It's not the Note 7. Relax! Only time will tell if the developer eventually adds the tons of content and updates that they actually 'promised' as opposed to the 'concepts' they expressed during development. In the end, I would probably reccomend this game to avid simulation gamers the most. If you don't have a fair amount of patience and don't enjoy micromanagement at all, then just stay away. If you pre-ordered... grow up and deal with your choice. That's life. The game is not broken or truly incomplete like say Arkham Knight was at launch. It just falls a little short of expectation. Personally, I'm just gonna play once in a while now and wait for more updates to see where my investment goes.  Additionally, At least in America, if you buy a car from a dealership, the moment you drive it off the lot it's yours. You can sue all you want, but you signed a lengthy contract stating so. The comparison is that you could pay thousands of dollars for something and it's still up to YOU to be smart about your purchase; for instance, reading reviews like the ones we're reading and commenting on ad nauseum here. I was impatient, took a chance and personally give it a conservative 7/10, so I guess I'm one of a few mildly satisfied customers. Again, it was still our gamble for a Needless Thing. There's a difference between protection and entitlement. I watched tons of videos detaling what they're adding to the game and what they'd LIKE and TRY to add to the game. Also, you deserve a refund because of poor advertizing? I suggest you don't ever buy anything in a supermarket considering most all advertizing is slightly misleading. Gourmet, Homemade, Zesty, Natural... See 'George Carlin - Advertizing Lingo.' Regardless, it's not a car or a shirt or even some basic necessity. This is essentially a piece of art. So, like it, hate it, we still bought something we absolutely didn't NEED. I guess I just don't have enough moral ambiguity to attempt to return something I at least mildy enjoyed, so far. If I go to see a movie and decide I didn't like it and the movie trailer seemed misleading, I just go, 'Oh well... That sucked.' and go on with my life. I just learn, move on and hopefully never make the same mistake again. Also, for Christ's sake, have some patience. You bought a game that could potentially be explored for multiple lifetimes, yet so few are willing to wait a couple months to see if there will be any content update? Seriously!? Some cautious optimism would be wonderful.

I understand how most people find NMS boring: you are truly doing the same thing over and over. However, this game has something no other has: After 100 hrs playing, you still find new, amazing things (of course, if you are looking).  I enjoyed the game for about 80 hrs. Then, its repetition ended overcoming the amazing feeling of exploring the unknown. I didn´t complain: 80 hrs of enjoyment was more than enough. But I left the game for some time.   Then I played it again yesterday, and I felt that exploration feeling all over again. Comparatively, I also played Skyrim again, which is a much greater game IMO. I admired again how amazing Skyrim was, but, I knew exactly what was behind every corner. It was amazing, but I already knew it all in high detail.   That did not happen when I replayed NMS: There I was, in a wonderful planet that I had never seen before. No idea what to expect, how the night would it be, how the sunset would it look like. Yes, I was still mining and doing all that repetitive stuff, but all what I was seeing was new in so many levels.   While, no doubt, with a lot of repetitive elements, there is no game in the world that can offer an infinite level of visual replayability as NMS does. Sure, I can get bored exploring similar planets, but once in a while, NMS suddenly offers you a true miracle of procedural generation. True art made not by people, but by math. If you are an 'explorer' type, this will probably be a great game for you. If you are a 'bullet storm' type, then no.  No Man's Sky is centered around going and finding. I see a lot of negative reviews here, from people that got sucked up into the hype and imagined it to be something it was never supposed to be.  If you need to be wowed and amazed in the first 10 hours of gameplay, this isn't for you.   Space combat is in the game, though pretty easy once you get the hang of it, and not central to the gameplay, it was never supposed to be. Ground combat is there to, but not the focus of the game.   Awesome, beutiful planets with all manner of creatures are there, but you have to know what to look for to find them. You're not just going to go warping around randomly and find the rare planets. Creatures vary from realistic to downright goofy, and tiny to EPIC huge!  Plants and rock formations are kind of repeptive after awhile, but I don't find that it detracts from the overall experience, kind of helps when you are looking for elements.   Performance wise, you will want a pretty solid rig. Mine is a beast so I haven't had any problems with crashing, stuttering or anything.   From all the pre release vids I watached, pretty much seems as advertised. Like Sean said though, the awesome amazing planets with big huge amazing creatures ARE exceedingly rare, until you know how to find them. Then they are not so hard to find.  All in all, a GREAT game, and I recommend highly for any 'explorer' type gamers.

Don't be fooled, this is a great game. It's just not what people expected. However, it was what I expected: great and varied vistas and not much pressure so I can look at them. Relaxing solo play. Maybe it will be your thing, maybe not. Read on to find out.  This is strictly an exploration game: travel and see the sights.  What can you expect? -Beautiful vistas -Different planet types: some lush, some barren, some toxic, some mostly underwater, varying densities of flora and fauna (and fauna type: hostile or docile). -Toxic dust storms, rain, sunshine, fog: only toxic dust storms will change gameplay and not by much. -Lots of exploring, even underwater -Lots of variation in environment in life -Seamless planet/space transitions -Varied animals: some weird, some boring, some small, some big, a few very big. No stampedes, simple AI. -Barebones NPCs and repetitive alien outposts with a few easy puzzle types. -Varied but meaningless dialogue. Alien language learning system. -No real quests beyond pushing forward and exploring new places -No backtracking ever -No base creation -Surface, underwater and caverns only, don't waste your time tunneling for hidden stuff. -Ship stays away from land, landing is automated. -Combat is easy and avoidable. Emphasis is on exploring and traveling, not fighting. -No multiplayer whatsoever  Regarding performance -I had no crashes and it runs smoothly -Expect your hard drive and CPU to stress, like in Minecraft. Works best with an SSD. -Not many bugs really. I went through the floor only once, on my first play.  Can't speak about the ending, but I hear it's nothing to write home about.

Game did have issues on release but all games have issues on release. I will try to sum this up:  The game's main focus is on exploration. You get paid game currency for discovering flora, fauna, and various outposts scattered on each planet. There are ancient alien ruins scattered on each planet that can be discovered. Each giving the player a little info into the lore of one of the races in the game as well as learning a few new words from that race's language.  There are survival elements in this as well. Your suit, ship, and multitool requires power which gradually decreases with use. They can be recharged with various items you can mine on each planet. All 3 can be upgraded to house more slots for upgrades/inventory space.  Space combat, while not as in-depth as some space sims can be quite entertaining once you get the hang of it. And deadly if you don't, as space pirates are unrelenting in some systems.  Ground combat is persay your classical fps. run, shoot, jump.  Each planet has a wanted system like that seen in the GTA series. Mine too much, kill too much fauna, or shoot the sentinels and it will riase your wanted level. The higher the wanted level the more powerfull the sentinels become ranging from flying annoyances to towering walkers that spew death in your general direction.  The visuals on some planets are utterly breathtaking.  So all in all I have found this game to be quite addictive and entertaining. I will be looking forward to what the developers have in store for us in the future.

First of all I would like to make an honest and unbiased review. I do like this game however as it is pretty much what I expected, yes a few features are missing (ie).  1. Can't see other people, well Sean Murray didn't actually promise this he only teased it, later views from him said you would see their results, ie planet names etc, but not people directly.  2. Large creatures? Well I've see seen some larger ones though not as big as E3 demo yet, give it more time.  3. Carnivore attacking other creatures, well I have seen this but very rarely so far.  4. Space battles, well I've seen quite a few, when jumping into a system you can sometimes see large ships being attacked by smaller ones and yes you can join in if you want, although recommend attacking small ones as large ships look pretty formidable. May have to take out roughly 10 or 12 of them though so don't try unless your equipped for it.  5. Orbits of planets, well yes this looks to be a no no, they look pretty static to me.  6. Hacking into trading post ship terminals to steal ship, No this doesn't happen, you can however buy that ship from trader but make sure you transfer items from inventory first, (not ship systems) Sean Murray said you can hack terminal to take ship in interview so may have meant this, although he didn't make that clear.  7. Planets closer to sun are warm and farther from planets are cold. Well this doesn't look correct so far not from my experience although some have no water and are very hot, not really taken much notice of this so far.  8. Play with your friends. No this is definitely a no no.  9. Fighting fighters on planets. Well this is possible I've done it, but you would have to attack them first as I've never been attacked yet by them. It is very tricky though as I found it hard to attack them from above especially because of the low flying restriction it's hard to hit them when they are directly below you.  10. Customising your character. Not physically no, but you can upgrade or change enhancements on back pack, ship and weapon.  11. Large Sentinels (2 legged). Not seen one so far but maybe these come later at very high levels or nearer to galactic core. Have seen many 4 legged ones if you take high value items from planet with rare items, ie. Gravitation ball or vortex cubes, then they will attack immediately.  12. Planets orbit suns and moons orbit planets. This is definitely a no. Have never seen the sun or a planet move across sky.  13. Landing on a comet No No. No comets seen so far. Maybe land on asteroid, will try this to confirm and let you know.  14. Portals, well these are definitely there, just nobody has found out how to activate one yet. Pretty sure that there is a way to do this but not sure how yet, has any one tried using dimensional matrix to activate one maybe 10 or more. Please let me know if you find out.  Okay I think that's enough of confirming certain elements that are or are not in the game, let get to review.  I have put over 140 hrs into this game so far, even restarted by deleting save because of no antimatter blueprint bug with pre-order, and so far I am enjoying it very much, yes things are becoming a little repetitive now as I have most of the blueprints now, but I'm still enjoying the exploration side of the game and renaming planets etc. The Survival element has improved since the storms have been added and taking on ships is a lot of fun (keep topping up shield often or you'll die). I have maxed out my inventory to 48 slots just need a bigger ship now, only have 20 slots on that. I've done plenty of mining especially gold, copper and Iridium so can make some good money there. Can make more money by trading at space stations with other ships just look out for items with a star on them, I get mostly dynamic resonator for 33,000 and sell for 54,000 to others that seems to be best, may have to wait sometimes for seller to turn up. Most plants and rocks and animal can be a bit samey but may get more diverse nearer the centre or if you go to another universe.  So overall I do recommend people buying this game as I've had a lot of fun playing it and have only now started heading toward the centre, I do love the lore of the game like reading the messages from monoliths, it's has a very old sci-novel feeling to it ie. A C Clarke, Asimov, Michel woodcraft, so love that. I like understanding the languages of the Korvax, Gek, Vy'keen and Sentinels. So if this is your thing then yeah buy it. If you want hard core fighting or survival or trading then no maybe it's not your bag. £40.00 is maybe slightly overpriced considering some stuff is missing all though not that much to be fair, when it's on sale then yes buy it you'll like it. Well I hope the helps anyone thinking of buying game or not, so thanks and have fun. I've got more stuff to do in this game so let's get back to it.

No Man's Sky. A very simple title. Yet, it hides an enigma. There has been a lot of hype about this game. For a number of years we were teased with trailers and interviews and all sorts of marketing that heightened the expectations and raised a high bar. People expected a game that would in essence be 'The mother of all games'. Then, when it finally arrived, it seemed to not meet all of the expectations and hype. Some complained of technical issues, the UI, the controls, the lack of a storyline, and so forth.I read that some even had their money refunded to them. All of that seems silly to me. I have been playing games for a very, very long time. I come from a the generation with an Atari 2600 console, Apple II, and casette tapes, VHS video and the like. Instant gratification WAS NOT the order of the day. If you wanted FUN, then you had to go find it. In No Man's Sky, I found FUN. Yes, it might seem as if some things are repetitive, and seems the same all the time. Yes, maybe there is only a thin storyline or three. Yes, maybe the controls are a bit funny, and not like those of the newest space sims. BUT, when your goal is not instant gratification, but putting yourself in the shoes of an Explorer, as it was when this game was originally announced, and you set yourself other, smaller goals, then the game takes on a different perspective for me. Scanning and finding ALL the different animal species on a planet, AND in the process learning new alien languages, AND fixing your spacecraft, AND trading your minerals, AND finding ruins, AND upgrading your ship and Exosuit, AND travelling throughout a star system, are all, together, part of a process, a process of discovery. The problem I have with nearly all of the negative reviews of this game is that the reviewer inevitably tries to impose their perception of what they Thought it would be or should be, and in nearly all the cases, of all the ones I have read, focus on a very narrow set of goals. My challenge to you is this:  Do not limit yourself by only expecting or setting a small set of goals. Make it big, daring. Think of the game as a window into the near infinite possibilities that I think exist out there in the real Universe, and then play it as such.  You will find things that will surprise you. Take the time to read about that new animal you just scanned, or the plant you identified. Try giving each and every one you find, a unique name. Play the Botanist or Zoologist while you are also the Spaceman, the Explorer, the Archeologist. I do not think that anybody can give an honest opinion about this game untill they have played a few hundred hours. That includes me.  But I did feel that I needed to write about this game, given all the unfair comment, in my opinion, it was receiving from people that have not given it a fair chance, but was measuring it against completely different types of games, or even with the wrong measures. I am enjoying this game. The thrill of finding a new species of animal, or blasting open the door of some abandoned building keeps me coming back for more. If you want to wait for the price on the game to drop before buying it, then do so. The universe in the game will not disappear, and there will still be lots for you to discover once you decide to join us, and you could become a sort of Indiana Jones in Space.

Buy it now and enjoy what there is or wait and see what else they do with the game - either weay this is a game that deserves to be played.

I love seeing what every planet has to offer and I love flying around in my space ship looking at all the different locations on a planet.  TL;DR- This game is not for everyone, but if you like exploring, then this is the game for you.

So far I am really enjoying this game. I can't actually see where a lot of the complaining comes from. From the very beginning this was a game you were mostly going to have to play alone...the idea of coming across even ONE friend, let alone GROUPS of them in such a vast and endless playground was kind of a silly idea to begin with.   The graphics are wow-esque and the animals are mostly adorable and once I docked at the space station I was overcome with the urge to get enough money to buy one of these awesome ships from one of the strange little frog dudes.  SPEAKING of the little frog dudes...it's worthwhile to pay a bit of carbon and learn several words, as well as finding the little nodes all around to learn more, because the more you know about their language the more it starts to become interesting to talk to them. There's a plot in this exploration game. I was not expecting that.  While it WOULD be nice for them to fix the issue of not being able to see others at all, if only to enjoy those rare encounters, I don't know why so many people seem to have gotten a message that this was a multiplayer game. I certainly didn't.  The only area where this game fails, I believe, is in inclusiveness. My brother and I got this game, wanting to compare and share creatures and worlds, and found out that he can't even play the thing due to his graphics card not being compatible. This is not an old graphics card, which leads me to believe that the game isn't as nicely optimised as my computer makes it seem.

Personally, I love it. If you enjoy explore, gather, upgrade, repeat type gameplay then you'll probably enjoy it as well.  Do your homework first! There are a LOT of very valid criticisms including technical problems, price, over-hype, and broken developer promises. At the same time, don't get bogged down by all the negatives. If nothing else, consider following this game to see where it winds up in a few weeks / months when things stabilize and calm down.

I liked the game, though its little overpriced but hope expecting much more refined graphics and other addons.

Well worth the wait. A nearly infinite galaxy to explore, filled with rich, exciting planets - all with things to do! Scan for new lifeforms, be the first to catalogue them, mine and sell your materials for credits, use the credits to upgrade your ship, suit, and tools. Or you can simply fly around and take in the sights. Is the game perfect? Hell no. There are a few glitches here and there, but does this deserve the crap ratings it's getting on Steam? Hell no, again. This game is amazing. Appreciate the hard work that went into it up to this point - and trust that the developer will continue to work tirelessly to fix the minor issues ongoing.   If you have an old crap PC and GPU, then don't get ♥♥♥♥♥♥ if your FPS is 10. I'm running this on a 4k gaming rig, i7 5820, GTX 1080, etc etc, and I'm getting 60+ fps in 4k.

For everyone complaining about performance, I'm running with an AMD 7970 Ghz Edition, and I'm getting around 50-60 fps consistently. So yes, a 3 year old GPU works just fine. I don't know what the cause of the poor performance is with everyone else, but it's not general optimization.  As far as gameplay, I'm enjoying it so far, but there's a steep learning curve. So I wasn't going to write a review, as I generally don't do that, but with all the negative feedback on this game, I had to give my $0.02. When I first launched, it had mediocre graphics and I was only getting about 20-25FPS with an AMD Radeon R9 280x and a i5 3.5 ghz processor. Then I turned off Vsync, anti-aliasing, turned UP the graphics to high, rebooted and it ran flawless with a steady 45-60 frames depending on what I'm doing, sometimes more. The pop-in is bad, but you get used to it and it's not that big of a deal. Then again, it's all procedurally generated, so you can kinda expect pop-in to be a factor.   The music is phenomenal, the concept is fantastic, and the POTENTIAL of NMS is limitless. I can't thank Hello Games enough for this title. I've put almost 10 hours in already today, and with so much content, I plan to add a few zeros to that. This is a very very chill game, like Sean said himself, and it's such a nice break from everything else out right now. The grind is real - if you want it to be. I've already got almost $2 million, and some decent ships will run you half that.   Anyways, this is one game that I paid full price for and do not regret whatsoever. I'm confident they will continue to update/patch this and make it even better than it is now. It has a few issues (fell through the map/planet while mining), SOME frame drop when entering planets at high speeds, and that's about it to be honest.   Also, to the idiots here saying they're stuck on the 'initialize' screen - try holding 'e', dumbasses.   Great work Sean and co. Can't wait to see what you guys have in-store for this wonderful title, and it was well worth the wait.

At its heart, this is a game about discovery. There is a story here if you care to unravel it, and mysteries if you want to find them.  You will like this game if: • You enjoyed the discovery and mining elements of Grav • You appreciate randomized worlds and creatures • You enjoy surreal sci-fi vistas with glorious color palettes • You love unraveling mysteries embedded in hidden places  • You like to chill out when playing games and flying from planet to planet through the vastness of a beautiful space sounds enticing to you • The thought of bartering for a starship with an alien whos language you barely understand (but can actually learn) is intriguing  You will not like this game if: • You prefer strictly action oriented games • Your goal is to beat a game as quickly as possible • Science fiction, biology or discovery hold no interest for you  I love this game and it has actually surpassed my expectations. I have encountered some occasional slowdown issues, but the dev team that made the game seems to be active with updates and I'm hopeful that they'll have that bit fixed soon. Ultimately I think Hello Games has made a great game and I look forward to many, many more hours of discovering the mysteries that the universe holds within.

I'm going to recommend this game on potential, but not sure I can recommend it for 60$. In it's current state the game is a really pretty, random grind. It is huge, even one planet could be a game in itself if there was just more to it than just collecting resources and upgrading. I don't hate the inventory management system, it adds a challenge to the game, however I do wish more things would stack. I really wish there was a way to map things, you can spend half an hour wandering around a cave, not being able to find your way out, simply because you couldn't leave 'breadcrumbs'. You find a broken down ship, that's much better than yours, but you don't ere the recipe is to craft the items required to repair it. By the time you do come across them, you have no clue where the wreck is even at anymore. Maybe I'll enjoy it more when some features are added, but for now it's just sort of meh for me.

I enjoy the freedom to go wherever I want and do whatever. The worlds are beautiful and the dimensions of the game are unbelievable. Also it is just a pretty game. I don't have any complaints. I haven't had any crashes or bugs. It is fun to play and see what new things I can find out there.

I don't usually review games, but I am critical of them commonly. No Man's Sky is a great indie game, it just needs some work. For all the haters and critics giving negative reviews on day 1, I raise the question posed by other reviewers with similar points: Why are you giving it a negative review on days 1-2? The game's barely been out for 2 days and there are already people giving it hate for such things as 'lag' or 'bad performance?' Sure, those exist. I'm not denying that, as I have massive lagspikes and framerate drops on my GTX 960 at low settings. But if that's the sole reason for a bad review, then the review is not helpful. Think about it, The Witcher 3 had day 1 problems, and look at the community's opinion of it now. My point here is, don't give a bad review on a game when it's barely been out for a day. Also, to the people who are saying that there's nothing to do, same thing. More content will be added eventually, as this isn't a game made by Activision or EA. There will be free expansions. Also, the only reason I wouldn't recommend this game is if Hello Games pulls an Ubisoft and abandones the game in its current state.

If you want this game but think that it is a bit too pricey and/or the negative reviews about frame drops is something you would like to avoid for now, do avoid it for now. Wait for the updates.

There is a lot of negativity going on about No Man's Sky and I don't give a ♥♥♥♥. I believe the reason people are so upset is because they waited so long for it. A review in two parts. For people who are hung up on the multiplayer issue, keep reading. For anyone who wants an opinion on the game itself, skip a few paragraphs.  First things first: the multiplayer issue. Like a lot of you, I've been glued to news updates about this game for a long time. I've probably watched or read at least 2/3 of every interview Murray gave during development. I absolutely admit that things don't add up based on all the statements that were made, and they might have gotten caught with their pants down.  HOWEVER, if you're going to damn them, let's damn them for the right thing and not blow it out of proportion. In every statement ever made about what the game would be like at launch, it was NEVER billed as a multiplayer game. EVERY time the question was brought up as to whether or not you could see other players, it was said it was so incredibly unlikely to happen. Fine, it happened. But that's not multiplayer. Multiplayer is a built-in, intentional, RELIABLE ability to find others and/or play with your friends. They told people REPEATEDLY not to expect it. The only thing that doesn't fit with what we were told so far is that if and when people ever found themselves in the same spot, that they'd be able to see each other. People latched on to the statement that they would be able to and forced that into a definition of multiplayer, even when players themselves would have no control whatsoever to make it happen - no matter how likely or unlikely those meetings are, they are still chance encounters. Even if you *could* see other players, not having any control over it would mean over the course of your gameplay you'd encounter 0-2 other people. Woo!  They did say a few months ago, AFTER the missed launch date earlier this summer, that they would be adding some form of multiplayer at a later date - not at launch. So why the whole world is hung up on the fact that two people can't see each other on the highly unlikely chance it will happen - and decide to call that failure to deliver multiplayer that wasn't actually promised - is beyond me.   So with that out of the way, my opinion on the game itself.  They promised exploration, survival, trading, and combat. They absolutely delivered all four. Admittedly, some better than others, but I feel they lived up to what they advertised, and I've enjoyed it immensely so far.  First and foremost, it's an exploration game. If you don't think you're the type who is happy finding out what is over that next hill, this game most likely isn't for you. The same concept applies on foot, flying over a planet, moving throughout a star system, and going from star to star. You don't know what you're going to find, and some people enjoy that while others don't. But let's make no mistake - it's exactly what they told us the game would be.  Trading is probably the most understated of the areas. Yes, you can buy low and sell high all the live-long day if you want to, I even enjoy that kind of thing in some games, but it isn't terribly rewarding in NMS. More often than not you'll find yourself selling valuable resources you gathered in order to buy what you want/need, or buying resources that you can't find out in the wild. And that's about the extent of it. You'd really have to be into commodity trading sims to find what you are looking for in NMS, but it's another facet of the game that helps make it more well-rounded than just exploration and combat.  I personally lump survival and combat into the same category, at least in how it was put into NMS (yes, survival extends to keeping your life support running and fuel in your tank, but otherwise they both mean staying alive in the face of hostile forces). Some people want combat to be the central part of every game they play, and that's fine. NMS is not that game, and again, it wasn't billed as that. It's another aspect of the game. It comes in three flavors: (1) against mechanical constructs that /usually/ only attack you if you do certain things they don't like; (2) wildlife that /can/ be hostile - varies by species; and (3) space combat. In all three categories, you can be the victim or the instigator. In the first two situations, you can easily, reliably run away if combat isn't your thing or if you just aren't in the mood. Space combat, it's possible sometimes, but more often than not you're going to have to fight. For people who want the combat, they've given both variety and a chance to escalate things to a challenging level. You can focus on improving both your hand-held weapon and ship weapons if that's what you want your gameplay to be about. So even though this isn't the center of the game, it exists, and I think they did it well.  One complaint I see a lot is that it gets boring. In part I think this goes back to people who aren't really that keen on exploring. But there's no denying that operationally, there's a good deal of repetition to the gameplay too. When is that not true of any game though? Break it down to the fundamentals, and every game is repetitive. In the case of NMS, it's roughly: explore planets to gather resources, make fuel to jump to the next star, and upgrade your ship and equipment as you go. It's unfair to judge any game when boiled down to that level. What that doesn't take into account is the variety of places and situations you find yourself in along the way.  For people who are criticizing the graphics, I'll bow out of that argument. I've got a middle-of-the road system (it was high end but not bleeding-edge 2 years ago, now, not so much) and I'm quite content with how it looks and plays. People who expect the ZOMG latest and greatest as of 2 seconds ago might not be thrilled - not being one of those, I can't say.  What am I less than thrilled about?  1. Two crashes in my first 35 hours of play. For a brand new game, that's not unheard of, but crashes are never fun. The upside is that your game autosaves *every* time you exit your ship, and at least the way I play, it's rare for that to be more than 15 minutes at a time.  2. One bug - there's one objective I've been given (no details, 'cause spoilers) that I currently can't get past because of a game bug. Searching online confirms that there are others, but clearly not everyone, also having the same issue. If it wasn't an obstacle to continued progression, I'd care far less, but it is.  3. For lack of a better word, 'chunking'. In Minecraft the game loads the world around you in large pre-defined areas at a time. NMS seems to do something similar and an unfortunate side effect is that when you're in one area but close enough to see into the next, you can see things that aren't there anymore -like you're seeing the pristine version before you mined that mound of resources a few minutes ago. So when you walk away, it shows up again, but if you return, it's still gone because you mined it. I speculate that the game is showing you your own personalized 'instance' of that chunk for lack of better terminology. This could also explain why two people in the same location can't see each other - because they are both in their own personalized version of that space.  4. Its problematic to find your way back to previous star systems once you've left. Not impossible, just far more of a hassle than you'd expect. The purpose of the game is to keep moving onward, but there's no reason they can't allow you to go back too.  5. Lastly, the game sorely needs instructions or a better tutorial. It's not rocket science, but they made very little effort to teach you the controls.  So do I think it's perfect? No. But I do think they delivered on the promise of the game, and I enjoy it greatly. I think that anyone who can honestly say they enjoy exploring will think it's worth the price of admission. Keep in mind as well what they've already commented on adding in future patches - building bases, freighter ships, and yes, eventually multiplayer.

I'm not usually one to review things, but given the negativity so far I wanted to weigh in. I've been playing for 8 hours on a pretty standard PC with no problems. So far it's been stable and I haven't experienced a single crash. Maybe I'm just lucky as there are thousands of reviews stating that they can't even get it to launch. If you do manage to get it to run, the game is quite beautiful and, in my opinion, it's delivered on what Hello Games promised; a vast universe with (mostly) unique planets to explore.   I'll start off by saying that the game isn't neccesarily 'exciting'. There is some combat but tou can avoid it most of the time. There is also a survival element (make sure you manage your inventory!), but it really does boil down to an immense walking simulator. It's kind of like roaming through a Minecraft world endlessly; constantly finding new resources, and interesting areas, but never creating an actual homestead. Sure you'll see very similar places, but nothing is exactly the same.  There are quite a variety off different types of planets, though so far lacking any gas giants, ringed planets, and a few other planetary bodies that make up the actual universe. Every planet I've encountered has life, some may be more barren than others however. There are also plenty of sentient Alien species that you can gain influenece with, trade with, and gather important upgrades from.   Another thing that came to mind while exploring was the Mako missions from Mass Effect. Some people really hated them, but personally I enjoyed driving around collecting resources and artifacts.   This game is definitely not for everyone, but if you do enjoy exploring, collecitng, and discovering new things, No Man's Sky will give you all those things.

A little over two hours in, and I have never experienced anything like this game. I kind of only want to call it an experience instead of a game because the scale of the experience is like nothing I have ever seen. It takes literal, real life HOURS to fly to a planet at a percentage of the speed of light. So you accelerate. 45 Minutes. Pulse Drive, 5 Minutes 10 Seconds. Everything is huge, planets are huge, systems are huge, the galaxy is supermassive on a scale that dwarfs our own galaxy. Gigaparsecs of real, tangible distance and adventure separate you from whatever is ahead of you. You can move as quickly or as slowly as you want.  Planetside, the creeping loneliness of hostile worlds is ever present. Youre alone, the universe denies salvation, but you have tools. Survival bites at your heels every step you take on the surface of a radioactive paradise world, or a beautiful tundra world, or a world that is 92% ocean. Creatures and other wildlife are abundant but can start to feel similar after a while, but thats hard to focus on when you are busy doing 10 things at one, scanning, mining, fighting and flying among others. The seemless transition from planetside to space will never, ever get old. You can help but pull back in your chair as your ship pushes through a thick atmosphere into space above.  After only two hours with No Mans Sky, it has shown me things I had never seen in any game before, or in real life. Thats a ♥♥♥♥ing win in my books, good job HG.

The game is great, for me, but I think I'm part of the niche demographic this game actually appeals to.  Exploring and upgrading ship/character is straight up what I wanted, and this game has it. I'm driven to see new types of star systems by upgrading my warp drive and to see what's behind the atlas pass v2 + v3 doors, by finding the recipes for those key cards.  Once I do that, I imagine there's not enough 'game' left in the game to hook me. But I'm already 15 hours in and not there yet.   I think for most people, this isn't a $60 game. It has an amazing foundation of technology, but the 'game' layer is unpolished and lacking. I hope they add to it with updates, but it'll never be the Star Citizen or Elite Dangerous contender some people want it to be - that's just not what the game is.

Preface: I was hyped for this game a long while ago and for that reason did not follow much of the news surrounding it. If you have seriously high expectations surrounding this game, and expect all of the bells and whistles, I'd suggest maybe watching some gameplay and making your own decision then. That being said, here's the review:  Good game that has something that I think a lot of reviewers leave out: Atmosphere. From the sound design to the true randomness of the planets, the game has the lonliness of space down. It's extemely relaxed while still keeping you on your toes when you burn through the atmosphere of another planet.   Personally, I really like the entire sandbox feel of the game and appreciate that there are more straightforward paths if you want a bit of hand holding (or simply prefer the direct route). That being said, the game can feel daunting at first, and doesn't give much of a primer of the mechanics of the game, and prefers that you discover these things on your own. I love the feel of the universe and how you can completely screw yourself and then at the same time work out of that bind with the resources around you.  Pros: Extremely open-ended  Nice sound design  Decent graphics at the moment  Does a good job of tempering the difficulty that randomness can provide  Cons: Odd bugs and glitches  Upscaled from 720p, hopefully this gets patched ASAP  Can be confusing if you don't read  All in all, if you are looking for a game that is about exploration, give it a shot. Not terrible, but doesn't bring gaming to the next level either.  The good:  + Lots of exploration + If you love gathering and crafting. This represents the bread and butter of the gameplay.  + A Good trading system + Fairly nice ambiance to it  The bad:  - Graphicly, not really good. The textures are rather ugly honestly and the environments on planet lack detail in my opinion. Planets can feel empty and lifeless at times (Even the Class-M planets) - The combat and flight in this game is clunky. Not attrocious... but nothing really appealing. - The game is very grindy. Go the system A... Gather ressources to refuel and be on your way... Go to System B... Repeat the process. For some pleople, this might not be an issue. But be warn that NMS requires you to farm for ressources a lot... It is not optional.  - The life forms look cool at first, but you quickly notice the 'lego' nature of their procedural generation... Which can break the immersion at times. the combinations work for some creatures... but for some... It really looks silly and breaks the immersion of the game. - If you are looking for a space simulation like Elite and Star citizen. Don't bother with NMS. THe game is really arcady/simplistic by nature. It can be a good thing for some, but if you want a detailed simulation, NMS is not the game for you.  Overall, NMS is not a bad game. It's an 'OK' indy game, and while i definitly recommend it... It can't say that it is worth 60 dollars. This is a 20 dollars games.. at best... 30 dollars. But not more.  So my advice, wait for the game to go on sale. Once it does. get it (if you really... and I mean REALLY love exploration games), and you will get a good chunk of fun out of it.

This review is mostly a recap of my experience so far.  I've spent 10 hours so far in game, spending all of it on just two planets (and the space station.) I discovered every creature on both planets, because that's what was fun to me, not to mention the sweet 200-300k reward for each planet.  The scale of the game is really one of the biggest draws of the game. (I know, the 18 quintillion thing has been repeated 18 quintillion times, but for good reason.) It definitely creates a sense of aw for me. I went into the game not expecting some deep space sim with deep combat, but an exploration game. If you don't like exploration games, this game is not for you. If you aren't the kind of person who sees a mountain in the distance and wants to go climb it, there won't be much for you in this game.  Many of the flora and fauna are lackluster, but I wouldn't really want a procedural generation that made them all epic screenshot fodder. I've found a couple cool plants and a few cool animals so far, including one bear-shaped animal with anglerfish-like lights on it's back. But I also found a cactus that is literally just a cactusy plain cylinder.  Oh, and one of my favourite mechanics is the way you learn languages. One word at a time. And when you speak to aliens of that race, you will only understand bits and peices. It makes for some interesting, alarming, and confusing interactions, such as the alien who greeted me by chanting 'death! death! death! death! death' followed by something I couldn't understand. Also I'm pretty sure I accidentally accepted a dowry to marry somebody's child. I might be engaged. I'm pretty sure that happened. We'll see if that turns up again I guess.  There are definitely optimization issues, and the negative reviews saying they can't load the game are completely fair. That hasn't been my experience, but I've encountered a few annoying but not game breaking bugs. I had a problem in the beginning with not being able to launch my ship, but a restart fixed it fine. Expect to have to close and relauch the game every few hours because of bugs, or in my partner's experience, what appears to be memory leaks.  Gameplay wise, there are some things I dislike. The space station designs are pretty much all the same on the inside so far. It's not a huge deal, but a minor dissapointment. Inventory management is very frustrating. I see reasons why, like trying to get players to go interact with NPCs at space stations more often to sell their stuff, to not make it a game of 'how many hundreds of stacks of iron can I get'. But still, you're either going to be throwing away a lot of things or interrupting your exploring to go liquidate your resources.  Another thing that is dissapointing, so far, is that the starter planets are, generall, kind of boring to look at. My first had neat wave/tentacle things all over, but it was all grey with few plants, most of which are cactuses. I've heard that the planets get more interesting and pretty as you progress though, so the increase in pretty planets may make progression feel rewarding.  The game is really chill too, btw. Don't let the hype make you think you're going to be on the edge of your seat. That's not a negative for me, but it isn't a gameplay style everybody is going to like.  In short, if you like exploration, I recommend this game. If you don't, skip it.

Other than that a few bugs here and there. Sometimes when you enter your ship on a planet it will bounce out into space... this has happened about 5-6 times in 14hrs of gameplay. I also discovered buildings that spawned half buried and I had to blast my way around to find the door which was inside a hillside. In that particular area the drones / sentinels glitched through the walls and floor and continued to attack me.  Vegitation and animals on planets do seem to have similarities with just a few color changes / mixups here and there but I've only been on like 4 diff planets and 2 moons. The caves all seem about the same.. literally. However, the planets do have their own unique features. The main thing that's boring to me is all of the buildings are identical inside and out with very little differences except for 'Monoliths' they seem to vary the most with different designs(still some repitition). The first time you talk to any alien entity they usually have something they want or a question / event and you get to choose what to do from there and depending on your choice will decide on what your given / learn / gain or lose rep. After that it's usually the same 3 options when you talk to them( health restore, shield, learn a new word, or they can gift you a small amount of a resource).   Earning money is a grind.
