There are performance issues, which will no doubt be fixed. You can apparently also get lucky and have them all disappear all of a sudden. Either way, patience will shortly sort you out. I think you can get all that it offers for lower prices elsewhere. Want an endless universe to trek about in at your own pace? Buy Elite: Dangerous, for half the cost. Want to play meter-filling-simulator 2016? Go buy literally any survival game. Want to just look at infinite planets in 1:1 scale? Go download Space Engine. For free. Want to look at eye-watering psychadelic colour schemes and randomly created mobs? Go buy Spore. No, seriously.   The controls are not much to brag about. You'll be doing a lot of running around, and the eternal insistence upon stamina meters in games will haunt you and drive you insane in this game, but on the flipside you have a jetpack that recharges itself. Flight is what gets me though. I do play a lot of flight sims, so I guess it's just the fact that they've simplified it compared to the genre standard that's putting me off. You can't pitch down much, for whatever reason. Your ship just kind of veers uowards again. And the roll control is like driving on ice, but the yaw is so overpowered you probably don't need to roll.   Certain things are intuitive, others are not. The way the game handles travel in spaceship is elegant, with automated landing sequences, fairly smart warp-jumping controls, you have one tool for everything, etc. And on the other hand, I literally had to Google 'how to craft' because the game decided to only show me the tutorial tooltips when it wanted to.   In short: Not a bad game if you're the right kind of person, but I'd argue that there are better games to scratch this particular itch. I will in the end say I recommend it, /if/ you enjoy repetitive survival and exploration gameplay, and /if/ the premium price tag isn't too much for you. Or if you're willing to wait for a price reduction, but like I said, if price is an issue, Elite: Dangerous exists.

As someone who has played alot of triple A games, I do have to say I am disappointed just a bit but not enough to hate on this game. Yea performance can be better and even with a GTX 980M 8GB, it stutters (not frequently but enough to notice) though it does mostly stay at 60 fps. This means that while my more powerful laptop card could run this mostly well, anything below that would probably run worse so keep that in mind.   Now here is where I might diverge from the main crowd on this game, I do actually like it though I deliberately turned down my hype for it before release. In short, it feels like a more colorful, varied, expansive version of Elite Dangerous that is single player instead of online. Longer story- Well I like the gameplay, I like the interconnectivity between land, air, and space. I like exploring these random and beautiful planets. Even though I know they're cobbled together like random puzzle pieces, the landmarks, animals, and atmosphere looks so convincingly unique that I can get immersed into the new worlds I discover. Also naming worlds is a nice touch, of course being a Star Wars fan, I name my planets after all the Star Wars ones, especially if they look similar to ones you saw in the movies. I like the grind a little bit because of the variety of resources you can find and mine and how you can use them for many different purposes. I realize alot of people still won't like that which is fine but it was alright for me-I've played much worse grindy games for this to bother me. I also like traveling to space stations, talking with (the one) npc there and seeing other AI ships docking and flying away, doing their own thing. I also like it when fleets warp into or leave your area, makes the universe feel lived in (though it could be imrpoved)  So the gameplay is decent, the performance is mostly stable (though it could be better), controlls are mostly fine, but now I'll go into the 3 big things that I think need to be put in the game in order to make it the game people dreamed of.  1st: More Player Agency: I know that one of the points of this game is to make you feel like an insect in the great cosmic scheme but then why does the developer constantly promote player choice and agency? Sure you can follow a main story and make little dialogue choices that can affect the main story or your reputation with factions but why not more? Like building your own base? I know they said they will develop something like this but I would've been fine if they delayed the game in order to implement something like that in. Like building a space station, building a land base, maybe specializing in trade, ship building for your own personal fleets, or exploration! That would be amazing! I mean if we could at least own a massive starship that could be explorable, that would be enough for me because you could consider that home but you can only pilot small fighter like ships which, despite the varied amounts you could choose from, is still disappointing.   2nd: Add more npcs on land or space bases: It is cool that you can see random ships flying in and out of bases, it really is, It does make the world more alive. And seeing the plant and animal life interact with each other on worlds is also pretty neat. But then why can't we see more frequency in NPCs on land or space stations. I mean on little outposts, ok I understand why there might be just one but on big space stations or big land bases? That seems really ridiculous and it might not have been so bad if the one alien you find there was actually doing things but they always sit in one place doing nothing but looking on their Ipad probably playing Candy Crush. Having more NPCs, not necessarily to talk to or interact with, but just working/ wandering around these bases would exponentially increase immersion for the better. Maybe have some NPC land parties exploring these unknow nworlds with you, giving you that sense that you aren't the only explorer out there and if you save them from animal attacks or something, your reputation with them increases! I don't know, this was quite noticeable for me and I would like to see imrpovement  3rd: Pardon my French but I have to emphasize how much this particular issue bugs me- *cough cough* *deep breath*-INVENTORY, THE ♥♥♥♥ING INVENTORY! Expand it, just please for the love of God expand this ♥♥♥♥ing inventory space. I understand you can't carry unlimited amounts of items but when the biggest goal here is to explore, then having only 9-15 inventory slots is just ridiculous! And it wouldn't be so bad if I could transfer that stuff to my ship from far away but you have to be within like 500 feet of your ship in order to transfer anything which is annoying as ♥♥♥♥. This is the main gameplay feature in No Man's Sky that drove me bonkers and still does. It needs to be expanded or remove the necessity to recharge so many different parts to our ship and exosuit. Like I said, I wouldn't be bothered by constantly refueling/repairing parts to my ship or suit but with such a poor amount of inventory space, that nuisance is amplified to ridiculous levels. This should be the easiest and most prioritized thing to patch. Devs, make it happen PLEASE! If you don't intend to patch any other big features in the future even though you said you would, at the very least, ADDRESS THIS THIRD POINT!  In conclusion, this game is mostly what it promised. Mostly, however much that means to you will vary but I feel that they delivered the core of what they promised and really just need to refine it....alot. I feel like they released this too early simply because of the unstable performance many users experience, the lack of immersion in certain areas, and the fact that there simply isn't enough player agency for this to truly feel like the epic player driven game the devs were stressing this would be. If they gave it another month or two, perhaps it would've ascended to a higher status but it feels like they took this thing out of the oven right when it was about to be finished but now is a bit undercooked. Don't get me wrong, No Man's Sky is a good game but it won't appeal to alot of people not just because of the type of genre they chose to approach but because what they already have here might not be enough for players to jusitfy a purchase even if it was heavily discounted. If they addressed each of the points I made along with making the performance more stable, I feel like this would absolutely be worth the 60$ asking price and to some, it still will be despite what's missing.  The devs could add a significant amount of features that could make this game what it should've been at release so I wouldn't be one of the people that looks at it, decides not to buy it , then ignore it for good. Keep this on your wishlist, see what progress the devs are making. Their attitude towards the gaming community I think is great. Not only have they promised to patch in features like base building, more trade options, ,etc but they would be delivering all major features FOR FREE. My Review   I have played the game for around 8 hours and I am really enjoying it. The game doesn't hold your hand, you find yourself are on a planet, and your ship is damaged. You need to repair and refuel the engines. You must explore the planet and mine the required materials to craft the required parts. Once repaired you're good to go. The controls are simple and flying the ship is nice and easy.  There is an in-game currency and galactic marketplace. The minerals found on the surface are worth a certain price, this price can go up and down, but the game shows the galactic average. Anything you mine or craft can be sold on this marketplace. With your profits you can buy minerals or parts from the galactic marketplace or you can approach NPCs and offer them money for their ships.  I can see why people find the game repetitive, but I enjoy the grind. I enjoy the exploration and the challenge to keep my ship fueled and in working order, I haven't explored the various in-game races and NPCs yet but I look forward to this. I have only visited 5 planets but each one has been different, some are full of lifeforms and others have no life but are full of valuable minerals but with hostile environments.   I love the management of resources and having to calculate what and how much I can carry on each excursion. I am just enjoying the game in general, and I can't wait to upgrade my ship. If you enjoy exploration and resource management I would recommend this game, if you are after fast paced action game then from what I have seen this isn't the game for you.    Performance  I am running the game on a Pentium G3258 3.2Ghz dual core, 8GB RAM and a GeForce GTX 950 with Windows 10.   On high setting graphics setting, with max field of view at 720p the game runs at a steady 30fps with no issues. If I turn the resolution up-to 1080p the frame rate starts to fluctuate, between 24 and 28 fps, it turns to a steady 30fps if I change the settings to graphic settings to medium.   I hope helps.

Most important thing to note about this game is it has a very specific need for hardware compatibility, so here's my build: Nvidia GTX 970 FTW PLUS - Drivers are 368.81 (7/14/2015) - Highly compatible driver with the most games Intel i7 2700k quad-core @ 3.5ghz If you don't have a nice CPU, terrain loading will be very slugging. If you do not have either a 'decent'(even a low-end) Nvidia Graphics Card or a newer AMD, you will not be to play at all. I think all of the issues with drivers not being provided have been solved so not going to go into those details.  Compatibility seems to be the #1 reason this game gets down-voted but since I've been able to play from the start, let me give you some details on why this game is great, and what needs work... You start out with a broken down ship, and have to go look for resources. Planets vary in which resources are available and what the environment is like(extremely cold/hot/toxic, or if you're lucky.. earth-like), but it seems a guarantee that when you start, your planet is new-user friendly and contains all the needed resources to get your ship into space and maintain your exo-suit's life support and environmental protection. The game leaves out a few details here and there that you learn about later in play that are affected by early-play, so if you haven't started yet.. or... well, make sure you choose to follow the Atlas story line! It's extremely important that you do. It gives you access to unique features of the game such as the 'Atlas Card v1' which can unlock certain doors, and storage containers. Most notably, the v1 card opens a door at every space station that is guaranteed to contain a device you may use to upgrade your exosuit's inventory space and occasionally has other various devices in it(No clue what lies in the rooms beyond that as you need a higher-access Atlas Card for them). If you have started and didn't make that choice.. you can reset by (most easily uninstalling and reinstalling the game, and disabling cloud synchronization. With that summary out of way, the only things negative I've found is that when buying ships or multitools, you are given no refund based on the value & contents of your current ship/multitool.. You can however dismantle items and move resources over when trading your ship(before accepting the purchase). And the other big negative is the limitation on inventory space, you start out with a tiny exosuit inventory, a tiny spaceship inventory, and a 5 slot multitool... it's enough to get started but I guess the big goal of the game is to get a bigger inventory. I also hear that there's a race to the center... anyway, if you can confirm your system is compatible with the game, then by all means, the purchase is worth it!

The greatness of this game can be easily lost on impatient people, but for those willing to give it some time, this game will not disappoint. I now understand what the creator means when saying it is a game of moments, and will share with you one such moment. The moment that hooked me. A moment in space and time that only I witnessed, that will replay and resonate with me over and again.   It was near the early stages of the game, I was in the midst of exploring some planet in order to find some zinc to use to build my first hyperdrive fuel canister. I do not know what zinc looks like, and haven't the slightest clue where to find it, so I land my ship on some undiscovered planet and start trekking. Scanning everything I see, I ponder what form zinc might actually take in this alien land. Is it an element? a mineral? Its used in pimple creams, might it be white? I think its a metal, maybe its in some kind of rock? Where do you find rocks, in caves? Oh, what ho over yonder, A CAVE!!  Jetpacking towards the mouth of the cave, I spy a sentinel patrolling, but its passive, and I haven't been disturbing the wildlife, so I pay it no mind and begin spelunking. Deeper I penetrate, finding gold and plutonium, carbon and platinum, but no zinc. After scanning and searching for nearly ten minutes, I decide this must not be the cave I was looking for, so I turn to depart. On my way out to the entrance, I decide to scan the local plants, get some info for my logbook, and maybe find some useful something-or-other, when I spot an odd looking bulb.  The bulb could not be scanned, but can be interacted with, how odd. Upon closer inspection, it seems that there must be something inside it. I press the interact button, and lo-and-behold, it splits apart like a giant banana, revealing some sort of intergalactic space pearl!! The space pearl has a value of roughly 27,000 spacebucks, and there are about 5 more bulbs all nearby, SCORE!!! But alas, I have no room in my inventory, so I start clearing items, recharging consumables, transferring, and sorting stacks to make as much room as possible without wasting any of my valuables, and finally have created 6 open inventory slots, so I begin looting.  Upon picking up the first pearl, my computer chimes in with a warning that sentinels have been deployed. That was fast. Wait, what was that, computer? Elite sentinels, you say? Well that escalated quickly, but I've probably still got some time before they appear, right? Wrong. Emerging from the mouth of the cave, I see the normal drones, followed by a few vicious mechanical dogs. No biggie, dogs have melee atacks, I'll be fine, I think. Not these dogs though, they've got dual laser cannons strapped to their heads. They only stop chasing to fire at me, and are very quick to pick up pursuit once again. I have no recourse but to flee, as my sheilds start depleting at a very rapid pace. Luckily I have an extended sprint perk that I picked up a few stops ago, and boy am I glad I had it installed, because I make it back to my ship just as my sprint wears out. Huffing and puffing, I climb into the cockpit, with my sheilds at roughly 10%, I slam on the W key to take off as the cockpit door SLOWLY clicks into place, and its off into the sky with me, laughing the whole way as I point the ship straight up and breach atmosphere.  Crossing into the cold emptyness of space, I see the local space station in the distance. Safe at last, I think; or was I? Excuse me, computer, I didn't quite catch that. Did you just say that my cargo is being scanned? By whom? Hostile, you say? Targetting me? Why? I'm just a lowly space vagabond, trying to get fuel for my hyperdrive. What have I got that is so valuable? Oh, right, the intergalactic space pearls. And thus begins my first space dogfight, I'm pretty sure I'm going down. Bobbing and weaving, I think back to what I know about space dogfighting, and the only voice I can hear is Peppy from Starfox, telling me to do a barrel roll. Frantically, I roll, and aim for an asteroid feild, hoping that the rocks will smash my pursuer's ship to smithereens. I speed up, and flip on him, track him, and let loose with my photon cannons, scoring some hits. I take heavy fire head on as we pass each other, but I am quicker on the turn around this time, catching my assailant mid bank as he is crossing my T. His starboard side is riddled with laser fire, and he spins out of control, only to explode in a fiery death a few seconds later. Acting purely on instinct I point myself at the space staion, and engage impulse speed as fast as I can, watching my arrival time click down. These are the slowest 8 seconds of my life.  I reach the station coming at a slight angle to the entrance, but I make the curve, and coast to a stop in the landing bay. My cockpit opens, and I emerge, victorious. I push my keybard drawer into my desk, spin my office chair around, and fall to the carpeted floor of my apartment, nearly hyperventillating with the adrenaline rush. I crawl on hands and knees into my kitchen, pull myself up with the refridgerator door handle, and drink 16 oz. of water in one gulp. I eat a few cheetos, and replay the events in my mind. I begin adding up the profit I will have made from the sale of the space pearls, it should put my bankroll up to around 500,000 spacebucks, halfway to that new ship I wanted. Would it be worth it to go back to that cave? Oh, no! I have no idea where it is!!!  Yet I will return to the planet's surface. Not for the fame, not for the glory, not for the women, and not for the spacebucks. No, I will return for still another reason. I MUST return, because I never found that zinc I was looking for in the first place.

So I guess the big question is whether or not this is everything everyone ever dreamed of in a space exploration game or if this hype train, like so many others, has run off the rails and crashed into the perennial wall of gamer disappointment and the answer is probably more with the latter than the former. HOWEVER, just because this isn't the absolute epitome of a wet dream for everyone that's ever wanted to pilot their own intergalactic vessel into the distant expanse doesn't make this a bad game by any means. I don't think any game could have really lived up to the level of hype that this game built and quite honestly I went into this game ignoring the majority of it because people have this overwhelming tendency to want to make a things grander in their head than what they actually are. With that being said what does this game have to offer and what is it lacking??  Pros - This game is ENORMOUS in scale - Each planet is unique enough that it makes exploring them enjoyable for the most part - This game is absolutely stunning to look at, there's a grandness but also a simplicity to its graphics that is extremely pleasant to the eye. - Exploration is definitely encouraged as the more things you discover and name the more money you make which can be spent on various different things from new space ships to resources for those who don't feel like gathering them. - Equipment can be upgraded by finding new blueprints or interacting with the aliens at outposts and space stations - There are some elements of danger to keep you on your toes. Some planets have hostile or passive drones, some planets have acidic atmospheres or extreme temperatures and there are also roving gangs of pirates looking to steal resources which breaks the monotony of space travel.  Cons - The game is extremely repetitive. Pretty much gather resources so you can upgrade to make it to the center of the universe...that's pretty much the point. Much of the flora on every planet is similar as well, the real unique aspect is the animals and some of the different location types.  - Resources are extremely easy to gather and the majority of your equipment is run off of common isotopes that are found on EVERY single planet regardless if it says resources are sparce. This makes survival a bit TOO easy when you can simply shoot a few trees and refuel your life support or shoot a few drones or various other metals to refuel your suit to keep out extreme temperature. - Combat is wonky. Space combat in particular is probably the worst in my opinion. Most ships that fight you are faster than you which makes catching up with them and shooting them down a pain, and with super sensitive controls it feels like I'm trying to fight someone while slipping on a block of ice which is a shame because bands of marrauding ships are probably one of the most interesting aspects of the combat system. I found myself dying to space ships more than anything. Drones are also pretty easy to defeat and serve as a threat mainly to someone who doesn't have much in the way of upgrades. - The language system is interesting but terrible in execution. I mean I get that they didn't want people to learn a language right away and I think it adds a layer of immersion to meet aliens you can't communicate with clearly BUT after close to ten hours I'm literally almost 0% closer to knowing what any particular person is saying despite unlocking multiple relics and monoliths because most of the monoliths I unlock have uncommon words that are almost NEVER used in the virtually simple dialogue of the aliens. It reminds me too much of the language system in FF10 and that's not really a good thing.    Overall If you're looking for the best of everything you won't get it here. This game tries to be a jack of all trades but ultimately masters none BUT honestly despite that I still like this game. I find the exploring and traveling extremely cathartic whether I'm checking out a pristine body of water on a lush green planet and documenting its varied animal life or searching through old colonial buildings destroyed by some odd plant life. I think this is the kind of game where mileage may vary, some people will see it as too repetititious with not enough variety on each planet BUT I found that even if I visited 4 planets in a system that were alike it made it that much better when I found a moon of a planet in a neighboring system teeming with a variety of creatures and colors. Is it worth the full retail $60??? probably not, it's more of a $30 to $40 type of game in my opinion BUT I would say when it goes on sale give it a shot but don't go into it with the impression that it will live up to even half the hype people created, examine the game for what it is and not what you think it should have been and you might enjoy yourself.

tl;dr: take a bad space shooter, a bad space trader, and mix it with a bad survival game to come up with a surprisingly OK game that has tremendous potential.   The non-ADHD crowd please read on:  + It's a great concept, and nicely executed. Hat's off to the developers who managed to pull this off: no (or rather: well concealed) loading time + Incredible scale. Yeah, a couple of thousand stars would have sufficed, and after a million it becomes meaningless.. 18 Quintillion? Overkill, But in a good way.  + Performancewise it's OK - I'm running it on an iMac in Boot Camp, and everyone knows Macs are %ç@#! for gaming. Still don't understand some folk's fixation on fps, though. A good game is good, as long as it's fps are bearable, and no amount of fps can make a crap game good. + this game has potential, more so than many others I have played in a long time  The game looks nice. Cartoonish in many respects, especially off-planet, but still nice. But then, I guess, we get into the decidedly mixed bag territory: gameplay, or rather: the substance beneath it. What do you expect, what do you want from a game. I'm an average guy - I want to be entertained. I expected a mix between Minecraft (survival type) and Elite:Dangerous (space combat/trader). The sad thing is - I got it.   Like when you describe someone a mix of Einstein and Schwarzenegger, it's the mix that makes or breaks it. An in this case, the game got something along the lines of Einstein's muscles, and Schwarzenegger's linguistic prowess. The space sim part is downright apalling. I'm aware that this game is designed for Console controls, but something that handles this badly is disappointing. Also (and I'm decidedly trying NOT being silly arguing how 'realistic' this is), I'm somwhat put off by the depiction of space flight and scale. In NMS, the planets float around, close to each other like large meat balls in a thick soup of asteroid spaghetti. IMHO, E:D has it right with immense stretches of nothing and a few gigantic balls of rock strewn in-between. The space stations are cartoonish, with (what appears to me) identical lay-out (this includes the poted plants) and nothing to do. Well, at least you can get out of your ship and walk about, so take that, Elite! Space combat is not something I enjoyed, which is probably due to the bad handling characteristics of the space craft, and its next to non-existing configuration options (if this was a space shooter, you'd have oodles of weapons, shields, sensors and other stuff). So OK, it's not a space shooter. Trading, on the other hand, is abysmally implemented (you have no storage to speak of, no market inteligence, and since the game continually drives you forward to the center of the galaxy, you don't exploit trading routes). So it would seem that space travel is not the focus of this game  Then there is the survival aspect. The core game loop of NMS is coming down to a planet, gather resources, explore an anomaly or structure, build some stuff to sell or re-fill your systems, leave planet, warp to next system, loop. The variety of theplanets is great, but after a couple of hours, they all blend into each other. The problem here is that the alien planets are all derived from an algorithm, and after a while you see the formula, no longer the result. Yes, the things are beautiful to look at. Winged cows are funny. Essentially, though, all this alieness derives from the same formula. But is *IS* entertaining, and I'll give full marks for that.  You go down-planet to harvest resources with some kind of mining gun, and use this to destruct the environment. This part is extremely well executed and stays fresh all the way. I wish Minecraft had such a tool. But here's the missed opportunity: NMS's goal is to get to the center of the universe, so you don't stay on any of the planets. I think NMS could have greatly profited from ditching the 'ST:VOY' premise (which killed that series for me) in favor of allowing you to build a base. Because although everything is there, it's not. Currently it's Minecraft without the crafting part. Great promise, though. I hear the developers are thinking abot adding base building, so here's hoping.  Some people habe criticized Elite: Dangerous as 'a mile wide, an inch thick'. NMS currently seems somewhat thinner. It's not a space shooter/trader. But it's also not a Minecraft type of game. Einstein's brawns, I'm afraid.  Then again, I've had fun playing NMS, and even though I feel that the space shooter (which I somehow thought it would be) is likely a complete write-off, the Survival part has a chance to become nice one NMS adds base building: Build stuff, fly to other planets to get tech and rare materials, and finally, add multiplayer (that was left on the cutting floor, it currently doen't work).

I jumped in with no expectations, I ignored the hype and I blundered around for the first half-hour turning plantlife and rocks into inventory filler and getting lost in caves filled with glowing nodes all while the sun set, leaving me even more wary of how far i was travelling from my shattered ship, naming everything I scanned after myself (of course!).   It was EXCITING when I rose off the ground for the first time, I took to the sky with a smile, although I dislike the awkward mouse/keyboard flight controls and the ship's inability to get close enough to the ground to land manually (I prefer the flight sim approach!), and you should have seen the grin on my face when I turned the ship skyward and shot for the stars! That visually incredible sensation of hurtling through space at a million miles an hour, watching the planet I had called home for a full day-night cycle...knowing I'd never see it again, was probably the most emotive experience I've had from a game this year. It was everything I had hoped Destiny's ship mechanic would be.  I'm 25 hours in, or therabouts, at the time of writing this...still searching for some important 'Passes' that let me access locked doors and the goodies behind them. For 25 hours i've been staring these doors down and walking away empty-handed (the explorer in me is in agony!). It's disappointing that these 'Passes' are so difficult to obtain (or do they just take AGES to find thanks to RNG? Also a cheap tactic IMHO).   I recommend referring to the wiki whilst playing this game...sparingly. As much as I prefer to learn a game's ins and outs without external help, a few little things like where to find some minerals and what certain crafted products do can't hurt. The game seems very stable alt-tabbing between it and a web browser. I daresay I'd have returned the game if it was anything as terrible at alt-tabbing as say Skyrim or Mirrors Edge. I can guarantee sci-fi nerds will either love or hate the game's art style. I see BSG/Star Wars in the ship designs, a lot of Mass Effect and Destiny in the Monolith/Atlas stuff...there's even a bit of the Half Life 2's citadel core in the Atlas Sphere design. Overall though, the game seems more a mashup of other things rather than a game of its own. NPCs are Morrowind-esque, they just stand there and give you dialog boxes. To be expected with this genre of game? I would have liked a little more substance there. There was that one funny moment when an alien warrior exchanged nudes with me and bam, suddenly I was betrothed to it, so there was that. The game does a good job of making you feel like you've genuinely stumbled across a galaxy full of sentient creatures with their own cultures, languages, and all the barriers of misunderstanding that brings. You may find yourself enjoying the quest to discover new words; each word learned can lead to a better understanding of their emotions, their struggles, their trade deals, it's fascinating in that regard.  But now the bad... I have to admit I would have liked it if it weren't so big. If we were given one single open galaxy to explore, and the ability to commune with other players on space stations (think Destiny's Tower social server system) to trade/interact with each other. Imagine if we were given a Mass Effect style galaxy map and we could see hotspots of activity that are actual players streaking through the galaxy toward the centre. I guess that's another idea for another game, some other time... I can respect that instead of an MMO, they took the Journey approach in the sense that the game is 'online' and you are sharing a universe with other people! One of the things i enjoyed the most about Journey was the fleeting touch of wordless communication between players. If you just happened to be in the same place at the same time, there you both were, and it was glorious.   Sadly this game is too big, too expansive, for me to ever hope to meet another real player. The Starbound player in me wants to jump on a server with a group of friends and go exploring the infinite universe together. Every time I stood on the planet's surface hacking away at plutonium shards and hear an engine overhead, I looked up with hope, but alas it's not that type of game. They said we'd theoretically be able to see other players coming and going from trading posts around the planets. I now understand what they meant by theoretically: they mean it's possible, but likely never to happen.  If exploration is your kind of thing, the procedural generation doesn't get old too quick. The worlds are genuinely incredible and space is immensely enjoyable to swirl around in, dodging asteroids, blasting them open for fuel... I still like this game, I still listen for the engines and look up just in case that ship is flying erratically, desperate to wrestle with the clumsy flight controls in order to land beside me. There are no gestures in this game, but if somehow we find ourselves on a planet together, you'll see me waving in spirit.

**This game is not for everyone**  I've got to say, I'm actually enjoying this game more than I thought I would. Probably not in the most conventional way, since this game triggers the crap out of my OCD's both in a good and negative way that its noticable. I can see why the reviews are mixed, why half the people are hating itand why half like it. This game is a mixed bag of stuff. Its very Spore like but at 1000 times Spores scale in terms randomly generated worlds and creatures. It is repetitive in its basic ideas, yet its still rewarding in many ways. NMS is actually quite educational and keeps the mind sharp. It does show and teach you a bit about the periodic table of elements and what entities, living or not, they come from. Which ever planet you start on or explore, you'll learn (not you personally, but your character) faux alien languages word by word, very similar to how you learn the Al-bhed language in Final Fantasy X letter by letter, except more vastly. You also solve different kinds of puzzles from math/algebra patterns to word phrases. Most are pretty simple, at least to me. As I meantioned my OCD above as well as having ADD/ADOS, the inventory and resource gathering is the really obnoxious part, especially with how you are limited on what you can carry. By limited I mean youll have to sacrifice resources (delete them) if you need to carry/farm another the repair/craft/reload your exo/ship/tool. But! If you figure out the pattern of how you want to play, then its less of a hassel but still remains tedious. I hate the 'Destiny' inventory system, especially how you can carry more than you can store in your ship for a long while till you find better ships.  Im not going to list pros or cons because I feel it would probably be to biased. The only thing I will say is that just because this game has 18+ Quintillion randomly generated planets, it doesnt justify the $59.99 price tag. This should've had a $39.99 price tag at most, especially being an indie kickstarter title that made tons. I wasnt part of the kickstart or even a preorder purchaser. Besides the price point, I am enjoying the game. Just remember, its not for everyone.  **TIPS** Stay on your starting planet as long as you can endure it. Dont waste your time and resources adding upgrades to your ship or tool as they are not transferable to any ship or tool you wish to upgrade to.  Just collect the blue prints until you are satisfied with whichever ship/tool you found or bought that has a lot of slots in it, then go resource hunting for the upgrades. Hunt for resources for 1 or 2 upgrades at a time or if you're OCD with ADOS like me you'll be over clutter and not want to get rid of anything.  You have less than 0.0001% chance in ever bumping into another player, but is possible!

This is Elite reimagined and it has many positive qualities such as complex crafting and a real sense of just one more discovery.... However the rest of the game just doesn't quite cut it today, land combat is basic, space combat is biased towards upgraded ships.   At this stage I'm giving a reserved thumbs up but Steam really needs a neural button because as it stands this game is neither good or bad it is somewhere in between. If you see the trailers and think 'This looks like my kind of game', the game is for you. If you see the trailers and think 'This looks boring', the game is not for you. No Man's Sky is a survival game, focused on exploring alien planets and gathering resources. There is a mystery that you unravel as you progress through the game, told in the form of text. The game is very hands-off, and largely leaves you to your own devices. If you're the type of person who loves exploring and finding out what lies at the end of this cave, or if you want a laid back experience with artistically beautiful (albeit technically dubious) presentation, you'll probably enjoy the game. If you judge a game's value on a dollar per hour metric, this game is worth it. Even though I am greatly enjoying the game, I do feel it is overpriced. This is NOT a AAA game. It is an indie game through and through. Expect nothing more than that. This is NOT 'Skyrim in Space' This is NOT 'Elite: Dangerous' This is NOT 'Star Citizen' TL;DR: If you're not sure about if you'll enjoy the game, pass for now and come back when it's on sale. What you get is a laid back survival game with a compelling mystery beneath the surface. For Fans Of: Don't Starve, Elite: Dangerous, Minecraft, Interstellar (movie).

Not long in this title, but long enough to know enough, know what I mean?  I will lay this out as simply as is possible. If you're looking for an action space epic, this isn't your game. If you're looking for a deep single/multiplayer component, this isn't your game. If you're looking for an overarching story, branching story paths and multiple endings (I'm assuming), this isn't your game.   However.....if you are looking for a game where the experience and the journey are what interest you....then this is your game. If you're looking for a sense of wonder and you're willing to forgive some flaws for what is, let's face it, an unbelievable feat of software/mathematical engineering, then this is your game. If you're looking for something that is unique, then this is your game.   Admittedly, there are some launch foibles. I have *not* had the game crash once, not once. I have, however, had some graphical glitches and frame-rate issues, a lot of camera jumping. It is highly likely these issues will be addressed, and quickly. Everyone attacking Hello Games here needs to have a good long look at themselves - look at what they've accomplished with a small team! They will sort these issues, quickly, and why? Because they believe in the game and they look after their gamers. There were bound to be launch issues, it was inevitable. Expecting otherwise was just unreasonable.   Listen, for those of you on the fence, read my second and third paragraphs. See what you're after. If you take the leap, or if you wait for the sales, you will be enriched by the experience in this game. That first planet you see? That's yours. All of it. The creatures were generated by code and you're the first to see the result. That sunset is for your eyes alone, for now. I can't convey quite strongly enough - this game is a marvel, if you can forgive certain preconceptions. Abandon your traditional sense of an AAA title, get rid of your gaming baggage, give this title a shot, it's worth it.

I'd like to start off by saying that I don't think I am one of the unlucky customers that is having issues with performance. When I first started the game, it seemed a bit shaky. However, once I changed the FPS Settings a bit and the map had a minute to generate, things ran very smoothly. Therefor, keep in mind that this review is from the perspective of someone without many of the issues that has plagues other players.  Now, I'll begin with the games opening sequence. I found that immediately throwing the player into the world without providing them with an opportunity to tinker with settings was a double-edged sword. On one hand, this cinematic opening experience allowed players to become more immersed in the game. Instead of letting the players' brain get switched into the 'this is a game' mode that settings tend to do, the game forces you into the opening sequence while the player's brain is still in the 'this is exciting as hell' state of mind it usually is when you run the game for the first time.  On the other hand, I can imagine that cinematic opening experience could be ruined quite easily if the game is running at 5 frames per second because the player hasn't optimized the graphical settings (although that player probably shouldn't have bought the game in the first place then). This is only made more frustrating when you do get the chance to tinker settings and you get a message saying you need to restart the game for those changes to take place. I understand that this is likely implemented for a reason, however that does not change the fact that it is frustrating.   Now we move onto the actual gameplay. Putting the technical quirks to the side, this game is gorgeous. It is not every day that so early on in a game, you can fly up a hillside and be left speechless by digital landscape complete with starship souring overhead and weird bipedal turtles awkwardly trotting in a field. Joking aside, this game truly is breathtaking. Even on the ugliest of planets, the color scheme manages to balance nicely and the somewhat almost cartoony art style masks the comically flat grass textures well.   However, there are times when you are really trying to progress in the game where you begin to wonder if maybe a bit too much time was put into the visuals and not enough was put into planning out the player's experience. An example of this is the plant life. Countless times you are drawn long distances to inspect a pretty glow only to find that it's just another source of coal. In games like this, it is better to provide a concrete way of telling if a resource is worth their time or not. It is not sources of coal that should be pretty and eye-catching but rather sources of rarer materials (I can't name any because I haven't really found any yet, not eye-catching enough).   Similarly, the game manages to throw just enough information at the player at once for that player not to be able to comprehend everything. Usually that information is just a menu or two away but the player shouldn't have to look something up when it was in their face 15 seconds ago. This translates into the crafting system as well, the same problem of too much information causes the player to miss instructions on simple tasks like crafting. It took me way too long to figure out how to craft the materials to repair my launch thrusters.   Believe it or not, all that I just complained about are actually pretty minor things. Once the player experiments and figures out what they need to on their own, they are off to the races. In a way, the way the player unintentionally has to figure things out on their helps to give that player a sense of freedom that really drives to beauty of this game home. There is a great sense of accomplishment when you figure out how to travel around a planet faster and a great sense of relief when you find out the hard way that you can smack into the asteroids.   In the end, when you get past the quirks and rocky launch of No Man's Sky and put in the time get learn the basics, playing the game becomes a blast. I would recommend this game to anyone so long as I can offer them my services as some kind of tech support when they need it.

Let me preface everything by saying that I actually bought this game on impulse before watching the trailers.  I like space, I like exploration, some of the early reviews were positive, so I bought it.  I regret that impulsive decision.    Take it from a 5 year veteran of Eve: Online this game is BORING.  Imagine Eve minus the hordes of players trying to kill you, it's more boring than that.    There is supposed to be septillions of stars and planets generated, but their algorithm is poor. This results in maybe 12 different planet types and 30 animal species. I'm being very generous with the planets, for the most part they are just different colors with a different icon showing you what is killing you today.   Now I wasn't expecting Spore like creature variety, but this is insulting. All of them look the same. There might be some slight variation between the crab like species trying to kill me, but I honestly couldn't tell.   The entire game is far too easy, in my trek from the start to the center of the galaxy my shields dropped a total of maybe 10 times, I still don't know what the death screen looks like.   The interface is utterly terrible. You have to hold to click EVERYTHING. I cannot fathom a reason this has to be for literally EVERYTHING. The galaxy map is the single worst aspect of the UI, a rather galaring flaw for something that wants to do space exploration. The path to the center is utterly useless, as I got close to the center it literally got stuck in a dead end. It ignores your hyperdrive upgrades meaning it's course will take you through about a dozen short hops and then abruptly stop, while you can reach the end in one jump or infact go much futher. There is a total disconnect between 'Distance from Center' and 'Linear Distance', 500ly for the former is about 1,500ly for the latter. You are down to luck for finding any particular location, even ones you've visited before.   The game play is more or less a resource grind, you land on a planet, shoot at a rock with a mining laser, you leave the planet to go shoot at a different rock. There are NPC, they are of three races, all of which just stand or sit alone in one place. They never do anything, you can talk to them and maybe get a blue print or something, but thats it, there is no personality, not even real interaction.   There was an Atlas quest line, that brought you to 10 admittedly rather spiffy looking space stations. Actually I lied, there are 4 rather spiffy looking space stations that are repeated a couple of times in no particular order. It starts no where and ends in a non ending. This may last you a couple of hours (or however long it takes you to realize the map system is trash and just jump to the end). But it pales in comparison to reaching the Galactic Center.   Thats the final insult, what happens at the center. I'll rant in a spoilerific manner after the next paragraph. Suffice to say if we reached the center and had a planet sized MIDDLE FINGER to explore, this would still be less of a ♥♥♥♥ YOU than what we got. Because at least the Flipping Bird of God would be an object of interest and discussion.    It was after I had played for a while that I went out and watched the trailers, holy ♥♥♥♥ I wanted to play that game, too bad it's not what I bought. I'm angry I wasted money buying this, I would have been furious if my expectations were that high. This isn't a case of a fandom hyping in a vacuum, the developers were outright lying to us. Not just in the trailers, but in the words they were speaking. ♥♥♥♥ this game. Hello.  I wanted to love this game, I heard about it in early March and was instantly enthralled by just how unbelievable the scope of it was, and the potential it had.   For the first 24 hours in the game, I can say I really did love it, anyone who asked me about the game I’d recommend they buy it. Around the 25 hour mark I started to notice just how repetitive the game is, not in what you do, as I always knew that was the case. However the planets were all the same. Every planet class has certain materials you’ll find on it, and those materials won't be found on another planet of a different class, even if it has the same characteristics of that other planet.. Ex: Planet X is cold, it has Element X in abundance, however Planet Y is inhabited by hostile sentinels, it has Element Y in abundance, Planet Z is cold, and inhabited by hostile sentinels, it has neither Element X nor Element Y, instead it has Element Z, which is found on all planets. (Updated) This game was highly anticipated and I was really looking forward to it. I like many ideas and concepts in the game and the general look and feel is gorgeous. The game feels very relaxed and enjoyable. It could be a lot of fun. But.  As of today, this is why I would suggest to wait for at least the next two or three patches before buying this game (aka: 3 months or so):  * the storyline feels a little 'thin' and is easy to miss alltogether. * (FIXED!) the game stutters and lags like hell, even with the latest 'No Man's Sky optimzed' drivers. * the 'radar' is basically a hoax / dummy and does not help you in any way. It is just a waste of GUI-space. * your ships' scanner looks neat but thats it. * your personal scanner is very picky about what it revaels to you. While it tends to miss ressources you are needing, it keeps pointing out others you already depleted (espec. platinum flowers, for example.) The scanner won't tell you about animals / aliens. * buildings you see don't necessarily get flagged. * (probably fixed) Locations you discover as a tag on screen will be lost on reload, espec. operation centers and factories which really sucks, since you need to invest ressources to discover them. * The chance of not getting the antimatter recipe is stellar and if that happens to you, you are grounded for ages (two real days now in my case). * landing on landingpatches or generally anywhere close to where you intend to land is a matter of pure luck. * many important functions and features of the game are not explained anywhere (are recipes for the multitool consumed? why does one sometimes launch from ground to orbit, sometimes not? etc. etc.) * avoid space/air combat vs small ships. they will outmaneuver you no matter what. * Why aren't there personal notes (saved locally, not uploaded) to a discovery? Like 'Is hostile' or 'Rich on copper' or whatever?  Due to the fact that you need antimatter to do interstellar travel, getting the recipe for creating antimatter is a cornerstone in the game. Unfortunately it is very very very easy to miss that step. There is no second chance in case of a blunder   . Same will possibly be true with other 'story milestones', which feels like the game was not really thought through. Sadly, this is true for many detials throughout the game.     One can actually find the missed recipes, but it takes some serious time and effort. In my case it took more than two days of grinding only factories and operation centers to finally get antimatter. The game itself does not exactly help you there.  All this cobined: To some degree No Man's Sky is exactly the game that at the same time I always wanted and never wanted to play. No Man's Sky has a lot of potential and many shortcomings and bugs. It sure is a lot of fun and a lot of frustration.  As said above: Wait till the first two patches went into the game before buying.  The first patch helped with most of the technical issues (stuttering, lag).

Alright, now I've only ever written a review for Life Is Strange. That game absolutely deserved it, and so does NMS, but for the exact opposite reason.    Look, I enjoy the game, and I like the idea, but jesus christ this is just pathetic, and I can't recommend it to anyone in its current state. It's playable, and has its fun moments, but really I wouldn't buy it unless you're dead set on it, in which a review wont change your mind. Definitely not for the price it's at either.      It's a space exploration game, but I have absolutely no desire to be in space or even in my ship. The controls for flying are HORRIBLE, the ship speeds are ♥♥♥♥ing annoying (basically like 1mph, 5mph, and 100mph), and space battles just ♥♥♥♥ me off and I can't imagine anyone finding them even the least bit fun. If you're flying in pulse mode (basically planet to planet warp speed) and hostile ships detect your 'rare items' (you can literally have nothing in your inventories and they'll still detect you...), it tears you out of pulse mode and forces you to fight them. You can't re-enter pulse or warp away to escape, and can't travel fast enough to ever escape unless you happen to be close enough to a planet or space station. Then with the pathetic controls, if there's a handful of ships attacking you you're basically screwed because they can somehow fly much faster than you and it's extremely difficult to even hit one. Oh, and your shield depletes way too quick and you have to sort through menus in real time to recharge it, with elements you either don't have or can't find in space, only on land. So you have no choice but to die basically.   And that happens a lot if you spend time in space.  Also I have a very highly upgraded ship that was like 47 million credits that has 46 inventory slots, so good luck with any ship.     So that leaves running around on planets as the only 'chill, relaxing' thing to do basically. Which I actually enjoy. Really, that part of the game is fun. However, there's a few things there that ♥♥♥♥ me off as well.    1. Literally every planet is inhabited. (Probably by other players too if you could actually see them) Theres some sort of sign of civilization every couple minutes of walking distance in every direction. Which is fine in terms of playing, it gives me something to head for and explore rather than just walking around on the dull landscapes. But when it's supposed to feel like you're exploring new territory, planets being overrun with shelters, trade stations, monoliths, etc. ruin that narrative.   2. About 95% of the planets I've visited have been some sort of barren hazardous bull ♥♥♥♥. Whether it's ice, radiation, heat, or poison, it's literally all the same. I have to run indoors or shoot my own shelter in a hill every 10-20 seconds to keep my hazard support from running out. That's not fun, that's just annoying and it makes me go to a different planet. And the nice planets I have found that I do want to explore are devoid of anything worth exploring. There's never any rare resources, hardly even any animals, and again I just go and find another planet.   3. Sentries are a decent concept, but honestly they should be removed completely. Again, it ruins that whole 'discovering planets for the first time' thing, and they do nothing but prevent me from doing what the game says I'm supposed to do.    4. When discount GLADoS from portal says 'incoming storm', you have straight up zero time to get anywhere. The storm hits as soon as it finishes warning you.   5. I like the idea of unique animals, but they could have actually just dedicated a couple weeks to designing the animals themselves so that they make sense, because most just look stupid. I don't care if that means theres only a few thousand animals versus however many there are, it would look better that way. An extension of that, some of the ships are ridiculous as well, but I am glad that inventory space is not related to size of the ship because I wanted a small ship not two sideways grain silos with a cockpit thrown on top.    6. Even though every planet is unique, it all seems the same. There's basically a handful of environments that all look and interact the same, the only difference is the shape of the landscape and where things are.        Really though, it is a bit of fun and it's worth trying, but not at 60 dollars. They have a lot of work to do to make this even a good game, and I do look foward to the updates they'll apparently be making (if they try to make any of it paid DLC though I wouldn't be suprised if they have to change their names and move to remote locations).    Bottom line is, don't expect to be blown away or even impressed, but it's a nice concept and might eventually evolve into something worth half its price.

For those of you who do not want to read the whole thing, here is the short version: This game feels more like a Beta, due to the slew of missing features. It is worth buying if it goes on sale for 50% off (until the updates are rolled out and we get the game we were promised), but right now the tutorial alone WILL take up the two hours of refund time Steam grants you. ---------------------------------WARNING: EXTREMELY LONG REVIEW AHEAD--------------------------------  I REALLY wanted to like this game....hell, I was excited for almost two years after I first heard about NMS. Then the interviews kept showing up on the air waves, promising this, promising that and made my excitement build to a point of almost buying a PS4 JUST TO PLAY IT THREE DAYS EARLY!  Alas, I waited for the PC release. Woke up early, brushed my teeth, threw on some jeans, my favorite Rick & Morty T-Shirt (I even shouted SHOW ME THE MORTY a few times, out of sheer excitement) and took off on my adventure into the unknown.   The first hour and a half was pretty boring, but I expected nothing less from a tutorial. My second hour in was kind of a.....ship wreck. Pirates shot me down and I crash landed on a water based planet.....fun fact, I needed Zinc to repair my ship and there were no Zinc flowers to be found....so, I went about wondering the planet for almost three hours, going to points of interest in hopes of finding another lifeform who can help me. FINALLY I found one - an overwhelming feeling of accomplishment & relief flooded my body and I was able to purchase some Zinc from the Galactic Trade Network (as well as a Bypass Chip, to get my ship back). With a loud 'WUBBA LUBBA DUB DUB!” I blasted off from that damned planet.   By now, I fixed my warp drive and was able to jump to different stars......and this is where things started to go downhill. I would go an entire three hour session not finding anything interesting (which, to be honest, was to be expected, based off of what Sean Murray said during many of his interviews)...but I never ran out of supplies, nor did I really have to do much mining. This was due to the abundance of Space Stations....like, literally, every star has a Space Station; anytime I was low on something, I could always hit up a Space Station, get the supplies I needed from the Trade Network (or an alien who happened to be visiting the same Space Station as me....which was always happening) and warp to my next star.   I don't want to be a ♥♥♥♥, so what you read next MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS    ----------- AGAIN, POTENTIAL SPOILERS AHEAD ------------------------    ---------- LAST CHANCE TO STOP READING -----------------------------        Okay then - making my way to the center of the galaxy (repeat, not Universe, you are working your way to the center of the current GALAXY you are in. Pretty big difference, Hello Games) became EXTREMELY redundant, until I found a Space Anomaly. Now, at this point you should have made a choice of staying on the 'Fixed Path of The Atlas' or doing your own thing. In my game, I said ♥♥♥♥ The Atlas and did my own thing (thug life)...but anytime you enter the Space Anomaly and speak with the High Priest, you are given a choice of getting back on the path of The Atlas, some resources (can't say I've picked either one of those choices), OR help getting to the center of the galaxy; I always asked for help to get to the center.  Now, here is where things get a little more.....strange. The Priest will open a black hole for you and you will travel XXXXXXXX lightyears toward the center...but if you look at your galactic map, it is almost as if your 'Distance to the Center' barely changes. For example, my overhead display said I travelled 699,400 lightyears, and my distance to the center before was 161,000 lightyears, but now it's only 160,800.....my warp drive can travel 300 lightyears each jump.....making the black hole useless and pointless. Now, this has turned into a grinding simulator. I'm nowhere near the center still....I've been playing for almost 38 hours and still, I am roughly 158,000 lightyears away from the center of the galaxy (again, not the universe, contrary to popular belief).  I may pick this game up and start playing it again, one day, but I can’t help but wonder what this game would have been like had all the features Sean Murray said were going to be in the game, were actually in the game at launch. The notion of “If you haven’t’ discovered it, it doesn’t mean it isn’t in the game” is overplayed so much that it is sickening: Once this game released on PC and folks started to monitor packets, it was quickly realized the only communication your game is doing with a central server, is when you name planets. That’s it. There is literally no way (contrary to what was said by Sean, multiple times) you can see another player, even if they stand right in front of you. There are not multiple “lobbies”, as the user can disconnect and reconnect as many times as he/she wants…the only packets that will be communicated with the NMS server is your save data, and planets in your area that may have been named…but that’s all that is being queried.  I won’t point out all of the other features that were left off of this “Full Release” version of NMS, you can look it up. All in all, this game is not worth the $60.00 price tag, primarily for the fact that this is more like a Beta Test of the actual game we will have in a year, after a slew of updates. Should this game ever go on sale for 50% off, then it would be worth it. But, again, I HIGHLY advise against buying this game in its current state – you WILL use up your 2 refund time just making it through the tutorial.   If you read this whole thing, thank you.

Overall - Pretty Poor 90% of the planets are the same - and the ones that aren't are rare. In 15 hours of playtime, I found 2 planets that didn't fit into the same red-rock mould; 1 moon with some snow, and 1 flora planet. Fauna is nowhere near as complex as shown in game demos. Food chains don't exist as shown and animals have no noticable interactions with each other. Dinosaurs like those which are shown in the gameplay trailer, and there is very little difference between species on different planets - the same few appear everywhere. No massive fleets jump in to star systems like shown in the gameplay trailer, as well as no large scale space battles where you can pick a side. At most 2 or 3 do, and a couple of pirates attack them infinetely until you join in. Even then, you can in duck in and out of a space station until you eventually kill them. Speaking of space stations, they were talked about as if they would be hubs for trading and interactions. Instead, you have a space station the size of a moon inhabited by a single NPC, with a few ships appearing every now and then. It was also advertised that you could take multiple routes in terms of your ship, either opting to take an exploration, fighting, or trading ship. This simply isn't true. All of the ships handle the same, with the same speed and same weapons. The only thing you're really looking for in a ship is the inventory size. Other than that they are all the same with a slightly different model and paint-job. There is no multiplayer, another feature that was lied about. You could spend over 20 hours trying to reach the same planet as a friend, only to find that you can't see or interact with one another once you arrive.  By far the worst thing about No Man's Sky is the number of bugs. On multiple occasions I would explore a planet 100% completion at which point I would be prompted to claim a reward. At this point, I would then try and upload a planet only for the game to tell me that I hadn't found everything, even though all boxes were checked and the game said 100% complete. The game is also terribly optimised, so much so that even high-end gaming PCs struggle to run it at a constant FPS, not to mention crashes, which are far too abundant. I probably spent more time loading into the game than actually playing it. What made this even worse is that a lot of the time, No Man's Sky would ignore my restore points unless I saved multiple times, resulting in several insanely frustrating moments where a planet I had completed would be uncompleted within seconds. The only thing worse than this however, is not being able to fully research a planet at all. Often, I would reach a point where I only needed to find 1 species, only to then find that this species was perpetually locked into the floor, where I was completely unable to scan it. Clipping through objects is also much more common than it should be. Whether in an exosuit or a spaceship, you can move through various objects as if you were a ghost, further damaging your immersion in the game.  Other problems with No Man's Sky include the variation. The game is supposed to take place in a galaxy, but I feel like I'm exploring a loop, with the same unending rock planets. Planetery gravity, an addition that might have made planets feel more unique, is unsurprisingly absent as well as orbits. Planets sit stationary around a sun. Sentinels, the game's main antagonistic force, are always samey. Passive walker sentinels don't exist like they do in the gameplay trailer. If you see a two-legged sentinel it is hostile no exceptions.  One of the most anticlimactic and disappointing endings in videogame history.  Overall, even with promises of future updates, £40/$60 is too much for this game. Overhyping and flat-out lying has been used to lure in players in. Don't buy this game, even if the price drops.

This game has a lot of potential. Unmet potential.   Let's go into the bugs first. The frame rate begins to suffer after I've played a while. My machine is a monster compared to the minimum specs for this game, so there is no reason for this other than the program was released in a state of unreadiness. No excuse for that.   There is an astounding lack of content. Many of the creatures on world A look a lot like the creatures on world B.   Now lets talk about gameplay.   The flight model is ludicrously stupid. I should be able to fly my ship into the side of a mountain if I want, or if I make a mistake. Instead the game doesn't let you have anything but marginal control when you're near the ground. This makes landing the ship basically an exercise in luck. Will you get close to where you want to land? Maybe. You do get better at landing in time with practice, but not because you get to look at your landing spot. You simply watch it pass under the nose of your ship, count, and hope you hit the spot you want. This makes landing at trade depots and outposts just stupid.   I have no idea how to look anything but straight ahead on the PC while flying. Maybe there is a way. If there is, I have yet to figure it out. This stuff should be intuitive. The numerical keypad, for example, would have been a great choice for allowing you to look around in flight. But I guess your head gets locked into place once you're in the ship for your own protection.   I played a game and with the bonus ship, wound up losing my hyperdrive. After that trying to get a hyperdrive proved futile. I had to start over, which involved going into my computer's SSD and deleting certain files, and then shutting off and restarting steam cloud. WTH? What sort of game doesn't have a 'NEW GAME' feature?  So much potential here. So little of it fulfilled.  This all said, I will probably play this game as patches come out, content is added, bugs are patched, and the game gets some actual depth. For now I guess it's back to Rimworld.

First off I do not HATE the game. It’s a great walking simulator and looks rather nice at times. There is so much potential in this but as of writing this review it's not there.  What i was expecting from this game and what you actually get:   -  A Space exploration game   While yes the focus was mostly planet side in most of the videos and interviews we saw leading up to the release. In these videos however we see epic space dog fights, fighters flying in wing formations and a rather fun looking experiance.   What we got: something that feels tacked on, an after thought. The ship flies like a drunk pregnant hippo in glue. Its sluggish unresponsive, you can't fly close to the ground. The landing mechanics DO NOT WORK, you basically guess if you are close enough to land on the landing pan but often land RIGHT next to damn thing! The ships often do look awesome but they all fly the same, once you have maxed the cargo slot space then there is never a need to change your ship other than visually.   -  Procedurally generated universe    Ok so yeah technically we did get this. however simply changing a colour pallet and what (rather limited) assets the game uses often makes things a little boring, Honestly i have seen more interesting landscapes from Minecraft.  Also with this come procedurally generated creatures to inhabit your 18 bizzilion worlds. Pity most of them look so stupid it's hard to take it seriously. I have gotten creatures with MASSIVE top portions then supported on 2 toothpick sized legs and then a tiny shrunken head. It's a laugh the first 40 times but after a time you notice the limited assets that the animals are using, and then they begin to look much the same.   -  A Survival Crafting Game   Ok i do like this style of game. However with it being survival you would assume there is some sort of SURVIVAL aspect to the game. Nope none to be had, EVERY planet ever has so many resources that you can't run out of ANYTHING. Sure you may have to hunt for some rarer materials to build some of the things but honestly the “survival” part feels very much like how many games call it an “RPG” just because you level up and can improve your character.  The crafting is also seemingly tacked on like a forgotten mini game. You find blueprints (often the same ones you already had) all over the place, so it really does not feel special or unique when you find these, just more like you should have had them from the start but we needed a way to make you grind.  -  A Chilled Game Experience   Holy buthole batman you need to a gosh darn zen master not to rage at the frame rate drops that happen every 4 hours or so (if one happened in first 2 hours i would have done a request for a refund trust me). Or the crashes to desktop? Or your ship that you landed on the surface of a planet now somehow stuck deep inside the core of the planet and you can mine down any more to get to. Best part is i am one of the lucky few that had a “good” release. I now sort of wish i had not so i could have asked for my money back instead of playing more to hope it got better.   When all's said and done, i would say pick this up on a sale maybe (like a 60% or more, then the price point will be fine) or wait until some content is added to the game.  However if they have the insane idea of EVER charging for the DLC i will change this and bit to simply   Originally posted by  Me in the future :

No Man's Sky is exactly as overhyped I thought it would be. It's style over substance, 100%. It looks great most of the time, the art direction is fantastic and the soundtrack is as immersive as it gets.  Sadly this game has two major problems: Gameplay and UX/UI. The marketing BS frankly bugged me the most about it, along with the blatant lies about multiplayer and Sean's evasive replies. I'm even more shocked that this old scheme worked: They built INSANE amounts of hype, underdelivered spectacularily, don't admit it and almost got away with it.  The way they sold NMS fell into the typical 'procedurally generated without meaning' category, other prime examples being TES: Daggerfall from 1996 (23,000 square kilometers! Over 15,000 towns, cities, villages! 750,000 NPCs! The size of Great Britain!) or Borderlands (17,750,000 different weapons!) which were both actually good games at the time which utilize procedural generation in slightly better ways than NMS.   A mere million things to explore wasn't sufficient enough for Hello Games: Here comes NMS with 18,446,744,073,709,551,616 planets to explore!   I guess their marketing department just came a little when they heard this magic number.  Unfortunately almost everything is in this game is either meaningless, as basic as it can be, has no context, or is incoherent. It tries to be the grandest of them all, but is actually the shallowest. There have also some really weird and sometimes outright bad design decisions been made for this game.  A few examples - You have seen everything there is to do on a planet after the second one you explore. - You will at most encounter one alien at any given time. - Obtaining Warp Drives and doing FTL jumps is easier than opening regular locked doors. You by the way need to talk to ancient alien beings to be blessed with the long forgotten art of opening doors. Behind these doors is mostly generic loot, btw. - Every space station looks the same on the inside. The layout is always exactly the same, with minimal randomized room layouts. - These HUGE stations literally contain zero or one alien(s).  - There are only three 'distinct' alien races. They all hold the same type of tablet. They all share the same type of alien artifacts you can discover. - Planets are LITTERED with man-made structures, but all of them are make-shift outposts, containing, again, zero to two aliens at most. No traces of forming civilizations or anything like that, no. Aliens apparently just randomly built thousands of outposts on every single planet, one alien at a time. They made sure to seal their doors too.  - You need Carbon(!) to talk to aliens multiple times. Why? I don't know! Even better, every room with an alien contains multiple indoor plants, containing carbon. - Everything in this game is a chore: Refilling fuel, unskippable/lengthy cutscene animations, exosuit notifications,  To add insult to injury, the UX is a crime. Often missing context-information and unnecessary click-journeys are just some of the problems. Why do I have to navigate through convoluted UIs to do basic actions as refilling fuel? If I want to liftoff but actually have it in my inventory refill it AUTOMATICALLY jesus christ.  It can't help but think the game would have been magnitudes better if they chose to A) hire proper gameplay and UI/UX designers and B) to invest their resources into hand-crafting a selection of distinct planets with richer, more meaningful content, alien races that are fleshed out, real colonies on planets.. the list of things that would have been the better focus than soulless palette-swaps is as big as the quintillions of planets you can potentially find in this game.   Anyway, I think NMS has it's charm but is way, WAY, smaller and more basic than it tries to be. This would be a great indie early access game release for 20 bucks.  Oh and Hello Games promised BASE BUILDING as additional content in the future. In a game that literally is about exploration and not being in one place all the time. Seems like they don't understand their own game's DNA. Good job!  No Man's Sky sometimes looks pretty good though and certainly has it's moments. It's a shame it was so overhyped.

Marketing materials and features discussed by devs do not represent the actual final product.  Had really, really high hopes for this game, and I still want to really like it, however at this point... it is hard to ignore the vast emptiness and overall rather shallow experience NMS actually is. The core mechanic is basically: Land -> Gather Stuff -> See some things that are kind of different -> Do the same NPC interactions -> Buy new things (maybe) -> Find another planet -> Repeat.  (Oh, and also 50% of the time above will be spent looking at your inventory... and with a game as beautiful as this is... [and OMG, the music, art, worlds, everything is really quite beautiful] why am I looking at the inventory screen so often!?)  So much of what was directly said and implied (and allowed to be believed by consumers) is just not there. It is a very pretty, but very shallow and rather repetitive 'game' (experience?).   Additionally, HG needs to hire a good PR person, Murray has become the new Molyneux (which is sad to see passionate creators [vastly] over-promise).  Also, $60... this should be like $20, maybe $30 (for what it actually has, right now).  Sorry, but scale without content and depth is just vast emptiness.  And this paid DLC nonsense, that better be completely retracted, that is the content that should be in what we were sold on and paid for to begin with... come on. :(  *(The trailers are not the actual game, and really should be removed... however, that is the game everyone expected, paid for, and still wants...)  ---  I am not so much 'not recommending' this game, but more a bit disappointed and feel somewhat misled and just drawing attention to these issues. Just know (exactly) what this game actually is (and is not) before you decide to buy. Wish I could give it like a '~' or 'Maybe'. [It really should be like a $20-30 Early Access... right now, for what it is.] And I hope this situation will change and it becomes what we all want it to be (HG included), and so we can highly recommend it.  ** I struggle with having this review be 'Not Recommended', I do recommend this game, just understand what it is currently (watch people play online), not based on the videos from the Store.
