I want to state that i was super looking forward to this game. I had no illusions of multiplayer or building. I wanted it solely for exploring and see diffrent planets.  And for the first 4-5 hours, i loved it. I really did. But the more i played it the more i started to realise how terrible this game really is.  First off, the interface is god awful. Its laggy, its unintuitive, and its slow as heck. Recharge multitool i have to open inventory. Seems completly random which of the three tabs i get, then click my multitool tab, then click the miningbeam or grenade or bolt caster part. Press and Hold, then select the material to recharge with. Why can't i just click R to reload? and it will use whatever available element i carry to do it? Its just overcomplicating things.  And this brings me to the actual inventory. Why does items take up so much space? The shielding plates you can craft are 100% pointless. They charge less than 250 of an oxide (iron, zinc or titanium). And use the same inventory space, plus i can use the actual raw material for other things. Maybe if i could use one shielding plate multiple times to recharge my shields, but no one won't even fully charge me with some upgrades in place. Least let us stack these things, like gravitino balls, atlas stones etc. With the limitations that are, crafting that weapon upgrade which needs 10 balls is a pain in the tushie cause you need to free up space to carry them, then another space to actually make it.  And why does the upgrades need another space in the inventory? I kind of like that you can link them together for synergy effects. But this is not mentioned in the game at all, the only indications is my 'stat circles' go longer when i link upgrades then when i don't. I feel this could be done far better. Just let us click the shield/lifesupport etc and it brings up a mini inventory with x amount of slots we can put the upgrades in. Not taking up valuable space.   Then we come to exploration. Which starts out really fun. But once you're at the 50th planet you explore. They all kinda become the same. Same buildings, same resource nodes. Even the animal life starts looking similar after awhile. I wanted to see an ocean world so bad, when i finally found one. I was amazed flying over it, until i actually landed. Swimming is annoying as hell. Its slow, you can't swim at surface to regain oxygen, you actually have to jetpack out of the water to refill it, if you don't have the scubatank upgrade things.  Which brings me to the resource nodes. Why do they look identical on all planets? The iron ones and carbon have such a variety. But on all planets, Copper nodes will defy gravity and fly in the air. Heridium are black/blue pillars. And then we have the 'additional element' as i've come to call them, which is gold, aliminium, iridium, titanium, nickel, etc. Which only seem to have one type per planet. So if you get a planet with gold, might as well leave and go to next if you're looking for nickel.  There are buildings which have no entrace. I've ran into probably 10+ buildings. All of them with the 'rare schematic' when i did a space scan. Fly to them, land, often dive into a lake and swim for 5 minutes, then get to it, and there is no entrace to it. Impossible to get inside.  The galaxy map is also very terrible, theres no indicator of planets i've been to, i have to physically click on each planet to find out if you been there or not. Maybe i wanna go back to a planet where i found some rare resource on, like omegon. But once you've jumped once or twice, finding it again is next to impossible. And the waypoint system is terrible. Why can't i free roam with the waypoint lines still showing? And why does the waypoint line only go like 500 lightyears when i can jump 1500 lightyears.  Theres also only three races in the entire game. Vy'ken which seems to be fighters/warriors. Korvax which are robot scientists and Gek traders. Each with their own distinct looks, language and ships. Three just seems to little for this big galaxy. And theres no interaction between factions, except the odd 'send data the vy'ken planning to bomb the gek' bla bla bla. The promised faction system just isn't there.  And the promised big space battles. Sure i've had 50 fighters attack 3 freighters. But holy ♥♥♥♥. One stray shot hitting a freighter and everyone turns on you, and sentinels fly in to attack you as well. And theres no real reward for doing it, get some reputation with the faction, which i had maxed out after 10 solarsystems anyway. Not to mention how clunky the ship controls are.  And why can't i upgrade the launch system or the engines in my ship? so i can boost at faster speed, or take off more then 4 times on one charge of the launch system?  And the creepy alien goo in the abandoned facilities. Why aren't they a story in the game, like get some history behind them, and maybe even run into them later. But no, only sentinels are the enemy.   Game could be so good, but this was released way way way too soon, even with the delay this is so unfinished. And i havn't touched the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ stability of the game. Experiment beta patch fixed a little, but i still crash at random. FPS drops mysteriously to 5-6 from 60+ after a few hours.   I really hope hello games will continue to improve this game, they have a lot of work ahead to make it fun, but there is so much potential, i hope they don't ♥♥♥♥ it up.

Absolutely horrible game. It was my own fault to pre-purchase this title (first time I've done it in my life), however it was mostly due to the incredible hype in the media and my love for the sci-fi/open exploration genre, of which there aren't enough representatives on the market.   The game is amazing during the first 2-3 hours. You get dazed by the vastness of the world (i.e. galaxy), travel distances, speed, theoretical possibilities, the music - it all seems like a glorious package. And after those couple hours you realise that's all that the game has to offer.   You mine minerals. Your inventory gets full in a matter of seconds (!). You sell the minerals. Eventually you get enough cash to buy a better ship (by 'better' I mean a ship with a bigger inventory; ships only differ visually, every other feature is identical). Finally you FTL jump to another solar system and repeat everthing anew.   The creatures are weird-looking and make no sense. I spent 40 hours playing this turd, exploring dozens of worlds. It's easy to notice that there is a very limited number of 'body parts' from which the random algorithm chooses to make its monsters out of.   The planets have 3 hazards - hot, cold, toxic. These planets also have different colors, mostly green, red and blue. Other than that they are mostly identical.   Combat is lacking. Like... lacking everything. Space combat is laughably idiotic.   The story and NPC interaction is close to non-existent.   Overall? DO. NOT. BUY. THIS. GAME.   Don't make the same mistake I did. Just look at the pretty screenshots - they give you all the pleasure and excitement that the actual game does not. The music is the only cool thing in this pile of steaming doo doo.   Go and buy yourself a different game, maybe some skins for CS:GO, whichever... just stay clear of this thing.  Again - 40 hours invested. I wanted to make sure this game is as ♥♥♥♥ as it seemed.   It is.

No Man's Sky is a game that gets in the way of itself. It feels like Hello Games really really wanted to make a purely exploration-focused 'Proteus-in-Space' — which would be fantastic and amazing, you can still salvage this, HG — but then at the last minute they felt compelled to shoehorn traditional gameplay elements in to legitimise what they were making. The (awful, unchallenging, tedious) survival mechanics only act as gates that keep the player away from the crunchy core of this game, which is the procedurally-generated galaxy.  The proc-gen is capable of delivering some lovely surprises, but feels artificially limited overall. I still find animals I've never seen before and I giggle out loud every time, but that sense of surprise and wonderment is limited in the fauna (there are only so many species on a planet, and they don't meaningfully interact with each other) and nearly absent from the flora and landscape. Planets have only one biome each. There's no such thing as a water table; caves in planets that don't have seas will never have water inside them. The strength of gravity is the same on a huge planet as it is on that planet's tiny moon. Barren planets are never barren. Every planet has a blue flower that gives you platinum, a gold flower that gives you zinc, and a solitary-growing vine that is the only plant species that attacks you.  I think that HG limited these elements to make the game easy to read for players: 'Oh I see a blue flower, I can get some platinum.' But those limitations cripple the game's own aspirations; if the point is to literally turn you into an explorer on the frontiers of a star system that no one has ever seen, and perhaps will never see again, then isn't that undermined by the fact that you can land on a planet's surface and immediately recognise certain plants as recurring resouce containers?  The reason I've been able to play this game as long as I have, the reason I didn't refund it nearly immediately, is because there's a decent-sized modding community springing up around this game, fixing or expanding on the game to bring it closer to what players wanted. But every uncommented patch that HG releases makes the modding community shrink a little more, and without proper mod support, HG will just lose all the creative in the modding community and their game will just fade to black.

In the 2014 e3 trailer we saw asteroids really far away and that was really cool and immersive; now they spawn at like 50m from the ship. This points to a downgrade to allow the ps4 to run this game.   - Really low view distance and massive fog. It's basically the same as ps4. Oh my.. where to start.    So I am one of those people that preordered this game, hoping that it would just be the thing they were looking for. Since I like Space and Exploration Games a lot, I thought I would have fun with this. My hopes for this game were very low though but I expected this game to at least work.  And that's where the horrific story begins: It does not work at all on PC. After the first ten minutes, I knew this was a badly done console port and nothing more. Here is a list of bad things I expierenced:  -Textures and objects just being spawned in front of you out of nowhere -Very low level of detail overall. That contains textures and viewdistance -2D-ish Skyboxes for planets. Planets only begin 'materializing' once you come close to them -Not being able to steer your ship like a real plane or spaceship. It feels more like a scripted path where you can steer and shot a little. -Microstutters over and over and over and over again. -No proper Joytick or Mouse support. I could not rebind Melee to my thumbmousebutton for instance and my joystick could not even be used to fly the spaceship. -The entire UI control is obviously a direct console port and simple feels weird on PC. This contains having to hold your LMB to click on something. Every UI element is weirdly controlled over hotkeys or things to press for a while. This system just does not fit on a PC with Keyboard and Mouse controls. -Minearls repeat themselves even on diffrent planets. You will always find the same crystal-ish things that are Plutonium, Aluminium and so on. -At least bird creatures just spawn in out of nowhere, much like objects and textures.    Now some things that are actually great about this game, we have to stay fair, right?  -Planets truly look amazing and have some very awesome landscaping. -Animals, at least from what I have seen, look reasonable but still diverse. They are no aweful monsters but actually look like animals. -Ambient events such as space ships flying by are very well made and give the game a more lively feel. -The Upgrade System in the UI is very clever. Each part of your Suit, Multitool and Spaceship is easily distinguishable and it shows what parts you need to upgrade or rearm that certain thing. -Planets are humongous. -Very colorful artstyle.   Keep your fingers off this! I really hope Hello Games will refine this game A LOT so it becomes a good PC Game but at this moment it is just a giant piece of console port crap.

I bought No Man's Sky on the basis of the video and images advertising it on the Steam store page, which feature a great deal of content which is just not part of the actual game, including massive creatures showing advanced AI behaviour, free flight at low level over planets and seamlessly into space, large scale space battles and player careers other than exploration. None of these elements were part of the game at launch and have still not been added since. I was hugely disapponted to find that, rather than the premium, ground-breaking title we were promised, No Man's Sky played like little more than an unfinished tech demo.  The ships in the game are functionally identical regardless of price or appearance. There are no improved flight dynamics or other advantages to upgrading your ship. The game doesn't even support a joystick which is ridiculous for any space simulation game in 2016. The in-game map is useless for navigation and does not allow you to return to planets you've been to before. Combat is extremely poor and repetitive.  As a fan of exploration games, and with '18 quintillion planets' to explore, I thought there would be plenty in No Man's Sky to keep me busy for a long time, but I found the procedural generation to produce very repetitive environments and such gameplay there is to quickly become tedious. I was already feeling bored after only two hours of play. Contrast this with other games in this genre such as Elite Dangerous, also a 'sandbox' game which I have played for over a thousand hours with no sign of losing interest.  I have only played No Man's Sky for seven hours, and have felt no desire to play at all since August. Content updates have not been provided and the developers have fallen slient. For a supposedly AAA title with a very high price tag of £39.99 I would expect to get hundreds if not thousands of hours of play from the game, not just a handful. This game would be a good buy for $15, but not a dime more. Wonderful idea and concept -- essentially a vastly simplified form of Elite: Dangerous. However due to not suppressing or disproving earlier hype and adding their own, I can not enjoy the game for what it is, because I expected what it is not -- a fully fleshed out space exploration game, rather than a gridfest with the most anticlimatic ending. I was fortunate enough to get my refund in after 12 hours of game play (4 being fun, 8 being me hoping something new happened)  Also for those looking, the two trailers in the Steam preview are both from E3, beta footage. It is in no way an accurate representation of No Man's Sky. At all. It is legitimate false advertisement.

If this had been an early access game, with an early access price tag (say, £10-£15) I think I would be very positive about it. The potential is there, the terrain generation can be breathtaking and the seamless flight from space to planets feels satisfying. It can even be quite a nice, chilled experience to have a wander around. But the depth just isn't there. Although i scoffed at minecraft comparisons prior to release, it is where my mind keeps returning to now - not because of the obvious mining resources comparison, but because of structure. Although games like minecraft are sandbox games, the crafting mechanic actually provides a satisfying structure of little rewards- as you gain new resources, you can craft better items, letting you reach better resources and construct betters items, and so on. Tasks that are laborious become easier as you build and craft. In No Man's Sky, blueprints for equipment are distrubuted at random, and finding rarer resources to construct some of the rarer blueprints is also random . As upgrading your ship, suit and multitool are the main rewards to chase (the journey to the centre is just that - about the journey, not the destination, and so effectively is just the same as if you wander randomly) this makes No Man's Sky feel unrewarding, and coupled with the first time you see an a.i. creature with a repeated asset or the twentieth time you see that alien plant that looks like an ice-cream wafer stuck in the ground, it all feels very empty. This game leaves me with new admiration for all the sandbox games that I thought I loved because they gave me freedom - I was actually responding to their cleverly designed systems that worked despite their sandbox nature.

Entirely not worth neither your money or time. In its current state, which it has been in since its launch, the game will not provide you enough content to keep you entertained for more than a few hours. As soon as all of your gear has been upgraded, there will be nothing new for you to do, and I mean that. Even though the different planets and star system look different, they play out exactly the same - if you've seen one, you've seen them all. Interaction with the game world is also limited to either shooting rocks and other things with your laser or using a dumbed-down simple dialogue system to make the three superficially different alien races grunt in various ways. The game also applies a weird mixture of hand-holding and vagueness, with every resource in your vicinity marked on your 3D-HUD and simplistic combat with next to no challenge paired with a lack of clear direction and purpose. For some, this might be pleasing, but in a world as superficial and one-dimensional as this, it will lead to a lack of enjoyment fast.  On a technical level, it is poorly optimized and badly, especially considering what it is and how it looks. The original score is one of the few positive aspects of the game. For a long time, the game suffered from major pop-ins and ugly draw distance. Another huge issue is the lack of even the most basic communication with the development team. The day of the release marked a sudden blackout of the once active lead devs Twitter, with next to zero talk about the game post-launch. The combination of false promises and lack of open discourse is a cocktail of pure frustration.  Definitely not recommended unless you're looking for a game that allows you to explore mildly varied biomes without major limitations while you create your own motivation to keep going - or if HEAVILY discounted and bundled with a bumper sticker that reads 'I witnessed the biggest disappointment of 2016!'. You're better off playing Minecraft or Star Citizen.

I feel compelled to write a review for this 'game' even though I have never posted a review on Steam before.  Please note that my stats show over 40 hours of playtime but that is not accurate. My actual gameplay time is closer to 12 hours. 12 wasted hours of trying to find a reason to keep playing this 'game.'   I had hoped that I would love No Man's Sky but I barely like it.  No Man’s Sky feels more like a gorgeous looking Alpha release than a complete game.   The “game” consists of flying from planet to planet so you can look at different scenery, plants, and animals while mining different things you need to stay alive. The only quest, so to speak, is to get to the center of the galaxy.   PROS: Beautiful scenery with an insane number of planets to visit. Controls are nice and tight.  CONS: Here is a partial list of what I feel is lacking in No Man’s Sky:  1. Quests – there are no quests other than the core quest. 2. Crafting is ridiculously, laughably simplistic. 3. No benefit to changing spaceships except to increase cargo slots.  a. Note that there is no difference between the types of spaceships other than looks and cargo space.  b.There are no classes of spaceships. All of them handle the same while flying no matter how big or what they look like. 4. No easy way to find your way back to any solar system you visit. 5. Other than survival, there is no reason to mine minerals or trade with the alien races. 6. The price. I would feel like I overpaid for this if I had only paid $20 instead of the $60 that it cost me. 7. Yes, there are a couple of alien races you try to talk to but there is no real reason or payoff for going through the hassle of learinng their language.  I could go on but I won’t bother.  If you are the type of gamer who enjoys walking simulators that don’t really have a point because you feel that it is all about the journey and not the destination, then No Man’s Sky is your kind of game.   I cannot recommend No Man’s Sky in its current iteration. Maybe if they update it, a lot, but not now.  In my opinion, No Man’s Sky is a major disappointment.

I would write a legitimate review for this game, but thinking about it kills more brain cells than it's worth.  Here is my refund request that I spent 3 hours on, submitted twice, and was declined both times due to the fact that I had more than 2 hours played.    I acknowledge the fact that I am over the 2 hour limit for most refunds. However my reasoning for this is that I was told by some of the community that the game would get better, more interesting, less grindy. So I kept playing, believing them. Sadly, the game did not meet my expectations. I do not feel that the 2-hour policy is fair in this situation due to the promised minimal amount of gameplay hours to reach the main objective (400 hours!) and the $60 pricetag.  My first reason for wanting to refund this game is that the gameplay footage that Hello Games - the indie devs of the game - released looks nothing like the actual game, and depicted some features that were not in the game. For example, in an interview with Game Informer, Sean Murray - the Managing Director at Hello Games - stated that other players would be able to see your character in the situation that you were both in the same place at the same time. This was proven wrong by two streamers on the first day of release, and the game is believed to lack any sort of visual netcode. These features that were promised are what originally drove me to become interested in No Man's Sky.  My second reason for wanting to refund No Man's Sky is because of it's low system requirements, and poor optimization. I have an Nvidia GeForce GTX 970 4G Video Card and an Intel Core i5 4690k processor that clocks in at 3.5ghz, and I suffered from frame drops as low as 9 frames per second. Even some of my friends that were well over the system requirements listed on the Steam Store Page ran the game at a maximum of 25 frames per second.  My third and final reason for wanting to refund No Man's Sky is that Sean Murray recently went back on his statements that Hello Games would provide large amounts of content free of charge, rather than in paid DLC.  Due to the developer's inability to satisfy customers, and their removal of major selling points (that hooked said customers) in the final product, I would expect that a well respected establishment like Valve would offer a refund for people that were dissatisfied with a game that fails to meet the very simple criteria of a game being sold for a AAA price. Please keep in mind that I have only ever refunded one other game, and am a loyal customer with more than 45 paid games.  Thank you for your time and careful consideration of my request.

I REALLY REALLY WANTED TO LIKE THIS GAME  I had low expectations, I didn't expect Star Citizen or Minecraft or anything like that. I thought it would be cool and chill exploration, even if a bit overpriced. Well, I got shafted for even thinking that. There's small things this game does that actually makes me think Hello Games had no QA team, and never consulted outside opinions on the game. This goes beyond the general lack of depth as pointed out by a lot of reviewers, although it does overlap. Here are things that stick out to me:  - Every planet seems to generate terrain on a sort of random sine wave kinda pattern with little variation. Land only flattens out a bit near some outposts. There's not even coding for specific biome presets or stuff to appear, like Minecraft did (which had procedural world generation too!). Its all just a sloppy, random mess. There needs to be some order but also actually cool and unique things to generate in order for me to feel like I'm exploring an interesting world.  - The textures are just bad in general and feel ripped straight from console, which is probably the case  - STOP GOING WIDESCREEN FOR EVERY MILESTONE AND EVERY NEW ALIEN MET. Is this intended to be good design?  - A lot of people have reported seeing similar animals with very little variation. I have heard from at least 10 people that they have seen the pineapple looking creature. Exploring seems to lose a sense of uniqueness when you figure this out.   - Give me an indication of where I'm actually going to land. I understand that coding flying close to the ground is tricky, but you can do it better Hello Games  - YOU CAN'T SET A WAYPOINT TO GO BACK TO YOUR PAST DISCOVERIES. WHHHYY. Remember:  This is a 60$ game   - Animals seems to have 3 behaviors only: run around and coo like idiots when they see you, attack you, or not care. This is all they do. Nothing else. No attempts to code ecosystems or more advanced behaviors.   - The sentinels being nearly everywhere on every planet is stupid. I hate fighting them because it lacks depth, and there is no real purpose given to them.  - Hazards like cold, hot, toxic, and radioactive all behave the exact same, just a different color and text. How long has this game been worked on?  My favorite thing about this game is the space flying, and approaching big planets at light speed, and then I feel a letdown realizing that there will probably be nothing memorable about the planet itself.   Hello Games, please, work on this game more. Make it worth our money. DO NOT PUT OUT PAID DLC UNTIL YOU MAKE THIS GAME WORTH IT. I understand a lot of problems can be pinned on Sony, but try to open your eyes to your criticism. We deserved much better from you.   1.1 UPDATE: Game definitely has more content, I will update this review after I play it more. Still not worth 60$ by any reasonable means as of yet.

I, unlike most people, actually enjoy the expereince of this game. The amount of unique things to expereince is highly limited however. In the 2ish hours that I have logged in this game, over an hour of it was spent trying to get it to actually work well on my PC, which is far better specced than the reccomended. In the other hour I actually played the game, I expereinced about everything that one could. I know this because after returning the game, I bought it again on my PS4 as a good friend of mine told me it performed well at least on the system. I enjoyed the game well enough in the hour that I had really played the game that I figured it was worth it. He was right, it performed much better, but after another hour of playing, I had accomplished pretty much the same amount that I had on my PC, and had nothing to do. I tried exploring new planets, but they were all pretty much the same, just with a different color scheme and most of them were already discovered. I tried making it a goal to learn a language, but it didn't help any as I never had issues trading with the other species in the game. I tried making a ton of money, which took me about 30 minutes to get to the point where I had enough money to buy the best ship I could find and still have enough money left over to buy 2 more. I tried hunting pirates, but because it only took me 30 minutes to get the best ship in the game, it was a breeze.   So to sum up. The absolute base idea of the game is brilliant and highly enjoyable. However, once you understand the base system, you are pretty much done with the game. If you get this game, you'll probably enjoy it for an hour, 2 at most, and that's because this isn't really a game.  It's a survival game that has no survival aspects.  It's a crafting game that allows you to do everything without ever crafting.  It's a shooting game that you don't ever have to shoot in.  It's an exploration game with nothing to explore.  It's an economy game with it's primary source of income as powerful as a cheat code.  It's an adventure game with no goal.  It's a game with no purpose.

Like everyone else, I was very excited for this game to come out.  Admittedly, Hello Games received much more hype than they'd wanted, but when you've land yourself in that situation, and you have Sony backing you, it should have been a good problem to have, but instead it became a missed opportunity.  The game by itself is okay, definitely for a niche market in it's current state, but even for what it is, it isn't worth $60.  Pros: - Experience of 'seamlessly' going between planets/systems is cool - Visuals are quite nice on certain planets - I experience fast load up times  - I had no issues running this game (only 1 crash so far), but I'm sure I'm a minority   Cons: - Game gets repetitive very fast - Combat system is very boring and even when upgrading your ship, you don't feel any stronger - Flight controls are clunky, and have an artifical barrier (can disable with mods) - No clear end game, just grinding to upgrade your ship and then to explore - Not enough variety within a planet, for the most part, you can go to a planet, fly around for 2 minutes, and then you'll know pretty much everything that planet has to offer - All space stations look the same in the inside - All building/bases you encounter (which will be many) on planets all follow the same 3 templates  - Interaction with NPCs are repetitive and superficial   The game was clearly marketed deceptively, only to realize there are alot of things missing that were explicitly stated would be in the game (eh hem...even a slgiht chance of multiplayer).  At time of writing, I have 24 hours of playtime, which is alot considering I don't like the game. I was waiting for this game since i heard of it, and was following its developement since announcement. This is not the game most people think it is. I noticed Sean trying so hard to manage expectations, always saying 'this game will be divisive' or 'this is what No Mans Sky is' and this is what 'No Mans Sky isn't', and it was disheartening to see why he was being such a Debbie downer about this game...and now I know why.  I tried to manage my expectations and tried to filter through all the hype, and at the end of the day I expected a game solely focused on exploration and discovery and some combat with the chance of meeting your friends. However, I also expected that there would be some variety and elements to keep me wanting to explore, but there is not.   If No Man's Sky becomes the game everyone wishes it to be through updates, then perhaps I'd buy it again, but for right now, it's simply not worth the $60 as it certainly feels like the scope of the game is unfinished.

So, No Man's Sky. I have bought the game on the wave of hype it has received and has got to play for quite a bit in it. I did hear the first days the game was out that it was something great and fresh, though probably not as much as it has been advertised, but I did not seem to care. My biggest mistake was trying to care about the pre-order, and not actually waiting for a lot of reviews, as I did before with other games - I followed the hype build around the game.  But finally, I can tell I found out tons of issues with the game, and not in the usual meaning: it is actually mostly connected with the way the game has been advertised, with how it has been shown by Sean Murray and Hello Games at various cons.  The first part, important for me is actually the multiplayer - I do really enjoy the not-so-MMO multiplayer parts, like the system the Dark Souls series (including Demon Souls and Bloodborne) uses: you have got your own world, and you can get a bunch of visitors in it, without need or even ability to cross your way with 10+ players simultaneously, creating small, rather random lobbies for a short while. But obviously, as it was found out by some streamers, the final game seem to lack this ability, and I relate to two Twitch streamers, that has come to the same spot of the planet, and could not see each another.  Second part, is the actual 'uniqueness' of the universe. Better say, the quality of that uniqueness, since taking a closer look, you do realize that summing up all the planet terrains, flora and fauna you actually always visit different planet. The trouble is, that there is just a tiny little bit of differences between a 'hooved cat-like creature' on planet A and on a planet B, which is really sad. Besides, it is even worse that the fauna follows very simplistic rules of actions, not talking about what has been advertised: the game trailers, showing the small herbivorous creatures going to the river-side t oget water/whatever it might be on the alien planet.  Third important thing for me, were ships. I obviously did not expect the ability to build your own gear, as it is possible in games like Space Engineers, or Starmade, but at least some class diversity? Traders, warriors, explorers - any type of 'profession' a player would choose is not going to require a special ship to get acquired, they are all  the same .  Fourth part of the game I have been highly disappointed in, is the actual NPC part - it is done very lazily. Like, you have got tons of NPCs scattered all over the world (even, worlds), literally sitting in their tiny little corners of the galaxy and doing nothing. I am not talking about the fact that such placement of NPC characters makes it sound kind of silly, when you happen to be the actual 'first explorer' of the planet - these NPCs seem to have been here for a while, even making a sort of infrastructure on the planet, including trading posts and things. Heck, you can even find various monoliths to find out about the races' past, and even the actual ruins! On the planets, you have explored the first. It does sound quite... Stupid, at the very least.  Bugs, oh well. This is another part of the game, and I only can tell I have not encountered tons of them. And my solution was simple: I switched the game's language to English. The most of the drops of the game I had seemed to be connected with the localization, the game did look like it has failed to write out technology names in Russian, when I tried to get reward after talking with NPCs. And I can't tell this is a big deal for me, but still something... Sad.   This far, the game does not either cost it's money, or time to really bother playing it - just go watch trailers and enjoy them. Hello Games has made a different game, not something they have advertised. Though probably charging for it as for an AAA project, they might have enough means to fulfil their promises.

No Man's Sky is a sci-fi space survival exploration crafting game. A very barebones, Early Access Alpha, tech demo version at that. In hindsight, for me the best part about it was anticipating the day it would come out rather than playing the game. Anyways for the actual review I'll try to be as unbiased and objective as I can. Skip to the last paragraph for my opinion on it.  You start off on a random planet very very far away from the center of the Euclid Galaxy. The object is to reach the center of said galaxy. You have an exosuit that will protect you from hazardous environments and allows you to carry materials that you'll need to sell for money or to craft upgrades or repair/fuel your starship. Now the starship, it's broken in the beginning. You'll need to use your handy multi-tool to mine materials needed to fix the ship. You can find the materials you need by scanning the local area. There can be some hostile creatures and these self-replicative machines called sentinels which may or may not attack you depending on the planet you are on. Another way to get money is to upload all the flora and fauna you've scanned. There are also journey milestones you can reach when specific feats are accomplished. There are also space stations and outposts & shelters where you can interact with static NPCs. You can learn their language so you can better understand them and try to figure out the correct solution to their questions. And if you're succesful they'll reward you with crafting blueprints or materials. If you have millions of this game's currency you can also buy a ship from a docked NPC or if you're broke, you can hunt down a crashed ship to repair it and make it your own.  There's also a mysterious entity named Atlas you can follow if you need some direction. The Atlas path has objectives to complete and waypoints to go to. There are also some helpful NPCs named Nada and Polo inside of spacial anomales that will aid you in your journey. As for game progresson, You will need to mine (or trade for) materials to fix your ship and refuel it. Then you can start flying around your solar system and complete Atlas Objectives until you're able to fix your ship's hyperdrive. Then you'll need to craft Warp Cells to fuel your hyperdrive so you can explore other star systems and begin the long journey to the center. There are short cuts you can take however. Nada and Polo can show you where Black Holes are that will take you considerably closer to the center. Why Hello Games decided to call them Black Holes and not Worm Holes (which makes more sense) is baffling to me but I digress. So that's basically it. Fix ship, fuel hyperdrive, fly towards center making frequent stops to gather materials to craft more Warp Cells and upgrade your Ship, Exosuit and Multi-tool all while learning alien languages and uploading your discoveries.  And now for my thoughts on it. This is probably one of the worst games I could not stop playing. At 60 dollars I wanted to justify the amount of money I spent so I set a personal goal for myself. Get 100% achievements and complete all the journey milestones. And I did that...it took 86 hours. And I didn't even have to reach the center of the galaxy, in fact, I'm not even halfway there and I have no desire to reach it after looking it up on youtube and seeing how much of a slap-in-face dissapointment it is. There are some fundamental problems with this game such as there isn't much to do and you have to repeat the steps of progression ad nauseam. Which is fine for the first few hours and then you're like...'oh my god, this is going to be the whole game, isn't it?' Technically, the ship controls are very clunky, there's a lot of texture pop-in which totally breaks immersion as well some hitching (which seems to be a word I've never seen or used in this context until this game) and stuttering when textures are loading in. Though I assume if you have a solid state drive that wouldn't be as bad but I dunno. If I had to mention one thing I DID like about the game, the music is pretty awesome. Anyways, even with all the hours I put into it, at $60 I would not recommend this game. I'd say wait a year for Hello Games to add more content and get the game at a heavily discounted price. So, long story short, I preordered when the false promises seemed real, and went over the two hour playtime line without being able to play. Longer story is that I preordered this game due to what it was promised to be. Shortly after I preordered, I learned that it wasn't what was promised, but still hoped it would be worthy of my money. The game released and I was still excited to play.  Upon starting up the game I was greeted by major graphical problems. And what I mean by that is nearly everything, except for smoke particles, and a few random bits and pieces, was invisible. I thought I needed to just adjust some settings, I spent nearly two hours doing that, and it didn't work. II decided since I was over the two hour refund time, I might as well continue to get this to work. stumbling through the invisible land, I hunted for materials to fix my ship. I eventually gathered them and promptly headed towards another planet hoping it would be fixed. It wasn't.  Afterwards I decided I'd try the age old tactic of deleting, and redownloading the game. That didin't work either. Eventually I found out my graphics card wasn't supported. Luckily, I was talking with my brother-in-law, and he knew I was still pumped for the game. Without my knowledge he sent a supported graphics card, and the game then worked. I kind of feel sorry for disliking this game so much because of that.  So, with the game now working, I promptly start my space adventure. And so I was promptly bored. After a handful of planets, I realised that each planet, each galaxy, was just going to be the same thing with minor changes. What these minor changes are, is things like, oh this planet has gold, this planet has iridium, these animals are just slightly different colored than the animals on a planet two galaxies away. I mean, even things like radiation, heat, and freezing, are all simply treated the same way, it just changes the planets color. In a universe of unimaginable number of planets, everything feels the same after maybe 3 planets.  And it is these reasons and a few more, that I would more then not recommend this game, but heavily wish I was able to get a refund. The only thing with that, is that I spent more than two hours on this game and so therefore I am banned from getting a refund, even though at least two of those are from trying to get it to be playable.

Although the game had a promising start for me ultimately I am forced to admit it is disappointing. I regret paying full price and I have to recommend against most people paying full price. I'm a little torn on that, but that's where I sit today.  I really like to support independent studios and interesting, unusual projects- things that get out of the ruts that the AAA titles tend to fall into. No Man's Sky definitely did this, and it did it big with a completely unique premise and some genuinely impressive advancement of game technology.  It also gave me among the better first 10 or so hours of gameplay that I've experienced in any game, AAA or otherwise. Sure there were technical issues, but they didn't break the game for me personally and they've already largely been resolved- this is not Arkham Knight and the bugs are not the problem. Looking past those the promise is there and at first No Man's Sky feels like something really special. The world and creature generation are great, the tone of lonely exploration is spot-on, and the sound is simply amazing. In fact I would absolutely buy the sound engine of the game alone as a standalone infinite soundscape generator with adjustable parameters.  So... why do I regret the purchase?  There's really no away around this, but we got lied to about this game.  It's not that the game is truly awful. For something so ambitious it's really not that far off the mark, actually. But sadly it is filled with direct contradictions to how it was sold to us. And what's worse those direct contradictions sum up to a game that was sold to us as a robust product worth a standard $60 price tag that really didn't turn out to be one.  This is not just a matter of overzealous marketing, self-hype, or even the common sin of playing cinematics instead of gameplay at E3, either. This was the creator and lead developer of the game saying things that simply turned out to be untrue about major features in the game that don't exist. There are whole ways of playing he described in rather vivid detail that simply aren't in the game. Even worse we were shown what was claimed to be gameplay footage that looks very little like the game and contains tons of really cool things that simply aren't there.  I kept on playing for about 30 hours expecting to find some of them... And I didn't. Gradually I realized there just wasn't going to be much more to the game than those first 10 or so hours.  I know games change a lot between pre-alpha and release, and I'm fine with that, but that's not at all what this feels like. This feels like Sean Murray pitched a lot of ideas that sounded great and that maybe he genuinely believed they'd be able to implement... But that weren't actually in the game and that turned out, perhaps, to be impractical to implement after all. In other words it's more like a Kickstarter-funded project in Early Access on Steam than it is a release build of a full priced game.  We were told about and actually shown, in what was supposedly real play, sentinel walkers lying dormant and awakening as we approached, vast windswept deserts with smoothly rendering-in scenery as you approached from space, capital ship battles between factions that we could meaningfully join on one side or the other, a continuously operating economy, and unique ships that we could discover and name, an infinite world of ships just as it is an infinite world of everything else, with the perfect one for every playstyle out there somewhere. Literally none of these things are there, among many others. And that doesn't even touch on the epic disappointment of the game's conclusion compared to how the mystery of it was teased to us.  What we got that WASN'T promised however are a lot of questionable choices that all seem designed to slow gameplay down. Things like absurdly long button presses to perform actions, constant manual recharging of equipment, painfully limited inventory, and awkward equipment upgrades. The cynical part of me wonders if it's to keep you playing long enough to go past any reasonable return window.  Bearing all of that in mind if Sean Murray's interviews had really been a Kickstarter pitch and the game was currently in Early Access for, say, $30 or so, I'd be happy. $20 and I'd be absolutely delighted. Either one and I'd not only be glad to have bought it but I'd also recommend it to everyone as an incredibly promising project to support. I'd be looking forward to seeing it finished, actively involvd in the community, probably even writing mods and maybe even hoping they might integrate some of my own ideas in the game. I would being saying it would be worth $60 when finished.  So who knows? Maybe in a year, if they continue to work on it and deliver on all the promises they made, as if this were a weirdly executed kickstarter, I might change my mind. Those first 10 hours really do feel like they were going in the right direction and there are a lot of things to love about the game. I don't think they have any financial incentive to do actually do as much more development as is needed now though, but if I'm wrong and they do it as a matter of honor or commitment I'll gladly, eagerly, change this review.  But as of today, even with most of the technical issues fixed, there are simply far too many unfulfilled promises for me to recommend this game.

Hour 0 through 4: 'Oh. My. God. This game is amazing!'  Hour 5 through 10: 'Pretty cool. But is every station basically the same? That can't be right...'  Hour 11 through 20: 'Ok I'll upgrade my ship, inventory, and gun. That seems to be the only thing to do.'  Hour 21 through 40: 'Wow, everything looks exactly the same... I guess I'll focus on making it to the center.'  Hour 41: 'Finally, I made it to the center. I finally get to experience what this game has been building to.'  Hour 42: 'F**k. This. Game'  You may be asking yourself why I have almost 60 recorded hours. Well one of the things that I found this game excells at is putting me to sleep. To be fair, I often have trouble sleeping, so that's somewhat of an achievemnent I guess. But about 15 to 20 hours of my 'play' time for this game were spent asleep.   I was one of those who boarded the hype train early on. Unfortunately, the last stop that the hype train makes is often in dissapointment town; which is where I currently find myself.   The first few hours were truly a great experience. The next twenty, however, were tedious. After that I played for the sole purpose of getting to the center of the galaxy. I spent hours grinding warp cells to travel from star system to star system, excited at what I would find when I finally 'finished' the game.   Spoilers are incoming, but you're actually probably going to want to know this before you play. So what's at the center?         Nothing. The game shoots you to the edge of another galaxy, and you get to start the whole process over again. All that build up, all those hours, and the game laughs in your face. And it was this, for me, that really sealed this game's review. I cannot, in good conscience, recommend this game. In its current state, it truly feels unfinished. So save your money (and what a lot of money it is...) and buy this game if/when they release more content.   That is, assuming said content is free...

For my first review, I really was hoping to say something nice. No Man's Sky is a fantastic concept and from the start sounded too good to be true. However, it defied my expectations by being actually released and by (theoretically) fulfilling all its promised qualities. The PS4 release seemed to affirm all these qualities and really give the Steam lot a great deal of hope for the release.  What actually happened was quite an embarrasing chaos of galactic proportions of crashes, shocking FPS rates, as well as many other issues. My system far exceeds the minimum requirements and yet in virtually every location, the frame rate was abysmal. If the planet had any water/vegetation/abundant wildlife, it was unplayable (I am talking 10FPS). The promise of more `exotic' and lush planets closer to the centre of the galaxy is enough to keep me to the outer rim, thank you very much. The actual content of the game is arguably what I had expected and I do not fault the developers for it, but the presentation of the product is what makes me NOT recommend this at all. There is simply no point paying 39.99GBP or $60 on something which is not finished and has clearly been inadequately tested. If any of you have tried the current version of `Stranded Deep' or other such early releases, this is actually more skeletal than that (and those actually run well). The talk of paid DLC in the future at this stage is actually hilarious. In any case, after updating my drivers today, the game stopped loading altogether, so confirming the waste of money.   Theoretically, as entitled as the gamer community sees itself, this would be a great time to point out that developing a game is a very difficult task and as consumers we need to appreciate what we have. Developing a game featuring an entire (albeit procedurally generated) universe is insane. However, professionally developed software needs to be written efficiently and tested before release. The release of patches which have minimal effect on performance is amateur if anything. Perhaps they should have focussed on a simpler project which they could have actually done well.  tl;dr Awful performance, don't get in current state.

This game has so much room for improvement and possible content, but that alone should tell you something about how complete the game feels.  Day 1, overwhelmed. There is so much here... Plants, rocks, creatures, damned sentry drones punishing you for stripping the planet's resources or destroying certain structures, and an interface that doesn't tell you much about itself so you've got plenty to keep your interest.  Day 2-4 Starting to get the hang of things and you're all over the place, looking for crashed ships to swap our your own with to get more coveted inventory slots on your ship. Oh, yeah, the ships...look at all the combinations of ships! You've found some items to help with that language barrier you have with the other 3 races, but you're still relying on the context of the gibberish to figure out what dialog you should pick.   Day 5-7 You start to notice that while the planets and systems are different, they're still the same. you're still seeing new ship hulls, but that matters less than the slot numbers, and where the holes are in the inventory slots...(no spoilers here, you'll figure it out).  Day 8+ You start understanding why the game's rating is where it's at, cause while you haven't and cannot visit all the planets in your lifetime, you no longer need to. The new has worn off and all that's left is to seek the center of the galaxy. Some still like the game, but for so many others, it's fallen flat. So, now comes the questions you should ask before you spend your money on this game..  1- Are you an optimist? Things could improve. Updates happen, content gets added..happens all the time. Not for No Man's Sky yet, unless you consider technical patches in that realm ( I don't..you forget to put a seat in my new car, you don't get to call it an update, you get to say 'sorry bout that, forgot to add the passenger seat.' and don't you dare brag about how you're fixing the issues, cause a finsished product is what we deserve, and what we paid for).  2- Explorer, or Hero.. If the latter, you'll do better to pass this one up, cause the pinnicle of combat is a sentinal capital ship that doesn't move, just sits there shooting you with half of it's guns while you flit around and destroy it's turrets. That is all. For you explorers, you'll last longer 'cause the next planet might have that life-altering gaming experience...or the next...   3- Want to potentially save the future of gaming? Then buy it play just long enough to discover that you agree with all the negative reviews, then immediately seek a refund because the game advertised above is not what you're getting (Please read refund policy first!). Features discussed in interviews or shown in screenshots or videos just aren't there. Maybe the pain of having to reverse charges or send refunds out to enough players will send the message to both Steam and the game development community at large that yes, they do have a responsibility to it's consumers to provide a product as advertised. I woudln't be surprised if they weren't sued for fraud. Even after the game was released, they never pulled the screenshots or videos depicting a different experience than you'll get in the game. Must have some epic lawyers somewhere...  So, to sum it up, if you're good with 60.00 for some entertainment that will most likely not keep your attention the way other games at this price range do, then by all means, hit the buy button. Otherwise, give it awhile... Maybe the people who's reputation will rest on this product will care about a future in this industry and fix it. Otherwise they'd do well to use the money they got (that isn't getting refunded), to legally change their names and have another go at it...

To clarify, I do not think this is a bad game, but it is not worth £40. I won't go over the usual stuff that the other reviews point out, but I will be pointing out one of the biggest flaws with the game that NOBODY seems to be talking about.   *Contains Spoiler*  So I decided to follow the Atlas path, which meant collecting the Atlas stones. Upon reaching the final Atlas Interface, I only had 9 Stones, because a sold some. I didn't know it at the time, but if you don't have 10, then you can't continue. I approached the interface, and tried to continue with 9, and it told me I couldn't. So, I went away, started grinding some units, bought an Atlas Stone from a trading terminal, and returned to the Atlas interface. However, I couldn't interact. Here's the main kick in the balls:  IF YOU DON'T HAVE ENOUGH ATLAS STONES UPON INITIALLY REACHING THE LAST STEP, THEN YOUR GAME IS IRREPARABLY BROKEN. You can no longer continue with the story line, and you either have to give up and start again, or spend a few hours jumping through black holes. Essentially, if you don't have 10 Atlas Stones when you get to the interface, then there's not much point in playing. This realisation has made my attitude of 'I understand the hate, but it's still fun to play', to 'I understand the hate, and it's pretty much all legitimate hate'. I don't know whether I'll start again, or just add loads of funny mods.  Either way, until this game is on sale, don't waste your time with it.

After two and three planet, I have noted the oddness and the out of place the way the planet designed; the flora and fauna scattered on the planet. Other words...bleak and boring. Summary: I haven't finish the game of course, but I already lost my enthusiasm to play the game. I did pop the game once in awhile between my others game, but after the update, the game lagging and FPS dropped so much, I probably going to stop playing this for now...maybe until something good happend to it.

The variables are incredibly limited in my perspective. And perhaps more anoyingly to me, weapons. You have a mining laser and you have a rapid fire gun. There's no variation, the mods dont seem to do anything meaningful and there's only sentinels to use it on who's rules i cannot grasp. I am not allowed to defend myself or mine a rock, but a giant gold ore deposit inches away from one is somehow perfectly fine?  I was expecting a lot from this game. Too much? Well, maybe they hyped it to be more than it actually was, and i kinda was expecting that to be the case. Yet from all the things i've seen and heard up to the eventual release, we barely have a handful of the things they said would be in it.   Does it look pretty? Yes Is it big? Yes Will you ever get to see everything there is to see? Very unlikely There's even some humor in it here and there and obscure references. It's not a bad game.  But it also brings a lack of variation in quests (it's always the same things), buildings (once you've played for more than 30 minutes, you've seen them all), creatures (very limited amount of parts they consist of), landscapes (there's random generation, but it's all roughly the same), weapons (there's two, and you can do everything with your mining laser).  I liked every other game in this genre, but this just feels so incomplete, rushed, almost Beta like... I cant believe i paid €59,99 for this...

Please view   this reddit post  to see a glimpse of what is in the preview images/videos but not the game.   Okay. So if you're reading this, you probably have heard the drama. That there has been a lot cut from the E3 version of the game, so the game available on Steam right now is very shallow. This is true. This issue is actually extremely complicated and while I'd love to discuss it, here is not the proper place.  Though I should explain the shallowness more, because that is relevant to the review. The game itself isn't shallow, but certain parts of it are. The world generation has very obvious patterns due to how procedural generation works, but each planet has its own unique feel, and once in a while you'll find a planet you feel you could stay on forever. This part of the game is very unique and relaxing, and I can't wait to see how procedural generation evolves over time.  Overall, I would say not to buy this game. As someone that waited years for this game and bought into the hype, I'm sorry to say that this game is an extreme disappointment. We were promised this beautiful universe where anything was possible and what we got was just... so far from that.   The biggest hyped thing about this game was the fact that everything is procedurally generated: the ships, planets, lifeforms, plants, moons, space stations, etc. You have literally 18 quintillion worlds to explore. That's exciting, right? Wrong.  Once you set out into the stars and land on more and more planets, you start to see the beautiful picture that was painted quickly fall apart. This isn't a game about exploration, it's micromanagement simulator at every possible level. At seemingly every turn there is an alarm going off telling you that whatever charge has been depleted. This means you have to roam around planets mining resources to charge up various pieces of gear at a near constant level. That's a major part of the game play: staring at inventory screens charging up various pieces of gear. Oh, and your extremely limited inventory space will make this even that much more maddening.   The fact that there are so many worlds to explore has to be this game's saving grace, right? Wrong again. After you land on a dozen or so worlds, you start to realize they are all pretty much exactly the same. Sure, the plants and animals vary slightly, but overall it's the same. This is especially true for any structures on the planets, which are actually part of the very little actual gameplay content in this game. All the structures follow the exact same layout. They all feature items in basically the exact same places. The aliens you sometimes encounter in these structures give you the same boring choices over and over again. The aliens themselves can't even be bothered with this game since almost all of them are too busy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ing on Reddit in their iPads. Really. Almost every alien is just starring into a tablet computing device they are holding. That's all they do. They don't walk around, they don't interact with the environment, they never even leave the chair they are sitting on.   Speaking of aliens, we encounter these same species on seemingly every planet but there is only ever one of them at each structure on the planet. Where is the rest of these people? Where do they live? Where are their ships? Why don't we see any of that? Why aren't some of these planets covered by massive cities? Nah, we just get more rocks, deformed wild life and repetitive landscapes. Hell, even the space stations you dock in are completely devoid of activity minus the same procedurally generated ships landing and taking off for no reason. You never see any aliens get out of their ships to sell goods, nothing. And for crying out loud, why is every space station laid out exactly the same? It just doesn't make any sense at all.   If you've seen the E3 gameplay, pre-release trailers, etc. just stop for a moment and forget you saw any of that. In the game files, you'll find special assets specifically created for the E3 demo. Everything we saw there was not procedurally generated, it was carefully curated and scripted to give the illusion that what was happening was going to be the status quo for the worlds in this game. It is not.   This game is not even remotely what we were shown in those videos. This game may someday be that game we were promised, but it is not that game today. I really wanted to love this game and it's such a tragedy that it turned out this way. What makes it worse is that Hello Games is probably the worst company I've ever seen when it comes to handling public relations. Hell, EA did a better job at handling the SimCity launch uproar, and everyone hates EA. Hello Games has been completely silent since the games release, not addressing the outcry of fans that are deeply disappointed or explaining why they straight up lied about what this game was. At the very least they should come out and say that there is a roadmap to add features to the game... SOMETHING.   Anyway, as somone that really really wanted to love this game, I just can't. There are so many terrible design decisions and gameplay mechanics that I'd rather just do a crossword puzzle-- cause at least that has a satisfying ending. Yeah, even the ending in No Man's Sky is like a slap in the face. Do yourself a favor, do not buy this game. At least not in it's current form. Maybe in a year with some updates it'll be playable, but something tells me that won't be the case.

Hoping to learn words for alien languages so I could figure out how to interact with other lifeforms. I carried on working my way toward the first Atlas, an initial goal.  Then the disappointment set in. This is it? Yes, that really is it. This is an indie game, and it should have an indie price. I'm thinking half-off normal. But it does not. The traditional full pricetag for a big studio AAA video game is way too high for No Man's Sky.  The game has a lot of small inventory management, which quickly becomes frustrating and annoying. Sure, you can explore a procedural universe, and that really is a groundbreaking, awesome feature. But that's all this game is. There's nothing else to it.  I hear rumors that the game will be expanded upon to include things which they initially talked about. Even then this game wouldn't be worth the full launch price.

Hype, turned to disappointment, turned to faith, turned to more disappointment.  I wanted to like this game, I really did, but the missing features, combined with the total lack of performance, really killed it for me.  First the performance:  My PC: Intel 4770K 2x 980TI SLI 16GB RAM  When the game first launched, I had to throttle my settings and limit the game to 60 FPS to prevent tons of hitching. When new drivers and a new patch were released, performance was worse. To this day there is tons o f texture pop-in and it is someone nausea inducing and infuriating.  Next the missing features: Do not watch the videos associated with the game. They are out of date and irrelevant. The fact of the matter is, NMS is a game where you go to a planet, farm some stuff, go to another planet, farm some stuff, etc. The 'discoveries' you make and 'upload' might get wiped and not reflected in the game. There is no multiplayer (it is not an MMO obviously), but it advertised you might run into other players, but... There are articles out there about how two players found the same planet, but were invisible to each other, environment conditions did not sync, etc.  All in all a huge let down, especially for $60.
